HEADLINE: NOW Reasserts Its Role as Outsider

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
The National Organization for Women celebrated its 25th anniversary here this weekend by embracing its status as a militant outsider in politics at home while reaching out to other countries in an attempt to create a movement of "global feminism."
Harking back to her days as an airline stewardess, NOW's new president, Patricia Ireland, told the group's plenary session on Friday that her job usually consisted of "walking up and down aisles, taking people's garbage, and saying 'thank you, thank you.' " For too long, she added, "women in Washington and other capitals of the world have been taking other people's garbage and saying 'thank you.' " 
 In a later interview, Ms. Ireland, who replaced Molly Yard as president last month, said: "I am less than interested in playing with the boys in the Democratic Party any more. We played in '84 and '80. We made great efforts to get the Senate back in Democratic hands. The reality is that as each more and more conservative justice has gone on the Supreme Court, they have been confirmed by a Democratically controlled Senate."
 
Membership at 250,000
 Instead, she said, the group would use this election year "to create a lot more feminist candidates, and those who come out and vote for them will also vote against George Bush."
Indeed, many of the 700 women present who told their stories and plotted their strategies in small groups that focused on topics like "violence against women," "economic empowerment" or "women and families," took pride in the devil-take-the-hindmost sense of separatism that pervades the organization. Since the group's charter was drafted by Betty Friedan, author of "The Feminine Mystique," and 27 other co-founders in a Washington hotel 25 years ago, its membership has grown to about 250,000.
Bolstered recently by women's outrage over the Clarence Thomas-Anita F. Hill hearings, the group's support is now as extensive as at any time since the defeat of the Equal Rights Amendment in 1982. In the wake of that failure, the group's membership, 220,000 in 1982, plunged below 130,000 over the next several years.
But compared with the heyday of the fight for the Equal Rights Amendement, this convention and birthday party seemed energized more by defiant anger than by any of the plethora of proposed actions.
Throughout the weekend, it was clear what the group did not like: the possibility that the Supreme Court could, within six months, reverse its 1973 Roe v. Wade decision legalizing abortion; pay inequity against women, who earn about 68 cents for each dollar a male worker earns, and all forms of discrimination against homosexuals.
It was less clear exactly what they intended to do about it. Or perhaps more accurately, it seemed clear they would support all actions suggested, but it was unclear which actions they would actually take.
That sense of diffuse inclusiveness was the signature of the four-day gathering. Like the the informal sidewalk market set up to sell T-shirts, jewelry, music, pottery, studies on date rape and manuals on lesbian love, the four-day event had the trappings of a politically correct bazaar, its intellectual and practical wares showing its desire to be all things to all feminists.
 
Boos and Catcalls
 That was not always an easy task, especially as the organization started to make its moves into global politics, as Friday's plenary session showed. The featured speaker, and the closest thing to a political celebrity (aside from Ms. Friedan) was Hanan Ash rawi, a Palestinian spokeswoman.
But her exegesis on Palestinian feminism consisted of a frontal attack on the Israeli Government, as she urged American feminists: "Stop sending military aid to Israel. Stop paying for the deportation of our people."
This prompted boos and catcalls from the new Jewish feminist caucus, which was enraged that the Israeli speaker chosen by NOW, Tamara Gozansky, is a Communist and a member of the country's Peace Party and someone unlikely to express views in opposition to Ms. Ashrawi's.
The disruption prompted Ms. Ireland to accept the Jewish feminists' insistence that Dr. Alice Shalvi, head of the Israeli Women's Network, be given the podium to rebut the views of Ms. Ashrawi. This was followed by hugs and a hands-joined-in-victory photograph opportunity.
Earlier, the audience had been riveted by the tale of Aminata Diop, a woman from Mali, who fled her family and her country rather than undergo a ritual clitordectomy -- the removal of the clitoris and inner labia, usually with a razor blade -- and is seeking political asylum in France.
 
'Seeking Gender Balance'
 This morning, the political empowerment caucus voted overwhelmingly for one suggestion after another -- from "seeking gender balance" to the creation of an international woman's congress to exchange information and provide financial support for women candidates around the world to the creation of a third party -- without giving any emphasis to participation in traditional politics.
The group's embrace of the nontraditional had a kind of apotheosis late last year when The Advocate, a California magazine on gay and lesbian issues, put Ms. Ireland on its cover indicating she was "coming out" as a lesbian.
In the following month, Ms. Ireland has been interviewed about her sexual preferences and has persistently dodged any labels like "lesbian" or "bisexual," saying that she considers both her husband of 25 years, James, and an unidentified female companion in Washington "part of my family."
"I have become increasingly and very personally aware now how obsessed our country is with defining women by their sexuality," Ms. Ireland said in an interview. "If they don't know what and how and how often and with whom they just don't know how to deal with you."
But the group's conservative opponents, like the Concerned Women for America, have gleefully seized on the disclosure to argue that NOW is unrepresentative of American women.
Indeed, in the caucus of young feminists on Friday, several people expressed concern that the word feminist had become a political epithet that hampers their ability to carry their message to students.
"Do you realize that in the last 20 minutes we haven't said the word feminist?" said Tara Muir, a graduate student of journalism from Omaha, looking around at about 20 other women and one man gathered in the room.
"That's true; it's a loaded word," said Lisa Diamond, a 20-year-old student at the University of Chicago. "I don't know how else to get people not to be afraid of it, except to let them come at things from their own direction," and not start discussions by using the word feminist.
Marilyn Fitterman, head of New York State's NOW offices, said her membership's reaction to the articles about Ms. Ireland was twofold: "One group said 'Why did she do that? Now I'm going to have to start every interview by saying I'm not a lesbian,' and another group said, 'We're proud of her.' "

HEADLINE: Mining Unhappiness in a Changed New Hampshire

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Jan. 11

 BODY:
Facing their first primary election in a state that is home to some of the nation's most economically alienated voters, this year's candidates for President have begun a battle to define themselves that could set the course of the 1992 election.
For the Democrats as well as the Republicans campaigning in New Hampshire, it is no longer enough to politely introduce themselves to voters at house parties and coffee shops. The compressed campaign season leading to the Feb. 18 primary, coupled with a recession that has tripled the number of unemployed New Hampshire residents since 1988, has forced a different approach this year. 
 Each candidate must now prove, through radio and television advertisements and in appearances at plant gates and shuttered stores, that he is tough enough to end the bad times.
Campaign strategists are trying to cut through the economic malaise to appeal to voters like Lou Marchand, who stood alone in her rural Hillsborough restaurant during a nonexistent lunch hour rush one day this week. Mrs. Marchand cared little that Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska was campaigning nearby.
Noting that Hillsborough had lost a vegetable wholesaler, a lumber company and a coin laundry in the last six months, she said business was so bad that she hoped for nighttime snowstorms so road crews would drop by for breakfast. She said she and her husband, Ron, strain to pay their monthly $250 health insurance premium and keep their business afloat.
"It's been pretty tough around here," she said with the New Englander's gift for understatement.
 
More Pragmatic
 To reach people like Mrs. Marchand, who sees little difference among the Presidential hopefuls so far, the candidates have abandoned the customary warm and fuzzy biographical advertisements. Instead, the first spate of television spots, which began appearing here this week, illustrate the new, more pragmatic manner in which the candidates are choosing to make themselves known to voters.
In Gov. Bill Clinton's 60-second effort, Mr. Clinton is in front of a flag in his Arkansas State House office. Gazing into the camera, he talks about the "forgotten middle class" and his plan to rescue its members.
In Paul E. Tsongas's commercial, the second he has put on the air in New Hampshire, he boasts of his accomplishments as a United States Senator from Massachusetts, including his role in winning Congressional approval for a bailout of the Chrysler Corporation and in pushing for the passage of the Alaska Lands Act. As with his first advertisement, which featured Mr. Tsongas swimming laps, the spot emphasized the former Senator's toughness and his recovery from a bout with cancer.
Senator Kerrey, who began attacking Mr. Clinton on the stump earlier this week, joined the advertising fray on Friday. He abandons the recitation of his record in the Vietnam War to discuss health care and to chide President Bush for going to Japan to "beg for a few concessions."
In his advertisement, Mr. Kerrey strides across an ice rink and likens the trade imbalance to a hockey game. "Fight back, America," an announcer intones at the end of the commercial.
Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa shot his own New Hampshire advertisements on a visit here last week, but they have yet to appear. Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, who spent much of last week campaigning in Iowa, has also not broadcast television advertisements here.
The Democrats have not been alone in the candidate-definition derby. Vice President Dan Quayle's two-day visit to the state this week marked the Bush campaign's first foray into a race made competitive, in New Hampshire at least, by the presence of Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator.
Mr. Quayle warned Republicans unhappy with Mr. Bush for backtracking on his 1988 no-new-taxes pledge that they should not use Mr. Buchanan's candidacy to send a message. "When times are difficult, don't you want and deserve the very best?" Mr. Quayle asked his New Hampshire audiences.
Mr. Buchanan took out a full-page advertisement in The Union Leader, the influential Manchester newspaper, while Mr. Quayle was visiting. It began, "Hey Dan! Where's George?" while the slogan at the bottom of the page promised, "He'll keep the promises George Bush broke."
But the most vociferous early squabbling has taken place among the Democrats, particularly between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Kerrey. After Mr. Clinton's advertising hit the airwaves this week, Mr. Kerrey said his health-care plan was "more revolting than it is revolutionary," the latest in a series of jibes he has aimed at Mr. Clinton.
"Voters up here have a very short window to not just figure out who these guys are, but how they're different from each other," said Bill Shore, an adviser to Mr. Kerrey.
It is difficult to determine how much of the jockeying between Mr. Kerrey and Mr. Clinton is merely political choreography. "It's my strategy to come and argue," Mr. Kerrey cheerfully acknowledged this week.
 
Weak Voter Interest
 Most political professionals here acknowledge that voter interest and support for particular candidates remain soft, in spite of early polls showing some popularity for Mr. Tsongas, who lives in neighboring Massachusetts.
Mr. Tsongas's advertising, intended in part to leaven his serious image -- "He's no movie star," his new advertisement begins -- sends the same can-do message the other Democrats are striving for. "This is someone who gets things done in Washington," said Mike Shea, a media adviser to Mr. Tsongas. "And that's a significant point."
Similarly, Mr. Clinton's advisers are seeking to tap into the anger of the economically depressed by appealing to the middle-class frustrations they detected when they conducted interviewed groups of New Hampshire voters. "They are demanding that politicians answer their questions and tell them what you want to do," said Mitchell Schwartz, who runs Mr. Clinton's New Hampshire campaign.
Mr. Kerrey's advertisements, filmed just this week, appeared little more than a day later. In them, he assails President Bush and, by implication, any Democrat who would do less than he would. "You've got an obligation to be explicit about it, not just to put yur ideas out there, but to say how they're different from the others," said Mr. Shore, Mr. Kerrey's adviser.
Mr. Harkin, who appeals to the party's left wing, is probably the most clearly defined of the five remaining major candidates, although he has not appeared on paid television. "Tom Harkin hasn't really changed what he has been saying from the very beginning," said Kathi Rogers, Mr. Harkin's New Hampshire campaign director. "He's saying, ' "If you want real substantial change, I'm the one to vote for.' "
Each of these candidates must find a way to appeal to skeptical and economically preoccupied voters like Helena Caldwell, who has worked at an electrical plant in Hillsborough for 20 years.
"I don't really know the fellow," she said as Bob Kerrey ambled by. "Hey, they're all alike. I'd like to see them talk about the economy. It's getting bad and people are worried."

HEADLINE: HAITIAN COMMUNIST SPEAKS OF HEALING

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Playing down his longtime Communist affiliation, a compromise candidate for the post of Prime Minister has begun efforts to reassure a torn society that his primary task, if he is ratified for the job, will be to tap talent from across the political spectrum and to heal the country's wounds.
In his first interview since his nomination was approved Wednesday in diplomat-brokered negotiations with the deposed President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, Rene Theodore, Haiti's Communist Party leader, described a political evolution that he said had led him to favor "modern capitalism." He promised that any government he formed would be one of true national reconciliation. 
 "Haiti sometimes sends very strong images abroad, and often we may seem anachronistic," Mr. Theodore said of his country's violent, running political crisis and the choice of a Communist as a compromise leader. "It is true that Communism is not on today's agenda, but it is not a Communist power that we would be installing in Haiti.
"We must consider the task before us one of national salvation, of rescuing the nation. For this, we must bring together all of the parties represented in the National Assembly. One could not think of forming any government that was not one of national reconciliation."
 
'The World Has Changed'
 Asked of the widely noted irony of the United States, which has pledged to support him if he is approved, backing a Communist after decades of determined efforts to contain the spread of Marxism in the hemisphere, Mr. Theodore, who said he studied history and politics at the Institute of Social Sciences in Moscow during his years of exile, smiled gently.
"Perhaps it is because the world has changed and the United States finds itself in an ideal position to support the social and economic development of our country," Mr. Theodore said, speaking in French during the interview on Friday in his sparely furnished home in the suburb of Petion-Ville. "We hope they will now be able to do so in accordance with their ideals."
Even as a debate raged in the country's Parliament, with one angry rightist deputy waving a pistol in the air to denounce a political settlement he said was being imposed by the United States, Mr. Theodore, a 51-year-old mathematician who has spent most of his adult life in exile, expressed confidence that he would be ratified in the job in a vote next week.
"I think that I have every chance of being approved," he said. Of the conservative elite, he said: "I have no concerns on that score. The positions we have taken since 1986 allow me to believe that no one would have any reticence about me."
 
Chosen Over Conservative
 Mr. Theodore was selected by Father Aristide after leaders of the National Assembly proposed him, along with a conservative politician, each of them among the exiled President's strongest critics, to form a new Government.
Once formed, the new Government has been promised international support for the quick lifting of a three-month trade embargo and the reconstruction of a shattered economy.
Under the settlement brokered by the Organization of American States, Father Aristide, the leftist populist who was the country's first democratically elected President, would return to Haiti as head of state from exile in Venezuela. Father Aristide was overthrown in a violent military coup on Sept. 30.
Although he retains much of the popular support that enabled him to win 67 percent of the popular vote in the country's December 1990 elections, Father Aristide was overthrown in part because of concerns among politically active people over his commitment to the Constitution, and growing fears of political and class-based violence, which many believe the President endorsed.
Mr. Theodore denounced what he said often appeared to be Father Aristide's guiding belief: "What the people want, God wants."
"One cannot gauge at every moment, either by elections or referendum what the people want," he said. "The work of government is much more complex than that."
To gain the confidence of the army, Mr. Theodore said, he has pledged himself to noninterference in its internal affairs, which he defined as "discipline, promotion and hierarchy," three areas in which Father Aristide's Government frequently became involved.
Despite his often stern criticisms, Mr. Theodore said he would have no difficulty sharing power with Father Aristide, who was widely accused of accumulating the functions of the President, Prime Minister and even individual ministerial portfolios during his nearly eight months in office.
"The Haitian Constitution is very clear on this," he said. "You have a head of government who manages the public administration and a President who assures the continuity of state and serves as the moral guarantor of engagements taken vis-a-vis the republic and the society."

HEADLINE: With Return of a Mob War, Prosecutor Presses for Peace

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
Faced with a deadly end to a holiday truce in New York City's most vicious mob war in 30 years, the Brooklyn District Attorney's office has recruited up to 120 Federal, state and city officers to try to push the battling factions into a new peace, a law-enforcement official said yesterday.
In the last seven months, since the struggle in the Colombo crime family broke into the open, there have been 10 attempted killings of members of two factions, leaving six men dead and seven people wounded, including at least four innocent bystanders. 
 After the fifth killing, District Attorney Charles J. Hynes subpoenaed 96 suspected mobsters to testify before a grand jury. There was a 30-day respite in the battle.
But last Tuesday, the peace was shattered when a captain in one of the factions, Nicholas Grancio, was gunned down in Gravesend.
 
'Economic Pressure'
 Mr. Hynes declined to comment yesterday. But another law-enforcement official, who demanded anonymity, confirmed that the task force was being organized, as first reported yesterday in The Daily News.
"It's the latest in a series of steps to create economic pressure on the warring factions so that they'll have to accept a truce," the official said.
"The first step was the subpoenas and the roundup of identifiable members," he continued. "Then, when Grancio was killed, a second phase went into effect -- an intensification of surveillance.
"Now there's another phase, a coordinated Federal, state and city task force in which more than 100 law-enforcement agents will be employed" to clamp down on the Colombo family's loan sharking, betting and numbers operations. The official said the task force would tighten surveillance on the four other crime families in the city so that the bosses of those groups would also pressure the Colombos.
The Colombo family, long known among authorities and in Mafia councils as erratic, was named for Joseph Colombo, its leader during the last major outbreak of mob violence in the city during the 1960's. After Mr. Colombo was shot at an Italian-American civil rights rally in 1971, Carmine Persico emerged as the family boss.
 
Hits and Misses
 Mr. Persico, 58 years old, is currently serving 100 years in prison for racketeering and bribery. In 1989, he named Victor J. Orena, 57, of Cedarhurst, L.I., as acting boss. "He believed he could trust him," the law-enforcement official said.
"Also in prison is Carmine Persico's son, Alphonse; he's supposed to get out in '93," the official continued. "Carmine's plan was that Alphonse would take over the family. But once Orena got the taste of honey, he not only took things over, he stopped the flow of tribute to the Persico faction."
Mr. Orena was the target of the war's first ambush. On June 20, he came home unexpectedly "and spotted a hit team from the Persico faction," the official said. He fled, and no shots were fired.
Then, on Nov. 18, Gregory Scarpa, a Persico soldier, escaped injury when shots were fired at his two-car caravan in Bay Ridge. On Nov. 24, Henry Smurra, a Persico loan shark, was shot to death in his car in Sheepshead Bay.
And in the next 20 days members of the rival groups were shot and killed, shot and wounded, shot and missed. People near them were also hurt.
Mr. Grancio, an Orena faction captain, was killed while sitting in his recreational vehicle in Gravesend -- ending the 30-day truce.

HEADLINE: Under Political Steam, Health-Care Issue Gains Wider Support in Congress

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
In the last few months health care has jumped to the front of the Presidential race and to the top of the Congressional agenda, with proposals as radical as the creation of a national health insurance plan like Canada's gaining momentum.
Yet for all the commotion, most Congressional leaders expect only modest change this year. They say the issue is so complex and the differences among members so wide that it will take months of study and hearings to arrive at a consensus. Stop-gap measures, like an expansion of Medicaid and Medicare benefits for pregnant women and children or tax incentives to expand private health insurance, are picking up strong support, but the leaders say such changes are only the beginning. 
 Both Democratic and Republican spokesmen on health care say the escalating campaign debate has set a course for more far-reaching plans in the next Congress and Administration, whether they are Republican or Democratic.
"Elections are an inducement to action," said Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Senate Democratic leader, who noted that many lawmakers were being forced to wrestle with the health-care issue for the first time. "There's been a dramatic change in popular interest and political concern about the problem."
 
Bipartisan Effort Predicted
 Senator Dave Durenberger, Republican of Minnesota, predicted that political pressure would help forge a bipartisan majority this year to pass a limited measure that he supports. The legislation would expand tax deductions for health insurance for the self-employed and provide continuity of coverage for workers changing jobs. "Later, we'll federalize low-income access to medical care," he said.
The recession has aggravated the problem of how to extend access to health care to the 35 million Americans who are uninsured or underinsured, without breaking the Federal treasury and fueling inflation. Among the uninsured are 450,000 pregnant women, increasing the likelihood that they will not seek the prenatal care they may need to avert premature delivery, an important factor in birth defects.
New layoffs have increased the number of uninsured in recent months, while the more gradual employment trend away from manufacturing toward the service sector has put workers in jobs that are less likely to provide coverage. And as fewer workers are insured, fewer of their dependents are covered.
 
Town Meetings by Democrats
 At the same time, the costs of health care have outstripped the rate of inflation by a considerable margin for more than a decade, making it more difficult for individuals and businesses to afford the health insurance plans they are enrolled in. The Commerce Department estimated that Americans spent about $817 billion on health care in 1991, about 11 percent more than in 1990.
House Democrats will try to exploit growing public concerns by holding 200 town meetings around the country on Tuesday night to publicize their various health-care proposals and put President Bush on the defensive. Representative Vic Fazio of California, the organizer of the events, said: "It's going to be a very interesting and educational campaign debate, which will be the precursor of real fundamental change in the aftermath of the campaign."
Democrats and Republicans have been jockeying for advantage on health care since last November when Senator Harris Wofford, a Democrat, defeated former Attorney General Dick Thornburgh in a special Pennsylvania election largely by contending that all Americans deserved decent medical care. Only hours after the polls closed, dozens of Senate and House members, including an unusual number of Republicans, made speeches criticizing President Bush for moving too slowly to develop a health-care policy.
In the last week, Administration officials responded to the pressure by embracing a number of proposals already outlined by Republican members of Congress, including restrictions on medical malpractice lawsuits and the establishment of new incentives for people to enroll in prepaid group health plans like health maintenance organizations.
Labor Secretary Lynn Martin and the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Louis W. Sullivan, sharpened the debate on Thursday when they charged that a plan favored by Senator Mitchell to force employers to provide health insurance would devastate small businesses and cause higher unemployment.
Senator Mitchell shrugged off Administration criticism, saying he was happy President Bush was responding to the political pressure. "Just getting the President to discuss the issue is an accomplishment," he said, adding that another dip in the President's popularity would increase the possibility that major insurance legislation could be passed and signed this year.
Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, Democrat of West Virginia, has been pressing Democratic Presidential candidates to hone their message on the issue by organizing two debates exclusively devoted to health care. In the first, only Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska and former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts offered detailed plans. But Mr. Rockefeller hopes the other candidates will be forced to tackle the issue before the next debate.
 
30 Plans Before Congress
 "You have to think of building political pressure through the political process," said Mr. Rockefeller, who is sponsoring a bill that would phase in requirements for employers to provide health insurance or pay an additional payroll tax to finance Government-supplied insurance. "I think the Presidential campaign helps the legislative prospects on health care."
Of the more than 30 health-care insurance bills now before Congress, only a couple that offer tax incentives to extend coverage appear to have a real chance for quick enactment. National health insurance has substantial support in the House but far less than it needs to win in the Senate. Plans like Mr. Mitchell's and Mr. Rockefeller's are gaining momentum, but opposition from Congressional conservatives and the White House is stiff.
One viable bill, proposed by Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, and supported by the Republican Senate leadership, would provide employers and employees who cannot deduct health insurance costs with tax incentives to buy coverage, and encourage small businesses to form insurance-buying groups to limit rate increases. It would also put controls on medical malpractice suits to lower insurance costs of doctors and hospitals. These costs are usually passed on to patients.
"The Chafee bill can be passed," said Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon, "but it won't end the debate."
Mr. Packwood predicted that within three years the Government would enact either national health insurance or sweeping mandates requiring businesses to provide and pay for the health insurance of their employees. "The battle will come between those two plans," he said.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Health Care: Four Plans"
 
Congress is considering more than 30 health care insurance proposals, which fall into four basic categories.
 
EMPLOYER MANDATES
 
A number of bills would require private industries to insure their employees.
 
One approach, sponsored by Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, would offer private companies a choice of providing coverage to employees and their families or making a contribution to an expanded public insurance plan. The mandated coverage would be phased in over four years for businesses with between 25 and 99 workers; for businesses with fewer than 25 workers, the phase-in would be five years.
 
MEDICAID AND MEDICARE EXPANSION
 
Some proposals would permit the unemployed to purchase Medicare, while others would eliminate the 24-month waiting period for Medicare benefits for the disabled or make early retirees eligible for coverage. A few plans would eliminate limits on Medicaid benefits to the disabled, aged and children.
 
One proposal, sponsored by Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon, would permit people to buy Medicare at age 55, 10 years before they would be otherwise eligible.
 
Another, introduced by Representative Sam M. Gibbons, Democrat of Florida, would extend Medicare benefits for prenatal, child and preventive health care.
 
TAX INCENTIVES
 
Several proposals would use the federal tax system to encourage more companies to provide health insurance and aid more individuals to purchase it. Some would grant low-income families tax credits to subsidize their expenditures on health insurance, while others would permit taxpayers to deduct more health care costs than they can now.
 
A proposal, offered by Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, would provide employers and employees who cannot deduct health insurance costs with tax incentives to buy coverage. The bill, endorsed by the Senate Republican leadership, would also attempt to reform malpractice law to lower insurance rates for health providers. President Bush favors the tax approach.
 
UNIVERSAL HEALTH INSURANCE
 
Several proposals, given little chance of passage, would replace all private and public health insurance coverage with a nationalized universal health insurance program.
 
Some are modeled after Canadian and Western European plans, in which the government pays for the medical care of individuals who continue to use their own private doctors; others would provide a mix of Government payment for private care and Government-established services like the British National Health Service.
 
Still others would mix Government and private financing by combining an expansion of Medicaid with mandated employer-provided insurance.

HEADLINE: Neediest Cases Donors Help Despite Pain of the Recession

BYLINE: By J. PEDER ZANE

 BODY:
The recession and the suffering it is causing are cited by many of the donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund as their reasons for giving. What is more surprising, perhaps, is that scores of donations received so far have come from casualties of the economic slump.
"As a victim of the downsizing of one of this country's major corporations, this is not the best of holiday seasons for me," wrote a Manhattan woman who gave $100. "And yet I am well aware that it is so much worse for so many other New Yorkers. So instead of feeling sorry for myself, I decided it was more important to focus on those who could really benefit from some help." 
 The nation's unemployment rate rose to a five-and-a-half year high of 7.1 percent in December, according to figures released by the Labor Department on Friday. The Northeast continued to be the country's hardest hit region -- with an unemployment rate of 7.4 percent -- and New York State's jobless rate remained above the national average, rising one-tenth of a percentage point, to 8.1 percent, last month.
Despite the financial and psychological hardships those numbers only hint at, many contributors to the Neediest Cases said their difficulties have made them realize that basics they once took for granted are truly blessings.
 
More Conscious of Problems
 "I'm sorry I can't be as generous as last year but I haven't been fully employed since then and my prospects don't glitter," wrote a New Jersey man who gave $30. "Still, I have a place to call home and enough so as not to go hungry. I hope this amount helps and that next year I can send last year's level or more."
Another New Jersey man, who gave $100, echoed those comments: "I feel especially sorry for people who need help this year since I am unemployed and much more conscious of what can happen."
Since it was founded in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, who was then publisher of The New York Times, the Neediest Cases has -- through two world wars, through the roaring 20's and the Great Depression, and through the booming 80's and the slumping 90's -- enabled millions of people to lend a helping hand to New York's sick, poor and disabled.
A Manhattan man said that he had been out of work so long that "I think I'm no longer part of the statistics of the unemployed." In a note attached to his $250 contribution, he wrote: "On the so-called trendy Upper West Side where I live -- among the sushi restaurants, the avant-garde clothing stores and the exorbitant toy stores -- everyday I see the homeless, the impoverished, the lonely old folks, all who have somehow slipped through the the government's fiscal safety net. But let us not forget the proverb:
'I cried because I had no shoes; then I met a man with no feet.' "

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
Working-Class Pair Now Reigns in Skating

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 11

 BODY:
The marinated chicken sandwiches are waiting for Calla Urbanski back at Kid Shelleen's restaurant in Delaware. So are the customers, who miss the tiny blonde waitress with the hoarse Chicago accent.
"She scoots around pretty good," Russell Jennings, one of the cooks at Kid Shilleen's, said over the telephone. "Those little legs can move fast." 
 Those "little legs" will be back toting trays in the Trolley Square section of Wilmington, perhaps later this week. Better times are coming, but Calla Urbanski still needs the money, and she is not too proud to admit it.
Instead of working at Kid Shelleen's last week, Urbanski captured the national figure-skating pairs championship along with her partner, Rocky Marval, who has been known to drive a truck when not skating.
 
No Longer a Novelty Act
 The waitress and the truck driver. They were a novelty item right up until Thursday night. They started in third place, but a few chords into Thus Spake Zarathustra, she came out of her throw triple loop in perfect form, with a huge smile on her face, and as her coach, Ron Ludington, said later, "They were electric."
A few minutes later, Calla and Rocky accepted their gold medals and became the biggest sentimental American favorites going into the Winter Games in France next month -- "Do You Believe in Miracles?" crossed with Mary Lou Retton.
In the movie, Calla would be played by Cissy Spacek or Sally Fields, but with his polished, well-coiffed manner, Rocky is more Michael J. Fox or John Ritter than Sylvester Stallone. And the truck he occasionally drives is part of a company that he and his brother own, that is to say in collaboration with a bank or two.
But call them the waitress and the truck driver, anyway. They are graphic examples of the current success of figure skating, which will be given approximately 33 per cent of the air time by CBS from Albertville.
The money is so good in figure skating right now that the federation can support enough skaters to insure depth and competition. People from working-class backgrounds like Tonya Harding, Nancy Kerrigan and Todd Eldredge have moved to the top of the American program, and Urbanski has stayed in skating 10 years past the time most female skaters are subtly told to let somebody else have a chance.
 
Skaters From Working Class
 The 31-year-old waitress and the 26-year-old truck driver have both felt the pinch of the recession first-hand rather than hearing about it from their parents.
Rocky is really Rocco Marvaldi from New Egypt, Pa., whose family has been in the meat-packing business for generations. He recalled being rejected by a tony Philadelphia skating club when he was 10.
He also recalled his nose being broken three times -- once in a fight, once on a left hook from his own father ("a little disciplinary action," he said) and once in a 70-m.p.h. dirt-bike collision that left him without memory for three days. He nearly lost his left eye in that one.
 
Buttons for Donations
 When Marval and Urbanski were first put together five years ago, he warned her not to hit his nose while they were performing. The match didn't take but they were reunited two years ago, two determined adults who were ready for each other.
To pay for their partnership, they created buttons that said "I Helped Urbanski & Marval Go for the Gold," and distributed them in bars and restaurants in Delaware -- "for a donation, not for sale," Urbanski noted.
On Friday, the new champions talked with gratitude about how the children at Gauger Junior High School in Newark had raised $4,000 for them. They both conceded that their four and a half minutes on Thursday night had raised the stakes.
 
'We Have a Title Now'
 "We have a title now," Urbanski said, hopeful of exhibitions and circuits in the near future. "We can get a few more zeroes."
Meanwhile, Urbanski's size 2 or 4 tan slacks and green shirt are waiting for her at Kid Shelleen's this week.
"Will the tips be good?" somebody asked her.
"They'd better be," she said crisply. "That's the reason I'm going back."

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
The Stomach Thing

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
Historians will analyze for years to come the causes and effects of the President's recent intestinal flu, or what Mr. Bush has begun to call "the stomach thing." Some have blamed fatigue, others jet lag, and a few have even posited that Mr. Bush intentionally fell ill to win sympathy from the Japanese, a kind of Bush-bugged-himself scenario that, if true, failed.
Americans considering protectionism, free trade and sushi watched the President keel over on the dais and shouted, "Lose the sea urchin, George." They were unaware that the Japanese had feted the President with the sort of country club cuisine that reached its zenith during the Administration of Gerald Ford: to wit, cold salmon, clear soup and the ubiquitous medallions of beef -- a dinner as much like a traditional Japanese banquet as cars made in Detroit are like what American consumers want to buy. 
 In fact, certain reports over the last three days suggest that the President's illness originated with a 3-year-old with a runny nose named Samantha in Bethesda, Md.
Samantha contracted the stomach flu in early December, a case made notable mainly by the fact that she only made it as far as the toy box when disaster struck, the unfortunate triumph of necessity over locale that may have prefigured the Bush incident at the banquet. Samantha then gave the flu to her brother Jonathan, and he to their mother, a Democratic lobbyist for various liberal organizations.
Jonathan gave it to his friend Alexander, whose father, a middle-level official in the Commerce Department, frequently used the Stairmaster at the gym just after the squash partner of one of the Secret Service agents assigned to the Japanese trip. All were later stricken, but not before the agent had stood next to the President with one of those little things in his ear, looking silly.
This is what is called the trickle-up effect, and is not unlike the song about the knee bone being connected to the thigh bone or those endless begat sections of the Bible. The scenario seems plausible since this is the way the stomach flu has traveled through most of America in the last six weeks. In fact, when they first saw the film of the President pitching over and heard of his symptoms, roughly a million people, Republicans and Democrats alike, struck themselves in the forehead and yelled, "That was the thing that I got from Phil just before the holidays!"
Mr. Bush's bout with the flu recalled his handling of the recession. He got it after everyone else did and he kept trying to pretend it wasn't that bad. When Mr. Bush suggested that he had only grossed out the dais and scared the bejesus out of his wife to get attention, Samantha's mother, for example, who had spent an entire week doing laundry after her children got the flu, found herself out of sympathy with him, a feeling that only grew when she was questioned by the F.B.I. and asked for the names of those in Samantha's preschool class and Gymboree group.
It is too late to tell whether the flu outbreak affected the outcome of the trip to Japan, or if it would have been just as big a bust if Mr. Bush had cleaned up his medallions and moved on to the passion fruit dessert and a splash of decaf. The illness did provide some public moments in New Hampshire for Vice President Dan Quayle, currently riding the crest of an amended American standard for high officials that, taken from the Latin, translates roughly as "Not half as bad as we originally thought."
What remains unclear is whether the President will use the stomach thing to boost his re-election chances by presenting it as an indelible link between himself and ordinary Americans, not unlike that magic moment when he discovered he was out of socks -- "Barbara, how in blazes do you always manage to let the dryer eat just one of each pair?!"-- and hightailed it over to J. C. Penney.
"I shared your pain," he could tell the nation. "Not to mention a few other piggy things I think we'd all prefer to forget."
A moment of disaster could become a defining moment, not only for Mr. Bush, but for the future course of American politics, in which we accept our national leaders as human beings.
A President as sick as the rest of us: it resonates.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Power Struggle

BYLINE: BY SAM HOWE VERHOVEK; Sam Howe Verhovek is a reporter in the Albany bureau of The New York Times.

 BODY:
AS THE GREAT WHALE River rises east out of Hudson Bay in northeastern Canada, its broad sandy shores quickly give way to a carpet of light-green lichen studded with granite outcroppings. Beyond the banks lies a vast expanse of black spruce and tamarack, great coniferous forests broken here and there by lakes and bogs and kettle ponds. In winter, the taiga can be harsh and remorseless, a region racked by "wind, snow and natural violence of every sort," as an adventurer described it a half-century ago. But it is also a landscape that teems with life in fall and spring, when enormous herds of caribous stomp across the earth and millions of migratory birds tarry in the estuaries of James and Hudson Bays, some stopping to double their weight as they feast on eelgrass and coastal shrimp before flying as far south as Tierra del Fuego. It is quiet in summer: on an August evening there is utter silence in the northern Quebec bush, save for the rippling of the river or the honking of a pair of geese overhead in a salmon-colored sky.
This subarctic wilderness is, in any season, an unlikely subject of an international controversy. But that is precisely what it has become hundreds of miles away, in southern Quebec and in New York State's capital, Albany, where the central question about the Great Whale River basin is this: Should large parts of it be underwater?
Hydro-Quebec, a utility owned by the province of Quebec, envisions flooding the Great Whale as the second of three phases in a planned hydroelectric power system of colossal proportions. To harness the kinetic energy in 20 wild rivers, Hydro-Quebec plans to erect three dozen huge dams and hundreds of dikes across the taiga, ultimately redrawing terrain in an area the size of France. 
 Affecting the regions east of James Bay and southeast of Hudson Bay, the James Bay development project would be one of the largest hydroelectric complexes in the world, churning turbines with a dozen times the force of Niagara Falls. It would easily rank as one of the largest construction projects ever undertaken.
The work already completed in the first phase of the project, south of the Great Whale basin and known as the LaGrande River complex, used enough fill to build the Great Pyramid of Cheops 80 times over. A feat like diverting the Caniapiscau River, so that it flowed west into James Bay, rather than northeast into Ungava Bay, as it had for eons, was considered a routine engineering matter, hardly worthy of comment -- until 1984, that is, when 10,000 migratory caribous died in its raging waters.
In Phase 2, Hydro-Quebec intends to push north into the Great Whale area and, in Phase 3, plans to divert the Nottaway and the Rupert Rivers into the Broadback River, storing the water in seven new reservoirs, sending it through 11 powerhouses and transforming the lower parts of the diverted rivers into dry bedrock. With all phases completed, sometime after the turn of the century, the project would produce 26,400 megawatts of electrical power, of which 15 percent would be available for export.
But Quebec's expansive plans are drawing bitter resistance from native Cree Indians, concerned about preserving the land and traditional Indian ways of life, as well as from environmentalists, who warn of impending ecological disaster. And, while the Quebecois tend to see hydropower as the province's pathway to economic, and possibly political, independence from the rest of Canada, there is a competing claim. The native people in the north -- there are about 12,000 Crees and 6,000 Inuit Eskimos living in the James Bay region -- say that if Francophone Quebec gains recognition as a "distinct society," they should be granted the same recognition and more authority over what happens to their land. Indeed, the Canadian Government lent renewed force to their argument last month, when it said it would grant the Inuits control over nearly two-thirds of the Northwest Territories, an area to be known as Nunavut.
And James Bay is the object of an increasingly fierce debate in New York, where Gov. Mario M. Cuomo must decide within the next year whether to go ahead with a 20-year, $19.5 billion contract to buy some of this power from the Canadian north.
At first glance, the agreement seems like the perfect match of Quebec's supply and New York's demand. By early next century, if the plan goes through, 10 to 12 percent of the state's electricity (compared with about 2 percent today) would come soaring down high-voltage lines from the taiga and into electrical outlets from Massena to Manhattan to Montauk.
Yet opponents have raised a number of disturbing questions that already have forced New York officials to postpone the decision once. Is the importing of "clean" hydropower the salvation of a state that has labored unsuccessfully to comply with Federal clean-air standards? Or is it simply tantamount to exporting environmental and cultural destruction to the taiga, the ultimate not-in-my-backyard solution to New York's energy needs? Will energy demand truly rise by 2 to 3 percent a year, as was forecast a few years ago, before the growth in demand slowed in the face of the current recession? And, finally, should New York not in any case try harder to meet its energy needs through conservation?
By virtue of its financial clout, New York will cast what many analysts say is the decisive vote on Great Whale. Hydro-Quebec officials insist that they will go ahead with the $50 billion to $60 billion project no matter what New York decides. The only effect, they say, will be to delay it for a few years. But less-interested observers doubt that Quebec can proceed without the contract and the capital it represents. "The whole essence of James Bay 2 depends on export sales," says Ihor Kots, managing director of Canadian Bond Rating Service Inc., the largest credit-rating service in Canada. "The electricity demand in Quebec won't be sufficient to take up the capacity for years to come. If there is not demand from elsewhere, it would add considerably to the financial risk."
WHILE HYDROPOWER HAS LONG BEEN TOUTED AS clean and cheaper than any other available source of power, virtually everyone involved in the James Bay dispute agrees that this is no longer completely true. Given current long-range projections for energy costs, the New York State Energy Office says the Quebec power would actually cost slightly more than electricity generated from oil, coal and natural gas. This could change, however, if New York, as some state officials predict, succeeds in negotiating a lower price with Hydro-Quebec this year.
For the moment, though, the debate about James Bay turns primarily on environmental questions. Proponents of hydropower purchases, including the New York Power Authority, warn of increased fossil-fuel pollution if the contract is rejected. They cite an energy office study that shows emissions of sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and carbon dioxide rising by 7 percent, 10.4 percent and 6.1 percent respectively in New York, without the hydropower. And, they point out, some of this pollution would be transported across the border and deposited on Canadian territory.
Critics insist that the only sure way to reduce pollution and avoid environmental destruction is to conserve energy use. Jeffrey Wollock, the executive director of the New York City-based James Bay Defense Coalition, a group representing 24 environmental and native rights organizations, calls the James Bay contracts "a case of exporting New York's environmental problems to another part of the planet. This is not environmentalism, but pseudo-environmentalism."
Hydro-Quebec's brochures stress its commitment to building "in harmony with nature," and feature pictures of Hydro-Quebec workers carefully airlifting animals to safety from islands created by the flooding. Nevertheless, the utility is fighting an uphill battle to improve its image, especially after the caribou disaster in the Caniapiscau River.
The mass drowning happened to occur the first year the reservoirs were full enough to require controlled releases down the riverway. Hydro-Quebec claims that, because of the torrential rains that year, the caribous very likely would have died anyway, and notes that the overall caribou population in the James Bay region has increased in the last 20 years. But the natives and some biologists insist that the mass drownings would never have occurred if the river had been left alone.
The most profound, but also most problematic, questions involve long-term threats to the James Bay region as the subarctic habitat is altered on such a dramatic scale.
Hydro-Quebec insists that the overall impact will be minimal, that humans and animals will adapt and that no animal species is threatened with extinction. Environmentalists paint drastic scenarios. Jan Beyea, chief scientist at the National Audubon Society, has concluded that "in terms of wildlife and habitat, the devastation of James Bay is the northern equivalent of the destruction of the tropical rain forest." Others say New York should back out of James Bay simply to avoid becoming "an accomplice to the crime," in the words of William B. Hoyt, a Buffalo Democrat who is chairman of the State Assembly's energy committee and a principal opponent.
The New York Power Authority has vigorously insisted to Hydro-Quebec that New York wants a proper environmental review of the project, and Canadian Federal officials have also vowed to monitor Quebec's plans. Still, some state officials have protested that cancellation of the contracts on ecological grounds would amount to drastic interference in Canada's internal affairs. But that is precisely what the Cree opponents are requesting.
"How can we expect the Quebec government to be fair?" asks Chief Robbie Dick, the band, or tribal, chief for the Crees of Whapmagoostui (also called Kuujjuarapik, in Inuit), the village at the mouth of the Great Whale River. "They are the proponents and the analyzers, the judge and the jury."
The James Bay dispute involves starkly conflicting visions of the landscape. "Who would consider the total elimination of the Hudson River?" Matthew Coon Come, the chief of the Grand Council of the Cree, asked a United Nations panel last year. "Yet great rivers have been destroyed where my people live."
Yet Robert Bourassa, the Quebec premier and original mastermind of James Bay, looks at the wilderness and sees kilowatts vital to the province's future. Northern Quebec, he wrote in a 1985 book, "Power from the North," is a "vast hydroelectric project-in-the-bud, and every day millions of potential kilowatt hours flow downhill and out to the sea. What a waste!"
THERE IS ONE POINT ON WHICH JUST ABOUT everybody involved in the clash over James Bay concurs: Hydro-Quebec knows how to build hydroelectric power plants, gargantuan structures that attract astounded engineers from all over the world.
There is the enormous dam, known as LaGrande 2, whose 16 turbines 450 feet below the surface of the water generate enough thrust to power 50 Boeing 747's at takeoff. And there is LaGrande 2-A, called the "baby sister," a generating station still under construction, whose 2,000 megawatts will be more powerful than the combined output of all the gas- and oil-fired plants and the single nuclear reactor in Quebec. (A megawatt is a million watts, or the power needed to light 10,000 100-watt electrical bulbs. A suburban shopping mall with 100 stores or so draws roughly 3 megawatts, the towers of the World Trade Center use about 32 megawatts each.) A few miles from LaGrande 2-A, across the reservoir, is a giant spillway blasted out of the rock and capable of carrying the combined flows of all the rivers of Europe (excluding the territory of the former Soviet Union).
Sixty-eight people died in construction accidents during the 13 years it took to build the first phase of the LaGrande project. Hydro-Quebec is quick to assert, however, that given the 150 million man-hours involved, this actually represents one of the best safety records for a major construction project in North American history.
Hydro-Quebec, which generates 95 percent of the province's electrical power and accounts for 5 percent of gross domestic product, has become a kind of adopted stepchild of Bourassa, the Quebec premier. He was in office to make the 1971 announcement kicking off the first phase of the project and, after an interval in political exile, returned to announce James Bay 2 in 1988.
The fantastic plans the Premier has already made for James Bay pale beside his grandest vision. In a project that would cost well more than $100 billion and that is not likely to be taken seriously until decades into the next century, if ever, Bourassa has advocated transforming James Bay into an enormous freshwater lake by erecting a dike across its mouth -- a distance of 100 miles. From there the water would be pumped through a series of enormous channels to the arid stretches of the Great Plains, the American Southwest and California. Bourassa has referred to his plan simply as the "Grand Canal."
STILL, WHILE NO ONE questions Hydro-Quebec's technical prowess, the company has enjoyed far less success in assuaging concerns about the environmental toll. These range from the still-disputed caribou drowning in 1984 to undisputed releases of toxic methyl mercury, which have led to limits on the consumption of fish in the region, a staple in the diets of the Crees and Inuits.
As vegetation decomposes underwater, bacteria transform mercury -- a common and harmless component of soil and vegetation -- into a toxic methylated form that is absorbed by fish, which then become dangerous to eat. A 1984 study of the Cree village of Chisasibi, downstream from the LaGrande complex, found that 64 percent of the residents had methyl mercury levels classified as unsafe by the World Health Organization. Methyl mercury is thought to cause numerous birth defects, including palsy and retardation, as well as stillbirths and convulsions.
Hydro-Quebec officials concede that methyl mercury will continue to be a problem for 25 to 30 years at LaGrande and, if it is flooded, Great Whale. Yet, through medication and strict limits on the consumption of predatory fish like trout and pike, they say, the incidence of unsafe mercury levels among residents of Chisasibi has been reduced to 30 percent since the 1984 study.
But the talk of limits on fish angers the Crees. "Telling us that we'll be O.K. if we don't eat fish is like telling us that we will be O.K. if we just cut our own legs off," says Andrew Natachequan, a Cree elder in the village of Whapmagoostui.
Hydro-Quebec has invested $18.5 million in studies for a methyl-mercury advisory committee. But other than coming up with the consumption limits and suggesting the Crees might turn a profit by grinding fish into commercial fertilizer, the committee has been largely stumped.
Longer-range questions about the effect of the construction on the James Bay habitat remain, in many ways, unresolved.
A number of Canadian and American environmental organizations argue that cumulative changes will have unpredictable and in some cases devastating consequences. For one thing, the James Bay project has already succeeded in reversing the normal flow of water in many of the dammed rivers. Water now runs faster in the winter, corresponding to the peak demand for electricity in Quebec (where more than 70 percent of homes use electric heat), and slower at other times as the water is stored in reservoirs. This means that coastal marshes and tidal flats have fewer nutrients in spring and fall, the times of heaviest migration, when many birds must eat voraciously to prepare for their flights. The scene at James Bay during such times has been described as a "rite of gluttony."
These migrants "may have no substitute habitat if key sites in James Bay are destroyed," according to a study of the area released in November by the National Audubon Society. The report further states that "many species of migratory shore birds would be severely threatened, possibly even to extinction, if a crucial stopover area were damaged."
Gaetan Guertin, director of environmental studies for Hydro-Quebec, asserts that any animals displaced by the flooding or the man-made reservoirs would thrive elsewhere in the area. While acknowledging that the company does not keep specific counts of species populations in the James Bay region, he insists that little damage will be done. "We have enough data, and we're very confident in the quality of our data, that our predictions will be borne out," he says. "They show that it's not a disaster there."
Hydro-Quebec further notes that all three projects together would flood only about 1.5 percent of the dry land in the James Bay region. But that figure still amounts to an area nearly the size of New Jersey, and it does not include the lakes and ponds swallowed up by the new reservoirs. Finally, for all the concern about flooding, the project's many diversions would also turn hundreds of miles of roaring riverways into dry riverbeds.
THE ELECTRICITY GENERATED IN THE Canadian north races down the transmission lines that stretch like forests of steel across the taiga, into New York State and ultimately across a grid that reaches into every home, apartment, factory and office in the state. Under a 1978 contract with Hydro-Quebec, New York buys anywhere from 800 to 1,000 megawatts during the peak demand period of the year, from April 1 to Nov. 1. The new contracts would extend this arrangement to the year 2018, and add a new year-round commitment of 1,000 megawatts beginning in 1995.
The question of whether New York State "needs" the James Bay hydropower is, on one level, unanswerable. Public utilities have achieved substantial energy savings in recent years through "demand-side management" practices pushed by the chairman of the state's Public Service Commission, Peter A. Bradford. Demand management includes both conservation and the manipulation of rates to discourage use during peak daylight hours and to encourage use during slack times at night.
These measures, coupled with the lengthy recession, have worked. As recently as two and a half years ago, Consolidated Edison, which serves New York City and neighboring Westchester County and is the state's largest utility, was projecting annual consumption increases of between 2 and 3 percent. Now the utility says it will meet all demand growth in coming years through demand management. And one official for the Long Island Lighting Company, at a rate-setting case before the P.S.C. last spring, said the utility appeared to be "reaching the point where we may have too much power," even after the closing of the Shoreham nuclear plant.
But many state energy planners caution that such optimism can extend only for the next few years. After that, with a hoped-for return to robust economic growth and the phasing out of New York's dirtiest fossil-fuel plants, the picture will be far more uncertain. And in any event, they say, even if conservation measures could succeed beyond anyone's wildest imagination, tapping Quebec's hydropower is still a lot better than burning fossil fuels.
And even as total consumption appears to be flattening out, there is another ominous measure of electricity use that keeps rising. That is the figure for "peak demand," which typically comes on a sweltering summer day, when nearly everybody seems to stay close to an air-conditioner. New York State set a new all-time record this July with a peak demand of 26,839 megawatts. Without adequate reserves, officials warn, technicians may some day have no choice but to impose widespread brownouts and blackouts at the worst possible time.
Opponents of the contract are skeptical of this doomsday scenario. In any event, some energy analysts contend it would be cheaper for New York to pay for an energy-conservation program in Quebec and then to import the freed-up electricity than for Hydro-Quebec to build Great Whale.
HARDLY A THOUSAND people live in the wind-swept village at the mouth of the Great Whale River. But in a reflection of the polyglot culture there, it has the distinction of being known by four names: Great Whale, in English; Poste-de-la-Baleine, in French; Whapmagoostui, in Cree; and Kuujjuarapik, in Inuit. Europeans settled there a few hundred years ago -- first arriving as missionaries and traders at the outpost of the Hudson's Bay Company. Another group arrived in the mid-1950's, to help build and maintain a huge airstrip for the Canadian Air Force.
Great Whale is an odd mix in another way. Most people live in trailerlike housing with all the modern conveniences, but they are more likely than not to have a canoe or a tepee in the backyard. And while about half the Cree natives still go miles out into the bush for months at a time to fish, hunt and trap, they often fly out there in floatplanes operated by a Cree-owned airline, Air Wemindje. "It's really a lot easier that way," explains Robbie Dick, the local council chief.
But the placid patterns of life in the village have been shattered in recent years as the Crees and Inuits, alarmed by the LaGrande hydro development to the south, have geared up to fight the Great Whale project. It is in many ways a different battle than the one waged by the Crees and a smaller number of Inuits in the mid-1970's over LaGrande, when no public hearings were held on the project outside of a lawsuit filed by native leaders against Hydro-Quebec. After months of hearings and a trial in which lawyers spoke in French, English, Cree and Inuktituk, the Inuit tongue, a Quebec Superior Court Judge shocked the province by ruling in favor of the natives and ordering a halt to construction.
Within a week, though, an appeals court had overturned the ruling. In 1975, with many natives now accepting the LaGrande project as inevitable, Cree, Inuit and Quebec officials signed the landmark James Bay and Northern Quebec Agreement. In return for allowing construction to be completed on the first phase, the Crees and Inuits received more than $170 million in land-use compensation, including trapping subsidies, government housing financing, mineral-rights royalties and hospitals -- and even a network of snowmobile trails. The pact also called for an environmental review and consultation with the natives on any future development in the James Bay region.
In light of the agreement, some Quebec officials have suggested that the native peoples' opposition to Great Whale is simply a tactic designed to gain another generous compensation package. But the Crees insist that they were misled about the ecological and sociological effects of LaGrande, which brought into their area tens of thousands of Quebecois workers and, with them, all the attributes -- good and bad -- of modern life. If they had known what was coming, they now say, they would never have signed the agreement.
The Inuits' opposition is not quite so adamant, possibly because they have not been as severely affected by development as have the Crees. While many do indeed object to further development, at least two Inuit communities have elected mayors in the past year who argue that the James Bay project is unstoppable, and that the Inuits should negotiate another deal with Hydro-Quebec.
Curiously, both the Cree and Quebec officials cite the same evidence as proof of their diametrically opposed views on the social effects of development: Chisasibi, the village at the mouth of the LaGrande, 165 miles south of Great Whale.
Development has brought some undeniable benefits to the 2,500 people there, most of them Crees. Infant mortality is significantly down compared with 30 years ago, life expectancy is up and tuberculosis, which used to ravage whole communities, is almost unheard of. Almost everyone lives in comfortable, modern houses; from the air, in fact, Chisasibi looks like a miniature Levittown on the taiga. There is a hockey rink, a post office and a shopping mall.
But there are also alcoholism, drug abuse, sexually transmitted diseases, family violence and suicides, all of which the Crees say scarcely existed a generation ago. And many of the Cree leaders find it distressing that elders and young people alike, once resourceful enough to survive winters in the bush, can now be found idling in the mall, playing checkers or eating junk food.
"What we have said is that yes, our life is in many ways much easier now than it used to be," says Violet Pachanos, elected chief of the Chisasibi band council. "But we are also prey to all the social diseases of the south. We are no longer in control of our lives."
Back in Great Whale, the protests against James Bay have occasionally turned militant, and some leaders have warned they will become increasingly so. For example, in June, a team of Hydro-Quebec engineers who had come for an Inuit-sponsored hearing on the hydroelectric project was blockaded by a crowd of Crees at the Great Whale airport. The officials left on the same plane, after native leaders said they could not guarantee their safety.
The anger so evident in these incidents is also softened by a sense of irony. For example, when asked what kinds of progress had come to his village since he was a boy, Sappa Fleming, the former Mayor of the Inuit in Great Whale, says, "Well, my children can choose from six different kinds of potato chips at the Northern," referring to the local store that is a direct descendant of the Hudson's Bay Company outpost. "I suppose that is a kind of progress."
IN COMING MONTHS, officials and politicians in Quebec and New York will try to balance their best estimates of future electricity demand, based on shaky forecasts, against the expected environmental effects of the James Bay project, which past experience shows are unpredictable. They will try to balance the rights and needs of native people, and of animals with exotic names like the beluga, bufflehead, Eskimo curlew and Hudsonian godwit, against the rights and needs of city dwellers. In the end, they will try to answer one of the basic questions of North American history: Do the land and its natural inhabitants have certain rights that outweigh the demands of urban, industrial society?
Canadian and New York officials will weigh Bourassa's assertion that James Bay represents "the means of liberating Quebec's people," economically and politically, against the observation of the Cree chief, Robbie Dick, that if the Great Whale project comes about, "we'll lose part of our lives, because the land is our life."
The rivers and lakes of northern Quebec can be harnessed to suit the demands of humans and to relieve ecological strains elsewhere. Or the taiga, the largest stretch of wilderness left in eastern North America, can simply be left alone. But in James Bay, you cannot have it both ways.
