SECTION: Section 3; Page 5; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1744 words

HEADLINE: No Guts, No Glory: Short-Selling in a Bull Market

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
Steven Kibbey of La Jolla, Calif., could be speaking for any number of bearish investors on Wall Street when he described what it has been like in recent weeks to watch the stock market flirt with new highs.
As a person who helps run Centurion Capital's $15 million fund devoted to short-selling stocks and thus an expert at pinpointing overvalued stocks that might be ripe for a corrective decline in price, he watched help lessly as his fund dropped 24 percent last year, versus a 42 percent rise the year before. Many sure-fire bets "went from being overvalued to wildly overvalued to downright silly," he said. "And then they doubled," he added, lest anyone mistake what kind of year 1991 was. 
 Certainly for short-sellers, 1991 will go down as being longer on pain and shorter on gain than any other year since market watchers began keeping track of the shorts' performance. The same trends that produced dazzling gains for investors -- a swift end to the Persian Gulf war and lower interest rates -- devastated the short-sellers.
"Nineteen ninety-one was a difficult year," said Harry Strunk, a Palm Beach investment manager who tracks 24 of the leading short-sellers as part of a larger universe of money managers. Losses ranged from 8.2 percent to 57.4 percent after fees were deducted. "It was the first year since 1985, when I started my index, that they've been down," he said.
Short-sellers are a much misunderstood group that actually helps police the stock markets against stocks that are selling for too much, whatever the reason. To play this risky game, the shorts borrow stock from brokers and immediately sell it at the prevailing price. If they're right about the stock's true worth and it does, in fact, decline, they will be able to buy back the same number of shares at a lower price by the time the borrowed shares need to be returned. If they are wrong and the stock price rises, they can lose their shirts, since they will eventually have to return the borrowed shares no matter what the price.
Over the decades, the strategy had always enjoyed a following among a handful of mavericks. Industry lore has it that Joseph P. Kennedy, the patriarch of the Kennedy clan, increased the family's fortune by shorting stocks during the Depression. But short-selling has only gained popularity since 1983, when investors like the flamboyant Feshbach brothers, Kurt, Joseph and Matthew, of Palo Alto, Calif., and James Chanos, a New York short, gave the maligned specialty its cachet with some savvy trades.
But last year's poor returns have started what could be a long shakeout. At least three portfolio managers appear to be pulling out or winding down.
"I'm out of the business because it's just too painful," said a San Francisco-based newcomer who insisted on anonymity. He recently returned the $1 million he had raised from investors. Paul Sonz, another respected San Francisco manager, is not accepting new money for his short-selling fund. And last year, Neil Dolinsky of Minneapolis cut back his short-selling after a change in heart by one of his major backers.
Still others are having to settle with being shadows of their former selves, most notably the Feshbach brothers. They started 1991 with $800 million in capital, which easily made them the industry's kingpins. Between losses, which approached 60 percent, and redemptions by shareholders in their fund, they are now down to $250 million.
"In 1992, with the market as strong as it is today, we need to tread rather carefully," said Joseph Feshbach. "But in the long run, the types of things we have traditionally shorted, companies that misrepresent their prospects, their potential or their true earnings power are still great prospects to make money on and that's what we'll focus on."
The short-sellers who look the best are those whose losses were only in the single digits: Leo Mandrakos of Mandrakos Capital Management of New York and Benjamin E. Kopin of Lynx Partners in Chicago, whom competitors snipe at by pointing out that he started up last February and thus missed a punishing rally at the end of the gulf war.
Just how much financial muscle the shorts have had in the markets in years past is difficult to assess, though it is clear their power has waned considerably in the last year. At the peak about a year ago, there might have been as much as $30 billion of short positions in United States markets, versus $4 trillion of long positions, according to Laszlo Birinyi of Birinyi Associates in New York. Such estimates, however, include all short positions, even those that exist merely to take advantage of price discrepancies in different markets, to bet on takeover fights or to accomplish other objectives that have little to do with making a bearish bet on a particular stock. Of that $30 billion, classic short-sellers, like the Feshbach brothers, probably control less than $2 billion, down from a high of perhaps $3 billion.
This erosion of power is likely to continue, even if the rising markets stabilize, because there are other factors at work that don't augur well for the shorts.
For example, many shorts that correctly bet on companies that went bankrupt, continue to hold the position rather than pay the tax on the gain. But the spate of bankruptcies has fueled speculation in these distressed securities, unexpectedly driving up their prices, catching many short-sellers.
"You have all these poor guys who thought that Continental Airlines, which declared bankruptcy in 1990, could do nothing but go to zero," said Bruce Hauptman, an investment manager in Fairfield, Iowa, who evaluates the performance of short-sellers and other managers who occasionally short stocks. "The stock went from $1 to $5, and they got completely beat up."
At the same time, many shorts are convinced that some large institutional buyers -- Fidelity Investments, Alliance Capital Management and Fred Alger & Company are often mentioned -- have become more brazen about buying stocks that have large short positions in hopes of driving the stock price up and forcing short-sellers to scramble to replace the shares they have borrowed at higher-than-expected prices. "There were always short squeezes in little stocks," said Centurion's Mr. Kibbey. "But this is the first time where it was almost institutionalized."
Shorts point to a public filing on Dec. 30 by an affiliate of Fidelity, the big mutual fund company, as an example of institutional investors squeezing shorts. Though it is nearly impossible to prove, the shorts contend that Fidelity, through its mutual funds, accumulated a large stake in Bolar Pharmaceutical, long a favorite target of the shorts. A spokeswoman for Fidelity said, "We do not engage in short-squeezing. We buy on fundamentals for the long term, and obviously in a strong market like this short-sellers are going to get hurt. It's easy to point the finger at a large mutual fund."
Such comments may signal a shift in the longstanding rhetorical battle between shorts and longs. The shorts were once decried as the bad boys of Wall Street for bad-mouthing battered stocks to drive the price down. Now, it is the shorts who are accusing a posse of big institutions of manipulating the market upward.
"Short-busting has been around for a long time," said Mr. Feshbach. "It was a little more popular in 1991 and apparently more effective. But those kinds of strategies, if they're based on collusive trading, will come to an end and it will be far more painful for the short-buster than for the short-sellers." He and other shorts contend that if buyers holding long positions are artificially driving up the prices of stocks, they may get caught, and suffer large losses when the markets settle down and stocks return to more realistic prices.
Such pressures, imagined or real, are causing even prominent short-sellers, a group that always operated quietly on Wall Street's fringes, to go underground in recent weeks. "My New Year's resolution is not to talk to the press between the months of January and December," said Mr. Chanos, whose $400 million fund is believed to be the biggest pot of money devoted to short-selling now that the Feshbachs have fallen. Like others approached about being interviewed, he is determined not to divulge what stocks he may be stalking, lest the short-busters gang up on him.
 
 
 
GOING OFFSHORE WITH THE SHORT-SELL
 One bright spot for short-sellers still earning decent returns is foreign stocks, largely because they have yet to attract much of a crowd. "I don't think anybody had a good year, unless they were shorting outside the United States," said Budge Collins, an investment manager in Newport Beach, Calif., who advises companies about alternative investment strategies, including short-selling.
Japan, Canada and Britain, and, to a lesser extent, Austria, Germany and Australia, have all opened up their markets a crack to short-sellers. The big concession for them was allowing brokers to lend stock in their inventories to short-sellers.
These countries are generally less interested in helping shorts get a toehold than they are in encouraging the use of futures and options. Of course, options trading cannot take place in any meaningful volume if investors cannot hedge their positions by selling short.
One New York short who has pursued that tack profitably is Michael Katz, whose $21 million short-selling fund was down 26 percent last year, versus a 70 percent climb the year before.
"One position where everything worked the way it was supposed to work was Central Capital," Mr. Katz said. Listed on the Toronto exchange, the heavily indebted company owns two subsidiaries that met Mr. Katz's test of "advancing internal rot."
One is a trust company, much like an American-style savings and loan, that lends money out against real estate. The other is a mortgage insurer that is on the hook if large waves of homeowners default on their mortgages.
Mr. Katz shorted the preferred stock at $20 a share and was eventually able to replace the shares he borrowed at 60 to 70 cents apiece.
Going abroad, of course, is not for everyone.
"To do that, you need a large staff, you need to be able to hedge currency risk and you need to understand accounting rules that may be different than U.S. accounting rules," said Benjamin E. Kopin of Lynx Partners in Chicago. "I have a hard enough time keeping track of what's going on here."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 19, 1992, Sunday

HEADLINE: Booking With a Computer

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS; PETER H. LEWIS writes The Executive Computer column
in the Sunday Business section of The Times.

 BODY:
THESE days, a journey of a thousand miles can begin with a single tap of the computer keyboard.
 The best way to get somewhere, some travelers assert, is through the personal computer. Using a computer and a modem, which allows two computers to exchange data over telephone lines, travelers can scan flight schedules and fares, check the weather at the destination, research restaurant reviews, uncover unadvertised bargains and in general tap into the knowledge of most of the world's travel providers and many veteran travelers. 
That's a lot of traveling without leaving home, and it is a clear trend in the business and leisure travel industry. The rise of personal computers and lightweight portable computers, as well as the growing sophistication of automated telephone services, have allowed tens of thousands of individual travelers to gain access to the same information used by professional travel agents.
 According to Steven Sieck, vice president for electronic services for the Link Resources Corporation, a market-research company in New York City, more than six million American households have modem-equipped computers capable of tapping into the various information and electronic mail services. Millions of business computers have modems, too.
 "Virtually every electronic mail service and on-line service has access to airline guides, typically O.A.G. or Eaasy Sabre," said Bill Howard, author of the "PC Magazine Guide to Notebook and Laptop Computers" (Ziff-Davis Press, Berkeley, Calif.). O.A.G. is the Official Airlines Guides Electronic Edition and Eaasy Sabre is the electronic information service owned by the parent of American Airlines. Another popular electronic airline guide is Worldspan Travelshopper, jointly operated by T.W.A., Northwest and Delta airlines.
 O.A.G., Eaasy Sabre and Travelshopper are, in essence, data bases that contain scheduling and fare information on tens of thousands of flights daily. Many business customers subscribe directly to O.A.G. or the other services. Others gain access to the services through such consumer information services as Compuserve, which says it has 903,000 subscribers; the Prodigy Services Company, which reports a million members; Dialog Information Systems Inc.; Delphi; Dow Jones News Retrieval, and M.C.I. Mail.
 But while on-line travel services are increasingly accessible, the people who might be expected to use them most -- frequent flyers in the computer industry -- say it is still faster, easier and cheaper to call a travel agent or the travel provider directly.
 "Yes, you can use a computer, and it's almost as good as the way you've done it for the past 20 years, and that's stupid," said Jim Seymour, a computer consultant who lives in Austin, Tex. "I use the telephone" and a pocket diary, Mr. Seymour said.
 Mr. Howard agreed, and said even skilled computer users find the travel services daunting to navigate.
 But "even the best travel agent makes mistakes," Mr. Howard said. "Having a laptop is the great equalizer because you can check airline schedules at the last minute, even when your travel agent's office is closed. But once you've done that, it's still important to pick up the phone and check person to person."
 Mr. Howard recounted a recent trip to Ithaca, N.Y., from New York City. His travel agent told him that he could choose a return flight at 6 A.M. or noon. "I took the 6 and had to get up at 4:30," he recalled. "It turns out there was a 9 A.M. flight that would have been perfect. Had I checked it through my computer I would have gotten the right flight."
Worldwide air fares are updated daily, and schedules are updated weekly, which makes the electronic versions much more accurate than the printed schedule booklets available at airports or by mail. For 17 major airports, including the three major ones in the New York City area, one can even check to see if a flight is on time and which gate and baggage carousel it will use. The information is as current as on air terminal monitors.
 On-line reservation services like O.A.G. and Eaasy Sabre "maximize the benefit of each travel dollar spent," said G. C. Bellaire of Dallas, who commutes weekly to a job in Wichita, Kan. "I can't say how much Eaasy Sabre has saved me over the years, but it is a pretty significant sum."
 Some leisure travelers, however, take an opposite view. "The only negative is that it's too darn expensive," said Lan Sluder of Asheville, N.C., responding to a reporter's electronic query in the Travel Forum on Compuserve.
 Subscribers in major cities can tap into Compuserve or the other services by dialing a local telephone number, so there is no long distance toll, but Compuserve charges $12.80 an hour for connection time. In addition, O.A.G. assesses a surcharge of 17 cents to 47 cents a minute for using its service, depending on the time of day. (There is no additional fee for using Travelshopper or Eaasy Sabre.)
 So, while using a computer to track down bargain fares can pay off for frequent flyers, the cost of using the computer and browsing through the services can mount quickly.
 A recent expedition into the O.A.G., Travelshopper and Eaasy Sabre travel systems via M.C.I. Mail and Compuserve revealed that it is difficult to do anything useful in a few minutes, and easy to spend hours browsing through data bases, all while the meter is ticking. O.A.G. seems to offer the most information for those willing to learn its complex system, while Travelshopper is the easiest but most limited system. Eaasy Sabre seemed more like O.A.G. than Travelshopper. Some travelers and travel agents have complained that Eaasy Sabre displays American Airlines' flights more prominently than competitors', but I saw no evidence of this.
 A typical session starts by loading the communications software that allows two computers to "talk" to one another. Using typed commands, I connect my P.C. to a Compuserve mainframe in Columbus, Ohio. The Compuserve "host" computer asks for an identification number and password, which are issued when one subscribes to the service. Once my identity is confirmed, the screen fills with a list of possible services.
 GOING to the Travel section yields a new menu, offering such choices as Airline Information and Reservations, Hotel Information, Rental Car Information, U.S. Domestic, International Information, Potpourri, Forums and an Electronic Mall where one can even buy luggage and other travel accouterments.
 I choose the Airline Information and Reservations branch, which triggers a new menu that includes O.A.G., Eaasy Sabre and Travelshopper. I choose O.A.G., and yet another menu appears.
 The O.A.G. choices include Airport Arrival-Departure and Gate Information, Accuweather Forecasts, Lodging and Dining, Worldwide Travel Facts, Travel Industry News, Frequent Traveler Programs, Leisure & Discount Travel, Cruises, and so on.
 Then I tap into flight information and the fun begins. The goal is to book a vacation for two to Hawaii. The computer asks the departure city name or three-letter airport code, and I type AUS, for Austin, Tex. It then asks my destination and, since I don't know the three-letter airport code for Maui, I simply type Maui. The computer helpfully tells me that I want to go to OGG. It asks the date I want to begin travel (01JUN) and what time of day I want to fly(600A? No thanks. How about 800A?).
 The screen fills with what at first appears to be gibberish, but which on closer inspection is a string of characters that provide details on each possible choice: departure time, departure city code, arrival time, arrival city code, airline, flight number, type of plane, meal service, number of stops (0 for nonstop), on-time rating, plus all the same information for the connecting flight, if any. There's also a note of the total travel time.
 None looks good. I press "+" for more choices, and suddenly there it is: a 7:35 A.M. flight on American to Dallas, a change of planes, and a one-stop direct flight to OGG. Total travel time: a few minutes over 10 hours.
 It takes several more minutes to find a return flight, going through the same drill.
 Now, how much will it cost? Using the "fare" command, I am presented with an array of prices, starting with the cheapest, $698 round trip, and ascending to more than $2,500 for regular coach and a breathtaking first-class fare so high I've forgotten it. I choose the $698, and ask to see the restrictions.
 Oops, that fare is not available; it must be sold out. So, I ask the computer to show me the lowest available fare. After a few seconds, it finds a $758 round-trip fare per person and notifies me that I have saved $2,568 over regular coach on the two tickets.
 Ticketing is handled in different ways, depending on the service. Travelshopper will make reservations, but tickets must be purchased from a travel agent or from the airline. Eaasy Sabre keeps a traveler's profile, including credit card information, and will send the tickets by mail or, using its optional and more expensive Quiktix feature, by courier or overnight delivery. O.A.G. tickets can be sent by mail or routed through a travel agent; a list of cooperating agents is shown, sorted by ZIP Code.
 My daytime search of 30 to 40 minutes on O.A.G. was slogging along at a rate of more than $40 an hour ($12.80 for Compuserve and $28 for O.A.G.), but even in the wee hours, when O.A.G. charges $10 an hour, it would have been $22.80. (Users of especially fast modems are charged even more on Compuserve. Prodigy, which charges a fixed annual fee of about $120, is more economical.)
 I prowled around for another half hour investigating hotels, rental car rates and other information. And then I called my travel agent. With the same information I had given the computer, she called back in four minutes with a cheaper flight that, using a combination of commercial flights and tour packages, included a three-day car rental. Using a personal computer to book tickets is "very handy when a person has a good grasp of airlines, rules and fare structures," the travel agent, Jane Levan of West Lake, Tex., said. "But sometimes a little knowledge can be a dangerous thing."
 But there is another side to traveling electronically, one that is difficult to assess in terms of dollars and cents. The travel forums allow travelers to exchange subjective data, as well as facts.
 Indeed, for about 25,000 keyboard travelers in the last year, including many members who participate from overseas, the Compuserve travel forum has become a destination in itself.
 "The typical user loves to travel and loves to talk about traveling," said Jerry Schneiderman of New York, the Travel Forum administrator on Compuserve.
 MR. SCHNEIDERMAN rattled off some recent topics. "I'm going to North Korea and want to know if there are any good beaches," he said. "I'm going to Hanoi and want to know if they accept Visa cards. I heard there's a trip you can take on a Soviet nuclear-powered icebreaker."
 "Those are some of the more adventurous ones," Mr. Schneiderman conceded. "You'll see any conceivable question about travel or customs. And the answers are unbiased, based on bona fide experiences."
 Even specialized computer data bases have travel services, for specialized interests.
 Marcus L. Endicott of Saint Simons Island, Ga., said that he regularly taps into a worldwide electronic network operated by the Institute for Global Communication (I.G.C.). The I.G.C. includes forums for "green" or environmentally-oriented travel, and a Servas forum, for those who want to volunteer their skills in developing countries.
 And, of course, it helps to be able to tap into the computer system while traveling, regardless of mode of transport.
 "During the last six months of 1990 I bicycled solo from Yugoslavia to Estonia, through all of the Eastern European countries except Albania," Mr. Endicott said. "I took a solar-powered, fax-compatible laptop computer, which I used successfully to telecommunicate with the I.G.C. from each country."

 
SAMPLING OF ON-LINE SERVICES
 All on-line travel services require a personal computer, a modem, communications software and a subscription or membership. There are many services, and most offer access to travel planning data bases. The two most popular on-line services are Compuserve and Prodigy.
 Compuserve, of Columbus, Ohio, can be reached at (800) 848-8199. Membership kits, which include a $25 connect-time credit, have a list price of $49.95 but are frequently discounted or given away with modem purchases. Connect time is $12.80 an hour at modem speeds of 1,200 and 2,400 baud, and $22.80 an hour at 9,600 baud.
 Prodigy Services Company, of White Plains, can be reached at (800) 776-3449. Subscriptions are $12.95 monthly, with no connect-time charges.
 The Institute for Global Communication (I.G.C.), of San Francisco, is at (415) 442-0220. The first-month fee is $15, and $10 a month thereafter (includes one free hour of connect time). Additional connect time is $5 an hour on nights and weekends, or $10 an hour weekdays.

HEADLINE: An Ethnic Road to Riches: The Immigrant Job Specialty

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH

 BODY:
When Parmjit Singh left his job as a mechanic on a Greek ship in 1981, he settled in New York City, instead of returning to the family farm in India. After working three years as a busboy and cook in a Greek restaurant, Mr. Singh met a fellow Punjabi who owned a gas station in the city.
 "He taught me how to run a station," the 32-year-old Indian recalled. "It's very hard work but it's easy to run -- to order gas, to clean, to keep the books." 
By 1990, Mr. Singh, with an Indian partner, owned 13 gas stations in the New York area. He has competitors, however -- chiefly, other Punjabi Sikhs who began buying and working in gas stations in the city at the same time he did, some of whom now own as many as 40.
 
Growing Economic Force
 Indian ownership of gas stations reflects the enormous ethnic transformation of the city during the last decade. With one million newcomers, the latest wave of immigration is the second largest in New York City history. Just a decade ago, gas station ownership usually mirrored the ethnic makeup of the surrounding neighborhood. But now, about 40 percent of the city's stations are run or owned by South Asians, estimated Linda Sachs, a spokeswoman for the the city's Department of Consumer Affairs.
 This turnover in gas station ownership is one of the many images of a changing New York. While the new immigrants come from a vast spectrum of countries, with a heavy emphasis on Asian, South American and Caribbean nations, and work in a variety of jobs, they have also developed their own specialized niches, virtually monopolizing certain businesses or professions and slowly changing the commercial, political and cultural profile of the city.
 The forces that draw immigrant groups to certain occupations and businesses -- Indians to gas stations, Koreans and Dominicans to grocery stores and Afghans to fried chicken places -- are complex and varied. Their occupational choices are based on factors like skills and values learned in the old country, the paths followed by fellow immigrants who preceded them, or merely a lack of more attractive economic options.
 Sociologists agree that there is no universal pattern to these ethnic niches and that often labor specialization is random and hinges on availability of positions in certain localities. Indians, for example, may be preeminent in gas stations in New York, but in Los Angeles those business are dominated by a Korean quasi-monopoly. But once a niche is found, it creates a snowball effect, gathering in labor from that ethnic group and expanding exponentially.
 The common thread linking all immigrant work niches is the insider's edge on the profession. "Recruiting through the ethnic network is the most efficient way the employer gets labor," explained Roger Waldinger, a sociologist at UCLA who has studied and written extensively on Koreans and Dominicans in New York City. Ethnic labor, in particular family labor, is cheap and easily exploited and there is no linguistic, cultural or discriminatory barrier.
 Many immigrants are self-employed entrepreneurs. More than 85 percent of the 1,600 green grocer stores in the metropolitan area are owned and run by Koreans, sociologists say. The more than 100,000 Koreans who have come to New York also own novelty shops, beauty salons, liquor stores and dry cleaning. Indians and Pakistanis -- close to 95,000 of whom reside in the city -- have a virtual monopoly on newsstands. Since the mid-1980's, they have been buying into gas stations, and their growing presence in the jewelry trade has made them the second largest ethnic group -- after Hasidic Jews -- in the Diamond District.
 Guyanese -- the fourth largest immigrant group -- can be found throughout the city's pharmacies and machinery repair shops. They also stand out, along with the Jamaicans and Irish, in the child-care business. Even the smallest of immigrant groups, like the Afghans and the Senegalese, have carved out their own niches. There are fewer than 4,000 Afghans in the city -- almost all war refugees -- yet they own more than 200 fast-food chicken restaurants, Afghan businessmen say, in particular a non-franchised chain of more than 40 called Kennedy's Fried Chicken. The Senegalese, many of them already traders by profession, came to the United States via Europe and have prospered hawking a variety of wares on street corners throughout the city.
 
Korean Success: Toil and Innovation
 One of the the most visible successes has been the Koreans. An estimated 100,000 Koreans have come to the metropolitan area since the 1970's and 65 percent of Korean families own at least one business, said Pyong Gap Min, a professor of sociology at Queens College, who is a specialist on Koreans in the United States. "No other group is as highly self-employed," Professor Min said.
 Few Korean green grocers owned such stores in their homeland. But they arrived in the United States at a propitious time, when many Greeks, Italians and Jews were leaving the grocery business. Most were highly educated professionals with limited English skills and no business experience. But they had money to invest. The grocery stores were attractive because, although they required long, hard hours, they could be run with only basic shards of English. In the United States, they revamped and spruced up the stores, filling the demand for items beyond the basics of the old grocery store. New immigrants learned the business from fellow Koreans before they invested in their own stores.
 Professor Min said that the first Korean to open a green grocery in Manhattan, To Sup Kwak, invested about $5,000 to start his business in 1970. Although Koreans in New York City were already firmly entrenched in the trade of Korean products, green grocers were their first businesses not tied to the products of their homeland, Professor Min said.
 The snowballing success of Korean grocers is due in part to an extensive and well-organized support system. New arrivals can rely on a 500-page Korean business directory, as well as dozens of business groups, including the Korean Green Grocer Association. When black residents of Flatbush, Brooklyn, organized a boycott of two Korean grocers in 1990, for instance, fellow Korean grocers put up money to help the stores remain in business. In the last several years, as a visible testimony to the phenomenon of ethnic succession, Koreans have begun hiring Central Americans and Mexicans to perform the menial tasks in their stores.
 Anderson Han, 41, has owned his green grocery on the corner of Union Street and 41st Avenue in Flushing for three-and-a-half years. His story reflects the successes of many Korean immigrants.
 Most of Mr. Han's 18 years in the United States have been spent working six-day weeks in the grocery business. In 1973, after his father bought a fruit store in Manhattan for $30,000, Mr. Han dropped out of college to help the family.
 "Before he died, my father wanted each of my six brothers and sisters to own a grocery store," Mr. Han said. The dream was realized, with each sibling owning a green grocery.
 In 1988, Mr. Han bought his store for about $200,000 from a Greek-American. His first year, Mr. Han and his wife worked 16 hours a day, seven days a week. In a good month, they make a net profit of about $4,000. He has been held up and robbed. But like many first-generation Koreans who have succeeded in their business, Mr. Han says he will not allow either of his two children to work in the store and wants them to become doctors or lawyers. Already he is employing two Central Americans because they are cheaper to hire than Korean laborers.
 
Indian Immigrants: A Society Recreated
 Indian immigrants offer a stark contrast to the Korean experience. Although most Indians who came to the United States in the 1960's and 1970's were professionals who spoke English, the arrivals since then are not as well-educated. Unlike many Korean immigrants, who came from the cities, many Indian immigrants come from small towns or the countryside. As Indian families have reunited in the United States, many have recreated the extensive social and kin networks of their homeland, said Madhulika Khandelwal, a sociologist in the Asian American Center at Queens College.
 For instance, various communities in India are devoted to certain occupations, a characteristic reflected in the professions Indians pursue in the United States. One example is the Indians working in the Diamond District in Manhattan, many of whom are Gujerati Jains, reknowed as traders and merchants throughout India. Most of the Indians involved in the motel business, which is completely built around the extended family network, carry the last name Patel, a sub-caste from the province of Gujerat that is known for its entrepreneurial expertise.
 And most Indians in the gas station business are Punjabi Sikhs.
 In India, Sikhs are known as farmers but also as transporters and mechanics. The largest fleet of trucks in India is owned by Sikhs who control more than 80 percent of the bus service throughout the country, said Baldev Singh, a former lawyer who now owns several gas stations in Long Island as well as the fifth largest truck stop in the United States in Jessup, Md.
 "It is not sheer coincidence that they are taking up these jobs," Mrs. Khandelwal explained. "Sikhs are very enterprising and they don't mind going into areas where no one else will work."
 At Parmjit Singh's Mobil station at 125th Street between Broadway and the Hudson River, the workers -- all Sikhs -- seem almost numbed by the long hours and grueling work. They earn $300 a week and save half of it. "All I know is this gas station and the Punjab," said Amrit Singh, a clock merchant who has been in New York for only five months and spends his only day off washing clothes, buying groceries and sleeping.
 Parmjit Singh's gas stations are held up an average of two times a month. Two Indian employees have been shot and killed during stickups, Mr. Singh said. But the station still makes a net profit of about $4,000 a month. "They see me and they want to be like me," Parmjit Singh said of his workers.
 
Afghan Refugees: Evading Barriers
 In the vast maze of cultures, Afghans offer yet another insight into the ethnic division of labor. One of the smallest and most recent groups of immigrants in the city, they are refugees from the fierce decade-long war in Afghanistan. Many of them lack higher education, trade skills, and have little knowledge of English. They are generally poor when they arrive. And unlike the Koreans and the Indians, their struggle for survival has had an impact on only a very specialized part of the city's economy.
 In the last decade, with more than 200 stores, the Afghans have become specialists in the fast-food chicken business. To circumvent language and discrimination barriers, even their carpenters and chicken suppliers they use are Afghans. Their niche in the business originated in 1979, when Abdul Karim Halemi, a student from Kandahar in Southern Afghanistan, got his first job was in the kitchen at Kansas Fried Chicken. A year later, he opened the first Kennedy's Fried Chicken. Now there are 40 unfranchised restaurants with that name -- all owned by Afghans, Mr. Halemi said.
 Mr. Halemi said he and other established Afghan immigrants in New York lead the new arrivals by the hand through the chicken fast-food business. The tough part is teaching them the intricacies of running a business in New York City. "It's like a formula," Mr. Halemi said. "We tell them how to go to the building department, how to save money by cutting and installing their own bulletproof glass."
 "You have to have some connection with somebody to succeed," said Mr. Halemi, who still works at his restaurant on Rockaway Boulevard in Queens behind the protection of bulletproof glass. "We all know each other. When the new ones come to the store, they sit. They watch. They learn and then they work."

As Mr. Singh's lawyer explained in a recent letter, it is $3,000 a month total, not $4,000 at one station. Because of an editing error, a picture caption with the article misstated the number of gas stations Mr. Singh now owns. It is two.

HEADLINE: ...and a New Home for a Pioneering Theater

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK

 BODY:
IT'S a success story that could be attributed to impeccable timing, terrific luck and slick marketing. But it took more than that to move the nonprofit Crossroads Theater Company from its modest beginnings 13 years ago on the second floor of a rickety factory in a depressed area to a new $4 million building in a revitalized district of New Brunswick.
It took the persistence, vision and understated power of Ricardo Khan, who has been instrumental in gaining for Crossroads the artistic credibility and high visibility that affirm its place in the forefront of black theater in America. All this at a time when the fortunes of the arts in general and professional black theater in particular are withering. 
 At an early rehearsal of "Black Orpheus," which closed last Sunday, Mr. Khan, the company's co-founder, producer and artistic director, worked the room. To a group of actors he said, "Let's talk it out so we can understand what's really going on."
 
Myth Set in Carnival Time
 He joined the musicians and beat on the congas. "Man, you got it," he said to the percussionist on the steel drums. In a corner, he huddled with Jesse Moore, who was playing Orpheus in a contemporary adaptation of the myth set in Trinidad at carnival time.
"Carnival brings the blood up closer to the skin, and you're closer to your feelings than you ever are," Mr. Khan said. "Things that used to be right are not so right. Something's a little dangerous -- but now it looks too comfortable."
The rehearsal ended, as they all do, with the company members' gathering in a circle. "We end every day by saying, 'Thank you for that,' " Mr. Khan said -- just as every performance he directs begins with a backstage prayer "to bring everybody together before you go out there."
About Mr. Khan's directing style, Mr. Moore said: "He takes the moment and carves away at it -- and he trusts you. He's very spiritual. And I can ask his advice. He knows that you get more flies with honey than with vinegar."
 
Ending in 'Place of Beauty'
 Suddenly reacting to being called a director, Mr. Khan said: "Only when people are lost. Everybody else, I guide. I believe the vision I have for this piece is spiritually driven. Although the outcome of the myth involves the loss of life and of love, it will end in a place of hope, a place of beauty."
Setting the piece in Trinidad was Mr. Khan's idea. "That's where my ancestors came to, from India as indentured servants," he said. "This is kind of like my personal way of claiming our new space for them."
Ricardo Mohamed Khan, the oldest of five children of Dr. Mustapha Mohamed Khan and Jacqueline Driver Khan, turned 40 years old on Nov. 4. He was born in Washington and raised in Camden and in Cherry Hill, where his parents still live.
His father, now a semiretired physician, left Trinidad to attend Howard University. "He was the baby of a family of 10 and the only one they saved up money for, because he had the best chance for success," Mr. Khan said.
While Mr. Khan's fervor can come off as theological as much as theatrical, he acknowledges that it is nondenominational.
"I was baptized Catholic and grew up Episcopalian," he said. "In Trinidad, where my grandparents lived -- we went back every summer until I went to college -- we were Muslim. Then, at Rutgers, I started to go to Baptist churches. By the time I hit grad school, mother found a Pentecostal church in the middle of Glassboro, in a little place that looked like a lodge, so we were Pentecostal for a while -- and after that, we ended up being everything."
By the time Mr. Khan was in graduate school, he was married to Dana Hollowell, another acting student, who came from Detroit. The marriage lasted 10 years.
"My ex-wife is a Catholic -- and I don't go to church that much, but I'll go into any one, anywhere -- mosques, synagogues," Mr. Khan said. "I don't worship any one religion because I think they're all one; it's not the building you go into -- it's coming into a place where there's a community, where people, like you, believe in the spirit."
He went on: "I don't leave my house in the morning until I've prayed and meditated. Once I've hooked into that, I say, 'Now I can go and get the elevator.' Otherwise, it's like going into a battle without armor. You don't do that.
"Every day, it's a battle. Everything worth fighting for is difficult, because there's a different force that does not want you to get it, so you need armor, and for me, the armor is myself."
For Mr. Khan, that armor came in handy after the 1989 Crossroads production of "Sheila's Day," which involved the collaboration of five South African women, three of whom were aliens. A hoped-for production at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater in Manhattan led to a dispute with Actors' Equity.
"We had to replace the nonresident aliens with American citizens or pay Broadway scale to a whole company of 12, and Joe Papp couldn't afford that," Mr. Khan said. "So Equity killed it. Having the committee that is called alien tell you to find five Africans who are Americanized is an insult. We have a union that is scared of the future. Its inability to deal with our global experience is a tragedy -- and that came up again with 'Orpheus.'
"I wanted a brother from Trinidad who was disapproved by Equity. Luckily, Jesse happened to be in the cast already. During the days of rehearsing and not having an Orpheus and fighting Equity, he was kind enough to read the part. The union should open the world up. I want to wage war on Equity. If the theater is not reflective of who we are, it is going to die."
The opening of a state-of-the-art showplace is a startling anomaly, given cutbacks in arts spending and the attrition of professional black theater companies. But it is the emergence of Crossroads as a high-profile nurturing center for new works and, by all accounts, the nation's foremost black theater company, with a budget this season of $2.8 million, that lends artistic credibility to a success story that looks like a variation of being in the right place at the right time.
"Money was created to make this building happen when the economy was high," Mr. Khan said, alluding to a 1981 city-appointed arts commission that led to a proposed New Brunswick Cultural Center, of which a new Crossroads Theater was to be a part.
 
Impressive Track Record
 In spite of a disappointing 1990-91 season, Crossroads has an impressive track record. Its reputation spread to Manhattan theatergoers by means of such moves from New Brunswick to Off Broadway as "The Colored Museum" -- the company's breakthrough play in 1986 -- "Spunk," "Further Mo'," "Ground People," which was produced here under the title "The Rabbit Foot," and "Black Eagles."
For all that, Mr. Khan has not been beguiled by commercialism, says Peter Zeisler, the executive director of the Theater Communications Group, the national organization of nonprofit theaters.
"Ricardo has come into his own as an artistic director," Mr. Zeisler said, "because he is centered in what the theater is trying to do: make a home for developing black artists -- and avoiding the traps of the transfer syndrome. It would have been so easy to change that after the success of 'Colored Museum,' but the Crossroads work still happens organically."
Practically speaking, Mr. Khan and Crossroads have been favored by one publicity triumph after another. After a widely praised televised version of the Crossroads production of George C. Wolfe's first play, "The Colored Museum," in 1990, a White House reception was held in February 1991 for the cast of "Black Eagles," which Mr. Khan directed.
It was prompted by President Bush's enthusiasm for Leslie Lee's play about the Tuskegee Airmen, unsung heroes of World War II and the Army's first black pilots. The reception preceded the play's move to the Manhattan Theater Club.
 
Aided by Cosby Shows
 And a week of festivities last October, proclaimed Crossroads Theater Week by Gov. Jim Florio and Mayor James Cahill of New Brunswick, was capped by five donated -- and unsolicited -- performances by Bill Cosby. The first marked the opening of the 264-seat Crossroads Theater, and the next four shows took place at the nearby 1,867-seat State Theater. Mr. Khansaid the net proceeds of the Cosby benefit and its attendant receptions were $240,697.
"It's not like Crossroads is rich or anything," Mr. Khan said. "We had nothing to raise for the building, but when we moved, we needed a cushion of money -- and to expand our base of support.
"You don't raise money for programs you want to do, but for programs you have already committed to. And people give you money because they buy into a passion, a belief, a faith. That's how I approach funding. That it's meant to be."
"And subscribers -- we had 2,000 last year and our goal is 4,000 for this year -- provide you with unconditional love," he added. "But if you think you have to cater to them, you end up being an institution that just serves them what they want, and that's not enough. You have to develop a relationship that leads them to a new place. We started by bringing people into the theater who had never been to a theater before. They stayed -- and now we've all gone further."
 
Began With Federal Funds
 The company's co-founders, Mr. Khan and L. Kenneth Richardson, then known as Lee Richardson, started Crossroads as a federally financed theater project in 1978. Both had received undergraduate and graduate degrees in acting and directing from the Mason Gross School of the Arts at Rutgers University. They began Crossroads with a $50,000 grant under the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act, and with the George Street Playhouse, now next door, as its sponsor.
Mr. Khan recalled that the project was intended to hire "hard core unemployed" and that black actors filled the designation.
"We wanted jobs, and what was out there?" he said. "Roles for pimps, drug dealers, addicts and black men who beat their wives, not artistically challenging or spiritually uplifting parts that were about helping your people. You either gave in or you changed it."
By the time Mr. Richardson left in 1988, Crossroads was on the threshold of international recognition, with "The Colored Museum," staged by Mr. Richardson, having had acclaimed runs at the Public Theater, the Royal Court in London and the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles. Mr. Wolfe, the playwright, was later to be named one of the resident directors in charge of the festival by its producer, Mr. Papp.
By then, Crossroads was going forth with new-play development instead of falling back on such staples of black theater as "The First Breeze of Summer" (its first produced play), high-voltage revues ("Bubbling Brown Sugar") and novelties for the purpose of nontraditional casting ("American Buffalo" and "Agnes of God").
Although the reasons for Mr. Richardson's departure remain unaccounted for and Mr. Khan said that relations between the two men were "strained," Mr. Khan has dedicated a seat in the new theater to Mr. Richardson's 6-year-old son, Garrett. The boy had taken part in a parade during the opening-week celebration.
"There's no reason for a child not to know what his father helped to create," Mr. Khan said.
 
'A Moment of Hope'
 Similarly, the importance of children as the stronghold of the future framed Mr. Khan's staging of "Black Orpheus." He said, "The first rhythm in the show comes from a child, and in the very last moments, the kids pick up the guitar and the sun rises on them. That is a moment of hope."
Oyamo, who wrote "Black Orpheus," commented on the significance of Crossroads in the contemporary black theater movement. "Black theater is in trouble," he said. "More risky black plays are being done by white theaters. You can't stick to plays about black people on the porch eating biscuits. Crossroads still is in a state of evolution -- and Rick is trying to create a vehicle for all kinds of approaches to a black esthetic. That makes Crossroads the most legitimate black theater in the United States."
Larry Leon Hamlin, artistic director and founder of the National Black Theater Festival, an event held every two years in North Carolina, cited Crossroads for being "an excellent role model for black theaters in America" and for its "acute financial management." Mr. Hamlin, who is also the head of the North Carolina Black Repertory Company, said of Mr. Khan, "The man is a visionary."
Mr. Khan, speaking about his vision of Crossroads as a world theater, which came to him when he heard Paul Simon's "Graceland" concert, declared: "I heard Ladysmith Black Mambazo and the Soweto Rhythm Section. Those rhythms sounded so much like what I knew from Trinidad, and that started me trying to get in touch with people in South Africa, which led to productions like 'Bongi's Journey' and 'Sheila's Day.'
 
'Celebrate Who You Are'
 "We are all political beings,and there is nothing you can do about that. This is not something that I want to feel, but there's a tinge of that in any black person who walks into a white world. And within that racial reality, if you can create and celebrate who you are and your color, your heritage, your ancestors, your work, your rhythms, then it becomes a movement that is international, that causes change, and that to me is what Crossroads is, not just a black theater. It denounces the forces that try to homogenize you -- and that's a revolution, a human revolution.
"Ultimately, we're attempting to turn the world a different way and say, 'This is good' -- and in doing that, we end up redefining black theater.
"Too many black theaters have died because they never created a leadership around the organization. I'm not interested in an ego trip. I tell my staff: 'I'm not into creating followers. I'm into empowering leaders, and if you're interested in becoming a leader, let's talk.' This is about longevity."

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
By the Way, Whose Money Is It?

BYLINE: By LEAH D. FRANK

 BODY:
ONE reason our economy is in its present condition is provided in Jerry Sterner's play "Other People's Money," at the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale.
The play, which won awards Off Broadway and became a recent movie, is a wry examination of the back-room corporate politics leading up to the 73d shareholders' meeting of the New England Wire and Cable Company. In a sense, it provides the flesh-and-blood excitement behind the profit-and-loss columns of a standard annual report. 
 The players in what develops into a bitter takeover game include William Coles, president of the company and a clever and careful manager; Andrew Jorgenson, chief executive, who inherited the company from his father, and Bea Sullivan, Mr. Jorgenson's professional assistant and longtime friend.
The outsiders are Kate Sullivan, Bea's daughter, who has grown up to become a powerful corporate lawyer, and Lawrence Garfinkle, a ruthless man known in Wall Street circles as Larry the Liquidator.
As in any annual report, what is important in the long run is the bottom line, and Mr. Sterner's explanation of the balance sheet involves the sterling principle of looking out for one's self, a philosophy that is 180 degrees from the Golden Rule.
Depending on the view of the capitalist system, you will find the ending happy or tragic. In either case, the play, if not this production, will satisfy.
In Frederic De Feis's direction, "Other People's Money" has lost its harsh comic edge. The evening takes on a monotonous rhythm, and whatever laughter or suspense might be in the script is missed. Part of the problem lies in the unfortunate casting.
Michael Fredericks, as Coles, sees his golden parachute descending unopened, and his bottom-line instincts are for self-preservation. Jacqueline Muro is chilling as Sullivan, the sharp lawyer who succumbs to her mother's pleas to save a small company from a corporate raider.
Ms. Muro and Mr. Fredericks give performances that are in no way matched by the three other actors.
A major problem is Jack Mertz's interpretation of Jorgenson. He portrays Jorgenson more as a narrow-minded doddering old man who is approaching senility than as a champion against corporate injustice. Mr. Mertz lacks believability as a hard-nosed but decent New England executive. He delivers his dialogue in a dull monotone, repeating each line by rote. The performance skewers the outcome, because the way of life Mr. Jorgenson is defending never seems real.
The sinister machinations of Larry the Liquidator are not particularly threatening. Anthony Bellucci manages to turn Larry into a charming Wall Street hero. His crudeness, cold-hearted nature and vacuous morality are lost in the folds of Mr. Bellucci's sweetness as a doughnut-eating tycoon. Mr. Mertz turns Mr. Jorgenson into a fool, and Mr. Bellucci creates a purring kitty out of a Wall Street fat cat.
Patricia Wallace does not provide Bea Sullivan with the iron will necessary for the character to be Kate's mother or Mr. Jorgenson's mistress.
I am told that the film has a different ending from the play. Even in this far-less-than-perfect production, "Other People's Money" provides much to think about. It also offers a painless lesson in Wall Street economics.
"Other People's Money" continues at the Second Stage Theater through Feb. 2.

HEADLINE: Following A Rough Year, Bankers See An Upswing

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
IN 1991 a record 20 banks and savings and loan associations failed in Connecticut, and about half the financial institutions still in business are under some type of special regulatory watch.
"I don't think it's ever been this bad in the past," said Barbara S. McGrath, Deputy Commissioner of the State Banking Department. "We've never closed this many banks before. We've never had this many regulatory orders outstanding. I guess the 1980's were too good to be true. It's not clear all the problems have been recognized yet, either." 
 Despite the problems, though, Ms. McGrath and others who work in or follow trends in the industry say that banking might have hit bottom, and that they even saw a few signs that it might be climbing back.
They point to a number of signs: New-home construction statistics for 1991 should end up about the same as they were a year earlier, ending a three-year slump. An increasing number of banks are breaking even or even posting small profits. During the third quarter of 1991 -- and apparently in the last quarter, although the statistics are not all in -- the banks had fewer loan defaults. The stock market rally has caused many investors to look for the place to make their next killing, and bank stocks are attracting attention. Another advantage, the bankers say, is that while the loan rates that bank charge their customers have dropped in the last year -- the prime rate has declined to 6.5 percent from 9.5 percent since last January -- the banks' cost of borrowing has dropped even more precipitously, by half, to 3.5 percent from 7 percent for the Federal Reserve's discount rate. "A lot of people think bankers like high interest rates," said an economist for Connecticut National Bank in Hartford, Nicholas Perna. "But that's not true. What bankers like is a wide margin between what money costs them and what they earn on it."
Predicting that "the worst is behind us," Mr. Perna recalled that at the start of 1991 one of the state's largest banks, the Connecticut Bank and Trust Company, was being taken over by Federal regulators, a war loomed in the Persian Gulf, and most economic indicators were plummeting.
"Put into that perspective, 1992 is starting out on a fairly positive note," Mr. Perna said.
 
Returning to Profitability
 William R. Attridge, president of the Maritime Bank and Trust Company in Essex, the only bank to start up in the state in the last couple of years, said: "We're far enough through the problems now that most banks have taken their biggest hits and set up decent reserves. We've hit bottom and, maybe, are starting back up."
David E. A. Carson, president of People's Bank in Bridgeport, said: "We're all striving to return to a level of profitability that makes banking a good business, and that's going to take a while. But I think things are going to take a turn for the better in 1992."
Others are much more guarded, including Edward J. Deak, a forecaster for the New England Economic Project and chairman of the economics department at Fairfield University.
"I would be surprised if we saw another 20 banks fail this year" in the state, Dr. Deak said. "But there are still several banks, half a dozen maybe, that have serious problems."
The president of the First Federal Bank of Waterbury, James C. Smith, said banks should also be uneasy until they have the answer to the most important question facing the industry now: what is the true value of commercial real estate?
"We were way overbuilt," Mr. Smith said. "And we have an increasing supply going on the market as banks take title through foreclosure and try to dispose of it, as demand is still on the wane. Ultimately, bank losses are going to depend on what they realize from the sales of these properties, so the full extent of these losses might not be felt for another year or two."
The president of Gateway Bank in Norwalk, Reginald DeKoven, agreed that commercial real estate could drag down earnings in 1992, but he saw some reason for optimism.
"The residential market has held up better in Fairfield County than I anticipated," Mr. DeKoven said. "And the other bright spot is the dramatic decrease in the cost of deposits."
Mr. Carson of People's Bank also pointed out that in the waning months of 1991 a lot people paid off or reduced the balances on their credit cards.
"Consumers are learning to be more conservative," he said. "And when the economy turns around, the consumer may have the resources to come into the market, which could make the recovery a little better."
Last year was the worst ever for banking in Connecticut, with 17 banks and 3 savings and loans closed by regulators. They ranged in size from the $7.1 billion Connecticut Bank and Trust to small hometown banks like Harbor National in Branford. Some were newcomers, like Enfield National, which lasted only two years; others had been around many years, like the 167-year-old Merchants Bank in Norwalk.
Hartford and Bridgeport lost three banks each, and the rate of failure statewide seems to have tainted everybody in the business. Bankers at Farmers and Mechanics in Middletown had to gear their advertising to address fears about the safety of their deposits when the similarly named Mechanics and Farmers in Bridgeport failed. At the Savings Bank of Danbury, an officer declined to comment on the effect on its business of the failure of the nearby Danbury Savings and Loan Association.
"There is, throughout the state, a real sense of caution about banks, much more questioning by the customers about how you're doing," said Mr. Carson. "But people are also concerned about when the recession will be over, and most understand the two are linked."
Dr. Deak said one of the biggest problems facing banks in 1992 will be their lack of capital, particularly with regulators pushing for increased levels of capital to cover loans that go bad. "It's not that banks don't want to lend money," he said. "It's that they don't have the money themselves to back the loans."
 
More Efficient Structure
 Ms. McGrath said banks are increasing their capital, through the sale of assets, the sale of part of their business to investors or through private or public stock offerings. As they begin to raise capital, banks will be able to write loans again, which will be one factor in helping the economy pull out of its slump, she said.
At the same time, bankers say, the closing of branches and merger of operations that follows each takeover is resulting in a much more efficient banking structure in the state.
"Yes, you can improve the efficiency of banks by consolidation, but that also decreases competition," Dr. Deak said. "And besides that, it's a very long process. What we need in Connecticut is a much faster process."
Dr. Deak said he advocates mergers with institutions from other parts of the country, like opening the regulatory gates to Bank One of Ohio or Bank of America in California. Banks that come in from elsewhere in New England or New York would bring many of the same problems as Connecticut banks have now, and they would be more apt to treat Connecticut banks as a "deposit-gathering subsidiary," he said.
"My preference is for banks to come in from a long distance, because they're going to have to set up a more autonomous organization here, which means a major commitment to the region," Dr. Deak said.
 
Regulatory Attention
 But he also said that allowing such mergers would require legislation, and this year, with a short session planned, the General Assembly is likely to be so busy with tax and budget matters, it will have no time for banking legislation.
"I don't see them being able to deal sensibly with any of these issues during this session," Dr. Deak said.
Ms. McGrath said the Banking Department was keeping a close eye on all banks, particularly those under special regulatory restrictions. These range from rather informal memorandums of understanding that require, for instance, that banks raise more capital before writing commercial loans, to cease-and-desist orders, which can go as far as requiring that banks charge off problem loans that are still on the books, or that their boards assess the banks' management.
"We are getting more detailed information on a quarterly basis from those banks," Ms. McGrath said. "We want to get a sense of how well they're able to cope with the problems."

HEADLINE: Responding to Academic Achievers as School Budgets Tighten

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG

 BODY:
IN a classroom decorated with children's self-portraits and essays -- along with globes, games and boxes labeled with different mathematical processes -- about a dozen third graders are intently engaged in proofreading logic puzzles before binding them into books. All is conducted under the watchful eye of their teacher, Judi Sternberg.
If it is difficult to determine exactly where these activities fit into a third-grade curriculum, that is because these students are not in an ordinary classroom. They are participating in Highview Elementary School's High and Wide program, one of the Greenburgh Central 7 District's answers to the special needs of academically able students in grades two through six. 
 These children -- who have been identified as intellectually gifted through a screening process that includes teacher recommendations and cognitive testing -- leave their regular homeroom class twice a week to meet with other children of similar abilities. They receive special instruction through activities designed to challenge and stimulate.
 
'Sometimes Children Decelerate'
 "There's a myth that all these children will make it on their own," said Mrs. Sternberg, who has taught in Greenburgh's gifted and talented program for 12 years and now also serves as its district coordinator. Mrs. Sternberg, a board member for the New York State Association for Gifted and Talented Education, views her program as a pull-together resource for these children.
"The fact is that sometimes these children decelerate, starting in second or third grade, and become underachievers or the class clown," she said. "I definitely believe that their needs must be addressed as gifted children. They must be challenged all the time. If you don't use it, you lose it. Society loses in the end."
At a time when the national educational agenda calls for raising academic standards and improving student performance, it would seem that programs for the gifted and the talented would be fully accepted. But those concerned about education for gifted students in the county are finding that many programs are in jeopardy, especially after recent cutbacks in the state education budget.
"There are two trends now that hurt," said Alan Kramer, director of the Westchester Institute for Student Enrichment, part of the institutional services division of the Southern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services. "We're running out of money generally for education. That's reality. In context, special programs to meet the needs of kids who are not problematic is last in line. We are bemoaning that we are losing out to the Japanese in technology. But we take the intelligence of the country and mush them down.
"There is a very deep mistrust of intelligent people, of using resources to make bright kids brighter," Mr. Kramer added. "As a nation, we've never come to terms with exceptional abilities. We don't apply that to sports. But when it comes to intellectual issues, we don't make the same connection. We need to help these kids learn how to harness their abilities."
Although the state requires schools to screen students to determine if they need special education, including services for the gifted, New York is not among the 27 states mandating gifted education. State law requires that schools provide special education for those students needing remedial help or those classified as learning disabled; a school's obligation to meet the needs of academically talented children theoretically ends with the screening process.
"It's appalling that there isn't more for gifted in the county," Mrs. Sternberg said. "We're going into a bumpy period because of financial constraints, and I'm scared."
 
Support for Programs Expressed
 But state education officials proclaim their support for gifted programs. "We're quite interested in seeing that gifted children receive an appropriate education," said Dr. David Irvine, coordinator for Gifted Education in the State Education Department in Albany. "We encourage school districts to take a broad look at giftedness," he said, adding that this encompasses such talents as leadership, kinesthetic ability and artistic skills, among others. "There's a real contradiction in what we're facing nationally and internationally and our willingness to sacrifice the education of gifted children," he said. "Many, many gifted children who don't have special programs drift along as good students, but not at what they would be capable of doing if we gave them the opportunities."
Many educators believe that gifted students would be better served if they were thought to be as needy of special education as children in remedial programs.
"Our philosophy is that these are children who have needs similar to special ed," said Joseph Rodriguez, principal of the Dows Lane school in Irvington. "We're not going to split hairs to try and identify whether a child is gifted or not. Youngsters do have a need to be with their peers."
The county's reputation as an enclave of affluent, well-educated professionals sometimes conspires against delivering appropriate educational services to those children who need them, some educators say.
"Westchester parents confuse smart kids with gifted kids," Mrs. Sternberg said. Some districts, like Scarsdale, don't offer any differentiated programs for gifted and talented youngsters. Some communities are suspicious of special programs for the intellectually gifted, viewing them as elitist frills that can be dropped in economic hard times.
And many districts that do provide some special instruction in the lower grades drop such programs by the time students enter middle school, arguing that honors classes and advanced-placement courses meet the needs of intellectual youngsters.
 
Program Expanded in Ardsley
 Debate within the educational community on how to deliver education for the gifted or, indeed, whether there should be differentiated programming for intellectual high achievers also complicates the issue of gifted education in the county.
In districts like Greenburgh, Ardsley, Dobbs Ferry and Irvington, gifted and talented children leave their homerooms to meet in small groups for special programming once or twice a week. Teachers refer to this practice as a pull-out program.
"Our philosophy is that children who have exceptional abilities need an opportunity to work with others of exceptional abilities," said Laurel Woolf, resource teacher and teacher of the gifted at the Concord Road School in Ardsley, which recently expanded its gifted program to the middle school. "Very bright children need each other. They need to work in areas above and beyond the regular classroom curriculum."
For example, second graders study endangered species, while third graders investigate architecture and fourth graders study communication and pursue independent-study projects.
Then there are districtwide magnet programs, like Yonkers's Pearls -- the acronym stands for Program for Early and Rapid Learners -- which offers a challenging educational program to talented youngsters who are clustered together in a particular school. Instead of simply offering fourth-grade math to third graders, for example, the curriculum is designed to meet the relentless curiosity of its gifted students.
 
Not Faster, but More
 "It's not just accelerating the curriculum but enriching it to give them more," said Lillian Mein, the Pearls program director and magnet supervisor for the Yonkers school system. "We encourage kids to be creative and productive thinkers. They can get facts anywhere."
Some districts also offer students who aren't selected for their school's on-site gifted education the opportunity to participate in a before- or after-school enrichment program sponsored by Boces. Southern Westchester Boces offers an after-school enrichment program in science, math, theater, writing and art for about 230 students in grades three through eight from seven participating school districts. During the spring semester, enrollment increases slightly when second graders are invited to attend.
Boces also gives about 90 high school students the opportunity to take college-level courses in the performing and visual arts at the State University of New York at Purchase, under the auspices of the Foundations Program for Visual Arts.
The Putnam/Northern Westchester Boces also offers high school students the chance to work with professionals in the fields of science or English. Through the SUNY Purchase-Westchester Partnership, 10 high school seniors can take a college-level course at the Purchase campus through a Young Scholars program. As an extracurricular activity, motivated Katonah students at the John Jay Middle and High Schools can participate in Future Problem Solving, a think-tank activity, which has its national headquarters at the University of Michigan.
Then there are educators who believe that students are best served through enrichment activities in the homeroom. "The philosophy of our school district is meeting the needs of children throughout the educational program," said Maryann Doyle, assistant superintendent of curriculum and instruction in Chappaqua, which discontinued its special classes a few years ago. Sel Shimmerlik, the gifted resource teacher, offers problem-solving activities and higher thinking skills exercises to 700 third-to-fifth graders in the district's three elementary schools.
"I feel that children have multiple talents," Mrs. Shimmerlik said. "If you select just a small group based on achievement tests or IQ, you're missing so many students. I can throw out lots of ideas for students and can meet many children's needs.
A similar sentiment prevails in Byram Hills, which offers an enrichment program to its middle school students as well as special classes for its third and fourth graders. "One problem with gifted and talented programs is that they can be exclusive," said Joel Goldsholl, the enrichment teacher in Byram Hills.
But if a seventh-grade group is studying algebra, Mr. Goldsholl can work on developing a unit of more difficult problems for those students who need more stimulation.
 
'Kids Know Where They Stand'
 Supporters of the enrichment model rather than special classes cite other benefits. "When I worked with classroom teachers as an enrichment teacher, I stressed higher-level thinking skills. The teacher could see kids in a different environment and would say, 'I didn't know that child could do that.' "
Whatever their individual philosophies about how to address the need to challenge academically talented children, or any children, many educators agree that the effort must be made.
"The attitude has to be that you take every child and develop them, and deliver services in a way that does not affect others in a negative way," said Dr. Karen Zumwalt, a Chappaqua resident and professor in the department of curriculum and teaching at Columbia University's Teacher's College. "Kids know very soon where they stand in the academic hierarchy. It doesn't mean that the child with unique potential should be ignored. Rather, you need good, old-fashioned teaching where a child's needs can be met, away from a whole class, lock-step approach."
 
Gifted Students Seek Companionship
 FOR many gifted children, their abilities can be a burden. Just as children whose abilities place them at one end of the bell-curve struggle to fit into the educational system, so too do academically gifted students.
"Kids who are truly gifted really have a hard time in the world and need support," said Jeri Waldman, a former teacher for the gifted who is a fourth-grade teacher at the Murray Avenue school in Larchmont.
Children whose intellectual capabilities outstrip their chronological age can have difficulty fitting in with their classmates. A child whose consuming interest is archeology or military history may not enjoy lunchtime discussions of the latest Nintendo strategies.
Patti Robbins, who had to struggle with the Springhurst School in Dobbs Ferry to have her 7-year-old son, Benjamin, recognized as gifted, said: "The school would not think of a child as being gifted before third grade. He needed other bright boys to be with, and he needed flexible teachers."
Jerry Buchanan, the mother of two children in Greenburgh's High and Wide program and president of the Greenburgh Association for the Gifted and Talented, added: "People think these children are gifted in everything, and that's not true. Kids need to know they're smart, but that's only one facet to them."
Children who participate in special classes, known as pull-out programs, appear to benefit as much from having a compatible peer group as from the intellectual challenges that the teacher offers.
"It's fun," said Jason Weingarten of Hartsdale, an 8-year-old at the Highview School. "You get to get away from class and be with people who have the same intelligence as you. I like studying one thing at a time and doing projects on it."
Melissa Goldstein, a classmate who is also 8 and lives in Hartsdale, said: "You can create your own thing and other people can see your work. It's more fun than my regular class."
Teachers and administrators say gifted children learn as much from each other as from the instructor.
"Gifted and talented kids have frustration and have uniqueness that needs to be addressed," said Patricia Tatlow, a fourth-grade teacher in Ardsley. "They need a chance to talk about their frustrations and their social and emotional needs. You need to offer some companionship to these kids. Gifted and talented kids weren't meant to raise themselves."
