HEADLINE: Anger Lingers After Leak at Atomic Site

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEAUFORT, S.C., Jan. 10

 BODY:
The scare is over, but in the "Prince of Tides" setting of golden coastal marshes, moss-draped live oaks and seaside resort communities, the questions linger after a leak of radioactive water from the Savannah River Site raised new questions about the safety of the nuclear weapons plant there.
At recent public hearings in Beaufort (pronounced BYOO-fort) and on nearby Hilton Head Island, residents demanded a halt to plans to restart the aging reactor that caused the leak about 150 miles from the coast. Energy Secretary James D. Watkins and other officials said that Federal monitoring and notification procedures should have been better but that there was no risk to public health in the incident 
 Still, the leak of 150 gallons of radioactive water on Dec. 22 has starkly demonstrated how high the economic and environmental stakes remain in a nuclear weapons industry that lives on after the cold war has died.
The leak at the Savannah River Site, the nation's only installation for making the tritium needed for nuclear weapons, has pitted Georgia against South Carolina and coastal residents affected by the spill against upstate residents whose jobs depend on the plant. The debate involves South Carolina's largest employer, with 24,000 jobs, and a site that is already storing 34 million gallons of radioactive waste.
 
Embarrassing Questions
 And the leak has raised embarrassing new questions about the Government's decision to spend more than $1 billion to repair the reactor amid general agreement that it is not needed now, and some doubts that it will ever be needed.
"I'm certainly a loyal American," said Robert E. Huber, an official with Hilton Head Island Water Utilities, which is considering using the Savannah River, where the spill occurred, as a drinking water source. "I believe in national security. I believe in high-risk situations the people have to take more risk, but that's certainly not the case in the 1990's. Therefore, the risk to people should be commensurately reduced."
The incident began Dec. 22 during preparations for the restart of the 37-year-old K Reactor on the 310 square miles of the Savannah River Site near Aiken, S.C. The reactor is the nation's only source of tritium, a radioactive gas that increases the explosive power of nuclear weapons and must be replenished periodically.
The reactor had been closed for nearly four years because of safety concerns. After years of debate, Secretary Watkins on Dec. 13 ordered it to be restarted.
But during the beginning of startup procedures, about 150 gallons of highly radioactive cooling water containing tritium leaked into the adjacent Savannah River through a crack the size of a pencil lead. The leak went undetected for two days because the official in charge of authorizing transportation of water samples to a nearby laboratory was out with the flu.
Because of elevated tritium levels, drinking water plants that serve the coastal area and oyster beds on the Georgia and South Carolina coast were closed. There was no disruption of water service. Tritium is not considered as hazardous as some other radioactive substances, but its ability to bind with water and flow through the body makes it a health concern.
Two industrial users, the Savannah Foods and Industries sugar refinery and Fuji Vegetable Oil, were also closed as a precaution but have reopened. Tritium readings have since returned to normal, and the normal uses of the river water have resumed.
 
Secretary Visits
 Mr. Watkins flew to the area to say that the reaction was unwarranted and that state officials and news organizations overreacted to the leak, which was equivalent to four bathtubs full of water. The Energy Department says there was no need to close the water plants. "There was never any danger to the public," Mr. Watkins said.
Peter M. Hekman, Jr., manager of the Savannah River Field Office for the Energy Department, said: "We are talking about one-hundredth of what a person can have in a year's time from tritium. This is not the first time, nor even the largest dose of tritium released by us."
Local and state officials agree that the amounts of tritium detected did not pose a hazard. But they say it was prudent to react cautiously and they disagree with the Energy Department's standards. One reading found tritium in the river to be as high as 67,000 picocuries per liter.
The Energy Department uses a safety standard that is based on the average of readings taken over a year. It says the average should not exceed 20,000 picocuries of tritium per liter.
"It's a meaningless standard," said Dean Moss, general manager of the Beaufort-Jasper Water and Sewer Authority. "If we operate on a nebulous annual average, no restraint is put on any polluter in its day-to-day operation."
And it is precisely the history of leaks that has raised concerns over the plant. An Energy Department report before the restarting warned of the possibility of such leaks and called for increased safety measures.
 
Huge Economic Stakes
 "It's the overall picture that bothers me," said State Representative Harriet Keyserling of Beaufort. "Two years ago they had a similar spill, and an internal report said they had to start monitoring it in a different way. Two years later, they have never done it. Now when everyone is screaming, they say, 'We're going to do it tomorrow.' "
The incident reflects the huge economic and environmental stakes. The area around the plant has boomed as employment at the plant has more than doubled in recent years. Officials there tend to be sanguine about the incident.
"The people who work there should be the ones who know the truth of what went on behind the fence, and they are feeling fine about the safety," said Jane Murff, head of the Aiken County Chamber of Commerce.
Near the coast, where the environment is the economy, the feelings are more intense. Federal officials received some withering, and often hyperbolic, responses at public hearings on Wednesday.
"I don't believe a thing that you're saying," one man said to loud applause at a hearing. "I'd like to see them shut down the plant for this reason: We have not used a nuclear weapon since World War II. We're not killing our enemies. We're killing ourselves."
 
Rift Between States
 There is a similar geographic breakdown between Georgia and South Carolina. Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. of South Carolina, a Republican, has been firm supporter of the plant, the state's largest employer. Across the border in Georgia, Gov. Zell Miller, a Democrat, has been a consistent opponent of plans to restart it or build a new reactor unless emissions are reduced into the air and water and existing contamination is cleaned up. Although most employees come from South Carolina, about 7,200 are from Georgia.
The fate of the plant is tied both to changes in technology and the startling changes in world politics brought on by the collapse of the Soviet Union.
Because tritium decays at the rate of 5.6 percent a year, it must be replenished for weapons to work properly. Officials say enough tritium has already been made to last at least three or four years, and some say recycling tritium from deactivated warheads could make it last far longer than that.
The Energy Department does not view the K Reactor as a long-term solution. Instead, it sees it as an interim solution until a new reactor is built.
Some critics say the shrinking tritium needs could be met by newer technologies that would not generate high-level nuclear wastes. Others go further. "We ought to stop fretting about where the next supply of tritium will come from and think instead of not needing it at all," said Kevin Knoblock of the Union of Concerned Scientists in Washington.
Still, even the end of tritium production, not a likely result, would not be the end of the Savannah River Site. Officials say the cost of cleaning up the plant's current contamination will dwarf the billions spent on maintaining it and getting the K Reactor running.
For now, officials have stepped up monitoring at the plant, now sampling river water every 2 hours instead of every 12. And some officials took pains by week's end to repeat Mr. Watkins's statement that there was no health risk. Mayor Susan Weiner of Savannah and plant and Energy Department officials drank the city's water at a press conference on Thursday.

(Wade Spees for The New York Times)

NEW YORK CITY
 
A FREE RIDE THAT COSTS A LOT
Fare beating has long plagued the New York City subways, but in the last 18 months it has reached epic dimensions. Despite stepped-up police efforts, parts of the city have become virtual no-fare zones. One recent day, 11 people entered the 135th Street station in a 15-minute period. Two paid the fare. A1. 

A MOTHER SPEAKS OUT, ON HER OWN TERMS
Nellie Wilson, the mother of two children who were attacked by four young white men who squirted them with a white liquid, has guarded her children's privacy even while speaking out on her fury over the attack. Her decision, along with efforts by the Dinkins administration and Borough President Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx, seems to have kept down the level of public hysteria that has characterized other bias attacks. B3.
 
MEMORIAL SERVICE BREAKS OUT IN PROTEST
A memorial service at City College for the nine young people who died there two weeks ago turned into a heated political rally. Organizers chanted "Whose school? Our school!" as they denounced college and city officials and rushed the guarded doors of a student center. The only bereaved family to attend it did not approve of the speakers' statements. "I don't see any need for hatred," said the father of Yul Dargan, one of the victims. B4.
 
AN EMIGRE'S DEATH STIRS HIS COMMUNITY
The slaying of Leonid Vinokur on Jan. 5 in Brighton Beach has revealed a new willingness among the neighborhood's 35,000 Russian immigrants to participate in the political and social life of their Brooklyn community. Michael Tartakovsky, a cousin of Mr. Vinokur, who was shot and killed as he struggled with a man trying to mug his wife, addressed a crowd of 250 people yesterday in Brighton Beach. "We will not let this happen again," he declared. "We demand justice." Brighton Beach Journal. B3.
A popular pastor who increased membership but clashed with church elders resigns from Fifth Presbyterian Avenue church. B3.
 
REGION
 
A RISE IN DEATHS OF HARBOR SEALS
For the last several years, more and more harbor seals have been stranded or washed up dead on Long Island beaches. While some of the increase may be from natural forces, biologists have begun to explore the possibility that man-made pollution, particularly PCB's, may be responsible for the condition of animals like NY-870, a harbor seal who died despite being cared for by the Okeanos Ocean Research Foundation. A1.
 
NEW YORK DEMOCRATS HUNGRY FOR A WIN
New York's 1992 Democratic Presidential primary campaign formally begins this week with two factors missing besides Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. So far, this year's campaign in New York has been dominated by electoral mechanics rather than by ideological jousting. No gut issue like the war in Vietnam or the vivid symbolism of a vigorous black candidate divides Democrats. Hungry after 12 years out of the White House, most want to win. Metro Matters. B2.
 
PASTOR AIDS POLICE IN ARREST
The Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d knew his part-time handyman as a young man from a fine churchgoing family. But the police told him that the man was wanted in a robbery that left an ice-cream store manager shot in the head. Two New York City detectives asked for the pastor's help in arresting the man, and yesterday he turned himself in to Mr. Butts. B2.
 
A CLASH OF PARTIES IN LONG ISLAND
Nassau County Democrats are flexing their newly won strength and are closely monitoring the impact of 3,000 layoffs and painful cuts in services as Repbulicans fret over their losses and squabble over who is blame for the budget woes. Both sides agree, however, that old approaches, like raising taxes, will not sell in the depths of recession. B7.
 
RAILROADS A NEW THREAT TO HARBOR
The amount of cargo that once steamed into New York harbor from Asia has been cut in half over the last four years. The reason is high-tech railroad flatcars, hauled on trains often a mile in length, that dash in from the West Coast in three days. It is a trend, experts say, that rivals the impact of the development of containerizing cargo three decades ago. B7.

HEADLINE: Despite Grief, Thinking of Neediest

BYLINE: By J. PEDER ZANE

 BODY:
People find many reasons to contribute to The New York Times Neediest Cases, but among the most touching are those that move people to give despite their own difficulties.
"With my marriage falling apart and my work very stressful because of the economic difficulties," wrote a Manhattan man, who gave $1,000, "I am thankful I have a job and a place to live. This contribution is the beginning of my efforts to give back more to the world this year." 
 Another Manhattan man gave $50 in tribute to his mother's three-and-a-half-year fight against bone cancer. "We were able to celebrate one more Christmas together," he wrote.
Shelly Orringer of Harrison, N.Y., who gave $100, wrote that both her parents had taken ill, "he with a recurrence of lymphoma, she with vision problems, leaving her barely able to see." She added that it was more difficult to care for her mother because her son was recovering from a ski accident and knee operation.
 
Honoring Dead at Lockerbie
 She continued: "Many years ago my husband, a Pan Am pilot, died in a plane crash. I was fortunate enough to rebuild my life. Enclosed is a contribution to honor those who died at Lockerbie, Scotland, on Pan Am 103 and for the demise of a once great airline, Pan Am. This year the need to reach out is greater than ever."
Since it was founded in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, who was then the publisher of The New York Times, the Neediest Cases Fund has raised money for New York's sick, poor and disabled. What began as the "Hundred Neediest Cases" has expanded to meet needs of thousands. So far this year more than $4.1 million has been raised from 12,163 donations.
As in the past, The New York Times is covering all the overhead so that every dollar collected can go directly to seven charities. The money provides relief including food, housing and clothing. The charities also use it for job training for the disabled, drug and alcohol counseling and many AIDS-related programs.
Many people, like Wendy Stedman Sheard of Stony Creek, Conn., have used contributions to the Neediest Cases to memorialize loved ones. Mrs. Sheard gave $100 in memory of her neighbor's sister, Hope Barnes, whom she described as an "inspiring leader in women's athletics, intrepid rock climber and loving daughter and sister who died in January 1991 in a climbing accident."

HEADLINE: Trade Proposal Draws A Lukewarm Response

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
A proposal to pull down world trade barriers has received a lukewarm response from many countries because of its provisions on farm products, forcing negotiators to focus more on opening world markets for other goods, American and European trade officials said today.
In the last three weeks, the European Community, the United States and Japan have all declined to endorse strongly a proposal made on Dec. 20 by Arthur Dunkel, the director general of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. All three trading partners have expressed concerns about exposing their farmers to international competition. 
 Mr. Dunkel's proposal was not comprehensive. When trade negotiators resume their talks in Geneva on Monday, they are likely to start off with loud complaints about his suggestions on agriculture but then shift their emphasis to issues Mr. Dunkel did not address, trade officials and analysts, both American and foreign, said today.
Most economists consider the lowering of trade barriers to be good, because it allows countries to specialize in producing and exporting the goods they make most efficiently, while importing other goods. Carla A. Hills, the United States Trade Representative, said on Thursday that the average American family of four would gain $17,000 over the next decade if a GATT pact is approved.
But American critics of the GATT negotiations contend that while many exporting industries would benefit somewhat, and hire some new workers, other industries would be severely hurt by imports and many of their employees would lose their jobs.
GATT is a Geneva-based organization that organizes talks on rules for international trade.
Negotiators from each of the GATT's 108 member nations are scheduled to announce on March 1 their proposed tariff reductions for 4,000 categories of manufactured goods and their proposed schedules for reducing trade barriers in the financial services, telecommunications, transportation and textile industries.
 
'Down to the Nitty-Gritty'
 After two weeks of reviewing other countries' offers, the negotiators are scheduled to make their final offers on March 15.
The March talks are, "where you get down to the nitty-gritty, that's when it means something commercially," said Willard A. Workman, the vice president for international issues at the United States Chamber of Commerce. "That's where U.S. industry will finally know whether it's a good agreement or not."
Trade officials hope that resolving these questions could give countries an incentive to strike a deal on agriculture after 13 months of squabbling that has blocked agreement on every other issue.
But farm groups remain influential in many countries. Largely because of agricultural concerns, the United States and Japan issued noticeably lukewarm endorsements of Mr. Dunkel's text on Thursday.
 
Pressure From the U.S.
 The European Community's council of trade ministers, acting under strong pressure from the community's farm ministers, said on Dec. 23, "Insofar as the Dunkel paper calls into question the foundation of the community's agricultural policy, the paper is not acceptable and therefore has to be modified."
Despite pressure in the last three weeks from the United States to change that position, including repeated calls for a GATT agreement by President Bush during his recent trip to Asia, the same ministers reaffirmed their statement at a meeting in Brussels on Saturday.
The community's trade negotiators have been told that "they're not to go to Geneva and say 'it's over,' " the same official said, adding, "They're to go to Geneva and ask for changes, notably in agriculture but also in other issues."
After initially seeking a 90 percent cut over 10 years, the United States had recently pushed for a 30 to 35 percent reduction in tonnage and spending over five years. The European Community seeks much smaller cuts.
France has been the most vocal advocate of agricultural subsidies within the European Community. An important question has been the extent to which Germany is willing to join the Dutch and the British in confronting the French.
The willingness of the community's trade ministers to condemn repeatedly the agriculture portions of Mr. Dunkel's text has been widely interpreted as a sign of German reluctance to cut subsidies. A German official who insisted on anonymity said today that "Germany has not abandoned the idea of shearing subsidies, nor has the European Community, but we have to find a reasonable compromise."

HEADLINE: Russian Scientists to Detail Plans For a Fast Nuclear Space Rocket

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
Scientists from Russia say they have made important strides over the decades in perfecting nuclear-propelled rockets, enhancing the prospects for faster space travel, and they plan to detail their achievements this week for the first time.
They will also propose a joint venture with the United States to build, test and use nuclear engines for sending humans to Mars, a feat whose distances and dangers might be beyond the powers of conventional chemical rockets. 
 In theory, nuclear-propelled rockets are at least twice as energy efficient as ones that burn chemical fuels. By generating vast power, they could substantially shorten a Mars voyage and enhance its feasibility.
 
Built for Efficiency
 Russian scientists say they have attained an important milestone in making nuclear-powered rockets. They say they have used highly heat-resistant metal alloys to build an engine that rapidly heats propellants to the highest temperatures ever. The propellants are not burned, but the heating causes them to expand, producing thrust. The hotter the engine, the more rapid the expansion and thrust.
Nuclear reactors have long been used to generate electrical power for spacecraft, especially by the Soviet Union. But they have never been used anywhere as powerful engines for pushing rockets away from Earth or deep into space.
Decades ago the United States built and tested prototype nuclear rocket engines on the ground but scrapped the work in 1973 for lack of a clear mission. The Federal Government has recently rekindled the effort with an eye toward new military and civilian uses, including a speedy way to send astronauts to Mars.
Some Western techinical experts have vaguely known of the secret Russian work but have gathered few technical or historical details, which turn out to be substantial since the work goes back many decades.
The disclosures are to be made this week by a team of Russian scientists at a meeting on space nuclear power held annually in Albuquerque, N.M. The conference starts today. But the new engine disclosures have already been outlined in advance.
"We have definite achievements in this field," Dr. Nikolai N. Ponomarev-Stepnoi, a high official of the Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy in Moscow, said Saturday in a telephone interview from his Albuquerque hotel. "The temperatures were higher than those obtained by our American colleagues."
Dr. Ponomarev-Stepnoi added that his team would propose a joint venture with the West to perfect such engines and "to go to Mars together."
Steve Aftergood, a nuclear expert at the Federation of American Scientists, a private group based in Washington, said the Russian work appeared to be worth close study.
"It seems clear we have something to learn from their advances," he said, adding that a joint program with Russian nuclear scientists might also help boost their employment in a time of economic discord in the former Soviet Republics and lessen their temptation to become nuclear mercenaries.
"We could help them preserve and stabilize their nuclear infrastructure," he said, "which is in their interest and ours."
Elliot B. Kennel, a nuclear engineer at Applied Sciences, of Cedarville, Ohio, who recently met with the Russian scientists, said his company had already agreed to help them further their engine work, which he described as impressive.
"They say they have several reactors that have been tested over a long period of time," he said.
 
Masters of Metallurgy
 Generally, the Russians, though backward in some fields of technology, are seen as metallurgical wizards who have mastered high-strength, high-temperature alloys that are virtually unknown in the West. These metals can be important in the design of advanced reactors, which generate great amounts of heat, by preventing the the reators from burning up.
The Pentagon wants to buy an advanced Russian reactor meant to power spacecraft, but the $15 million deal has been stymied by red tape. The existence of that reactor, known as Topaz-2, was disclosed three years ago at the Albuquerque conference, which is sponsored by the University of New Mexico.
In the interview, Dr. Ponomarev-Stepnoi said Russian achievments in nuclear rocketry involved super-hot reactors that used hydrogen as a propellant.
Extensive trials of the technique have been conducted at the Semipalatinsk nuclear test site in Kazakhstan, now part of the Commonwealth of Independent States, he said, most recently on a large scale in the late 1970's. He added that the technology was still being developed but that progress was imperiled by the collapse of the Soviet economy.
"Taking into consideration the disintegration of our country, this technology also disintegrates," he said.
Tests of nuclear engines at the Semipalatinsk site are thought by some Western experts to have been viewed by American spy satellites and falsely interpreted as relating to lasers and other types of beam weapons. In the 1970's, speculation about mysterious tests at Semipalatinsk helped fuel American interest in exotic arms for attacking enemy missiles, which culminated in the 1980's with President Ronald Reagan's "Star Wars" program.
Dr. Ponomarev-Stepnoi said the Russian achievement of high reactor temperatures could result in far more powerful nuclear rockets for a Mars voyage than ones now envisioned by American scientists.
He added that the Semipalatinsk site would probably be available for future tests with the West to develop a Mars rocket.
"I believe that with joint efforts this problem could be solved in several years," he said. But he noted that much care would have to taken with ecological issues, which could slow things down. The exhaust from nuclear rocket tests can be radioactive unless precautions are taken.
To further the Mars goal, he said, American scientists would be invited to a September meeting in Semipalatinsk on the development of nuclear rocket engines.
Dr. Ponomarev-Stepnoi said the Russian engine work was to be detailed at the Albuquerque conference on Tuesday. A preview was published last week by The Dayton Daily News after Dr. Ponomarev-Stepnoi stopped in Ohio to discuss his work with the experts at nearby Applied Sciences, Inc.
In the United States, nuclear rocketry received a boost last June when a report to the White House praised nuclear-powered rockets as one of the safest ways for human to reach Mars.
Known as the Synthesis report, it said nuclear propulsion could sharply shorten the travel time to Mars, thereby reducing crew exposure to weightlessness and space radiation. It also said nuclear propulsion could cut by about one-half the materials that must be lofted to low earth orbit and increase the number of launching opportunities for the start of a Mars expedition.


GRAPHIC: Scientists from Russia have made significant strides developing a nuclear-propelled rocket, such as might be useful for human exploration of Mars.
 
How It Would Work
Diagram: "Next Stop, Mars"
Hydrogen pumped into the nuclear reactor would be heated to extremely high temperatures, converted to gas and expelled through the rocket nozzle, providing thrust for the launching of heavy payloads or for blasting spacecraft on long-range missions. Some experts advocate using conventional chemical engines to loft the rockets, so that their nuclear engines would not be fired until they were far form the earth's atmosphere. (pg. B10)

HEADLINE: SLUMP PLAYS ROLE IN PICKING COLLEGE

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
The recession has forced many freshmen to put aside educational considerations in selecting their college, according to a survey released today.
The number of freshmen who chose colleges because of low tuition, financial aid or to live near home reached record highs in 1991, the Higher Education Research Institute at the University of California at Los Angeles found. 
 And the number of freshmen who said they went to college because they could not find a job was at its highest point since 1982, in the last recession.
More than 210,000 students enrolled at 431 colleges and universities responded to the survey, which is in its 25th year. The study, sponsored by the American Council on Education, found that 27.7 percent of the students surveyed chose colleges based on low tuition, compared with 23.4 percent in 1990. Financial aid lured 27.8 percent, compared with 25.2 percent the previous year. The survey said 21.3 percent selected colleges to live near home, compared with 19.8 percent in 1990.
Also, 7.3 percent of those surveyed attended college because they could not find jobs. That was the highest level since 1982, when 7.4 percent said they went to college because of the stagnant job market. In 1978, 4.4 percent attended college because they were unable to find job.
More than 37 percent saw a "very good chance" they will have to get a job to help pay expenses, compared with 34.7 percent in 1989. The percentage who expect to work full time during college rose for the third straight year, setting a record at 4.8 percent, compared with 3.5 percent in 1988.
The survey included these other findings:
*Health professions are increasing in popularity, with a record 12.9 percent of the students selecting a major in the field. About 7 percent of the students majored in health-related field in 1987.
*Business careers are losing their popularity, with 15.6 percent of those surveyed planning to major in that area. That compares with 18.4 percent in 1990 and 24.6 percent during the peak year of 1987.
*Freshmen who said they smoke increased to 11.3 percent after declining from 16.6 percent to 8.9 percent from 1966 to 1987.
In addition, beer drinking among freshmen was shown to be at its lowest level in the history of the survey, 57.3 percent. It peaked in 1981 at 75.2 percent.

HEADLINE: Government Service Gets Nasty

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY

 BODY:
When the Comptroller of New York State, Edward V. Regan, announced last week that "there are no philosophical differences or partisan differences" between Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the Legislature over the state budget, he drew this snarling response from John E. McArdle, the spokesman for the Senate majority leader and a fellow Republican. "What is he -- on drugs?"
Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the Connecticut Governor whose high-handed manner almost undermined his crusade to impose the state's first income tax, was asked recently if he had learned any lessons from his heated, ugly fights with the Legislature. "No," Mr. Weicker snapped. 
 Lawmakers in New Jersey, seeking to hand off responsibility for a $2.8 billion tax increase, were too busily engaged in parliamentary feints and stalling techniques last week to speak ill of one another publicly. There, inaction spoke louder than words.
A new spirit of churlishness has invaded the region's legislatures, executive mansions, and local governments. Elected officials are refusing to attend meetings, boycotting quorum calls, hanging up on one another, leveling insults and threats at their opponents, and in general, being as nasty as they want to be.
Resentment, testiness, and rudeness have become so pervasive that they have even soured discourse among political allies. Politicians do bicker even in the best of times, but the stress and frustration of trying to reach agreement on budget cuts and tax increases in the middle of the recession have strained political civility to its limits.
New York State's normally mild-mannered Lieutenant Governor, Stan Lundine, a Democrat, distributed a news release on New Year's Day that heatedly blamed the Republicans for New York's budget impasse. He received dozens of irate phone calls from Republican legislators, including one from State Senator John B. Daly of Niagra Falls who got so angry that he hung up on Mr. Lundine. But not before he told him what he thought of his news release.
"I called it a piece of," said Mr. Daly, stopping himself and noting that he had used a word, "very direct and to the point."
Voters may be dismayed at the vitriol, but psychologists are not surprised by the increase in boorish behavior. "When people are under pressure or stress, they tend to regress and act like children," said Dr. Michael P. Nichols, a professor of psychiatry at the Albany Medical Center. "For some, it takes the form of aggressive defiance, and for others, sullen withdrawal."
Senator Joseph L. Bruno, a Republican from Brunswick, engaged in a high-volume shouting match with Mr. Cuomo at the first leadership meeting that the Governor called after announcing he would not run for the Presidency.
"Frustration and anxiety is causing short tempers and low-boiling points," Mr. Bruno explained. Mr. Bruno is one of many Republicans who have demanded "structural reform" of the state budget system.
In his State of the State Message, Governor Cuomo could not resist taunting his old adversary. "Someday," he said, "we're going to reform your structure, Senator Bruno."
 
Breach of Etiquette
 Yet the most noticeable breach of etiquette on the day of the Governor's address occurred between two Democrats from Queens. When Mr. Cuomo suggested docking his own pay and that of each lawmaker for every day that the budget remained late. He was brashly interrupted by Assemblyman Anthony S. Seminerio.
"Don't tell me I won't get paid for my work -- that's political nonsense," he shouted. "We're here every day, 14 or 15 hours a day." Even by Albany's frontier standards of behavior, the outburst was considered unusual.
Throughout the region, frustration took many forms, from tiny social solecisms to more drastic assaults on governance.
At the first meeting of the newly expanded New York City Council last week, the mood was festive and upbeat. When Speaker Peter F. Vallone gave his State of the City address, the council members rose repeatedly to give standing ovations, all except Sal F. Albanese of Brooklyn, a longtime critic of the speaker, who alone remained sullenly in his chair.
The sniping was decidedly more serious in New Jersey. After two years of budget shortfalls, despite a $2.8 billion tax increase -- the biggest in state history -- fiscal crisis has become a way of life in Trenton.
Last fall, the Democrats lost their majority in both houses because of a fiery tax revolt that was fueled, gleefully, by Republican candidates. In their last lame-duck session, the Democrats decided to call the Republicans' bluff by recommending a repeal of their own tax increase, an "apres moi, le deluge" gambit that would almost certainly bankrupt the state's coffers and force the Republicans to raise taxes on their own.
 
Retreat to a Diner
 The Republicans retaliated by refusing to show up for the Senate appropriations hearing on the rollback proposal. When the Democrats managed to squeeze the rollback bill onto the Senate floor and get it passed, the Republicans proceeded to boycott any discussion of measure in the General Assembly. When the Democrats called a quorum, the Republicans retreated en masse to a nearby diner leaving their opponents to fume in the State House without enough votes to take any action on the measure.
When the Democratic leadership finally corralled enough Democrats to reach a quorum on their own last Monday, the Republicans, who had camped out in a rented meeting room across the street, sourly filed onto the floor and called for a quorum every time a Democrat strayed from the floor.
Republican minority leader, Garabad (Chuck) Haytaian, repeatedly nagged the Democratic Speaker, Joseph V. Doria Jr., about whether he had maintained a quorum. Peering pointedly about the chamber, he said, "I don't think you have 41 people here. I don't believe it." Mr. Doria replied menacingly, "Believe it!"
When the measure finally came up for a vote on Friday, it fell six votes short of passage.
In Connecticut, where a new state income tax was greeted with about as much enthusiasm as Lyme disease, discontent was expressed in ways both ancient and state-of-the-art. Some political opponents regressed to the 18th-century tradition of burning Governor Weicker in effigy; others improvised "chain-fax" hate-mail, faxing doctored pictures of Governor Weicker with a Hitler mustache to the offices of lawmakers and business executives throughout the state.
Irritability, like laughter, is contagious. Even lobbyists, who usually lionize lawmakers, are getting testy. Richard Miller, the chairman of the coalition of New Jersey Sportsmen, for instance, reacted in a less than sportsmanly manner when a vote to override a bill obliging the owners of assault weapons to dispose of their guns failed to reach the floor. "The Legislature is just a bunch of prostitutes," he fumed in front of television cameras, "and the Governor is their pimp."

HEADLINE: Uncertainty and Recession Prevail at Electronics Show

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 11

 BODY:
The future of television, stereos and video games was on view here at the Winter Consumer Electronics Show, which concluded on Sunday. But like the direction of the national economy, the course of the industry seemed sluggish and tentative.
That was due, in part, to uncertainty over the shape and cost of new technologies like high-definition television, mini-disks and digital compact cassettes, and compact diskread only memory, which could drastically change the video-game business. 
 Adding to the hesitancy was manufacturer nervousness over the receptiveness of a public already reeling from rapid and expensive changes in the last decade in consumer electronics formats, including the demise of eight-track tapes, the near-extinction of vinyl records and the recent decline in sales of audio tape cassettes.
As if waiting for Godot, most television makers coped with high-definition television, the cinema-like format due in the late 1990's, by moving essentially nowhere. Most contented themselves with small innovations, like Goldstar's prototype of a voice-recognition television that changes channels in response to shouted commands.
The biggest innovation at the show was also the one least likely to be bought by anyone except fanatical consumer electronics buffs. Thomson Consumer Electronics, the maker of the General Electric and RCA brands and the biggest company in television manufacturing, offered an innovative wide-screen television that more closely resembles the rectangular shape of the theatrical film format.
A version is on limited sale in Europe for $6,000, but the wide-screen television is likely to cost half that when Thomson introduces the RCA Cinema Screen in the United States this fall. It would be for a limited production run of 5,000 to 10,000 units in an American color television market of nearly 20 million units.
Although the price has not been determined, the television is likely to be slightly more expensive than the current $2,900 for a 52-inch projection set, the most costly now on the market. The Philips Consumer Electronics Company and the JVC Company of America may come out with their own versions.
Today's television sets have proportions of 4 by 3 , but the RCA Cinema Screen is 16 by 9, meaning the wider screen has 30 percent more space on each side. The new sets will come in three sizes -- 26, 30 and 34 inches, measured diagonally.
That means that in wide-screen epics like "Lawrence of Arabia," both the British adventurer T. E. Lawrence and King Faisal of Saudi Arabia can be seen simultaneously on screen. Currently, when such films are broadcast or transferred to videotape, a technician dictates the camera movement with a technique called pan and scan, shifting back and forth between Lawrence and King Faisal.
 
Old TV Standards
 But Cinema Screen is only as good as the television signal it receives and the videocassettes and laser disks played on it. Network and cable-television broadcasts are in the square format, as are most videocassettes, although a growing number of titles are in the so-called letter box format that forms black strips on the top and bottom of nearly square sets.
Thomson will have to work out agreements with broadcasters and film studios for wide-screen programming. Currently, the sets will only get a nearly square picture.
Another problem that Thomson will encounter is with television technology itself. In North America, the broadcast standard, which is nearly 40 years old, uses only half of the potential sharpness of a color television set. The signal only incorporates 330 lines of resolution, compared with the nearly 600 lines possible on today's televisions.
 
The Effect on Music
 More lines of resolution mean a sharper picture. High-definition television, or HDTV, has yet to work out its standards, but is likely to have as many as 1,000 lines of resolution.
But RCA Cinema Screen has only 600 lines of resolution, like today's sets. Until the mid-1990's, when the most optimistic experts expect HDTV standards to be set, Cinema Screen may be caught in an awkward transition between plain-old television and HDTV.
Also caught in a transition are the makers of compact disks and tape cassettes, as well as the prerecorded music industry. With their digital clarity, compact disks have nearly supplanted scratchy vinyl records and are hurting sales of analog tape cassettes. But CD's have one big drawback for consumers: They cannot be used to record voice or music.
Philips Electronics N.V., the Dutch company that helped to invent the analog cassette, has also helped develop a new digital version called digital compact cassettes. Philips introduced a $700 recorder in Las Vegas that also accepts the old audio tapes; the company says the unit will be available to retailers this spring.
BASF A.G. of Germany, a leading maker of audio cassettes, plans to sell the digital cassettes in Europe for about $8.50, quadruple the price of analog cassettes, but the American price has not been determined.
A rival to digital compact cassettes is a recordable compact disk called the Mini Disk, made by the Sony Corporation. But the Japanese giant did not even have a product exhibition at the show, leading to speculation as to whether it will meet its announced introduction date this year.
 
Improving Video Games
 Overshadowing both formats is proposed Congressional legislation about royalties to music companies, since consumers will inevitably use the machines to copy prerecorded compact disks. A Senate version is near completion, but the House of Representatives is still considering legislation.
Another version of compact disks, known as compact disk-read only memory, or CD-ROM, promises to revolutionize video games by incorporating cinema-quality live action and animation in video games. CD-ROM technology could incorporate actual scenes from movies like "Batman" and "Terminator 2."
Nintendo of America Inc., the largest maker of video-game systems, plans a CD-ROM offering in January 1993. But Sega of America, whose 16-bit machines have been selling strongly against Nintendo's version, plans to have one on the market this fall.

HEADLINE: No Recession for Firearms Industry

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Other businesses may feel the gloom of recession. But at the Shooting, Hunting Outdoor Trade Show, the annual meeting of the firearms manufacturing industry, the glow of prosperity was in the air.
The 1,200 companies that took part in this year's SHOT Show, as those in the gun industry call the four-day gathering, needed 15 percent more space than last year to show their wares, from high-tech rifles and pistols to scopes, decoys and "Bee-A-Tree" camouflage. Most of the 15,000 manufacturers, gun shop owners and weapons buffs attending the meeting, which ended today, had little to complain about. 
 "Profitability was up in 1991 over 1990," Alan Gottlieb, publisher of "Gun Week," one of several trade journals that took a booth here, said of the manufacture and sales of weapons in the United States. "They're making more, and the feeling is that they are going to do well in 1992."
Not even the threat of gun-control legislation could dampen the mood. At booth after booth, exhibitors cited both the fear of such restrictions and the recession itself, which they say has increased concerns about crime, as factors driving purchases of weapons.
 
Handgun Production Is Up
 According to government statistics, United States firearm production in 1990, the most recent year for which figures are available, totaled 1.8 million pistols and revolvers, down slightly from 1989, but up about 20 percent from the mid-1980's. Domestic rifle and shotgun production was 1.7 million, and more than a million weapons of all types were imported.
One of those enjoying boom times is Ronnie Barrett of Barrett Firearms Manufacturing in Murfreesboro, Tenn. A photographer turned gun designer, Mr. Barrett became something of a cult figure in the firearms industry after the .50-caliber semiautomatic rifle he designed was certified by the United States military and performed well in the Persian Gulf war.
"I'm real proud," said Mr. Barrett, who is 37 years old.
At $6,600 per rifle, plus another $1,000 for a scope, Mr. Barrett's weapon is not cheap. Mr. Barrett said that his main market would remain the armed forces of the United States and 16 other countries, "all friendly," but that he was happy to sell to gun buffs.
"It's a fun toy, a nice collectible," Mr. Barrett said of his creation, which has also appeared in "RoboCop," "Navy Seals" and other Hollywood action movies. "This is not something a drug lord or a bank robber is going to want to use. It's not easy to conceal."
 
Seeking the Female Buyer
 Traditionally, guns have been considered a male preserve. And it is true that this year's show had its share of models in camouflage miniskirts and its stacks of posters of bikini-clad blondes cradling rifles and shotguns.
But gun manufacturers, distributors and dealers appear to have realized that women also constitute a large and mostly untapped market. "We need to teach women that handling a gun is no different than driving a car," said Roy Melcher of Interarms, a weapons distributor with its headquarters in the Washington suburbs.
Smith and Wesson has responded with its "Ladysmith" line of handguns, the latest model of which was introduced here and will be in stores this spring. "We've lightened up the trigger and smoothed out some of the rough spots," said a shooting instructor, Paxton Quigley, who taught the actress Geena Davis how to shoot for her role in "Thelma and Louise.
 
Foreigners Make Inroads
 Jean Warren, owner of a gun shop in Amarillo, Tex., estimates that 15 percent of her customers are women, compared with less than 10 percent a few years ago, and that most are just like her: living alone, either widowed or divorced. "I can relate to them and them to me," she said.
The SHOT Show also attracts makers of foreign weapons, which are gaining in popularity here. Suppliers from countries like Brazil, which produces one-third of the 683,000 handguns imported into the United States in 1990, and Italy were here, along with companies from Czechoslovakia and Yugoslavia, which were forced to scramble for new markets after the end of the cold war.
"The American market today represents 40 percent of our production," said Luciano Rossi of Amadeo Rossi Municoes, a leading Brazilian manufacturer of handguns.
Glock, an Austrian manufacturer, was also here, hoping to increase sales of models equipped with its popular "New York trigger." That device, introduced less than two years ago, was made to fulfill a request by the New York State Police for a trigger with more uniformity of response.
"It's become very popular throughout the country in law-enforcement circles," said Richard E. Perkins, a former armorer for the District of Columbia police who works for Glock.

HEADLINE: Worldwatch Report Calls 1990's Decisive Decade for Environment

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Two years ago, the Washington-based Worldwatch Institute warned that the world had about 40 years in which to reverse environmental deterioration or face a long decline into economic and social ruin.
But in its latest annual report, the institute asserts that the 1990's are the "decisive decade" for environmental change, declaring that nothing short of an "environmental revolution" will save the planet. 
 This revolution will require radical changes, from a reduced reliance on fossil fuels to redistribution of resources and a rapid shift to smaller families, the report says.
Lester R. Brown, president of the institute and director of the study, said that the world had "not succeeded in turning around a single major trend in environmental degradation" since environmental issues came to global prominence at the 1972 United Nations Conference on the Human Environment in Stockholm.
The report lists several warning signs of potential environmental disaster, including continuing evidence of global warming, excessive population growth and deforestation.
Environmental degradation has affected global food production, the report says, citing statistics indicating that temperature changes, soil erosion and air pollution have reduced crop yields by about 1 percent annually since 1984. As a consequence, it says, personal incomes have fallen in more than 40 countries with a total population of 800 million people, nearly one-sixth of the world's population.
"We've underestimated what it will take" to reverse these trends, Mr. Brown said. "Stabilizing the climate depends on restructuring the world economy to phase out fossil fuels. Stabilizing the population will require a revolution in human reproductive behavior."
The report emphasizes the "pivotal role" of governments and corporations in stopping environmental degradation, and points to some positive signs that people are responding to the crisis: the European Community's proposal to replace some of its existing taxes with an energy consumption tax; Germany's pledge to reduce carbon emissions by 25 percent by 2005; the reduction of soil erosion on American croplands by a third in the last five years, and Denmark's ban on throwaway beverage containers.
But these steps are "all too few," Mr. Brown said, adding that it may take a nuclear accident, catastrophic climate change or a food crisis to rally global support for drastic measures.
If the world does not respond to environmental degradation, he said, it will lead to economic distress that is politically unmanageable. He said a look at many archeological sites provided hints of what might come.
"North Africa was once the granary of the Roman Empire," Mr. Brown said. "Now it's largely desert."
Copies of the report may be obtained for $10.95 from the Worldwatch Institute, 1776 Massachusetts Avenue, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20032.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
F.B.I. Shifts Its Course After Cold War Thaw

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
On the surface, the redeployment of 300 counterintelligence agents at the Federal Bureau of Investigation to combat street gangs represented a small but concrete example of what the collapse of the Soviet bloc can mean at home.
But within Federal law-enforcement circles, the shift announced last week by Attorney General William P. Barr came as a stunning break with the past. It represented the first substantial contraction of the F.B.I.'s counterespionage operations in 50 years and is the largest single reallocation of resources in the bureau's history. 
 In a stroke, an agency whose institutional character has been partly defined by its preoccupation with chasing spies, staking out embassies and investigating security leaks had succumbed to the shake-up that has swept the rest of the intelligence community following the transformation of the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.
At its core, the move seemed to symbolize a change in attitude within the senior ranks of the F.B.I. and the Justice Department about the role of counterintelligence. That shift appeared to be prompted by the grudging recognition that global political change had rendered some of the agency's operations superfluous.
"I think realism hit them," said Representative Don Edwards, the Democrat of California who is chairman of the House Judiciary subcommittee that oversees F.B.I. activities. He has criticized some counterintelligence activities, like the Library Awareness Program, in which librarians were asked to report people seeking access to scientific and technical materials.
Mr. Barr played a catalytic role in the reallocation of agents, department and agency officials said. He is trusted by senior F.B.I. managers and has a background in intelligence, and since he became Attorney General last fall, he has prodded subordinates to look for ways to expand the Federal role in combating violent crime.
Federal law-enforcement officials said that some counterintelligence officials at the bureau had opposed deep reductions in staff. But in a view that eventually proved persuasive to top managers at the bureau and the Justice Department, other officials in the bureau's criminal division had been pressing for the personnel shift as a long-overdue reassignment.
Still, senior law-enforcement officials insisted that the move did not represent a downgrading of counterintelligence. "What this represented was a mid-course correction based on resources and needs," said George J. Terwilliger 3d, the Acting Deputy Attorney General.
The precise number of F.B.I. agents engaged in counterintelligence remains classified, but Government officials said the reallocation would bring about a reduction of 15 percent to 20 percent.
Mr. Barr said further cuts would come in next year's budget. Government officials predicted that these planned reductions could result in the redeployment of as many as 100 additional counterintelligence agents to violent crime.
The reassignment seems abrupt because until recently the F.B.I. stoutly tried to protect its counterintelligence budget. Last spring, William S. Sessions, the bureau's Director, said in testimony before a House Judiciary subcommittee that a world in flux demanded an enhanced counterintelligence effort.
"The political, economic, social, cultural and military structure in every region of the world will undergo significant stresses that will result in diverse political transformations," he said. "As a result, U.S. plans, programs and capabilities will be increasingly targeted by our traditional and non-traditional adversaries."
Despite Mr. Sessions's assertions, Congress balked at the bureau's request for a sizable increase in its counterintelligence budget, whose dollar amount is secret, Government officials said.
Since then, the world has undergone even more radical changes. Once-active espionage efforts by East Germany, Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia have disappeared, and one senior Justice Department official said the K.G.B., the Soviet secret police, had virtually dissolved its operations in the United States.
As Mr. Barr put it at a news conference, "Some of the intelligence services that used to be operating against the United States are no longer in existence."

HEADLINE: Volunteers to Help Ex-Soviet Lands

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Richard Garnitz, a 70-year-old former furniture store owner, is considering leaving his two-bedroom apartment overlooking the third fairway in a suburban retirement community to enter a two-year life of uncertainty where he may find himself in long lines just to buy eggs and milk and fretting over a scarcity of fuel to heat his living quarters.
Mr. Garnitz, a former Commerce Department employee, Foreign Service officer and international trade expert, may join the Peace Corps to become a part of its first group ever to enter and assist what was once the Soviet Union. 
 The Peace Corps director, Elaine L. Chao, announced recently that the organization, for the first time in its 30-year history, will send more than 600 volunteers, mostly with business backgrounds, to the former Soviet republics over the next two years to help their transformation into capitalist democracies.
 
Businesses and Governments
 Volunteers will assist business people in the Commonwealth of Independent States with concepts of private enterprise and will help governments define their goals.
"This is an opportunity for volunteers to participate in shaping world history," Ms. Chao said in a recent interview. "This is a very special and exciting period of time."
Shortly before his trip to several of the republics last month, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said, "I would like to see at least 250 Peace Corps volunteers on the ground by next winter."
While the volunteers have yet to be selected, Mr. Garnitz and his wife, Sydelle, are part of a new breed of potential candidates, many of them older than the usual Peace Corps volunteer. The average age of Peace Corps workers is 31.
 
'Take the Plunge'

"We both like adventure, if you will, and both feel we could contribute to the democratic and open market economy of the countries," said Mr. Garnitz, of Silver Spring, Md., a Washington suburb. "We're physically able to go. No problem about that. If we decide it's right, we might take the plunge."
Mr. Garnitz's interest in answering the republics' appeals for American help has as much to do with his views about Communism and American foreign policy as it does with adventure.
"The best way to help what amount to new countries to develop a democratic and market economy is to help them help themselves rather than pour a lot of money into them," he said. "I feel very strongly that an economically stable country is not a danger to its neighbors and the rest of the world. Communism is a wasted way. They've got about 75 years of wasted time. I don't want to see them go back to that type of economy and that way of life."
The volunteers will most likely be working as alone, and they will receive only a modest living allowance, health care and housing.
 
'Unique Period'
 Ms. Chao said: "The conditions will not be easy, so volunteers will have to have a high level of motivation. But as evidenced by the high number of phone calls we've gotten already, a lot of people are eager to participate in this very unique period in world history."
So far, the Peace Corps is not having trouble luring business executives away from comfortable jobs to endure two years in an area of political unrest, economic uncertainty, scant food and hyperinflation.
In fact, the average number of inquiries received by the Peace Corps a day jumped from about 250 to 750 since the beginning of this month.
The Peace Corps is actively recruiting volunteers for the Baltic republics, Armenia and Ukraine, which have formally requested assistance, Ms. Chao said, adding that she expects other republics of the Commonwealth of Independent States, including Russia and Kazakhstan, to follow suit.
 
Technical Expertise
 Participants can look forward to assignments like teaching English, educating business people about marketing products, cost accounting, structuring and managing new businesses, seeking addition capital sources, determining whether a private venture is worthwhile. They will also help local governments design systems and procedures.
"This is really an opportunity to work on a close basis with a local community at a very grass-roots level, very hands-on," Ms. Chao said. "This will enable them immediately to see the impact of their work."
The Peace Corps seeks volunteers with either a degree in marketing, business administration or public administration with five years' work experience, or five years of "significant experience" in fields like finance, management, accounting, marketing, operations or transportation, Ms. Chao said.
It is not necessary that candidates speak the language of the host country or be knowledgeable about its culture because the Peace Corps provides a preliminary three-month intensive language and cultural training period, Ms. Chao said.
The Peace Corps plans to send 60 volunteers by June to the Baltic republics -- Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia -- about 150 to other republics by late summer and another 100 by November. Then in 1993, another 60 will be sent to the Baltic lands and 250 to the other republics, bringing the total number of volunteers there to 620 by the end of next year, Ms. Chao said.
Bob Russell, 56, who has a master's in business administration and works in Richmond as an independent consultant in organizational development, is interested in going to the republics that have sought America's help.
"This would be an opportunity to work in a field where I have some expertise in a completely different culture, to help broaden my perspective of the world and see how other cultures look at life," Mr. Russell said. "It sounds like an adventure."
Some former Peace Corps volunteers and Congressional Democrats are concerned that the corps' move into the Commonwealth of Independent States could come at the expense of the organization's mainstay -- developing nations in Africa, Asia and Latin America. Similar criticism arose when the corps began sending volunteers into former Soviet bloc countries in Eastern Europe last year.
"I think it's great to want to put them in the former Soviet Union," said Steve Lamar, who served in Botswana in southern Africa in the mid-1980's and now works as a consultant in Washington. "But they also need to consider what new countries in parts of Africa and Asia need assistance."
The Peace Corps says the new program will operate with new financing and will not reduce the amount going to third world countries.
"Our commitment to the rest of the world remains strong," Ms. Chao said.

HEADLINE: Connecticut's Tax Agency Is Facing Chaos in Its First Collections

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Jan. 10

 BODY:
In the shabby, overcrowded building that houses Connecticut's Department of Revenue Services, optimism reigns: The 1.6 million blank tax returns that went out last week under the new income tax will be filed in timely fashion by April 15, officials insist. Refund checks, they say, will be processed just as smartly.
But some ominous portents say otherwise. 
 Widespread confusion and antipathy toward the income tax, which was adopted last year after a tortuous battle in the Legislature, plus understaffing at the tax department, errors and ambiguities in the tax tables and the likelihood of yet another drive next month to repeal the statute, could make Connecticut's leap into income-tax-law compliance a messy, chaotic affair.
The Revenue Services Commissioner, Allan A. Crystal, said that given the time pressures -- payroll withholding began just three months ago, 38 days after the law was signed by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. -- his staff has performed brilliantly. But he concedes that the next few months will be the real test.
 
Software Unfinished
 Consultants hired to write the software for processing returns are still completing the work. The banks signed up to process the tens of thousands of checks in turn will depend on the software and the ability of less-than-seasoned tax processors to keep up with the flow of returns.
Some anxious department officials sought out advice in New Jersey, the last state to impose a broad-based income tax, in 1977. But the neighborly advice was cold comfort: every state is different, New Jersey officials said; you just have to jump in and hope for the best.
"It's an absolute crush unless you've prepared properly -- and it's hard to imagine what proper is," said Robert K. Thompson, the assistant director of audit activities for the New Jersey Division of Taxation, who worked the telephone banks answering taxpayer questions in 1977 and vividly remembers being skewered by arcane questions that no one had ever thought of. "The magnitude of implementing something like an income tax is unlike anything else," Mr. Thompson said.
In Connecticut, deep political divisions about the tax, labor turmoil in the state government and the effects of the recession have all compounded the difficulty in getting the tax up and running.
 
Returns More Complex
 One of the biggest problems is that income-tax returns for 1991 will be far more complex this first time around than they probably ever will be again. Because the law took effect only in the last quarter of 1991, the returns had to be contrived as an amalgam of old laws and new, covering differing types of income calculated under different formulas. Dividends, interest and capital gains income have separate tables this year that will be scrapped when the tax season is over. Next year, all income will be treated equally and taxed at 4.5 percent of the adjusted gross total.
Forms for out-of-state residents who work in Connecticut will not even be ready until the end of the month.
And there have been repeated stops and starts. Forms were sent out in October, for example, telling residents who had substantial income from dividends and interest that estimated tax payments would be due before the end of the year. People who called the state directly, however, were told that if they did not file, it really would not matter.
"It was a law that for some strange reason had no interest or penalties if not adhered to," said Hank Hofflich, a managing partner at Schwartz & Hofflich, an accounting firm in Norwalk, "and most people who didn't have professional advice probably sent a check." Mr. Hofflich said his 30-member firm told any client who called to simply throw the October paperwork in the garbage.
Tax tables have also been completely overhauled, causing confusion about how much should have been withheld from residents' paychecks. The initial tables, for 1991 income, were harshly criticized by some lawmakers who said the state was taking out too much money from paychecks and thus hurting residents and the already battered economy.
 
Refunds Will Be Missing
 New tables that took effect on Jan. 1 cut withholding. As a result, most people will not get refunds on their 1992 taxes, and residents who have income from savings or investments may face large bills.
And questions have continued to plague the department about whether it can hire additional staff to handle taxpayers' questions. The agency, which had 835 authorized job positions as of July 1, had requested nearly a 30 percent increase in personnel, about 250 new people.
Last week, only 40 of those people had been hired and trained, however, and a conflict with other state agencies threatened even many of those. Most of the 40, said a department spokesman, A. J. Janschewitz, were state workers who had been laid off from other agencies during a prolonged standoff between the unions and Mr. Weicker last fall.
Last month, however, the labor dispute was resolved, and the original agencies said they wanted their workers back. A decision late Friday afternoon by the Department of Administrative Services, which oversees personnel matters, said the workers could choose whether to keep their new jobs or go back to their old ones. Mr. Janschewitz said he thought most would stay.
Another uncertainty is that some residents may be so angry that they will deliberately mess up their returns or not file at all, a strategy that many phone-in listeners on radio talk shows have advocated. But one anti-tax leader, Thomas Scott, who helped organize a huge rally at the Capitol in October that drew more than 40,000, said he believed most people would comply with the law.
"People are going to continue to resist this thing any way they can, you know, within the law," Mr. Scott said.
But the tax department has also clearly set itself up as a target for critics who have argued that taxing wages will sap the state's economy, or at least not help it. Clearly, it has not been helped by the fact that the 1.6 million tax returns that will begin arriving in mailboxes this week were printed in Illinois, Tennessee and Pennsylvania, then addressed and mailed from Wisconsin.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Contradictory Signals Cloud Outlook on Bonds

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
It has been a wonderful six months for credit market participants, as weak economic data and an increasingly concerned Federal Reserve Board allowed interest rates to move in a predictable downward direction. The economy remains weak, but some credit market analysts suggest that the buying and selling of fixed-income securities is going to be a bit more complex over the next weeks and months.
Movements in market interest rates will probably become less predictable for a number of reasons, these analysts said. Chief among these is the still-resonant message sent by the Fed on Dec. 20, when it cut the discount rate by a full point and lowered its target for the overnight Federal funds rate by half a point. 
 The fact that the Fed took such a drastic step has done much to change opinions about the future, some analysts contend. For traders, it has raised the question of whether the steps previously taken would be sufficient to start a rebound.
 
A Paradox View
 "The discount rate cut has changed people's opinions about the outlook," said Thomas Synnott, chief economist and senior vice president of the United States Trust Company. "Part of the reason for the decline in confidence has had to do with the uncertainty as to whether the Government was really concentrating on the economy."
Mr. Synnott and others say the sharp rise in stock prices over the last three weeks indicates how much better people are feeling about the future. And the bond market, which had largely ignored the rally in stocks, seemed to sit up and take notice last week.
"Financial market participants are grappling with the paradox of slowly improving expectations of economic recovery and a lack of supporting data," Robert DiClemente, an economist at Salomon Brothers, wrote in the firm's weekly newsletter on the credit market.
Indeed, there are many reasons to buttress the notion that the brighter mood about the future is very fragile.
Chief among them, as Mr. DiClemente noted, are reports that attest to continued weakness in the economy.
The December employment report surprised many economists because it showed that payrolls actually expanded last month; many had expected them to shrink.
But virtually all of the gains were for health-care and government workers. Given the financial condition of most states and localities, analysts said government jobs were unlikely to keep increasing.
A decline of 32,000 in manufacturing jobs put the number of factory workers at the lowest level since March 1983, said David H. Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International. And private-sector payrolls have not been so low since March 1989.
"These numbers are pretty dismal looking," Mr. Resler said. "Apart from people who want to buy stocks, I find it difficult to see how confidence has been improved."
Despite its recent decisive actions, even the Fed seems on uncertain ground.
In Congressional testimony on Friday, the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, said he was optimistic that cuts in interest rates engineered by the central bank in recent months would provide "considerable impetus" for economic recovery.
But Mr. Greenspan also used recession-like words like "disinflation" and phrases like "personal and corporate balance sheet restructuring" to explain what is happening to the economy.
"Our gut impression is that the Fed knows no better than the average person what will yet happen to the economy," said Maria Fiorini Ramirez, president of Ramirez Capital Consultants.
To underscore the message he helped to telegraph on Dec. 20, Mr. Greenspan intimated in his testimony last week that if the most recent declines in interest rates were not enough to revive the economy, the Fed would move again.
That note would have reassured the credit markets, were it not for worry about what role Congress and the Administration will play in creating a turnaround.
Some analysts contend that although the concerns are real, they will probably prove to be unfounded.
Fiscal policy initiatives are likely to be modest. Over the last decade, the power of the financial markets and the growing budget deficits have narrowed the options available to legislators.
"Anything that causes any financial market to get hit hard in reaction to proposals from our elected officials results in those proposals being retracted," said Jerry L. Jordan, a senior vice president at First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles. "These are enormously fluid international capital markets, and it is relatively cheap to shift money from market to market if you see something you don't like."
With President Bush back in Washington and his State of the Union Message scarcely two weeks away, the focus on proposals coming out of the capital is likely to intensify.
Of the economic reports expected this week, analysts said that December numbers on retail sales, expected on Tuesday, and on consumer prices, scheduled for Thursday, would probably be most important for participants in the fixed-income markets.
Of the two, the retail sales figures may be more critical, said James F. O'Sullivan, an economist at Morgan Guaranty Trust. The sales figures "will be looked to for signs of how much more weakness" in the economy can be expected, Mr. O'Sullivan wrote in a weekly letter to clients.
"Most likely, sales fell sharply in the key December shopping season, pointing to a further run-up in inventories and the need for additional employment and production cutbacks in the months to come," he wrote.
Morgan's analysts are projecting that retail sales took a giant drop of eight-tenths of a percent last month after rising three-tenths of a percent in November.
