HEADLINE: For Detroit, Time to Buckle Down

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 12

 BODY:
With token concessions and little relief from President Bush's mission to Japan, the nation's auto industry enters a new and critical phase in which it must seek its own strategies to keep from being overwhelmed by competitors and a floundering economy.
The negotiations last week over America's access to the Japanese automotive market were mostly a sideshow to the American auto industry's overriding concern: how to fix its operations in this country, which are steadily losing ground to Japanese competition. To make matters worse, the industry also suffered a public relations black eye last week as it was cast as a supplicant seeking help from the Japanese Government to sell its wares, an image that could repel even more customers. 
 The chairmen of the Big Three had little choice but to accept the President's invitation to participate in the Japan trade mission. They have gamely sought to portray the trip as helpful in raising business and economic issues to the same level of international importance as military matters or diplomacy.
"We started a meaningful process in Japan and we mean to follow up on it," said Robert C. Stempel, chairman of the General Motors Corporation. "For the first time, Japan saw the power of a joint U.S. Government-industry initiative."
But consciousness-raising won't change the stark reality that the financial might of the Big Three and thousands of suppliers has withered to dangerous levels. With car sales slumping and their market share eroding over the years, Detroit must accelerate the reorganization of its manufacturing, engineering and marketing networks to reduce costs and build better cars and trucks.
Detroit has begun to sweep away the hierarchical bureaucracy that impedes development of new models and execution of business strategies. In its place are "flatter" organizations with fewer bosses and more responsibility at lower levels of the company.
But top executives are candid in saying that lots more must be done. They all speak of too many meetings, memos and tasks unrelated to improving products, sales and customer service. They are avoiding, as Mr. Stempel has often noted, wrenching reorganizations that confuse, anger and upset workers.
The industry's organizational strategies amount to trying to get "a dollar's worth of development for 90 cents," in the words of Alex Trotman, executive vice president at the Ford Motor Company. That will mean more efficiency akin to what the Japanese use in plants and engineering laboratories, with fewer meetings and less activity of all kinds related directly to designing, building and selling vehicles. G.M. and Ford Motor are closely watching the Chrysler Corporation's development process as a possible model for changes. It has been stripped to its essentials because of Chrysler's lean resources.
In Washington, the auto industry also may throw its weight behind protectionist legislation soon to be introduced in Congress. Although passage is uncertain, protection could restrain the sales of Japanese cars, including many models assembled in the United States, at least temporarily.
In the early 1980's, the United States and Japan agreed to what were called voluntary export restraints that limited the number of cars Japan could ship to the United States. The idea was to give Detroit a few years to adjust its product line to the reality of higher gasoline prices.
In retrospect, those restraints are regarded by most Detroit executives as a failure. Japanese auto makers used their limited allocation to ship mostly higher-profit luxury models, which hurt sales of Detroit's highest-profit models. And the restraints encouraged Japanese auto makers to build more plants in the United States; consequently, Japanese auto makers have more political and popular support because they employ many Americans, contribute to charity and, thus, seem less foreign.
The Toyota Motor Company, Japan's largest, as well as other Japanese auto makers have become significant producers and employers in the United States. Toyota estimated that 72,000 workers were directly employed by its factories, dealerships, engineering centers and other installations. This fact poses difficulties for Democrats like Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, Representative John Dingell and Senator Donald W. Riegle, both of Michigan, who are proposing to limit sales of Japanese-brand cars and trucks -- even those made in the United States.
Robert B. McCurry, executive vice president of Toyota's American sales operations, naturally opposes such limits and believes they are mis-- directed. "We need solutions, not scapegoats," he said. "Instead of blaming others for what we've become, we need to look in a mirror and ask ourselves what we can do to get back on track."
Mr. McCurry like many American executives now employed by a Japanese auto maker, worked for one of the Big Three, in his case, Chrysler for 28 years.
Also, the National Automobile Dealers Association, representing 19,000 dealers, on Friday proposed reinstatement of the investment tax credit to stimulate business purchases of cars and trucks and a repeal of the luxury tax on vehicles costing more than $30,000.
The industry's public relations could use some polishing as well. The last week clearly has been galling for an industry that never dreamed its leaders one day would find themselves asking the Japanese "to play fair." Lloyd Reuss, president of General Motors, assured reporters previewing the North American International Auto Show in Detroit: "Contrary to what is being written, we have not been defeated."
But that image could stick, given all the news accounts over the last week and the longstanding perception that Japan builds better cars than Detroit. The result could be further defection to foreign makes by Americans fed up with Detroit. On the other hand, Phil Guarascio, head of G.M.'s advertising, believes the week's events in Japan may spark interest in domestic models. "We're seeing some signs," Mr. Guarascio said.
In coming weeks, Detroit is expected to announce 1991 losses that will be the industry's worst ever. Those losses will further impair its ability to invest in new models. G.M. and Ford Motor are "postponing" some future models because there is little cash for development that must be paid for now. Chrysler has bet its last billions on a new Jeep Grand Cherokee utility vehicle that is just coming off the assembly lines, and a series of mid-size cars due later this year. If those models fail, Chrysler's future as an independent company will again be in grave doubt, experts say.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Consumers and Pros Pick Same Commercials as Tops

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
WHENEVER advertising executives gather to bestow honors on one another's campaigns -- in other words, every week or so -- they always ask this question: What do consumers, at whom those award-winning ads are aimed, think of them? One awards organization was curious enough to seek an answer.
The New York Festivals, which annually presents awards to international television commercials, has inaugurated a Consumers' Choice Award. At its initial presentation, at the organization's 34th annual awards banquet in Manhattan on Friday, the winner was a humorous spot for DHL Worldwide Courier, created by Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising in Sydney, Australia. 
 It turned out that the same spot, in which a cat connives to get DHL to ship a noisy parakeet to Siberia, also won the 1991 Grand Award for best commercial from the ad executives who served as the organization's judges. In fact, the consumers and the ad professionals also agreed on their choice for second place, a whimsical spot created by Hunt Lascaris TBWA in Johannesburg for Nashau color copiers, in which a boy hands out valentines, inscribed, "I love only you," to every girl in school.
"I was expecting some overlapping, but it was a surprise to me they came in exactly the same," said Marcio M. Moreira, chairman of the judges, who is also vice chairman and chief creative officer-international at McCann-Erickson Worldwide.
The award was Mr. Moreira's idea. "Consumers are what the game is all about," he said. "Who in the world sets out to write advertising for their peers?" When it was suggested that those who want to win awards from their peers do that, he replied, "That's irresponsible."
To determine the consumer award's winner, Audits & Surveys Inc., a market research firm, was hired to canvass 202 people in four cities: Buenos Aires, London, New York and Sydney. They were shown the 12 gold-medal winners that the judges scored highest from more than 4,000 initial entries.
"Researchers look for consistencies and confluences," said Solomon Dutka, chairman and chief executive of Audits & Surveys. "So I was pleased." He praised Mr. Moreira "for saying, 'Let's stop talking to ourselves. What is the impact on consumers?' "
On the 10 remaining spots, the opinions of the consumers and the ad professionals diverged. The widest disparity was six places apart; a commercial the judges voted No. 5 was voted No. 11 by the consumers, for instance.
In those cases, said David Silverstone, senior vice president and director of market planning for McCann-Erickson U.S.A., the consumers seemed to favor emotional appeals, like a spot by the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago, in which a boy shyly gives his teacher a Hallmark card. The professionals, he added, favored well-crafted spots, like one by BBDO Worldwide in New York, in which celebrities from Tiny Tim to Jerry Lewis sing a Diet Pepsi jingle.
Next year, Mr. Moreira said, he would like the organization to expand the consumer participation to at least 10 cities worldwide.
"It's a learning tool and a lesson," he added. "Sometimes, something is so cleverly done that only we in the industry get excited by it."
Three more Grand Awards were presented by the ad professionals. Burnett won for best television campaign, for three spots in a long-running series of offbeat commercials for Cheer detergent. GGK London won for best creative and production achievement, for three animated spots featuring human-like animals for the Electricity Association. And winning for best public service announcement were Contrapunto, an advertising agency, and Film Deluxe, a production company, both of Madrid, for a spot for the Spanish Government promoting condom use.

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Looking for the Democratic Vision

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
NEW York's 1992 Democratic presidential primary campaign formally begins this week with two factors, besides Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, missing.
So far, this year's abbreviated campaign in New York has been dominated by electoral mechanics rather than by ideological jousting. No gut issue like the war in Vietnam or the vivid symbolism of a vigorous black candidate divides Democrats. Hungry after 12 years out of the White House, most want to win. 
 "Sensitive people," said Representative Thomas J. Manton, the Queens Democratic leader, "are putting aside their litmus paper."
Since Mr. Manton has endorsed Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the chief beneficiary of organizational support from New York's political and labor leaders, his view may represent short-lived wishful thinking. Things could change if the candidates challenge their rivals' access to the ballot and as their philsophies become more defined.
Another factor that is still missing from the campaign was more predictable: few candidates have focused on an urban agenda.
That was true, too, in previous presidential campaigns. Early primaries are in predominantly rural states, the influence of big cities has declined and urban problems seem so intractable that proposed solutions can represent political liabilities.
Those excuses will be even less valid this year, though. Social and economic woes have gotten worse and are no longer unique to big cities. By comparison, security threats from overseas have largely evaporated.
This week, would-be delegates for the five surviving Democratic candidates begin circulating their green petitions to get on the April 7 primary ballot.
Today, John A. Marino, the Democratic State Chairman, will submit 25 questions to the candidates seeking to define their urban vision in the 12 weeks before the New York primary: How would you cut taxes, invest in human capital and still reduce the deficit? How would you reduce defense spending without harming communities that are dependent on it? How would you increase access to health care and housing? How would you define the Federal role in protecting a woman's right to abortion, in reducing prison overcrowding and in fighting illegal drugs? Should any drugs be legalized? Where do you stand on gun control?
Mr. Marino's questionnaire marks a good beginning, but only a beginning. Ask these questions, too: Which positions do you hold that are regarded as unpopular? What have you accomplished that would not have gotten done without you?
How would you match job training and employment needs? Would you provide drug treatment on demand? Should welfare mothers be required to work? What if they refuse?
What is it about American society that precipitated the drug epidemic? What is government's responsibility in dealing with the failings of family? How would you handle homeless people with mental problems? How would you help people with AIDS?
How would you encourage private developers to build affordable housing? How would you reduce segregation in housing and schools and further bridge ethnic and racial gaps?
And the question that Mr. Cuomo suggested in 1976, which provoked Jimmy Carter's poorly worded pledge to preserve a community's "ethnic purity": Should low-income housing be built in middle- or upper-income neighborhoods?
There are no easy solutions. There are not even easy answers. There will be no answers at all, though, unless somebody asks the questions.
That the three candidates who are leading in early public opinion polls -- Mr. Clinton and Senators Tom Harkin of Iowa and Bob Kerrey of Nebraska -- represent predominantly rural states near the center of the continental United States may signal the nation's priorities.
Presidential candidates bred in a big city have rarely gotten elected. Rarely have Democrats who win the New York primary gone on to win the nomination and the presidency.
But even in New Hampshire, unemployment has tripled since 1988. And last week's withdrawal of Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia may trigger a recognition among the remaining candidates that vague slogans are no substitute for well-defined vision.
Regardless of the outcome April 7, the Democratic nominee will be selected in New York -- at the party's national convention in July. How he answers compelling urban policy questions may determine whether the candidate runs away from New York once the convention is over.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Three Whine Mice ...

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
The Bush mission to Japan was so ill conceived and executed as to raise fundamental doubts about the President's capacity to manage U.S. foreign policy in the post-cold war world.
Here's what the trip shows about Mr. Bush: 
 * He doesn't understand that international power now depends on domestic economic strength. And so, he went to Japan in the worst possible position -- to bash on bended knee.
* Neither he nor his closest advisers know the first thing about Japan, perhaps the country that will have the most profound impact on U.S. interests. In their ignorance, they unleashed a whole new level of Japanese contempt for America, an attitude that could have the direst consequences.
* He doesn't get the point that he ought to be fighting to open up markets for American industries that can compete, not those that don't. Because of that, he used up his chips on U.S. automotive manufacturers, the least worthy of help.
* He hasn't begun to tailor his Government toward the new agenda in world politics, namely the issues of trade and competitiveness and the connections between foreign and domestic affairs. Just look at who didn't accompany the President to Tokyo -- Secretary of State James Baker and Carla Hills, the chief trade negotiator.
All these Bush weaknesses were hidden by his skillful handling of the Persian Gulf war (until its end game) and the devolution of Soviet power. Mr. Bush is good at the old security and power issues. He knows how to muscle other nations on such matters, and that's useful . . . on such matters.
But economic issues, the heart of new world politics, are not such matters. Power in this world turns on internal economic strength. By that measure, the U.S. is in relative decline -- on education, infrastructure, the running of many traditional industries and self-discipline.
Mr. Bush seems to perceive this central fact only dimly. What he did in Tokyo proceeded from weakness and not strength. That's why he missed the point that his muscling actually came across as begging.
His bashing on bended knee generated only contempt in Japan. And it is deadly dangerous for Japanese to harbor such feelings toward America. Respect for America helps to contain a Japanese cultural arrogance ever close to the surface and always threatening. Regard for America helps to anchor a Japanese democracy ever fearful of being overloaded by conflicts.
Mindful of these inner demons, Japan's leaders wanted to stay close to the U.S. Their main and unrealized aim for the Bush trip was to form a global partnership. But that idea is now sinking in a new contempt for America that could cause Tokyo to assert itself in ways all will regret. Clashing Japanese and American titans could unhinge the fragile democracies of Asia, further unnerve a churning China and destroy prospects for freeing world trade.
Mr. Bush seemed particularly unprepared in Tokyo, arriving without a viable trade strategy. He should have been helping to clear away Japanese hurdles to dynamic American businesses that know how to compete -- like services, telecommunications, computers and construction.
Instead, he hitched his and America's prestige to the Big Three automobile whiners who, along with Mr. Bush, had to be among the select few blind to the looming catastrophe. These whiners are the guys who pay themselves more than 100 times their workers' salaries, or 10 times higher than their Japanese counterparts; who raise their compensation even as their companies' profits plummet, and who cry about not being able to sell left-hand-drive American cars in Japan when the Japanese drive from the right side.
Even into his fourth year, Mr. Bush simply isn't organized to think about and manage these critical trade and economic issues. His emphasis in staff and structure remains on the old security agenda. That -- and the upcoming Presidential elections -- explain why the policy people like Mr. Baker and Ms. Hills got brushed aside and the Bush pols took over the President's Asia trip.
Mr. Bush's judgments throughout the Japan trip were deeply flawed. And the questions are now inescapable: Does he comprehend his mistakes? Can he change and lead America in today's world of power and diplomacy?

HEADLINE: Essay;
The April Surprise

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Last week, approaching the first anniversary of Desert Storm, George Bush again called on the Iraqi people to "take matters into their own hands and get [Saddam Hussein] out of there . . ."
That caused much wincing among the Kurds and Shiites who rose up in the aftermath of our stop-short victory last winter. 
 They trusted Mr. Bush to suppress the Iraqi helicopter gunships, but Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf, in his own word, was "suckered." Mr. Bush, persuaded by Brent Scowcroft and James Baker on March 26, 1991 -- the turning point of his Presidency -- that a Kurdish victory would lead to "dismemberment" of Iraq, allowed the rebels who answered his oust-Saddam invitation to be slaughtered.
We will hear much this week about the wisdom of the war. Democrats who opposed it were at first embarrassed by its success, and will now disparage its results. Thanks to the moral cowardice of March 26, Mr. Bush snatched defeat from the jaws of victory: Saddam remains in power, persecuting his people, and the Kuwait we restored remains a feudal fiefdom.
Through all the posterior-covering denigration, let us remember what would surely have happened had we not struck decisively to drive Iraq from Kuwait. Bad enough that Saddam Hussein would have dominated the world's supply of oil, driving up the price, adding inflation to recession; much more important, he would now be a nuclear power.
That, lest we forget, was what the war was about. Not for the noble spirit of collective security, though that was a part; not for "jobs," as Secretary Baker insisted, a political bleat echoed thrice in Mr. Bush's recent Japanese rejection; not to allow the royal family in Kuwait to force an exodus of its Palestinians, and not to exorcise our Vietnam syndrome, making us feel good by flexing our muscular technology.
When the debate was going on before we struck, the single argument that got through to the American people was this: Saddam Hussein, a ruthless murderer and aggressor, was within a year of developing a nuclear device. American security would be at stake, and ultimately American cities at risk of atomic destruction.
Though that was pooh-poohed at the time as deliberate disinformation to stimulate war hysteria (and the C.I.A., misleading most of our media, was still in its dream world of "5 to 10 years away"), we now have on-site proof that Iraqi scientists were well on their way to bomb production. Riyadh, Tel Aviv and Cairo would be under nuclear blackmail today, with Paris and New York vulnerable to Baghdad's nuclear-tipped missiles next year.
Thanks to George Bush's courageous initial decision, overriding Sam Nunn's wrongheaded talk of delays for unworkable sanctions, the world dodged that bullet. Iraqi nuclear production was set back.
But not destroyed. The threat -- not as immediate, but now more widely understood to be real -- has once more begun to grow. Both Iraq and Iran are obtaining technology and materials from China and from K.G.B. renegades, easily hiding it from U.N. inspection teams.
Mr. Bush knows that he will have to return to Saddam Hussein. As Manuel Noriega can testify, this American President is better the second time around. He has asked the Joint Chiefs for a plan to strike again. The Pentagon replies: for the coup, try the covert boys across the river next time -- test ye everlasting Gates.
Perhaps we will see a U.N. relief column to the starving, freezing Kurds through Iraqi territory, with an aerial counterattack if it is stopped; or a similar reaction to a refusal to allow inspectors into areas where mass-destruction weapons are being made. The military punishment would be accompanied this time by a coordinated internal Arab-Kurdish uprising (with a freelance Mossad backup if all else fails; the Scud attacks have not yet been answered).
A majority of Americans may not support a war to save the Kurds from genocide. But most Americans would cheer overt-covert aid to a Kurdish-Shiite uprising to drive Saddam from Baghdad -- if convinced the overthrow will stop a terrorist threat to American cities. Even America-Firsters can handle that. And Iranians planning a similar nuclear buildup would get the message.
When? An October "surprise" would be too obviously political. Much depends on Saddam's cooperative recalcitrance, but some of our spooks expect a balloon up in April or May.

HEADLINE: Race and Crime: Let's Talk Sense

BYLINE: By Barney Frank; Barney Frank, Democratic Representative of Massachusetts, is author of "Speaking Frankly," from which this article is excerpted.

 BODY:
Crime has become -- for conservatives and liberals -- a marker for race. If America were a racially homogenous country, the crime problem would not be a significant factor in Presidential elections.
For most of this century, crime was not an issue in national elections, and certainly was not the problem for liberals it has since become. Then came the 1960's, when the growth of violent crime in the cities and active, vigorous civil disobedience by antiwar protesters helped cement the impression that liberals supported the disturbers of the peace. 
 The police response to these actions became a major issue, especially after the Democratic convention in Chicago in 1968. A willingness to speak out against police brutality and other misconduct became very important for those seeking support from the increasingly organized and vocal left.
The unhappy consequence of all this was that just as many Americans were becoming more frightened of crime, more unhappy at disorder and more supportive of strong police action, they saw liberals explaining away the actions of the lawless and harshly criticizing the police. Most important, for many white Americans the fear of crime became a fear of crime by young black males.
The first Republican efforts to take advantage of this in the Nixon-Agnew law-and-order campaign in the 1970 Congressional elections fell short. But as fear of violent crime became more and more a factor in American life, the notion that the Democrats were soft on crime took on more political strength. And the racial element of the crime question merged with the perception that Democrats were so much the prisoners of special interests that we wouldn't even support tough anticrime measures lest we offend some of these groups.
For many swing voters specifically, Democrats appear unwilling to stand up firmly against criminals because we fear alienating black voters. Of all the political misperceptions from which we liberals suffer, this is the worst -- the least accurate, the most socially pernicious and the most politically corrosive.
It is also the one where all of our internal contradictions, guilt feelings, and disabling cultural lags work against an effective Democratic response. Unfortunately, especially for Michael Dukakis, these elements came together perfectly for the Republicans in 1988 in the person of Willie Horton.
Race and crime together show the "notsaposta" syndrome at its worst. Liberals are notsaposta take note publicly of the fact that young black males commit street crimes in a significantly higher proportion than any other major demographic group. We are notsaposta admit this because we fear that if we do, we will give aid and comfort to those who will draw wholly inaccurate, racist inferences about African Americans and crime.
What happens, of course, is that liberal efforts to ignore the racial aspect of crime today rarely work, and when we do address the issue, we do so defensively and in a manner that exacerbates our political difficulty without effectively combating racism. Liberals over-argue the point that social and economic conditions are the cause of crime. By asking people to believe too much of this argument, we end up with their not believing as much of it as they should.
Of course, the point that social and economic conditions heavily influence the crime rate should be central to the liberal approach to this issue. And given the history of racism in this country, African Americans suffer most from these conditions and most often manifest their effects.
But we must avoid the mistake of appearing to be justifying -- or even mitigating -- the actions of individual criminals by stressing the poverty and racism around them as if that made their actions less heinous. Poverty, racism, social disorganization all explain the prevalence of crime to some extent, but in no way do they justify it. We liberals have allowed ourselves to be restrained from saying what the public at large wants -- and has every right -- to hear: that people who assault, rape, rob, or otherwise terrorize others are bad people from whom the innocent majority must be protected.
Nothing causes liberals more political harm than the perception that we are as sympathetic to criminals as we are to their victims.
A related mistake liberals make is to use the bad social conditions that lead to crime as if they were an argument that will help persuade people to support social equity programs. In effect, we are telling voters who bitterly resent the incursions that crime has made on their lives that if we improve welfare benefits, fix up public housing, provide more job opportunities for minority teen-agers and do a better job of integrating our work force, the beneficiaries of this largesse will be less inclined to rob or beat them. This does not advance our chances of success.
What happens through this process is that a series of morally justified, sensible programs to improve social conditions comes to look like a form of sophisticated bribery. Measures to combat racism and reduce inequality have a far better chance of gaining support when they are defended on their inherent merits than when they are presented in a way that makes the swing voter see them as preferred rewards to get people to stop behavior that they should never have adopted in the first place.

HEADLINE: Now Let's Learn Self-Help From the Japanese

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Don't Look for Jobs in Japan" (editorial, Jan. 6), you assert that "the number of employed Americans is unrelated to the size of the trade deficit" and invoke the experience of the 1980's, when full employment accompanied the huge trade deficits. 
 But, how were those people employed in the 80's? You ignore the basic restructuring of our economy away from manufacturing and toward the service sector, a trend that began before the 80's but accelerated with the economic fuel of the Reagan tax cuts. Increasingly, Americans were employed in a sophisticated broker network, marketing and servicing imported manufactured goods. In balance, we exported plenty of manufacturing jobs and capital.
Our living standards were "improved" by the availability of less costly imports, but at the expense of our economic strength today.
Yes, the trade deficits are home-grown, and certainly not made in Japan. But it is a United States Government responsibility to do something about them. When the financial decision makers in American business are not rewarded for keeping their factories open and modernized, but are instead encouraged to manufacture their goods abroad, with immediate benefits to the bottom line, you have the incentives stacked against the United States, and our manufacturing jobs are exported. When American consumers have no American alternatives to the goods they wish to buy, our capital flows out of the country.
The Japanese are not to blame for taking advantage of our gluttonous consumption of consumer durables, regardless of the country of origin. It has been smart business for them to purchase our Treasury bills and feed our coffers, so we could keep shifting our manufacturing base to Japan.
And it is not the formal Japanese trade barriers to foreign goods that make the Japanese resistant to American products. It is their desire to purchase products from their own country. The same can be seen in our European trading partners. Japanese trade barriers to a foreign product are only eased when a Japanese competitor has been safely established.
You state that the Japanese have been losers because their standard of living has suffered, that they have not had access to foreign goods that were better value than Japanese-made goods. If only we had made the same sacrifices! Look at their economic growth, their national savings, their overall prosperity.
Neither is it a given that if we bought fewer Japanese cars, the consequence would be fewer American goods exported to Japan because of increase in the value of the dollar. The Japanese will buy the American products they cannot live without. During the years that the yen more than doubled in value, exports of Japanese products, in units, to the United States continued to rise. A strong dollar, not a weak currency, is the envy of the world, and if the return of manufacturing to America leads to a stronger dollar, that would only be to our benefit. We would buy their companies and land, not the reverse.
Yes, we Americans would be better off if we did not outspend our income. However, you call for further lowering of interest rates or a reduction in taxes and an increase in Government spending. All of which might not be injurious to the economy in the long run, if we recycled the capital and did not use it to buy so many foreign goods. But unless we use such a capital infusion toward rebuilding our manufacturing base, those measures would produce a short-lived recovery.
In addition to them, we must also make sure we restructure to deliver longer-term economic health, and not just a temporary kick. That will mean altering our tax structure to favor savings and investment, particularly investment in manufacturing plants here. And it will require leadership to make it clear that American consumers should favor American products, when given the alternative. And that is good common sense, not unfair trade policy.
 
JANE E. NICHOLS
New York, Jan. 7, 1992
 
The writer is a marketing consultant.

HEADLINE: As West and South Grow, Northeast Continues Slip

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Americans continue to abandon the Northeast for the West and South, making Nevada, Alaska and Idaho the fastest-growing states since the 1990 census, the Census Bureau says in a new report.
"We're still abandoning cities in the Northeast to a large degree and building up new ones elsewhere," said Carl Haub, a demographer at the Population Reference Bureau, a research group based in Washington. 
 The report covers population changes for April 1990 through July 1991. Unlike the 1990 census, which was based on house-to-house surveys, the new report consists of estimates based on state records like utility accounts and birth and death rates.
The estimates showed that the nation's population as a whole grew 1.4 percent during the period, which the Census Bureau said works out to an annual growth rate of 1.1 percent.
 
Feeling the Slump
 Population growth was far below that in the Northeast because of the economic slump, it said. New York State's population grew 0.4 percent, to 18,058,000; Connecticut's grew 0.1 percent, to 3,291,000, and New Jersey's grew 0.4 percent, to 7,760,000.
The estimates showed that population continues to shift to the South and West, a trend that began more than 30 years ago.
Nevada's population jumped by an estimated 6.8 percent during the period, to 1.28 million; Alaska grew by 3.7 percent, to 570,000 people, and Idaho gained 3.2 percent, to 1.04 million.
The Census Bureau cited the economic downturn in New England as the reason for the small increases in Maine and Vermont and the population losses in Massachusetts and New Hampshire. The only other places to show declines were North Dakota and the District of Columbia.
 
Growth in Midwest
 In the Midwest, population growth increased notably from April 1990 to July 1991. Iowa, Nebraska and South Dakota, which reported losses from 1985 to 1990, showed small increases in the latest figures. Illinois, Indiana, Ohio and Wisconsin showed much higher growth rates than from 1985 to 1990.
"The Midwest has stopped losing people at the rate it once did," Mr. Haub said. He added that the gain of about 500,000 people during the latest period was due mainly to reduced migration from the region, rather than new people moving there.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 14, 1992, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A chart yesterday showing population growth since the 1990 census mislabeled figures for three states in some copies. Alaska grew from 550,000 to 570,000 between 1990 and 1991, an increase of 3.7 percent; Arizona grew from 3,665,000 to 3,750,000, an increase of 2.3 percent, and Arkansas grew from 2,351,000 to 2,372,000, an increase of 0.9 percent.

GRAPHIC: Table: "Growing Since the 1990 Census" lists population in 1990 and 1991 showing percent change from 1990. (Source: Census Bureau)

HEADLINE: 2d Wall St. Agency Downgrades Bond Rating for New York State

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 13

 BODY:
Going beyond the censure issued last week by another Wall Street credit monitor, Standard & Poor's today lowered its rating on a wide range of New York State securities, including the bonds regarded as the state's safest investment.
The downgrading will force a state that is struggling to close multibillion-dollar budget gaps to pay millions of dollars in additional interest costs on the sale of new bonds. Just as damaging, it may also affect the creditworthiness of bonds sold by dozens of school districts from East Islip to Niagara Falls. 
 If the state's credit rating drags down school district credit ratings, school boards already facing the prospect of devastating cuts in state aid will also have to pay more to borrow. As a result, several superintendents predicted today that they will have to consider deep cuts in staff and instructional programs or higher property taxes, or both.
 
Far More Damaging
 Because the downgrading by Standard & Poor's affects virtually all of the state's debt, including its general-obligation bonds, it is considered far more damaging than last week's downgrading by Moody's Investors Service.
Standard & Poor's announced about 11 A.M. today that it had dropped the rating on the state's general-obligation bonds from A to A-, the state's lowest level ever. New York, which had been tied with Louisiana for the second-lowest general-obligation bond rating, now claims sole possession of that dubious distinction. Only Massachusetts, with a Standard & Poor's rating of BBB, is lower.
None of the state's school districts were downgraded today. But Vladimir Stadnyk, a managing director with Standard & Poor's who is the chairman of the rating committee who voted to approve the downgrading, said it was possible that some of the 40 school districts with A ratings would also be downgraded after a case-by-case review, which is expected to take several weeks.
Last Monday, Moody's lowered the rating on what is known as the state's appropriation-backed debt but did not change the rating on general-obligation bonds, which are the state's most secure debt instrument.
Unlike appropriation-backed debt, which must be repaid through annual appropriations by the State Legislature, general-obligation bonds are backed by the full faith and credit of the government. Their repayment is the first obligation of the state's revenues. At least theoretically, the repayment of appropriation-backed debt must compete for resources with the state's other fiscal demands.
Standard & Poor's, like Moody's before it, attributed the downgrading to a confluence of factors that included the continuing deterioration of the New York economy, the state's chronic operating deficits and the stalemate over the state budget. The agency stressed that the recurring failure of New York's political leaders to deal with its budget difficulties had fueled a crisis of confidence on Wall Street.
"Failure by legislative and executive leaders to come to a consensus resolution -- not only of the fiscal 1992 financial imbalance but also of the chronic structural budgetary imbalances -- in a timely and permanent manner significantly increases credit risk," said a statement released by Standard & Poor's. "Current and past legislative standoffs provide little comfort that ongoing financial balance is forthcoming."
Wall Street bond traders said the downgrading pushed down bids on outstanding New York State agency securities by as much as three-fourths of a point, or about $7.50 for each $1,000 face amount of bonds.
But given the current low level of interest rates, demand for New York State securities is likely to remain fairly robust, traders said.
 
'A Real Problem'
 "They've got a real problem up there," one trader said. "But there certainly doesn't appear to be much risk that New York won't honor its obligations as they mature."
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo agreed. "The notion that this suggests that maybe you won't pay your debts is a joke when it comes to New York," he said. "But there are a lot of things that are dumb that you have to accommodate in this life, and this is one we should have been able to accommodate."
Almost ritualistically, state officials reacted to the downgrading with news releases and news conferences but offered little hope that the budget impasse would be resolved anytime soon. For more than two months, Mr. Cuomo has been negotiating unsuccessfully with the leaders of the Legislature to craft a plan to close the $875 million gap in this year's $30 billion budget and the gap of nearly $4 billion projected for the next fiscal year, which begins on April 1.
Mr. Cuomo called the downgrading "a disgrace" and said it seemed likely the state would end its fiscal year on March 31 with a budget deficit of nearly $500 million. He said the state would have to borrow for the fourth consecutive year to erase the deficit, adding to the accumulated debt disparaged by Standard & Poor's.
Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin, a Queens Democrat, said, "For four weeks, I've been warning that the state was sliding closer to the brink. Today is the brink."
And the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, a Republican from Oyster Bay, L.I., used the downgrading to reinforce his call for deeper cuts in the state's Medicaid program. He said the downgradings encouraged him to stand his ground rather than to compromise. "The time to say no is now," Mr. Marino said.
Because state aid to schools can be used to repay school district bonds if school boards cannot afford to do so, rating agencies use the state's credit rating as a floor for district ratings, Mr. Stadnyk of Standard & Poor's said. As of today, that floor was lowered from A to A-, and Standard & Poor's began evaluating the ratings of the 40 districts with A ratings.
School officials around the state expressed frustration that they might become the innocent victims of the state's financial failures.
 
'No Fault of Their Own'
 "The school boards are being told that because the Legislature and Governor can't get their houses in order, they're going to get hit through no fault of their own," said Louis Grumet, the executive director of the New York State School Boards Association.
Anthony J. Napoli, the Superintendent of the Port Chester-Rye Union Free School District in Westchester County, which has an A rating, said a downgrading would be a capping blow in a year when his district's state aid was cut by 30 percent and property tax revenues were softened by a weak real-estate market.
"I can't keep going back and raising property taxes," he said. "So we'll have to cut staff, physical maintenance, sports programs and programs for gifted students."

HEADLINE: Israel Is Said to Expect Less In Loan Aid for Immigrants

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Jan. 13

 BODY:
Israel's leaders are increasingly resigned to the likelihood that they will have to settle for far less than the $10 billion in United States loan guarantees that they are seeking to resettle new immigrants, Government officials and representatives of American Jewish groups say.
Although the Israelis are formally pressing ahead with their request -- $2 billion worth of annual loan guarantees spread over the next five years -- "they are accepting the inevitable," an official of one Jewish group said. 
 That inevitability, several officials said, is that Israel will be lucky now to get a $2-billion commitment for a single year. Even if it does, they said, it will almost certainly have hundreds of millions of dollars chipped away from the total as a penalty for the Government's insistence on building Jewish settlements in the occupied territories in the face of the Administration's vociferous objections.
 
New Taxes Considered
 As a sign that the Israelis recognize they probably will not get all that they want, the Finance Ministry is said to be studying alternatives, including new taxes, to cover additional borrowing costs that the country may face if it does not get the American assistance.
According to one newspaper report, Finance Minister Yitzhak Modai, who counted on getting a full $2 billion in guarantees to keep his 1992 budget together, has asked for a list of the world's wealthiest Jews, so that he can turn to them for help if the United States fails to come through. But an official of an American Jewish group cautioned, "There is no way in my mind that American Jewry can make up this enormous shortfall."
The requested guarantees, which are not actual loans but rather an American commitment to be ready to provide money in case Israel defaults, would enable this country to get relatively favorable interest rates from commercial banks for the billions of dollars it expects to borrow. Assuming Israel does not default -- and officials here insist that that will not happen -- the actual cost to the United States will probably be a few hundred million dollars that must be set aside under new budget rules.
Israeli economists warn that times will get tougher here if the loan guarantees fall through. At the least, they say, it will be appreciably more difficult for Israel to absorb 1 million Jews from the former Soviet Union who are expected to arrive by 1995.
When the aid issue first arose last September, President Bush demanded that Congressional debate be postponed for 120 days so as not to complicate the nascent Middle East peace process. That decision led to one of the nastier disputes in many years between Israel and the United States.
Now the waiting period is about to expire, and although both sides are trying to keep the discussions on a lower key this time, bruised feelings are apparent all around.
For one thing, Israeli officials acknowledge that the mood in the United States has turned against foreign aid. For another, Mr. Bush is strongly opposed to Israel's settlement-building in its occupied territories, and the Government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir has been warned by a series of visiting members of Congress and American Jewish leaders that the President is more fervent than ever on this matter.
But Israel has dug in its heels, thereby potentially inviting the sort of confrontation with Washington that it says it wants to avoid.
If anything, settlement housing in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip is by certain yardsticks being erected at an accelerated pace. Two-thirds of the new houses and apartments anticipated in the 1992 budget are to be built in the territories. Moreover, documents put together by the Housing Ministry and disclosed last week by two opposition legislators show that 21,000 housing units had been started over the last 18 months in the territories and the Golan Heights, annexed in 1981.
Altogether, the lawmakers estimated that the construction program had totaled $1.5 billion and accounted for 25 percent of the Government's public-housing budget for that period.
Leaders of some American Jewish groups are plainly angry with Mr. Shamir, both for putting them in a difficult bargaining spot with the White House and for spending limited resources on an ideological goal that they argue means far less money to resettle newly arrived Jews and to combat spreading poverty in Israel proper.
One widely accepted view is that the Israel is ready to "take a hit," as one knowledgeable person put it. That means going along with a formula that would reduce the value of the loan guarantees by an amount equivalent to what Israel spends on settlements.
According to estimates, a $2 billion program for one year could be cut by a quarter or even one half under such a formula.

HEADLINE: Bush Raises Trade Issue In Bid for Farm Support

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Jan. 13

 BODY:
In a speech laced with patriotic slogans, promises of economic recovery and defensiveness about his recent Pacific trip, President Bush appealed for support from American farmers in the first of several ventures before the start of the Presidential primaries.
Appearing before the American Farm Bureau Federation's annual meeting here, Mr. Bush previewed the themes of his re-election campaign, presenting himself as the candidate "savvy" enough to maintain America's position of leadership in the world. 
 "Do not listen to those prophets of doom, those frantic politicians who say we are a second-class power," Mr. Bush said, nearly shouting in his appearance at the Municipal Auditorium. Proclaiming that the war against Iraq had "lifted the spirits of our nation," Mr. Bush added, "We are the undisputed, respected leader of the world. We are the U.S.A."
 
New Hampshire Looms
 Because Mr. Bush has yet to announce his candidacy for re-election and because he was speaking to a national business organization, the White House was able to list today's trip as "official" and charge it to the Federal Government, not to the Bush-Quayle campaign.
But virtually everything Mr. Bush now does is seen by the White House as part of his re-election effort and today's trip was one of several forays around the country that the President will make in the five weeks remaining before the Feb. 18 New Hampshire primary. On Wednesday, he will make his first trip to New Hampshire and on Friday he will fly to Atlanta to commemorate the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
Clearly stung by heavy criticism of his recent trip, weeks of attacks on his economic policies by Democrats and conservative Republicans and concern about his health, Mr. Bush seemed to be intent on portraying himself in his speech as a strong leader prepared to champion American business interests abroad. But today's speech also underscored some of the political problems facing Mr. Bush in his re-election bid. These include the conflict between his strong anti-protectionist stance and his insistence, repeated here today, on keeping American farm subsidies in place.
While Mr. Bush was warmly received here as he tried to address the economic concerns of American farmers, the difficulties he faces in courting the farm vote also were clear.
Speaking before Mr. Bush, Dean Kleckner, President of the Federation, offered a stinging attack on the Federal Government and on the 1990 budget deal between the White House and Congress. The agreement, which sets specific limits on government spending for the military and social and other programs, is the cornerstone of Mr. Bush's economic policies.
Declaring that "Republicans and Democrats are equally guilty," Mr. Kleckner added: "Our Government's economic policy, if you could call it that, refuses to recognize the need to reduce spending. A year ago, to reduce the budget deficit, a deal was made to cut spending and raise taxes. We got half that deal -- higher taxes."
Mr. Kleckner said the Federal Government should "scrap" the 1990 budget agreement. The President has made clear that while he is willing to renegotiate the balance of spending within budget categories, he has said he is not willing to jettison the overall budget agreement.
 
Anxious About Support
 Mr. Bush's critics have said his visit to Japan last week failed to produce any significant agreements on lowering Japanese barriers to American trade, and the White House launched an effort to counter those assertions as soon as Mr. Bush set foot on American soil last Friday.
Today, Mr. Bush called the visit to Japan "an important and successful step" toward a new trade balance. "Some political critics say I should not have taken this trip," he said. "Wrong! I will continue to fight for American jobs -- everywhere."
Mr. Bush acknowledged that agricultural export subsidies "stifle growth, burden the taxpayer, cost consumers and make industry less competitive." But, keenly aware that he needs the support of American farmers and anxious not to surrender any leverage in ongoing talks aimed at lowering trade barriers worldwide, Mr. Bush said, "I also know that I must -- and will -- safeguard the interests of American farming. I will not let American agriculture disarm unilaterally."
In the global trade talks, the United States is demanding that the European Community end its broad farm subsidy program as part of an effort to achieve a more equitable balance of world trade, but the Europeans have so far refused to make any concessions and Mr. Bush repeated today that he would not reduce American subsidies until that happens.

HEADLINE: G.M. Announces Recall To Repair V6 Engines

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 13

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation confirmed today that it was recalling about 1.5 million cars to repair defective V6 engines.
The announcement comes at an awkward time for G.M. as it tries to win back American customers by saying that the quality of its cars matches that of Japanese autos. 
 The recall had been under way for about six weeks, but was first made public in the Jan. 13 issue of Ward's Automotive Reports, a trade newsletter, which did not disclose how it learned of the action. Recalls are never good for an auto maker's image and are often kept quiet when they do not involve safety.
Among the cars affected by the announcement are several models of 1986 and 1987 Buick, Oldsmobile and Pontiac, compact, midsize and large. The cars are equipped with either a 3-liter or 3.8-liter engine. A G.M. spokesman said as many as a quarter of the engines covered by the recall tended to stall when starting or at normal driving speeds.
With the economy soft and the market share of foreign cars increasing, G.M. and other American auto makers have been trying to persuade shoppers that the latest models erase the perceived gap in quality between American and Japanese vehicles.
The American auto makers are also using that argument in pressing for more access to the Japanese market. The chairmen of the three big auto makers asserted last week in Japan that that country's inspection and certification procedures are used to exclude American autos. Japan says they are used to spot defects.
Back in the United States, Robert C. Stempel, G.M.'s chairman, and other company executives have complained that many Americans will not consider buying G.M. models because of defects in those sold in the mid-1980's and earlier.
The recall also underscores a problem for consumers: How can they be sure that current G.M. models will not develop similar problems? In the case of the flawed V6 engines, a G.M. spokesman said, the problem was not determined until July 1990, nearly five years after the first were built.
The company initially fixed the defective engines under its warranty program. But the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration recently said that sudden stalling could be a safety problem, and the company decided to notify all owners of the cars affected that the engines would be inspected and repaired without charge.
The offer of repair or reimbursement expires at the end of 1992, or when the vehicle has 100,000 miles, whichever comes first.

HEADLINE: U.S. Reviewing Ways to Prevent Flipping of Cars

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13

 BODY:
The Federal highway safety agency has begun reviewing how to prevent thousands of the most dangerous automobile accidents, those in which a vehicle tumbles out of control and rolls over.
The review could lead to mandatory design changes in many small cars, pickup trucks and sporty off-road vehicles. Depending on what changes are required, prices of these vehicles, including some of Detroit's hottest sellers in recent years, could increase by hundreds of dollars. Some models might even be discontinued if they could not be made safer. 
 About 10,000 people are killed every year in the United States when the vehicles in which they are riding overturn. That number has been growing as cars get smaller and light trucks become more popular.
 
Lifesaving Measure
 Some lifesaving measures might be relatively straightforward, like requiring automatic seat belts, which alone might eliminate more than half of the fatalities in cases when people are flung from tumbling cars. Current regulations do not require automatic seat belts in vehicles that have air bags, which do not help prevent ejections from rolling cars.
Other measures might be considerably more difficult to devise, and potentially much more costly to implement.
Among the types of changes that could be required are lowering the center of gravity of some cars by requiring wider wheel bases; improving drivers' control over their vehicles by requiring anti-lock brakes; improving the chances of surviving an overturn by installing stronger roofs, and consumer education, perhaps using window stickers to identify the most dangerous types of vehicles.
Despite years of pressure from safety advocates, the Federal safety agency, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, has never before proposed performance standards to reduce deaths from this kind of accident.
 
'Significant Safety Rule'
 "This is the agency's most significant safety rule right now," said Barry Felrice, the highway safety agency's associate administrator for rule making. "It deals with the largest safety problem that we are working on right now."
Brian O'Neill of the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, a research organization in Arlington, Va., said: "Potentially it is very important, but there are many difficulties ahead if the rule making is really going to have an impact. If they are going to make a difference, they have to influence the design of the vehicle. What they face if they issue regulations that are going to have any effect is very, very strong opposition from the manufacturers."
The prospect of new rules is of particular concern to Detroit's three major car manufacturer's, since the domestic industry has been battered by imports as well as the lingering recession. But officials of the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association, which represents the auto makers, said they had not yet presented their views on the issue to the Government.
"Roll-over rule making is inevitable," said David R. Houston, a safety expert at the Ford Motor Company. "The Congress wants it, the consumer people want it, and there is tremendous pressure on N.H.T.S.A. to come up with something."
While the automobile industry is anxious, he said, its objective is not to block regulations, but to "help come up with a rule that is good for the motoring public."
 
New Rules Required
 The transportation law approved in Congress last year requires the safety agency to write new rules within the next two years to prevent such accidents, and although the agency had already announced plans to begin its review and issue proposals this year the topic is so complex that the full two years are likely to be taken. It might then take auto makers years to completely adopt whatever design changes are ordered.
The agency announced its review early this month in a formal notice seeking comments from the industry, consumers and other interested parties. The notice included a broad range of possible measures that the agency wants to study.
The safety review could fuel a continuing debate within the Bush Administration over how far the Federal Government should go in writing regulations when both the benefits to consumers and the costs to businesses are potentially great.
So far, the highway safety agency has published no estimate of either the costs or the benefits of the actions it is considering. That will not be possible until the agency decides how it wants to go about solving the problem.
One possibility would be simply to put test vehicles on a tilting platform and measure the inclination at which the wheels on the uphill side lift up. Under this approach, vehicles that begin to overturn at relatively slight angles would have to be redesigned.
 
Reducing Highway Deaths
 More complicated approaches would make other changes in vehicles so as to prevent the skidding that often leads to overturns, or to protect passengers from being crushed or ejected from a rolling car.
In newly published technical documents, the agency calls such accidents "the most dangerous collision type" based on the rate of death and serious injury per person involved.
Among the leading causes of highway deaths, only head-on collisions and accidents involving alcohol rival overturns, safety experts say.
The highway agency has taken on the problem at a time of significant progress in reducing highway deaths. Through a combination of new laws, driver education, road improvements and changes in car designs, among other things, the highway death rate in the United States dropped 7 percent last year, to about 41,000. That was the lowest number of highway deaths since 1962.
The agency is not considering simply outlawing types of vehicles that tend to overturn most easily, like all-terrain vehicles. But it could order drastic design changes in the worst cases. It might also decide to set performance standards only for some types of vehicles, exempting those that are already less likely to overturn.
"We are taking a kind of scattergun approach," said Mr. Felrice of the safety agency. "We really have not narrowed our focus yet.
"We would like to be able to do something in the crash-avoidance area," he added. "To keep the vehicle from rolling over, that is the ideal solution. We are not certain how to do that, or whether we will be able to do so."
One of the leading ideas, he said, is to require anti-lock brakes on vehicles that are known to frequently overturn. The agency is seeking detailed comments from experts on this and other ideas.

HEADLINE: Pension Fund's Housing Effort

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 13

 BODY:
California's public-employee pension fund said today that it would invest up to $225 million to build homes as part of an effort to help the state's depressed housing market.
Officials said it was the first time the California Public Employees Retirement System, the nation's largest public pension fund, with an investment portfolio of nearly $60 billion, had budgeted money to invest in residential real estate, a field that pension funds generally avoid. 
 The decision illustrated the growing pressure on funds from elected officials to invest in their own states.
"Housing is the backbone of the California economy, and this investment means more construction jobs," said Gray Davis, the state controller, a Democrat who is a member of the fund's board.

HEADLINE: Big Denver Cattle Show Reflects Sunset on West

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DENVER, Jan. 13

 BODY:
Al Rose, a tall, craggy 66-year-old rancher, leaned an elbow against a fence post and watched a handsome Hereford strut past the reviewing stand at the National Western Stock Show. "Used to be, almost everyone I knew was a rancher," he said, tipping back his Stetson. "But there just aren't many of us left out in the country anymore."
But even as so many cowboys fade from the range, this most powerful of American myths only grows stronger. To many urbanites who rope their paychecks from behind computer terminals and glass-covered desks, the ranch has become the nation's most exotic place. 
 This year, the 14-day Denver Livestock and Rodeo Show, which has been called the "Super Bowl of cattle shows," aims to surpass last year's record attendance of more than 500,000. And across the country, there is an extraordinary appetite for rural and western symbols.
Garth Brooks, the country singer, sold more albums last year than any other musician in any category. The movie "City Slickers" and "Dances with Wolves" were wildly successful. Old West tourism has been shattering records. The recent spring fashion show in Europe was replete with "Cowgirl Chic."
"No question about it, the American cowboy is riding back at full bore," said Jack Ravage, a professor at the University of Wyoming and expert on western pop culture. "The sociologists would point to the breakup of the family and say we're looking for the mythic, nuclear family. And some people would just say we like antiques."
 
Life Styles Under Siege
 And antiques are just what ranchers fear they are becoming, or something. For all the popularity of cowboys, ranchers say they are under siege. Price supports for farmers have been cut. Environmentalists, who now outnumber ranchers, are pressing for a reduction of grazing on public lands. Red meat and eggs have become illicit substances for many people.
The number of ranchers has dropped by nearly half since the 1960's. And the average age has risen to 59, as fewer young people have been willing, or financially able, to bear the risks and hardships of working the land.
"I'd like to ranch full time, like my dad did, but there's just no way," said Dan Webster, as he ran his hand across the back of Mocha, a South Devon breed heifer in competition at the show.
Mr. Webster, a 30-year-old graduate of the University of Wyoming, works as a computer operator in Gillette. In his spare time, he works as a ranch hand, his first love.
 
The Trend to Bigger
 "When my dad was a young man in South Dakota, you could lease 300 acres for little or nothing, buy a few cows and you're in the cattle business," he said. "But now it's mostly big operations. And the guy whose got grazing rights on public land, his granddad had it. And he ain't giving it up."
The stock show, now in its 86th year -- it was canceled only once, in 1915, after an outbreak of hoof-and-mouth disease -- gives urban dwellers a rare chance to see and smell what real cowboy work is about.
More than 10,000 head of livestock are exhibited, including cattle, hogs, sheep, goats, horses and llamas. Vendors in booths hawk everything from fudge to tractors to shots of whisky. And most city people who come to the show wear cowboy hats and boots.
Jim Carrier, a columnist for The Denver Post, recently described the stock show as a handshake between rural and urban. "Denver extends its soft city hand today to a bunch of callused palms from the country."
Noting the divisions, he added, "We're all westerners, but the gap between Denver and its neighbors has never been greater, resentment and suspicion never sharper."
 
Where Are the Horses?
 The basic mission of today's cowboys remains largely the same: raising cattle. But the business of ranching has changed remarkably. Today's rancher, said Chuck Lambert, an official with the Cattleman's Association, knows less about roping skills and more about embryo transfers and is more likely to ride the range by truck or motorbike than on a horse.
"There are ranches in some parts of the country where the rugged terrain means you've still got to have a horse," he said. "But a lot of ranches in other places haven't had a horse on the land for a generation."
The vast majority of ranchers today run fewer than 100 head of cattle, he said. But only 5 percent of ranches produce nearly 50 percent of all beef in the country. Texas, Nebraska and Kansas are the leading beef producers.
About 3 percent of ranchers run cattle on public lands, mostly on acreage administered by the Bureau of Land Management. Ranchers lease the public land for about $1.89 per animal unit month, or the estimated amount of forage needed for one range cow each month. Environmental groups and some members of Congress, led by Representative Mike Synar, Democrat of Oklahoma, have vowed to try to raise the fees to more than $8, which they say would more fairly reflect the open market. The low prices have encouraged overgrazing, they say.
But that contention is disputed by ranchers like Mr. Rose, who runs about 500 head of cattle, some of it on national forest land, near Longmont, Colo. "We've been running cattle on the land for four generations," he said curtly. "And the land is in a lot better shape now than it was then."
Mr. Rose, whose ranch is seven miles from the nearest road, recalled the solitary old days. "At the end of hunting season, that was the last we'd see any people," he said. "But that was before the four-wheelers, of course. Now they're everywhere. They're running over fences with their jeeps. They're knocking on the door in the middle of the night, wondering where the heck they're at."
For Denver, where an earlier generation of cowboys drove cattle to slaughterhouses and trains headed for Eastern markets, the stock show has been an economic boon. City officials estimate that $80 million is pumped into the local economy during the show, which runs through Sunday.
For many participants, the show is like a family reunion. But 11-year-old Emile Hoffner wanted only to show off her prize Yorkshire pig, nicknamed "Yorkie." Like many young people here, she belongs to a 4-H club.
Her father, Jeff Hoffner, encourages his children to work with animals, a recreation he deemed "a lot better than playing video games."
But Mr. Hoffner, whose grandfather started the farm in Ault, Colo., when he came from Russia, said he does not want his children to follow the family's tradition: "It's just too risky. I want them to go to college."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Emile Hoffner, left, and her brother, Justin, sitting on an equipment box in the pig pens after Emile's Yorkshire pig had a not-so-spectacular showing in the National Western Stock Show in Denver. (Eric Lars Bakke for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Week;
If Clinton Leads Pack, Teeth Are at His Heels

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13

 BODY:
If the buzz inside the Capital Beltway can be believed, the Democrats may well have a candidate before they ever have a real campaign. Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, by virtue of his early strength in organizing and fund raising, not to mention message-making and pundit-stroking, has become the hot candidate of the post-Cuomo period.
Some of the more cautious Democrats note that at this point in 1984, Walter F. Mondale was a much more prohibitive front-runner and former Senator Gary Hart barely showed a pulse, yet Mr. Hart proceeded to win New Hampshire and nearly destroy Mr. Mondale's campaign. 
 Front-runners, in other words, are often bleeders, particularly front-runners who acquire that status with no input from the voters, like Mr. Mondale or Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine in 1972.
Still, the Democrats have constructed not only a primary calendar but also a state of mind for 1992 that could allow a well-organized Southerner like Mr. Clinton to wrap up the nomination early. But quickly settling on an untested nominee from an under-financed, struggling field carries risks of its own.
"It's an extraordinary myth that all the party needs is an early nominee," said Harrison Hickman, the poll taker for Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska. An early nominee might have more time to organize against President Bush, but he misses the seasoning of a tough campaign and is open to the pre-convention jitters that produced the panicky "Anybody But Carter" movement in 1976.
The scenario for an early Clinton victory was fueled by recent polls showing him at the head of the pack in New Hampshire, neck and neck with a neighboring son, former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts. If Mr. Clinton wins there, many Democrats believe, it will be hard to stop him.
The major reason is March 10, Super Tuesday, which involves a large number of delegates, as its name suggests, and has a strongly Southern cast.
Twelve states hold primaries or caucuses that day, eight in Southern or border states. Mr. Clinton's fund-raising edge is also important; because of its sheer size and expensive media markets, Super Tuesday demands super money to compete.
Between New Hampshire and Super Tuesday, Democrats have only a handful of opportunities to change the zeitgeist of the race.
Still, as Thomas E. Donilon, a veteran Democratic strategist puts it, "It's late, but it's early." In other words, it is just five weeks before New Hampshire, but real people are only beginning to pay attention.
This week will be important to Mr. Clinton, as he tries to maintain the image of a sleek front-runner with a national campaign and the ever elusive "Big Mo," as George Bush called it in 1980 before he lost it to Ronald Reagan.
Mr. Clinton was in Chicago today, and will head on to California, Nevada and Florida, then back to Boston and New Hampshire. Next Sunday could be his first, full taste of the downside of front-runner status: Most of his rivals will probably be gunning for him in the televised debate that night in Manchester.
Chief among them will be Mr. Kerrey, who is clearly -- perhaps desperately -- looking for his opening and can ill afford another week of underachieving.
The Senator from Nebraska was widely predicted to be one of the most formidable competitors. But he entered the race late, drifted for most of the fall, and has gone through the kind of downgrading by the press and the political professionals that comes to candidates who fail to live up to expectations.
He has now reorganized his campaign and signed on Doak and Shrum, the consulting firm that produced television ads for Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri in 1988 -- emotional appeals to economic nationalism that ran under the theme, "It's your fight, too."
Mr. Kerrey is on the air in New Hampshire with a similarly trade-oriented message that urges "Fight back, America." The question is whether he has time to pull off this transformation.
Senator Tom Harkin's rallying cry for traditional Democratic values certainly has its appeal in the party, but the Iowan has yet to begin his television campaign in New Hampshire and has shown little movement in the state.
Mr. Tsongas still has to persuade many in his own party that his candidacy has credibility beyond New Hampshire, and former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California is running more of a crusade than a campaign for the nomination.
In other words, Mr. Clinton may be breaking from the pack -- but this has not been the most powerful pack. These are the candidates who entered the race when Mr. Bush was at the top of the public opinion polls; they may be risk-takers, but with the exception of Mr. Brown, they are all novices to Presidential campaigns, all largely unknown, all forced to scramble for money.
Down the road is President Bush, who might look vulnerable now but already says, bluntly, that he will do what is necessary to win. His advisers are expert at raising the risk factor for a little known Democratic challenger.
