HEADLINE: Grocers' Own Fancy Brands Are on the Rise

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
A.& P., like a growing number of the nation's largest supermarket chains, is pushing a fancy new line of cookies, pastas and olive oils: its own.
Store brands have been around for years, but the latest generation is a far cry from A.& P.'s plain, and now defunct, Ann Page bargain line of canned goods. The new ones feature olive oil laced with garlic essence, champagne mustard packaged in handsome ceramic pots and blue corn tortilla chips with sesame seeds. They are likely to be called President's Choice, Sensational or World Classic. 
 Faced with slow sales growth in the competitive food retailing business, grocers are emphasizing their own higher-quality goods as a way to cement customer loyalty and increase profits. In Europe, where food retailers rely more heavily on their own brands, grocers' profit margins are nearly twice as high as those in the United States.
The sharp interest in what one food analyst calls "non-cheapo" store brands is a significant shift for the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company and other food retailers, whose main selling efforts used to be devoted to national brands like Coca-Cola, Ocean Spray juice products and Pepperidge Farm cookies.
Now, many chains like Kroger, Safeway and Von's have been improving the quality and packaging of their store brands, which are sold primarily under the chain's name. Managers often set up signs that encourage shoppers to save money by buying the store brand of pasta sauce instead of the more expensive Ragu.
Profit margins are 4 percent higher on store brands than on name-brand products, A.& P. executives said. A.& P.'s Master Choice cookies cost 10 cents to 20 cents less than Pepperidge Farm cookies, which are about $2 a bag.
The shift has created tensions between grocers and food manufacturers, who are seeing their products shoved aside to give store brands more favorable displays.
"They are zeroing in on our section," said Mick Sidari, vice president of biscuit sales for Pepperidge Farm, a unit of the Campbell Soup Company. "Obviously, it changes the relationship somewhat."
While denying that store brands have nibbled away business, Pepperidge Farm executives complain that store brands are taking over valuable shelf space. Mr. Sidari said Pepperidge Farm cookies had been moved from the most desirable eye-level shelves to make room for A.& P.'s shortbread cookies. "It was somewhat upsetting," he said, to walk into a supermarket and see that his cookies had literally been moved down a notch.
The weak economy has lifted sales of all store or private-label brands, including the inexpensive versions of dog food, paper towels and juice. These low-cost store brands still outnumber their more expensive cousins, although no statistics are kept on the size of the market for premium store brands.
For the third quarter of 1991, unit sales of coffees, cereal and other dry grocery products increased a meager four-tenths of 1 percent, compared with the corresponding period the year before, according to the latest data available from Nielsen Marketing Research in Chicago. For the same period, however, private-label sales rose 4.1 percent.
In all, store brands accounted for 13 percent of supermarket sales, for the year ending June 30, 1991, the most recent period for which data are available, according to Information Resources Inc., a Chicago market research firm. During that period, sales of private-label goods grew by 6 percent, nearly twice as quickly as those of the overall industry, the firm said. Overall supermarket sales increased by only 3.65 percent during that period.
 
Similarity to the 50's Seen
 Some marketing experts are convinced that consumer interest in private-label brands will outlast the recession. "People don't want to pay for the enormous marketing cost of branded products," said Sid Doolittle, a marketing consultant in Chicago. "The times are getting much more like they were in the 50's, when private label was very popular."
In one telling sign of the growing interest in store brands, Wal-Mart Stores Inc. recently started selling colas, juice and cookies under its own Sam's American Choice label.
The Finast chain recently introduced its Sensational brand in the New York area. Wegman's in upstate New York and Topco's in the Midwest with its World Classic line also offer high-quality store brands.
Gary M. Giblen, a supermarket analyst with Paine Webber, called the move toward improving store brands "one of the most important trends for the 90's" in the supermarket industry.
Supermarkets can charge slightly less for cookies and crackers than national manufacturers can because they do not have to spend tens of millions of dollars on advertising and new-product introductions. Another expense that grocers avoid is the fee for new-product placement that most stores charge manufacturers to get new products displayed.
To order a warehouseful of pasta, grocers turn to makers of packaged goods, like the Hershey Foods Corporation. C. Mickey Skinner, president of Hershey's pasta group, said he did not mind selling retailers pasta that would compete with his own Ronzoni brand. The reason, he continued, is that he makes the same profit on a case of Ronzoni pasta as on a case of pasta he makes under contract for a supermarket chain.
For lessons in developing their own products, many supermarket executives are looking north to Loblow Companies Ltd. of Toronto, a supermarket chain that makes the top-selling chocolate-chip cookie in Canada. Store brands account for 20 percent of Canada's supermarket business.
 
'The Next Great Trend'
 David Nichol, president of Loblow International Merchants, is now focusing on the United States, where, he predicts, premium store brands will be "the next great trend in the food industry." Mr. Nichol, like many other marketing experts, says that packaged-goods companies have squandered their valuable brand names by blanketing consumers with money-saving coupons each week, encouraging shoppers to buy whatever is cheapest.
Loblow's President's Choice is sold in D'Agostino supermarkets in New York, Bell's in upstate New York and Smitty's in Phoenix. The products will soon be sold in the company-owned National Tea Stores in St. Louis. Mr. Nichol said he would offer the President line to just one supermarket chain in an area.
A.& P.'s interest in private label is a byproduct of the European influences on the company, which is 52 percent owned by the Tengelmann Group of Germany and has several senior managers from Europe. There are 140 Master Choice products, ranging from cookies to tea to bread sticks to pasta and pasta sauce. A.& P. is keeping its low-budget store brands at its A.& P., Food Emporium and Kohl's supermarkets, while it expands its Master Choice label.
"A bit watery" is how Deidre De Blasio, a broadcast analyst with A. C. Nielsen, described Master Choice marinara sauce. But she still uses it regularly. "It's cheap; that's the No. 1 reason I buy it," she said. Ms. DeBlasio, 26 years old, used to buy Newman's Own tomato sauce, but it costs about 60 cents more a jar. Still, when she has friends over, she splurges for Newman's.
A.& P.'s private label business has jumped to 22 percent, from 18 percent in 1990. The company plans for private labels to account for 25 percent, but no more.
"It would be very dangerous to push private label too far," said Peter J. O'Gorman, executive vice president of A.& P. Twenty years ago, the company was nearly destroyed by its attempt to foist too many private-label goods on consumers who were in search of national brands.
Mr. Skinner of Hershey's is not convinced that premium store brands will be a permanent fixture in America's pantries. "While store brands might be in vogue in the early 90's, something else will be the vogue in the mid-90's," he said.

HEADLINE: James I. Loeb, 83, Former Envoy And Organizer of Liberal Group

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
James I. Loeb, a former Ambassador to Peru and Guinea and the first national executive secretary of Americans for Democratic Action, died on Friday at the Alice Peck Day Extended Care Facility in Lebanon, N.H. He was 83 years old and was a resident of Hanover, N.H.
He died of pneumonia, said Ralph Knight of the Knight Funeral Home in White River Junction, Vt. Amy Isaacs, national director of Americans for Democratic Action, a liberal public-policy organization, said Mr. Loeb had been suffering from Alzheimer's disease. 
 Long active in politics, Mr. Loeb was the Kennedy Administration's Ambassador in Peru from 1961 until he was recalled to Washington in July 1962 as a gesture of disapproval against a military junta that seized control in Peru earlier that month.
The military coup ousted a democratic Government and annulled general elections that had been held the previous month. It was a blow to President Kennedy's Alliance for Progress program of aid for Latin America. The charter of the alliance called for economic and social progress in a framework of developing democratic institutions.
United States officials in Washington said that in accordance with policies personally approved by President Kennedy, Mr. Loeb repeatedly warned the military against mounting a coup and later carried out sanctions, including suspending diplomatic relations and cutting off economic aid.
From 1963 to 1965, he was Ambassador to Guinea, in West Africa.
Earlier, Ms. Isaacs said, Mr. Loeb was "instrumental in bringing together liberals, educators, theologians, labor leaders and businessmen" for the founding in 1941 of the Union for Democratic Action, which became Americans for Democratic Action in 1947. He was executive secretary of the union and then of its successor from 1947 to 1953.
From 1953 to 1970, he was part owner and co-publisher of The Adirondac Daily Enterprise in Saranac Lake, N.Y.
Mr. Loeb, who was born in Highland Park, Ill., received degrees from Dartmouth College and Northwestern University and then taught French and Spanish for some years.
His marriage to the former Ellen Katz ended in divorce.
He is survived by his second wife, Anna Frank Loeb, of Hanover; a son, Peter, of Boston; a daughter, Susan Loeb Luppino of Florence, Italy, and four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Voters;
Economy, Not Politics, Is Focus in New Hampshire

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HENNIKER, N.H., Jan. 10

 BODY:
The bulletin board by the entrance to Daniel's Restaurant and Pub displays the usual assortment of small-town business notices for house painting, massage therapy and firewood. Recently the offerings have been updated with a flier advertising a consumer seminar on "foreclosure, bankruptcy and alternatives."
That such a seminar could be useful is a given among the early evening patrons at Daniel's, much the same way falling real estate prices are now seen as normal. Touched briefly by the boom of the 1980's, Henniker is now settling back, albeit somewhat sullenly, into just getting by. 
 "It's not in vogue to be rich anymore," said Lorrie Russell, a mother of three. "It's in vogue to survive."
With the New Hampshire primary, the nation's first, just five weeks away, President Bush and his many rivals are trying hard to convince voters in this recession-wracked state that they have what it takes to lead the country through hard times. But such is the pessimism among voters here that they question not only the candidates' abilities, but even whether a solution exists.
"I think it's basically gone beyond the point of anybody solving it," Jim Brown, a supervisor at a local sawmill, said over a beer. "The way the country usually gets out of a recession is government spending, but with the debt so big we can't do that. I just see things getting worse and worse."
Tom Seavey, a self-employed carpenter, offered a similarly gloomy prognosis. "If a poor guy with a sensible brain got in the White House, it would take five generations to heal what has gone wrong," he said.
With his recent overseas trip, President Bush tried to export some of the blame for the country's economic ills to Japan. But the bar crowd in Henniker seemed to think the problem would more reasonably bear the label "Made in America."
Duane Bishop, a supervisor at the Henniker Hardwood and Pallet sawmill, suggested that the auto executives who traveled to Asia with the President ought to do some soul searching before they criticize the Japanese. "The auto industry doesn't have anybody to blame but themselves," he said. "You've got to look in the mirror when you make $4 million."
Mr. Brown agreed. "I don't understand how Bush could expect the Japanese to buy American cars," he said, noting that he himself drove a Volkswagen.
 
Trying to 'Buy American'
 Inspired by all the talk of Japan, several Henniker residents said, they had made an effort in recent months to "buy American." It turned out, they said, to be surprisingly difficult.
After her husband was unemployed for a few months last year, Mrs. Russell decided to buy only American-made goods at Christmas. The clothes were too expensive, she said. And the electronic goods simply were not as good.
"The sad truth is their technology is better," she said.
Melanie DeWit, a real estate agent, said that she had gone out to purchase a stereo with the intention of buying one that was made in this country. "I went into several places and I couldn't find any American product to buy," she said. "So I bought Japanese."
 
The Boom Is Gone
 Henniker, population 4,151, is typical of the white clapboard towns of New Hampshire that flourished as suburbs spread in the 1980's. To escape higher real estate prices to the south, commuters from Concord, Manchester and Massachusetts built houses in town, supporting a small army of builders.
Now the town is reeling from job losses in distant cities. The commuters are losing their jobs, the building has stopped, and the houses cannot be resold. The only steady work these days comes from New England College, a small liberal-arts college in town.
Looking back on the go-go years of the 80's, Henniker residents express a certain nostalgia for the time before the boom, when the town still counted cows among its residents.
"I think people have forgotten the simple life," said Daniel Carmichael, a telephone repairman, who was having a cup of coffee at the fountain of Henniker Pharmacy. "We used to have 10-party lines, five farms on each line," he said. "Now not only are the 10-party lines gone, so are the farms. The last one sold out last year."
As for the coming election, Mr. Carmichael said that he would probably not focus on it until the summer. When he did, he said, his main concern would be health care.
Mr. Carmichael said he and his wife had recently taken out supplemental health insurance to provide coverage if one of them ever needed long-term care. "It's almost to the point where you have to be working till the day you die," he said.
Although there is only a little more than a month left before the New Hampshire primary, most of the residents of Henniker said they did not know whom they would vote for, or if they would vote at all. There seemed to be a widespread opinion that President Bush had been a disappointment, and that the Democrats had not distinguished themselves.
"They're all stereotypical pols," Mr. Brown said. "None of them really impresses me much."
Lisa Rudolph-Cushman, a resident of nearby New Boston who was visiting Henniker, said she would probably vote for Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas in the Democratic primary. "But," she said, "I would have loved to write in Mario Cuomo."
Several people said they applauded Edmund G. Brown Jr., the former Governor of California, and his campaign against the wealthy interests in politics, but they doubted he could get elected.
"I think Jerry's coming from a great place," Mr. Seavey said. "Democrats, Republicans, it's all become a gigantic, business-run thing. A lot of grown men are wasting huge amounts of time."

HEADLINE: D'Amato Cleared in Roosevelt Raceway Sale

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 13

 BODY:
The New York State Investigation Commission said today that it had found no criminal wrongdoing in the publicly financed purchase of Roosevelt Raceway by private investors in 1984 or in Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's efforts to secure Federal tax relief for the raceway.
The commission's report, issued after an 18-month inquiry, was another victory for Senator D'Amato, who was cleared last August by the Senate Ethics Committee after accusations that he had violated Senate rules and Federal laws to help campaign contributors and political associates. 
 Mr. D'Amato, who faces a crowded field of Democratic challengers for his seat, said he was elated by the report.
"It basically says that what I did was right and proper in trying to help a development in my state to create jobs," he said.
The investigation was ordered in 1990 by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo following allegations that Senator D'Amato had helped secure a Federal tax exemption for the track's owners in return for $4,800 in campaign contributions and the hiring of his brother, Armand, as the track's legal counsel.
 
No Evidence of Collusion
 The commission said it found no evidence of collusion between Senator D'Amato and the track's owners, Roosevelt Raceway Associates, noting that the Senator ultimately voted against a legislative package that included the tax exemption. The commission also concluded that the hiring of Armand D'Amato's firm was not connected to the Senator's initial efforts in behalf of the track owners.
Senator D'Amato, however, is not yet free of official investigations into his activities. Allegations that he performed favors for his brother's law clients remain under investigation by the Justice Department, law-enforcement officials say. Federal prosecutors are examining allegations that real-estate developers and other businesses around the country hired Armand D'Amato's Mineola law firm as a way to curry favor with the Senator.
Senator D'Amato supported Federal legislation in 1984 that would have removed the Federal tax exemption on various industrial development bonds, but included Roosevelt Raceway in a list of continued exemptions. The legislation was approved by Congress, although Mr. D'Amato ultimately voted against it because of certain restrictions on the use of the bonds that had nothing to do with the raceway.
 
$52 Million in Financing
 The raceway, once the nation's premier harness racing track, is on 172 acres in the heart of Nassau County. It was sold in 1984 by Madison Square Garden, a subsidiary of Gulf and Western Industries, to Roosevelt Raceway Asssociates, headed by Charles L. Evans, an investment banker and race horse breeder.
The group put up $750,000 and received $52 million worth of financing in the form of tax-free bonds issued by the Hempstead Industrial Development Agency. The track is in Westbury in the town of Hempstead.
Although the buyers had said they intended to continue to operate the site as a race track, they shut it down in 1988, citing falling revenue. At that time, the value of the site as commercial property was estimated at more than $200 million.
Critics charged that Hempstead had been duped and that the buyers had always planned to develop the property as a real-estate venture.
 
Municipal Bond Review Urged
 The state commission, in its report, said it had found no evidence that Roosevelt Raceway Associates had "used fraudulent or other criminal means" to obtain the financing. It also said it found "no evidence that any party to this transaction violated any law."
But the commission said it found shortcomings in the way the $52 million in public financing was arranged and it recommended a statewide review of the practices of local development agencies empowered to issue bonds that may be exempt from Federal, state and local income taxes.
"While we were confident that there was no criminal conduct committed, we did see a lot of problems in this particular case," said Donald O. Chesworth, chairman of the Investigation Commission.
He said the Hempstead Industrial Development Agency "was remiss in its obligation to adequately investigate the raceway project prior to approval of the I.D.A. financing."
But he said there was "no basis" to recommend that Governor Cuomo appoint a special prosecutor.
Joseph N. Mondello, the Presiding Supervisor of the Town of Hempstead -- the office held by Mr. D'Amato before he won his seat in the United States Senate -- said today that he was "delighted with the result that there were no criminal or fraudulent actions."
 
'I See Affordable Housing'
 "This now frees governmental officials to be able to deal with Roosevelt Raceway in a way that will benefit the people of this county," he said. "I see affordable housing for senior citizens and other projects that this area needs and would help pull us out of the recession."
But Peter King, a fellow Republican and Nassau County Comptroller, said he remained skeptical of the investors in the raceway.
"The owners may have relied on the letter of the law in this deal, but they certainly were not abiding by the spirit of the law," Mr. King said. "I felt from the beginning, and I still do, that they never intended to run it as a raceway, but to cash in on the real estate."
Besides Mr. Evans, the partners included Barry B. Goldstein, a public accountant, David Stevenson, a former jockey, and William B. Hopkins, the former president of Roosevelt Raceway for Madison Square Garden.
 
Attempt at Development
 Jonathan Kantor, a lawyer for the group, said, "My clients welcome being exonerated."
In 1986, as racing revenues were steadily declining, Roosevelt Raceway Associates unsuccessfully tried to develop part of the property commercially. After it tried to sell off part of the site, the Town of Hempstead imposed a moratorium prohibiting development of the raceway.
By early 1987, the continued decline of racing and the failed attempt at partial development caused the partnership to decide to sell or redevelop the entire parcel. It redeemed the development bonds that year and replaced them with private financing. The land, its old raceway and extensive parking lots have remained something of a ghost town.
Despite the recession, the property has continued to increase in value, real-estate brokers say. It is in the middle of a commercial area surrounded by shopping malls, restaurants and small businesses.
Senator D'Amato faces re-election in November. Likely Democratic challengers include former United States Representative Geraldine R. Ferraro, Representative Robert A. Mrazek of Long Island, New York Attorney General Robert Abrams and Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman of New York City.

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Getting the Most From Each Ruble

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
MINDFUL of Russia's destructively high inflation, the Savings Bank of Russia announced higher interest rates last week for the millions of people who keep their savings in the bank's numerous branches. Rates on passbook accounts went to 3 percent from 2 percent, while the returns on certificates of deposit now range as high as 15 percent for a five-year certificate, up suddenly from 9 percent.
That is not much help when the annual inflation rate is more than 300 percent and a 15,000-ruble account -- for many middle-class Russians a once-handsome sum that two years ago could buy a country dacha -- is now barely enough to keep a family in food and other necessities for a few months. 
 Still, Russians are not rushing to withdraw savings. Wild inflation is still new to them, and they have yet to develop the investment dodges to preserve savings that are so common in the West.
"People got used to government supporting their lives, and now that times are bad, the first reaction is that we have to get the government to take care of us," said Tatyana Zaslavskaya, a sociologist and the director of the Soviet Center for Public Opinion and Market Research. "We still have a great share of such people, but their numbers are declining. Life is teaching them."
The second reaction to the commonwealth's first intense experience with inflation, according to Ms. Zaslavskaya's polls, is a scrambling for ways to increase wages: working more hours, trying to get a raise, holding two jobs, starting a business, trying to get on the payroll of a joint venture involving a foreign partner where wages are sometimes paid in hard currency. That's the good life in a country where a dollar sold on the black market for 100 rubles late last year, is 150 rubles now and might easily be 170 rubles next week.
Only slowly is the Western reaction to inflation and currency devaluation -- seeking out clever investments that sustain the value of savings -- taking hold. Or, as Ms. Zaslavskaya, 62 years old, puts it: "How can I talk seriously about savings at all when my monthly salary is 2,000 rubles, and I am not a poor woman in this country."
Her own savings totaled 16,000 rubles several years ago, enough to buy a three-room dacha or a small car then, but now she has only 7,000 rubles, equal to $47 in American currency. The cheapest dacha, meanwhile, goes for about 150,000 rubles, and in the last two weeks, the Russian Government has allowed new-car prices to jump to more than 250,000 rubles from 20,000.
"What you have here is a psychological tragedy," said Irina Z. Yarigina, a manager at the Bank for Foreign Economic Affairs. "People did not think of interest income on their savings as valuable. It was a gift from the state, which took care of their needs."
Clearly, such blase disregard is out of place, and changing attitudes are increasingly evident, particularly in Moscow. Mutual funds and money market accounts with floating interest rates are still unknown here, but stocks aren't. Frequent television commercials and newspaper ads urge Russians to buy shares in newly private companies, promising big returns.
Buying an apartment is now widely permitted, and owning one is viewed as an inflation hedge. So is holding dollars, purchased on the black market in Moscow and a few other major cities. Now officials are saying that ordinary citizens will soon be allowed to buy dollars legally at some banks. That is a step toward making the ruble freely convertible, but one that could make holding dollars a commonplace family investment.
For the moment, owning dollars or stocks or apartments is limited to the most entrepreneurial. For the vast majority, the response to inflation is more primitive. While a New Yorker can easily buy a mutual fund that invests in foreign stocks or bonds -- an investment that rises in value when the dollar weakens -- a Muscovite buys vodka.
Certain goods have become, in effect, hard currency. Vodka is high on this list, largely because it is so widely consumed, creating a demand that can be counted on to exceed supply. The confidence in vodka's steady value explains why payment in a bottle or two of vodka happens often -- to a plumber, for example, to fix a pipe.
Vodka's value as a currency brought Yuri Kislikov to a line that stretched around a corner outside a liquor store recently. "If I go to a worker and ask him to get me a spare part for my car, he'll refuse an offer of money, but he'll do it for vodka," said Mr. Kislikov, a 34-year-old computer dealer who had already made one purchase of second-grade vodka and was in the line for a second time, to buy two more quart-sized bottles at 58 rubles each. "The money is less reliable than the vodka."

HEADLINE: Castro Cracking Down As the Hardships Grow

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Jan. 13

 BODY:
With Cuba's economy spiraling sharply downward, leading ever-larger numbers of citizens toward desperate efforts to flee the island, the Government of President Fidel Castro has stepped up efforts to crush internal opposition. At the same time, it is seeking to forge greater unity by raising the specter of invasion by the United States.
After a year in which more than 2,000 Cubans escaped the island on makeshift rafts, the largest number of refugees since the Mariel boatlift in 1981, the New Year began with a spate of spectacular new efforts by its citizens to flee a life where annoying shortages have given way to grinding hardship in the wake of the dissolution of the Soviet Union. 
 Less than a week after 34 Cubans dashed across the Straits of Florida in a comandeered tourism helicopter to request asylum in the United States, three policemen were killed in what Havana says was a bungled attempt by five men to steal a boat to flee the island.
With foreign broadcasts that reach Cuba giving abundant play to the incidents, Cuban authorities were obliged to acknowledge their occurrence quickly, rather than allow them to pass unmentioned or note them in terse statements buried in the news, as has often been the case in the past.
 
Three Exiles Captured
 Rather than simply condemning the flight of its citizens, however, the Government has woven the incidents into a campaign already well under way to attack dissidents, warn of a predatory United States and urge greater unity in the face of economic hardships.
On Dec. 29 three Cuban exiles were captured while trying to invade the island carrying small arms and equipment the Government said was intended for economic sabotage. The three were convicted Saturday and sentenced to death by firing squad.
Experts in Cuban affairs say that while the capture of the exiles may have provided a welcome leap in morale for the Government and lent some credibility to its fever-pitch campaign warning of an increasingly hostile United States, Havana's greatest worry is an economy in near free fall whose continued deterioration will only increase emigration pressure and political discontent.
Until recently, economists say, the Soviet Union and its Communist allies of Eastern Europe provided Cuba with over 85 percent of its imports. By some estimates, about 40 percent of the island's gross domestic product was generated by these imports, many of which were obtained through subsidized barter arrangements and outright aid.
With the generous arrangements severed, however, even common goods like soap, rum and cooking oil have become rare luxuries. Meat has disappeared from most diets. Other sources of protein, like fish, which was once plentiful on the island, have also become extremely scarce, and rations of chicken, long a staple of the diet, have been repeatedly cut. Cubans must wait in long lines for virtually all consumer goods, and the supply and variety, never rich, have become scanty.
Television and movie theater programming has been cut back to save electricity. Newspapers have been forced to publish fewer pages on reduced schedules for lack of newsprint and public transportation has become all but unavailable because oil supplies have been interrupted.
"In 1989 Cuba imported just over $5.5 billion of goods from the Soviet Union," said Andrew Zimbalist, an economist at Smith College in Massachusetts who travels frequently to Cuba. "We are looking at a falloff to about $1.74 billion in 1991, and even worse for Eastern Europe. With a drop like that you are no longer talking about economic performance, you are talking about staying alive and feeding people."
In interviews last year, many mid-level officials in Cuba and ordinary citizens said they expected that with the country's crisis growing graver by the month, a Communist Party congress last October would usher in changes that would at least allow more people to work for themselves and farmers to sell their products freely.
Instead of sweeping changes, observers of Cuban affairs say, Mr. Castro has limited himself to calls for Cubans to increase their "resistance" against the United States and to defend the island's Communist system. Experts say he has introduced only relatively minor economic and political changes, including direct elections to the National Assembly, which has never played a central role.
But even the modest hopes created by these changes have been wiped out by the continued slide of the economy and a harsh crackdown on dissent, many experts say.
To build morale, Mr. Castro has spoken repeatedly in recent speeches of the high hopes the Government places in tourism and biotechnology, whose exploitation he says promises to replace the revenues lost from the collapse of former Communist allies.
Economists and political scientists who follow Cuban affairs say they doubt either of these areas alone can provide the lift needed to keep the economy afloat. Moreover, they say, efforts to develop tourism and attract other private investments are hindered by the climate of political repression.
"We are in a situation where one has to weigh what the Government is saying about the promise of foreign investment, tourism and biotechnology against the cost of the debacle in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe," said Marifeli Perez-Stable, an expert on Cuban affairs at the New School for Social Research in New York. "Even if the Government plan could work on paper, it faces problems of motivating people amid such constraints and shortages that it seems beyond realistic."
In recent weeks, the Government has announced a new crackdown on political dissenters and human rights advocates and many have been arrested.
At the funeral ceremony for the three policemen slain in the failed attempt to flee the island, the President's brother, Raul Castro, who is Armed Forces Minister, warned that if necessary Cuba would revert to "revolutionary courts" to try and punish political opponents quickly. Mr. Castro blamed the United States for both Cuba's internal and external opposition, saying of those who cross the Government, "He who lives by the sword, dies by the sword."

HEADLINE: 4th-Quarter Loss Seen By Citicorp

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Citicorp, at the midpoint of a two-year plan to restore its financial equilibrium, said yesterday that it would report a loss of $125 million to $150 million for the fourth quarter of 1991, mostly because of bad real estate loans, but would earn a profit this year.
There is little Citicorp can do immediately to cure its problems with bad loans, but the company said it was making good progress in reducing expenses in its far-flung network of corporate and consumer banking businesses. 
 In addition, the company expanded its four-member top-management team, which John S. Reed, as chairman, continues to head. Pei-yuan Chia, head of Citicorp's consumer businesses in the United States and 36 other countries, was promoted, and H. Onno Ruding, a Citicorp director since 1990 and the Dutch Finance Minister from 1982 to 1989, was reportedly also brought in.
 
Well Known Among Bankers
 Mr. Ruding, who was head of the International Monetary Fund's policy-making arm for much of the 1980's and is well known among bankers, will oversee the corporate banking business in Japan, Europe and North America. That business, which Mr. Reed says is still "the intellectual heart" of Citicorp despite the recent losses from bad loans, was most recently headed by Michael Callen, who is leaving Citicorp. Lawrence Small, who previously headed the group, left Citicorp last year to joint the Federal National Mortgage Association.
The importing of Mr. Ruding "is another move by Citicorp to rebuild its credibility in the marketplace," said James McDermott, president of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, a securities firm that specializes in banks. Mr. Ruding's appointment was reported in The Wall Street Journal, but has not been confirmed by Citicorp.
 
With Citicorp Since 1974
 Mr. Chia, who joined Citicorp in 1974 from General Foods, has headed many of Citicorp's consumer businesses, including domestic credit cards and the introduction of automated teller machines in 1977, which helped pushed Citicorp far ahead of its New York rivals. He comes from a Chinese banking family and was educated in Taiwan and at the Wharton School, where he earned an M.B.A.
Although Citicorp will not issue its complete earnings report until Jan. 21, several big banks have already reported their results. Yesterday Chase Manhattan said its earnings dropped 30 percent in the third quarter. [D7.]
Although Citicorp cut costs by $700 million last year, it remains far from its goal of $1.7 billion in cost reductions by the end of the year. To keep up momentum in the cost-cutting program, Mr. Reed outlined a new organizational plan to top officers this weekend. It is intended to preserve the entrepreneurial spirit the company has cultivated, while squeezing out more cost savings.
Mr. Reed said in an interview yesterday that with the weak economy preventing any rapid growth in revenues and with loan losses remaining high, the shuffling of senior management was needed for the company "to get down to earth" and make the expense cuts.
The four present members of the top management group that Mr. Ruding and Mr. Chia will join are: Richard Braddock, president; William R. Rhodes and Paul Collins, both vice-chairmen, and Mr. Reed. That group will meet monthly with each of the 15 executives in charge of Citicorp's main businesses.
The 15 executives have a mandate to manage the day-to-day operations of their businesses as they see fit. But their success will be measured by the health of Citicorp as a whole, rather than comparisons with their budgets.
 
'Big Cultural Change'
 "This is a big cultural change for us," Mr. Reed said, noting that in the past, cooperation among different Citicorp units "was not high on the list" of qualities that would be rewarded. If Citicorp falls behind its goals, he said, "we are going to pass the hat" among the various parts of the company, including those that might be exceeding their goals.
Intense speculation in financial markets about its prospects led to yesterday's announcement of a loss of $125 million to $150 million. Citicorp's stock, which fell 16.8 percent last year while other large banking companies rose an average of 67.3 percent, rose sharply yesterday and was the most active issue on the New York Stock Exchange. At the close, Citicorp was up $1.50 a share,to $12.
 
Increase in Write-Offs
 The fourth-quarter loss, which will lift Citicorp's loss for all of 1991 to about $450 million to $475 million, was caused primarily by a sharp increase in write-offs of bad loans to businesses. The $650 million of loan write-offs, including about a $125 million decline in the value of real estate Citicorp owns after foreclosure of delinquent loans, compares with a $370 million write-off in the third quarter.
Mr. Reed said Citicorp's holdings of troubled business loans rose by less than the $407 million increase of the third quarter. He added that Citicorp's internal records showed that loan problems were stabilizing, after deteriorating rapidly in the last two years.
Citicorp continues to hold fewer reserves to cover losses on bad loans than many analysts say is needed. The company says it prefers to charge off bad loans as a loss, rather than to set aside reserves, but it is gradually building its reserves, nevertheless. The company said it added $200 million in the fourth quarter.
The combination of a modest $300 million increase in revenues during 1991 and a $700 million cut in expenses meant that Citicorp's operating margin -- the difference between revenues and expenses before the costs of bad loans -- grew by $1 billion during the year to $5.8 billion. The company hopes to increase the operating margin to $7 billion by the end of this year.
Frank DeSantis, a banking analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette who recently predicted that Citicorp's profits would rebound strongly, said he was not surprised by the large write-off of bad loans in the fourth quarter.
"The year was going to be terrible anyway," he said, "and I expect that the write-offs of bad loans in the fourth quarter were exaggerated because they absorbed some losses that could have been delayed." Mr. DeSantis and other analysts were impressed by the cut in Citicorp's expenses, a skill the company had not shown in previous years.

HEADLINE: Candidate With U.S. Citizenship Blocks Clear Victory in Bulgaria

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 13

 BODY:
The surprising third-place finish of a dark horse candidate who holds United States as well as Bulgarian citizenship was being credited today with siphoning off votes that would have given President Zhelyu Zhelev a clear victory in this country's first direct presidential elections on Sunday.
In tallies reported today Mr. Zhelev, the candidate of the Union of Democratic Forces, received almost 45 percent of the vote. Velko Valkanov, the candidate of the Socialist Party, which evolved from the former ruling Communist Party, received 30.6 percent of the vote for a strong showing in a field of 21 contenders. Mr. Zhelev and Mr. Valkanov will now face off in a second round, since neither won a majority. 
 Diplomats and political commentators here agreed today that Mr. Zhelev would have almost certainly won such a majority if not for the unexpected third-place finish of George Ganchev, a previously unknown businessman who captured 16.8 of the vote.
 
Business Bloc Candidate
 A former Olympic fencing champion who ran as the candidate of the tiny Bulgarian Business Bloc, Mr. Ganchev promised to give the freest rein to businesses, arguing that only such policies would insure Bulgaria's economic well-being. Before the voting, his candidacy drew attention primarily because of challenges asserting that he had not lived continuously in Bulgaria for the last five years, as candidates are required to do.
Little concrete information has emerged here about his life in the United States, except some reports that he had studied acting and had been involved in business.
His Presidential campaign and his showing recalled the case of Stanislaw Tyminski, a Canadian businessman who returned to his native Poland as a unknown to mount a presidential campaign. In Poland's first direct elections in 1990, Mr. Tyminski, came in second to Lech Walesa. But Mr. Tyminski returned to Canada after his effort became the subject of ridicule and jokes.
 
'A Joke Candidate'
 Referring to Mr. Ganchev's run for the presidency, a Western diplomat here said: "Sure he's dashing, cavalier and jocular, and he learned to manipulate the camera. He is a joke candidate who turned out to be a bad joke, because he prevented Zhelev from winning on the first ballot."
Bulgarian commentators also offered their analyses of the preliminary results, which are expected to be officially confirmed by the Central Election Commission on Tuesday.
"The results show the new Government's accumulation of negative effects, especially its slow response to the needs of the economically weak," said Dimiter Dimitrov, political scientist at Sofia University.
Inflation in Bulgaria reached 4.9 percent in December, up from an average 3.5 percent in previous months. Unemployment is about 10 percent.
"The problem now will be the struggle for Ganchev's electorate," said Peter Emil Mitev, director of the Bulgarian Sociological Association.
Many surmised that most of Mr. Ganchev's supporters had defected from Mr. Zhelev's camp, either as a result of the gradual fragmentation of the democrats' movement, or in anger over the President's soft approach to former Communists.

HEADLINE: Nonstate Plants in China at Risk in U.S. Talks

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: XIAMEN, China, Jan. 10

 BODY:
As American and Chinese negotiators wrangle over trade issues this month, the credit or blame for China's growing surplus with the United States goes to people like the 1,400 Chinese working at a factory here to assemble coffee-makers and ship twice as many to the United States this year as in 1991.
The workers, mostly young women hunched over assembly lines, earn about $74 a month -- dazzling salaries in China -- and the ethos here is capitalism rather than Communism. The factory is financed by Taiwan, which lies just across the Taiwan Strait from this city in Fujian Province, and there are no political study classes as there are in most Chinese companies. 
 In its three years of production, the Eupa Company and thousands like it have expanded sales to the United States sharply -- and added to frictions about China's estimated $12 billion to $13 billion trade surplus in 1991, the largest after Japan's.
"America is a good market for our coffee makers and toasters," said Tsay Mingshan, a senior Taiwanese manager at the plant. "And it's a very lucrative market."
Yet now Mr. Tay and his eager employees are facing new risks because of the trade disputes between Washington and Beijing, and the possibility of a trade war in which Chinese factories would be the big losers. If by Thursday there is no substantial progress in negotiations now under way in Washington on copyright and intellectual property issues, the United States is expected to impose much higher tariffs on some Chinese products.
If that happens, China has threatened to retaliate against American exports of airplanes, steel and corn. In such an atmosphere, and in an election year in which candidates may point to China's continuing brutal treatment of political prisoners, there would be a greater chance that Congress would succeed in its efforts to attach human rights conditions to a one-year extension of China's "most favored nation" trade status.
The challenge for American policy makers is to force the Communist Government in Beijing to protect American computer software, music tapes, books and videos -- hundreds of millions of dollars worth are pirated each year in China, often by the Government itself -- without harming the private and collective enterprises that make a growing share of China's exports. Many of these factories like the Beijing Government no more than Americans do, and they are considered a force for economic and political change.
A Hong Kong-financed factory in Guangdong Province last year exported one million pairs of leather loafers, athletic sneakers and other shoes -- half of its production -- to the United States. But last month, two of its large American customers canceled their orders out of concern over the trade talks, said the venture's senior Chinese manager, who spoke on the condition his company not be further identified.
"We're extremely worried," he said at his booth in a trade fair in Xiamen. "If the tariffs cut into our sales to the U.S., we'll have to let some of our workers go."
Most of the foreign-financed ventures in China's south may escape injury, and about a dozen other Chinese managers at foreign-financed ventures did not seem particularly concerned.
Washington has indicated that if it imposes sanctions because of the lack of protection for intellectual property, it will pick from a list that includes industries like textiles, shoes, electronic instruments and pharmaceuticals. It will try to select imports made predominantly by Chinese state-run companies rather than by small collective and foreign-financed enterprises.
But many products on the list are made by small entrepreneurial ventures.
Not everyone is worried, and enterprises in this southeastern special economic zone are looking more toward markets in Southeast Asia and Europe rather than the United States. Some believe they can continue to sell to the United States and outwit trade and customs officials even if stiffer tariffs are imposed on Chinese-made imports. Already, some factories evade quotas on textiles by stitching "Made in Philippines" labels on their products.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Boeing Seen Near Selling De Havilland

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TORONTO, Jan. 13

 BODY:
The Boeing Company is close to an agreement to sell its de Havilland commuter aircraft division after a year and half of trying to unload the money-losing Toronto company, the Canadian Auto Workers union said today.
 Merv Gray, chairman of the union's Local 112, representing 2,000 production workers at the de Havilland plant, said: "We're close. We'd better be. If this deal doesn't come through very shortly we're not going to be here." 
 Craig Martin, a spokesman for Boeing in Seattle, said, "Negotiations are continuing." He declined to give further details.
 Mr. Gray said that under the terms of the deal, Bombardier Inc. of Montreal would take a 51 percent stake for $51 million (Canadian), or $41 million (United States), and the Ontario government a 49 percent interest for $49 million (Canadian), or $43 million (United States).
 The Ontario government would also cover up to $100 million (Canadian), or $87 million (United States), a year in losses for three years, Mr. Gray said.
 A Bombardier spokeswoman, Linda Coates, declined to furnish additional details.
 A deal with Bombardier, which owns Lear Jet Inc. through its Canadair Group, would extricate Boeing from what many analysts have said has been a costly mistake.
Boeing bought de Havilland in 1988 from the Canadian Government for $155 million (Canadian), equal to $137 million (United States), in a bid to diversify its product line into smaller commuter aircraft. It invested millions of dollars, but analysts say the unit has been losing between $50 million and $100 million (Canadian), about $44 million to $88 million (United States), a year.
 De Havilland's work force was cut in 1990, to 3,700 from 6,200, as orders for the maker's Dash 8-300 40- and 50-seat planes slumped during the recession. Another 140 workers are scheduled to be laid off at the end of January. Boeing has had de Havilland on the block since July 1990. This summer, a deal to sell the division to Alenia S.p.A. of Italy and Aerospatiale of France was scuttled by the European Community on antitrust grounds.
Boeing's share price gained 50 cents on the New York Stock Exchange today, closing at $48.875.

HEADLINE: Chess

BYLINE: By Robert Byrne

 BODY:
The recession is having its effect on Swiss-system open tournaments in the United States. Entries are down, and since entry fees are almost always the source of financing for this type of competition, so are the prizes.
The American Open at the Marriott LAX Hotel in Los Angeles at Thanksgiving was typical: only 320 players turned out when 500 were needed to sustain the hoped-for prize list. Thus, the winner, Joel Benjamin, was awarded $1,800 instead of the intended $3,000. Benjamin, a New York grandmaster, had scored 7-1 in the eight-round event to finish a half-point ahead of the grandmaster Patrick Wolff and the international master Douglas Root, who tied for second place. 
 Overall, Benjamin played an enterprising brand of chess. His game with the Czechoslovak grandmaster Lubomir Ftacnik (who now resides in Seattle) was one of the most exciting of the tourney.
In blocking with 4 Nbd2 against the Bogo-Indian Defense, White counts on obtaining the bishop-pair after 4 . . . O-O 5 a3 Bd2 6 Qd2, but this costs time and it soon allowed Benjamin to invade on the light squares with 8 . . . Ne4.
Ftacnik prepared to drive out the intruding knight with 12 Nd2, but perhaps after 12 . . . Bd7!, he should have chosen the low-key 13 f3 Nd2 14 Qd2 and planned on a slow maneuvering game. In the method he selected, 16 f4 gave the important e4 square back to Black.
Benjamin boldly reinforced it with 16 . . . d5!, offering a gambit that would yield Black a promising attacking position after 17 cd Nd5 18 Bd5 ed 19 Qc7 Bb5.
Benjamin's 23 . . . Nf6!? was a thematic pawn sacrifice for the sake of achieving iron control of e4 after 24 Bc6 bc 25 Nc6 Nde4. After 26 Kg2 Nh5, both players said after the game, White should have played 27 Ne7 Kh8 28 Rh3 and the outcome would have been unclear after 28 . . . c6.
In the Dec. 23 issue of Inside Chess, Ftacnik castigates himself for playing the immediate 27 Rh3 and underestimating Benjamin's nice sacrifice of rook for knight with 27 . . . Rc6!? 28 Qc6. But it need not have worked out badly: Benjamin said during a recent conversation that after 28 . . . Qg6 29 Kh2 Qg4! 30 Re1 Nhg3, Ftacnik had misanalyzed the consequences of 31 Rg1! Qe2 32 Rg2 Nf1 33 Kg1 Qe1 in his annotations, overlooking the powerful defense, 34 Qc1! Benjamin further pointed out that he would therefore have had to take a draw with 31 . . . Nf1! 32 Rf1 Qe2 33 Kg1 Qg4 34 Kh2 Qe2, forcing a repetition of position.
After 31 Qc2?, Benjamin bored in with 31 . . . Qf4 32 e3 Qd6 33 Kg1 f4! 34 ef Rf4. Ftacnik mentions that he could have tried 35 Qg2 Rf2 36 Rg3 Rg2 37 Rg2 Qf4 38 d5 but that after 38 . . . e5, Black should win.
Benjamin allowed the position to be repeated twice, at moves 38 and 40, in order to gain time on his clock. What prevented Ftacnik from claiming a threefold repetition was that the h4 pawn was still on the board at Move 36.
Benjamin's last move to the time control, 40 . . . Ng5!, was a crusher. On 41 Qd1, there could have followed 41 . . . Nh3 42 Kh2 Ne2! 43 Kh3 (or 43 Kh1 Rg2 44 Kg2 Qg3 45 Kh1 Nf2 mate) Rg3 44 Kh2 Rg2 45 Kg2 Qg3 46 Kf1 Qf3 mate. On 41 Qd3, there could have followed 41 . . . Nh3 42 Kh2 Ne2 43 Kh3 (or 43 Kh1 Rg2 44 Qh3 Nf4 45 Qc3 Qd5 46 Re5 Rg1!) Rg2 44 Kg2 Nf4, winning the queen.
Ftacnik tried 41 Re5, but after 41 . . . Nf3 42 Kf2 Ne5, he could not play 43 Rg3 because of 43 Qf8 Kg2 44 Qf3!, winning outright.
Dazed and defeated, Ftacnik wandered into 45 . . . Qf3 mate.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
$28,300 a Second? A Bit Too Super

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
For many mega-marketers, the Super Bowl still provides a glitzy backdrop for extravagant advertisements and promotions. But others that once thought the game as super for them as for the football teams that play in it intend to sit out Super Sunday this year.
The game's diminution, which began after several ho-hum matches in the late 1980's, has accelerated for three reasons: the relentless rise in the cost of a commercial, to more than $28,300 a second; the sluggish economy, and a sense that Super Bowl hyperbole might be just another example of the excesses of the 80's. 
 For each 30-second spot during its telecast of Super Bowl XXVI on Jan. 26, CBS is asking a record $850,000. That figure is up by 6.25 percent from $800,000 last year, despite the softest television sports ad-sales market ever. Commercial time is still not sold out, as Super Bowl XXV on ABC was not sold out at this time last year.
 
Enticing Sponsors
 Trade publications have reported that to entice advertisers, CBS is offering deals that include spots in the pre- and post-game shows or in its Winter Olympics coverage. CBS reiterated yesterday that it expected all of its time to be sold out, at full price, before the game.
The high cost of advertising, particularly amid a sagging economy, has persuaded a long list of advertisers to seek exposure elsewhere. One result is that some of the marketing battles that had made the game an annual advertising showcase will not be waged when the Washington Redskins meet the Buffalo Bills at the Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome in Minneapolis.
Though Pepsi-Cola will be a sponsor, Coca-Cola will not. L. A. Gear, which skirmished with Nike and Reebok during last year's game, is not expected to appear. Consumer electronics, once a hot category, is losing last year's sole participant, Panasonic. And the automotive category, once fiercely competitive, will have just a single representative again. Last year, it was Audi of America. This year, it will be American Isuzu Motors.
"Maybe the best word to describe Super Bowl advertising is 'throwback,' as in a throwback to the 80's," said Andy Berlin, a principal in Goodby, Berlin & Silverstein in San Francisco, which handles the creative portion of American Isuzu's account.
"The Super Bowl as the great American advertising contest has kind of petered out," he added. "It's not what's happening. It's a habit." Though Goodby, Berlin created a 30-second American Isuzu spot to run during the game, touting incentives on the Isuzu Rodeo sport-utility vehicle, the decision to buy the time was made by SFM Media, the auto maker's media-buying service.
 
Nike Stays the Course
 Given the tough times many marketers are suffering through, those "that look at their advertising on a strict cost-per-thousand basis just might see themselves elsewhere," said Thomas E. Clarke, the vice president for marketing and a general manager at Nike Inc.
But Nike does not count itself among them, he added. "The Super Bowl is the most watched sports event of the year," he said, "and, as a company that made a name for itself in sports and fitness, it's very important for us."
So, at the start of the second and fourth quarters of the game, Nike will run its new 60-second "Hare Jordan" commercial, teaming the basketball star Michael Jordan with the cartoon character Bugs Bunny. In the spot, Mr. Jordan comes to Bugs's aid after the rabbit is harassed by basketball bullies who ignore his greeting, "What's up, jock?"
Those marketers still eager to participate in the Super Bowl contend that consumers consider such advertising "to be an event in and of itself," said Paul M. Bentley, the senior vice president and director of client services for Cramer-Krasselt in Milwaukee, the agency for Master Lock. Once more, the lock company will spend its entire annual ad budget on one 30-second Super Bowl spot.
Cramer-Krasselt says its research has shown that on average 60 percent of Super Bowl viewers agree that the ads they see are more interesting than commercials during prime-time programs. And 54 percent can recall a Super Bowl spot, compared with an average of 23 percent for a conventional commercial.
Other advertisers returning for Super Bowl XXVI include Anheuser-Busch, with its fourth annual "Bud Bowl" mock football game; Gillette; McDonald's, and Merrill Lynch. In all, CBS's revenues from sales of the 50-odd spots is likely to reach almost $43 million, slightly ahead of what industry executives estimated ABC took in last year.
"The Super Bowl is part of Americana," said David Green, the senior vice president for marketing for the McDonald's Corporation, "and participating is one of the ways we at McDonald's reaffirm our relationship with American families."
Another reason marketers give for Super Bowl advertising is that among the game's 110 million or so viewers every year are people other than customers -- franchisees, wholesalers and retailers, for example -- they are seeking to reach.
Though critics scorn the Bud Bowl, which pits bottles of Budweiser, Bud Light and Bud Dry against one another in a fanciful football game, Anheuser-Busch says it is particularly popular with beer distributors.
And before each Super Bowl, Cramer-Krasselt sends special mailings to hardware wholesalers, "reminding them that because we're the only guys on television establishing a brand," Mr. Bentley said, "people will pay a premium for Master Lock."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Except vs. Yen; Gold Prices Off Worldwide

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined on world foreign exchange markets yesterday against all leading currencies except the Japanese yen, which was buffeted by a scandal involving a Government official.
Gold prices declined worldwide. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $353.80 an ounce, off $2.40 from Friday. The Republic National Bank said gold lost $2.50 an ounce to settle at a late bid price of $353.75. 
 Currency trading was slow and choppy as dealers took profits following the sharp run-up in the dollar late last week, analysts said.
Word of the arrest of Fumio Abe, a senior political ally of Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa, sent the Japanese yen lower. Mr. Abe, who is charged with accepting bribes from a company facing fraud charges, is the first Japanese lawmaker taken into custody since 1976.
 
Speculation on German Rates
 Elsewhere, speculation that German interest rates would remain high kept the dollar depressed against the mark. Michael Malpede, a senior analyst with Refco Inc. in Chicago, said the Bundesbank, the central bank, was not likely to lower interest rates while negotiations were under way with a leading trade union.
Talks with a leading union of metalworkers have reportedly stalled over wages. "Psychologically it is not good for the mark to be confronted with labor problems," said Randolph Donney, research director of Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J.
Higher interest rates abroad are negative for the dollar because they make dollar-denominated securities with relatively lower yields less attractive to investors, thereby reducing their need for the dollar.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.45 yen to close at 126.30 yen. Later, in London it was quoted higher, at 126.80. In New York the dollar settled at 127.00 yen, up from 126.90 yen on Friday.
In London the British pound rose to $1.8030, from $1.7925 late Friday. In New York it cost $1.7990 to buy 1, more expensive than Friday's $1.7885.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.5765 German marks, down from 1.5850; 1.4040 Swiss francs, down from 1.4120; 5.3790 French francs, down from 5.4090; 1,190.25 Italian lire, down from 1,197.00, and 1.1493 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1548.

HEADLINE: Careers;
For M.B.A.'s, Dim Outlook This Spring

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
MORE than 70,000 M.B.A.'s will be awarded this spring, but many proud holders of those degrees will find slim pickings in the job market. Recession has stripped away whole layers of middle management, and even companies that are hiring aggressively, like financial firms, are taking experienced people who have been laid off elsewhere. Those who are lucky enough to find jobs will have to settle for less than the $60,000 to $70,000 typically offered by many large companies in the New York area. And many will end up with small- to mid-sized companies.
William E. Mayer, dean of the William E. Simon Graduate School of Business Administration at the University of Rochester, suggested one possible outcome of this fierce competition for jobs. "We see many fewer graduate business schools in the future," he said, citing about 900 currently, which might eventually evolve into 75 or so. "Only the best ones will survive." 
 Last week more then 100 prospective M.B.A.'s from the Simon School were in New York for two days to interview for jobs at some major financial companies.
Mr. Mayer, former chairman and chief executive of CS First Boston, listed some of the companies recruiting -- A.T.& T.; Goldman, Sachs; Salomon; First Boston; J. P. Morgan, and Equitable Life.
This is the 12th year of this type of recruiting for the school. As might be expected at a school named for a financier, many of the students like the idea of taking jobs with financial and other well-known companies in the New York metropolitan area, and they have been trained for the relatively conservative corporate culture of most of the financial companies that interview them
Mr. Mayer discussed the possible glut of new M.B.A. degree holders in an interview at the luncheon meeting.
In fact, William J. Morin, chairman of Drake Beam Morin Inc., the large nationwide outplacement firm, has pointed out that financial companies are "hiring aggressively" this year. But he warns that many are rehiring M.B.A.'s dismissed in recent years because they have the needed experience with the companies. This, he said, can make it harder for the 1992 crop of M.B.A.'s.
Business schools have been trying to adapt curriculums to the new managerial needs -- global perspectives, ability to work with a team, skills that can motivate and manage people, negotiating skills, selling skills and ethics. One group, the Japanese M.B.A. holders, who are often financed by their companies because Japan has few graduate business schools, go back to the same jobs they held before at the same salary. Americans typically expect higher salaries after they have earned their master's degree in business.
One trend influenced by the recession is for M.B.A.'s to take jobs with smaller companies. With this in mind, Duke University began in 1990 a center for mid-size company education and research -- an indication of where it thinks jobs for many of its M.B.A.'s will be in the future.
Even with the dearth of jobs, some universities report that their applications for M.B.A. programs have increased sharply. For example, Anne Sandoe-Thorp, director of admissions at the Fuqua School of Business at Duke University, said applications had increased by a startling 83 percent this year compared with this time a year ago.
"The jump in applications is evidence of the ongoing strong interest in M.B.A. programs in general and the Fuqua school in particular," she said.
She attributed the increase to people planning career changes and to those who want to strengthen their professional background "at a time of corporate layoffs and a sluggish ecnonomy."
John Reddy, who heads the business department and teaches telecommunications at the Wilkes-Barre campus of Pennsylvania State University, said the layoffs of middle managers are expected to continue this year at a rapid pace,
Mr. Reddy, who worked for A.T.& T. for 32 years, said that A.T.& T.'s financial success after big layoffs had influenced other companies like I.B.M. and General Motors to cut back as well.
" A lot of big companies thought that if A.T.& T. had been overloaded with people, maybe they were, too." he said. The breakup of A.T.& T. into regional companies, which have also been laying off personnel, means that "we sacrificed our telephone system on the altar of competition without thinking about the toll it would take in human terms," he said.

HEADLINE: In Russia, Secret Labs Struggle To Survive

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
TEN previously unknown cities of the former Soviet Union have suddenly emerged from the mists of the cold war, prompting anxious speculation about their fate.
The cities, with code names like Tomsk-7 and Arzamas-16, formed the heart of the Soviet military's vast industrial complex for the design and production of nuclear arms. Their disintegration is now seen as threatening to send scientists and materials flying into foreign hands in a new kind of international peril. 
 But scores of interviews with experts in the United States and Moscow, including Russian arms scientists themselves, show that the nuclear cities and their hidden reservoirs of scientific talent are also struggling to save themselves. Lifting some secrecy, they now want to go commercial, embark on joint projects with the West and do nearly anything in their power to survive and avoid falling apart.
These cities are mirrored in America by a coast-to-coast complex built over the decades. Its major sites, Los Alamos, Livermore, Hanford, Pantex, Savannah River, are well known and far less secretive. The American complex employs nearly 100,000 people in 13 states and costs about $11 billion a year to operate.
It turns out that the former Soviet complex is far larger. Its fate poses far larger problems -- and perhaps opportunities.
The Bush Administration recently warned that economic chaos, military decline and high unemployment could shatter the complex and scatter its experts to the wind. Yet some Western analysts, and Russian ones as well, express guarded optimism.
"There is hope," Dr. Nikolai N. Ponomarev-Stepnoi, a high official of the Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy in Moscow, said in an interview. But he added that if cuts in government financing were not offset by new revenue or joint ventures with the West, "there is danger."
Not all experts agree. Russian Government officials often dismiss the specter of atom mercenaries as a scare tactic used by arms scientists intent on stabilizing their salaries in a time of economic discord. Cultural barriers, these officials say, would bar the easy transfer of scientists and their families to foreign lands.
Yet ferment is real. Russian nuclear experts have received job offers from Iraq and Libya and a few are said to be taking up Western posts, in Albuquerque, N.M., for instance. Meanwhile, Russian bomb makers in the secret cities are striving to invent new ways of making money at home. Some of the initiatives would hinder atomic leakage, others encourage it.
A Russian leader trying to save the cities is Viktor N. Mikhailov, a chain-smoking apparatchik who directs the bomb complex from his Moscow post at the Ministry of Atomic Power and Industry. He exudes confidence, even when asking for a handout.
Smiling broadly, he argued last month in Moscow that $400 million recently appropriated by the American Congress for warhead dismantlement in Russia should be given exclusively to his agency, saying his workers "are almost unemployed these days." Some American experts fear any American aid might covertly be used to bolster Moscow's arsenal.
In a different area, Mr. Mikhailov has stirred Western anxiety by encouraging his legions in the secret cities to sell atomic services abroad, including peaceful nuclear explosions for the bulk incineration of chemical weapons and toxic wastes. Western experts fear such nuclear sales will expand to include bomb parts and weapon materials, but Mr. Mikhailov derides that idea.
A favorable outcome from all this is possible, some experts say. But many speak only of lessening the dissemination threat, not eliminating it.
 
'Window of Opportunity'
 Dr. William G. Sutcliffe, a senior physicist at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California, a Federal center for the design of nuclear arms, recently went to Russia to speak with his counterparts there. He said the danger was acute.
"The brighter people are likely to drift away" unless steps were taken to aid them, he said. "The more we get in now, and the better we do it, the greater the chance that we can redirect them toward societal problems. There's a window of opportunity opening that could close in the near future."
The Soviet Union got a late start in the nuclear arms race but then forged ahead in perfecting weapons for the cold war. Its first atomic bomb was detonated in 1949, four years after America's initial mushroom cloud. Its first hydrogen bomb was exploded in 1955, three years after the United States set one off. In 1961, the complex came into its own by detonating the largest nuclear blast of all time, one equal to a staggering 58 million tons of high explosive or nearly 4,000 times more powerful than the bomb that leveled Hiroshima.
By the late 1980's, the Soviet Union's secretive maze of nuclear design labs, reactors and factories had grown enormously, dwarfing the American complex.
 
900,000 Weapons Workers
 "It was several times larger, if only because it had 14 reactors operating" simultaneously to make plutonium and tritium for bomb fuel, said Dr. Robert S. Norris, senior researcher at the Natural Resources Defense Council in Washington and co-author of the "Nuclear Weapons Databook," a multivolume reference series.
A recent Federal intelligence report estimates that the complex now employs some 900,000 people ranging from blue-collar workers running lathes to members of the military guarding nuclear arms. Federal officials said as many as 2,000 people know how to make nuclear arms.
The newspaper Yomiuri Shimbun of Tokyo, citing a secret Russian document, reported late last year that 755,800 experts and their families lived in the 10 top-secret Soviet cities devoted to nuclear arms work. American experts are familiar with only some of the cities.
The Soviet complex was a closed society for decades. But it is now opening to the outside world in a desperate bid for survival, giving a rare glimpse of its inner workings.
 
City Disappeared in 1940's
 Some 200 or so miles east of Moscow, not far from Nizhny Novgorod, or what used to be called Gorky, lies the main nuclear weapons laboratory of the former Soviet Union, Arzamas-16. It is now regaining its former historical name, Sarov. This ancient city was once known for the famous Sarov monastery and one of Russia's most hallowed saints, St. Seraphim. But in the 1940's it was ringed with barbed wire and disappeared from maps as it was turned into the first Soviet center dedicated to the design of nuclear arms. It created the first bomb.
Today the site has 80,300 residents, including scientists, their families and townspeople, Yomiuri Shimbun said. In addition to designing arms, the laboratory has developed powerful lasers for trying to harness nuclear fusion for energy production.
The laboratory's day-to-day activities are run by Dr. Yuri A. Trutnev, a elder physicist who speaks of shifting the lab's nuclear work toward peaceful ends. "The genie is out of the bottle," he said in an interview last month. "Let's use it for the benefit of mankind."
But Dr. Trutnev was quick to add that the weapons legacy would not suddenly disappear. "Realistic politicians say nuclear weapons must be preserved," he said. "That doesn't mean we shouldn't reduce them. But the knowledge and the know-how must be preserved."
 
Plan to Destroy Arms
 At a Kiev meeting on warhead dismantlement in December, Dr. Trutnev outlined a plan to use underground nuclear explosions to destroy the cores of discarded nuclear arms. A single blast could demolish up to 20,000 cores, he said. Such work would give the laboratory a new challenge, at least for a while.
In a similar vein, Arzamas-16 is allied with Mr. Mikhailov in marketing nuclear blasts for the incineration of highly toxic wastes. It has close ties to a new Soviet company, International Chetek Corporation of Moscow, which is promoting the work, and has a team of scientists preparing a bomb for a test. Yet some analysts said political foes of underground blasts might succeed in blocking the project.
Just east of the Ural Mountains, some 25 miles north of Kyshtym, lies Chelyabinsk-70, founded in 1955 as the second design laboratory. Today it has 46,300 residents, according to Yomiuri Shimbun.
Ahead of the times, the scientific director of Chelyabinsk-70, Dr. Yevgney N. Avrorin, went to the Livermore weapons laboratory in California to discuss joint research in 1990. On his agenda was what to do with nuclear materials from old warheads, how to conduct ecologically clean blasts in closed chambers and how to make fuels for laser fusion. To date his efforts have yielded no joint projects.
 
Selling Personal Computers
 More successfully, Chelyabinsk-70 has gone commercial. Soviet television reported last year that it was producing and selling personal computers. And it has perfected the explosive synthesis of very small industrial diamonds, which are now for sale.
"Entrepreneurs and business are the best way to go," Dr. Vadim A. Simonenko, the senior arms designer at Chelyabinsk-70, said in an interview.
Stalin's early interest in the bomb got serious in 1943 when he directed that its feasibility be studied in Moscow. Dr. Igor V. Kurchatov led the work, which included building the Soviet Union's first nuclear reactor. Since then, the Kurchatov Institute, as it is known, has focused on making innovative reactors, including ones for use in space. Though not a secret city, it is facing serious problems as budgets fall and temptations rise to send its nuclear expertise abroad.
Dr. Ponomarev-Stepnoi, the institute's first deputy director, said Kurchatov experts had been recently courted by Libya, adding that the job offers were rejected.
"Our scientists should work in the civilized world, in civilized countries," he said. "There is danger that our people will try to find employment in third world countries if their desire to work in the civilized world is not appreciated."
To help finance its scientists amid growing turmoil, the institute last year agreed to sell one of its formerly secret technologies, a Topaz-2 space reactor, to the Pentagon. But the $15 million deal has been stymied by American red tape.
Dr. Mohamed S. El-Genk, a nuclear engineer at the University of New Mexico, has bought Kurchatov equipment, saying the power of the dollar over the ruble is so great that even relatively small sales can keep Russian teams supported financially for years.
In a sign of the times, Dr. El-Genk noted that he now runs a collaborative research project with Kurchatov and that some of its Moscow experts were soon to take up posts at the University of New Mexico.
Russia and other former Soviet republics have many other secretive nuclear sites, including Krasnoyarsk-26, Penza-19 and Zlatoust-36. New projects at them could easily include the accelerated cleanup of pollution.
Western experts say the fate of the Russian complex partly depends on the American Government, which is still pondering its options and wary of aiding its former foes. The Natural Resources Defense Council, a private group whose Washington office has strong ties to Russian weapon scientists, is mounting a crash effort to finance their research and shift it toward environmental issues, including how to clean up Russia's mountain of nuclear waste.
"The U.S. should hire all of them and put them to work on some hard technical problem," said Dr. Thomas L. Neff, a physicist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who attended the Kiev conference last month. "It would be cheaper than buying a battleship."
Indeed, Dr. Sutcliffe of the Livermore laboratory has calculated that as little as $10 million a year could finance the work of 10,000 important nuclear experts in the former Soviet Union.
But many experts say the Federal Government is likely to balk at direct bailouts, given the reticence it has already shown in buying Russian technology.
"There is hope," said Dr. Ponomarev-Stepnoi of the Kurchatov Institute. "But the American bureaucracy works very slowly. Up to now, there is no agreement between our countries for the peaceful utilization of atomic energy. And this makes any other contacts and programs very difficult."
