HEADLINE: DEMOCRATS BEGIN HEALTH OFFENSIVE

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 14

 BODY:
House Democrats held meetings with their constituents at 285 sites around the country today to publicize their proposals for sweeping changes in medical insurance and to underscore what they describe as a slow response from President Bush.
The events highlighted the emergence of health care as a potent Presidential campaign issue, one that Democrats say they are well-positioned to exploit. In his State of the Union Message on Jan. 28, Mr. Bush is expected to propose new tax incentives to extend private health insurance. But Democratic strategists contend voters will not be satisfied until the Government controls escalating medical costs and expands coverage to the unemployed and all women and children. 
 "We need to hear from you," Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, said at a town meeting in St. Louis. "We've got to look for solutions. We have to figure it out together." In response, people complained that the quality of the medical care they received was poor, that drug companies engaged in price-gouging and that they feared they could lose their health insurance if they change their jobs.
Several in the audience called for a national health plan similiar to those offered in Canada and Western Europe, but just as many warned that a government plan would bring exorbitant taxes and inefficiency.
Those at the meetings around the country were shown a videotape prepared by the House Democratic leadership that depicted a crisis in which 33 million people are without health insurance, small companies are forced to drop coverage or go out of business, and women are needlessly giving birth to deformed children because they cannot afford prenatal care.
 
Significant Missouri Meeting
 "We're the only industrialized nation in the world except South Africa that doesn't guarantee its citizens affordable health-care coverage," says the narrator of the tape. "And yet we spend more per person on health care than any other country." Complete with images of an American flag, an unemployment line, and an empty hospital bed, the tape had the appearance of a slick campaign commercial.
The town meeting presided over by Mr. Gephardt at Charles Lindbergh High School was seen as particularly significant. Mr. Gephardt has been trying to find a consensus among Democratic legislators backing three alternative methods of approaching the health-care issue. Mr. Gephardt's staff workers said he was eager to gauge the public reactions to each plan.
One proposal would provide Medicare benefits to all Americans. It would cover preventive care like standard physical examinations and limit the out-of-pocket expenses of families to $3,000 for an illness.
A second plan, backed by the Senate Democratic leadership and known as "pay or play," would require employers to become the primary providers of medical insurance, either by providing policies to their employees or by paying an extra tax to finance a supplementary public insurance program.
A third proposal would establish a national health insurance plan similar to Canada's. It would replace all private and public health insurance coverage with a nationalized program. But Senate and White House opposition significantly lowers the chances that such a proposal would be approved soon.
When Mr. Gephardt summed up the three plans, only the national health insurance plan was received with hearty applause by the more than 300 people who overflowed the high school auditorium.
"The applause meter is on," he said.
But other people jeered or laughed when Mr. Gephardt suggested that Government could efficiently administer health-care programs.
Ava O'Reilly, a middle-age woman from Fulton, Mo., stood up and asked the Congressman, "When is Congress going to get off its duff and pass a national health-care plan?"
"I don't know if there is a consensus on that," Mr. Gephardt answered. "But a lot of people think we need change."
At a news conference, Representative Vic Fazio, the California Democrat who helped organize the events, said their purpose was to determine what the people want and to pressure the President to support a comprehensive overhaul of health care. He said he doubted that Mr. Bush would sign any of the more sweeping proposals among the more than 30 health-care bills now before Congress, but he added that political expediency may force Mr. Bush to endorse one of the Democratic plans before Election Day.
Representative Benjamin L. Cardin, Democrat of Maryland, held his second town meeting today at Saint Joseph Hospital in Towson, north of Baltimore.
"We know we have a national problem. We know we have to do something about it," he told the packed lecture room.
Representative Cardin proposes a plan offering providing affordable health care to all Americans by building on existing insurance and health-care programs. He says his plan can be introduced without major tax increases by limiting the growth of health- care spendingexpenditures and and through malpractice reform.
Today's town meetings ended more than a week of public consultations among the 268 Democratic House members and their constituents. Several lawmakers said the meetings had demonstrated that constituents around the country supported divergent health plans, making Mr. Gephardt's attempt to find a consensus solution all the more difficult.
"The more you delve into the issue the more complicated it gets," said Representative Peter A. DeFazio, Democrat of Oregon.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Surges Against Mark On Strike Fears in Germany

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar gained yesterday against most leading currencies, especially the German mark, which has been depressed amid concerns about labor strife and a weak economy.
Currency traders said the dollar rose against the mark in heavy trading following reports of strained talks between the Bundesbank and a German metalworkers' union. Also hurting the mark was the prospect of a walkout by German bank employees, perhaps as early as tomorrow. 
 "That probably fueled some of the negative speculation against the mark," said Curtis Perkins, currency trader for the Chemical Banking Corporation.
The dollar was quoted at 1.5930 German marks in late New York trading, up from 1.5765 late Monday. In London, the dollar closed at 1.5905 German marks, up from 1.5720 late Monday.
Another factor behind the dollar's strength is that the Bush Administration and members of Congress are proposing a range of tax cuts, including investment tax cuts and tax credits for health insurance, all intended to put cash in consumers' pockets and stimulate the economy.
Andrew Hodge, vice president for Bank Brussels Lambert in New York, said such incentives would be positive for the dollar. "It not only creates expectations of stronger economic growth but also acts as a substitute for lower interest rates," he said.
He said the dollar followed in step with other markets after the release of a dismal retail sales report, which led investors to conclude the Government would take more action to stimulate the economy. The Commerce Department said retail sales in December totaled a seasonally adjusted $151.2 billion, down from $151.7 billion in November.
The British pound rose in London, to $1.8150, from $1.8030 late Monday. At closing in New York, the pound was worth $1.7840, down from $1.7990 late Monday.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.25 yen to finish at 126.05 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 126.35 yen. At closing in New York, the dollar was at 126.85 yen, down from 127.00 Monday.
Mr. Hodge said the dollar's slight fall was merely a technical correction following the yen's steep fall on Monday because of a continuing political scandal.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.4125 Swiss francs, up from 1.4040; 5.4330 French francs, up from 5.3790; 1,201 Italian lire, up from 1,190.25, and 1.15025 Canadian dollars, up from 1.14925.
On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery was quoted at $354.60 an ounce, up 80 cents from Monday. A late bid from the Republic National Bank quoted gold up 85 cents an ounce to settle at $354.60.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Decline Once More

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday for the fourth straight session on heavy trading, despite further evidence that the economy remains weak.
Reports that retail sales fell for the third straight month in December and that auto sales for the first 10 days of January remained at low levels did not impress traders. 
 Analysts said a more immediate concern to dealers was the substantial amounts of corporate debt securities that remain in inventory.
To hedge the risk to their unsold corporate portfolios, "dealers appear to be selling Treasuries with similar durations to the corporate bonds they are underwriting," said Raymond W. Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides research on the foreign-exchange and fixed-income markets.
 
Leftover Positions
 "Given the volume of new debt that has been priced recently," an investment banker said, "there are some pretty good positions that are still left over."
New corporate debt securities worth roughly $1.25 billion were priced yesterday, following $1.2 billion on Monday. Last week, corporate securities worth more than $13 billion were priced.
Mr. Stone and others said prices of Treasury securities could be expected to rise once the corporate bonds were distributed.
"As guys get lifted out of the corporate paper, they will buy back their hedge," a Government securities trader said. "What is going on now won't last forever."
Despite the recent rise in intermediate and long-term interest rates, Mickey D. Levy, chief economist at CRT Government Securities, said he remained optimistic. "What we are seeing is a correction," he said. "There is still room for a further fall in interest rates. This isn't the end of the recent bull market."
The selloff in the Treasury securities market continued to be concentrated among intermediate and long-term issues. Prices of short-term notes and bills were little changed.
By late yesterday, the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 10514/32 , down 15/32 , to yield 7.53 percent, compared with 7.50 percent late Monday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7.50 percent 10-year notes were offered at 103 3/8, down 17/32 , to yield 7.01 percent. And the 6 3/8 percent seven-year notes were offered at 97 7/8, down 17/32 , to yield 6.76 percent.
Over the course of the last week, yields on 7- and 10-year notes have risen by more than a quarter of a percentage point.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were narrowly mixed. Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.80 percent late yesterday, down a basis point, or one-hundredth of a percentage point. But six-month bill rates rose by a basis point, to a late offered rate of 3.86 percent.
Among the companies pricing new debt securities was the Gulf State Utilities Company, which offered a total of $300 million worth of 30-year first mortgage bonds and 10-year notes through an underwriting group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The 8.94 percent first mortgage bonds, worth $150 million, were priced at $100, or par, 1.40 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 at the time of pricing. Gulf State's 8.21 percent 10-year notes were also priced at $100, 1.18 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7.50 percent 10-year notes.
The securities are nonrefundable. The issue is rated Baa-3 by Moody's and BBB-by Standard & Poor's.
 
Morgan Stanley's Offering
 Meanwhile, the Morgan Stanley Group offered a total of $400 million worth of five-year and 15-year securities through underwriters led by its principal subsidiary, Morgan Stanley & Company.
The $300 million worth of 7.32 percent five-year notes was priced at $100, or par, one percentage point over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 1/8 percent five-year notes at the time of pricing.
The remaining $100 million worth of 8.33 percent 15-year notes was also priced at $100, 1.30 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7.50 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are noncallable for life. They are rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by Standard & Poor's.
Activity in the tax-exempt municipal bond market was highlighted by the negotiated sale of $653 million of serial and term bonds for the California Department of Water Resources. Yields on the serial bonds range from 2.70 percent on securities maturing in 1992 to a maximum yield of 6.10 percent on bonds maturing in 2006. Yields on term bonds range from 6.32 percent on securities maturing in 2010 to a maximum yield of 6.37 percent on bonds maturing in 2020.

HEADLINE: Magic Johnson Urges Bush to Lead AIDS Battle

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Magic Johnson, the newest member of the National Commission on AIDS, met privately today with President Bush and said afterward that the President needed to exercise greater personal leadership in the battle against the disease.
"If he speaks out and says that it's out here and he cares and he cares about our nation in terms of this epidemic and then people will listen, whether it'll be old, young, black, white," said Mr. Johnson, who recently disclosed that he had tested positive for H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. 
 Mr. Johnson told reporters shortly after a 25-minute meeting in the Oval Office, "I am going to try to do my part, but I think that the higher source -- and that's the President -- can have a better effect than I can."
Mr. Bush later said Mr. Johnson "had some good, constructive suggestions," but he did not elaborate. Mr. Johnson said he would return to the White House in about a month to offer detailed recommendations on the role the White House should play in educating the public about the disease.
Asked later whether Mr. Johnson had been critical of his AIDS policies in their meeting, the President responded: "If he was, well, he didn't tell me that." Mr. Bush interrupted a day of political fence-mending and Federal budget deliberations to meet with Mr. Johnson, the former basketball player for the Los Angeles Lakers.
 
Budget Plan Largely in Place
 Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said Mr. Bush had largely nailed down the framework of his proposed budget for the fiscal year that begins next Oct. 1, and had also decided on a proposal to revise the national health care benefits system. Both are to be announced when the President delivers his State of the Union Message to Congress on Jan. 28, he said.
Mr. Fitzwater also said that the White House had "fairly well" decided on a package of economic measures to rouse the nation from recession and that it would also be disclosed in the President's address.
The President may touch on some proposals on Wednesday in New Hampshire, where he will make the first overtly political trip of his still-unannounced 1992 campaign.
Mr. Fitzwater said Mr. Bush would focus on his plans for economic recovery, including the need for changes in the Federal tax code.
The President is also expected to speak out once more on the economic benefits of free trade and the growth of American exports, messages he stressed during a 12-day tour of the western Pacific that ended last week.
Those messages are especially important to Mr. Bush in New Hampshire, where he faces potentially strong opposition in the primary from a Republican, Patrick J. Buchanan, who has sounded an "America first" theme that has proved attractive to some in the state's economically depressed population.
 
More Money Is Possible
 Before his meeting with Mr. Johnson, Mr. Bush said today that researchers had told him that the Government has provided a "good level" of funding for research into the prevention and cure of AIDS, but that he was ready to provide more if asked.
Although Mr. Johnson said at a news conference today that Mr. Bush "needs to do a lot" about AIDS that has not yet been done, he did not directly criticize Mr. Bush's performance on the issue. Rather, he said, both he and the President agreed that "he is going to do his homework, I am going to do mine," and that the two would meet again in a month to discuss how the public could be better informed about AIDS.
Mr. Johnson also chastised the national press for failing to explain the rapid spread of the AIDS epidemic adequately and how individuals could keep from contracting H.I.V.
"The young people, we haven't done a good job educating them. And that's where you people of the press have to come in," he told reporters. "You have to help with this fight because if we don't educate, first, society, which is the grown-ups, then the kids won't be educated. Because the parents are the key to this."

HEADLINE: China's Premier Plans Visit to United Nations

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Prime Minister Li Peng is scheduled to visit the United Nations in New York at the end of this month, Western diplomats and the official New China News Agency said today. The visit will mark the first time a top Chinese leader has been in the United States since the military crackdown against the Chinese democracy movement in 1989.
Mr. Li's one-day visit, to take part in a summit meeting of the 15 members of the Security Council, will coincide with a five-nation European trip that is seen as a sign that China is slowly restoring normal relations with much of Europe. 
 The New York meeting, which is a United Nations conference and does not involve an invitation from President Bush, will give Mr. Li an opportunity to sit down with the leaders of Western countries that for the last two-and-a-half years treated China as something of a pariah for using tanks and machine guns to crush the Tiananmen democracy movement in 1989.
China's Foreign Ministry refused to confirm Mr. Li's visit to either Europe or New York, but the New China News Agency said in a report from the United Nations that Mr. Li would attend the summit meeting on Jan. 31. Western diplomats said plans were now firm for Mr. Li to visit Italy, Switzerland, Malta, Portugal and Spain as well.
The trip is seen as a personal triumph for Mr. Li, a hard-liner who played a central role in the 1989 crackdown and who remains widely disliked at home. After the crackdown, some Chinese leaders were reported to want to move Mr. Li to another position partly because of the difficulty in finding foreign dignitaries who would be willing to shake his hand.
"For Li Peng, I think it's very important, that after all the speculation that he would have to go as a scapegoat for June 1989, then here he is sitting at the top table with world leaders," said a Western diplomat in Beijing. "For Li Peng's domestic political position, that's very good stuff."
This will be the first time that any top Chinese leader directly associated with the 1989 crackdown has traveled to a Western country since those events. Until now, Mr. Li and the Communist Party leader, Jiang Zemin, have been restricted to visits to developing countries and the ever diminishing pool of Communist nations.
Japan, which has moved more rapidly than any other industrialized country to resume links with China, announced this month that Mr. Jiang would visit Tokyo in the first half of this year.
While Europe and Japan are rebuilding links with China, relations with the United States are strained and may worsen. Washington is prepared to establish retaliatory tariffs against Chinese exports unless a trade dispute is resolved by a Thursday deadline, and the result could be a small trade war.
There has been no outcry in Europe about Mr. Li's impending visit, but his hosts in several capitals are expected to raise human rights issues and the hospitality at times is likely to be more proper than friendly.
Mr. Li's trip is scheduled to begin with an official visit Jan. 27 and 28 to Italy, followed by a trip to Switzerland on Jan. 29 and 30. Chris Meuwly, a spokesman for the Swiss Department of Foreign Affairs in Bern, said Mr. Li would meet with Rene Felber, the Swiss President and Foreign Minister, before going to Davos to attend a meeting of the World Economic Forum.
"For us it is considered a private visit to Switzerland, at the invitation of the private organizer of this symposium, and also an opportunity for private talks," Mr. Meuwly said in a telephone interview. He added that human rights issues would be raised, and that Switzerland was unlikely to lift its ban on arms sales to China.
From Switzerland, Mr. Li is expected to fly to New York for the Security Council summit meeting on Jan. 31. Then he is tentatively planning to fly back to Europe to spend Feb. 1 in Malta, and to fly to Portugal on Feb. 2. Diplomats said the main topic in Lisbon would be the Portuguese enclave of Macao, which is scheduled to be returned to China in 1999.
On Feb. 4 Mr. Li is scheduled to fly to Spain, and two days later he is due to return to Beijing.

HEADLINE: U.S.-North Korea Talks Planned On State of Nuclear Development

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
The Bush Administration, concerned about North Korea's nuclear program but encouraged by Pyongyang's recent assertions that it would agree to international inspections and safeguards, is planning the first high-level official meeting to discuss the issue with North Koreans, the State Department indicated today.
The approach to North Korea comes at a time when American experts on nuclear proliferation are voicing doubts about Pyongyang's intentions in signing arms control agreements with South Korea, including a pledge of a nuclear-free peninsula. They are also skeptical of assurances by Kim Il Sung, an increasingly isolated leader in a vanishing Communist world, that he will open all nuclear plants to international inspection, nearly seven years after signing the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. 
 It is widely believed that North Korea would be able to produce a bomb within the next year, and may be preparing to test a nuclear device in a matter of months. Several experts testifying today before the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on East Asian and Pacific Affairs, questioned whether the overstretched, underfinanced International Atomic Energy Agency could be counted on to detect a weapons program in one of the world's most secretive countries.
William A. Higinbotham, a consultant on nuclear materials management and former executive of the Federation of American Scientists, told the subcommittee that North Korea had at least one new 30-megawat nuclear reactor that could produce 30 grams of weapons-grade plutonium every day. The new reactor, unlike an older Soviet one, is not safeguarded by international agreement, he said. But he added that just signing the nonproliferation agreement should not be confused with putting it into effect.
 
Jan. 22 Talks Indicated
 "All the recent publicity about the ease with which Iraq was able to develop a nuclear weapon secretly could well have emboldened the North Koreans to believe that they can sign on the international proliferation safeguards and still proliferate," said Senator Alan Cranston, the hearing chairman.
Newspapers in Seoul, the South Korean capital, reported this morning that a meeting between United States and North Korean officials would occur in New York on Jan. 22. Quoting Korean and American officials, the papers said that the American Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, Arnold Kanter, would meet Kim Yong Sun, director of international relations for North Korea's ruling party.
At a briefing for reporters later in the day, the State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, would say only that an announcement on talks was "very, very near." Until now, contacts between Washington and Pyongyang have been made at lower levels in Beijing between diplomats from the two nations.
President Bush said in Seoul last week that relations with North Korea could improve if Pyongyang committed itself to resolving outstanding nuclear issues.
 
Bases Called Nuclear Free
 Supporting efforts by North and South Korea to resolve differences and move closer to unity, the United States has agreed to an unusual public statement that all bases in South Korea are nuclear free and that they could be open to inspection. The United States traditionally does not confirm or deny the presence of nuclear weapons or nuclear material. President Bush also said the joint American-South Korean military exercises known as Team Spirit would be halted if progress is made on nuclear control.
Leonard Spector of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace said in an interview Monday that "the concessions we made there we never made anywhere else."
If North Korea in return is willing to halt its plutonium reprocessing, and does not move some of its nuclear installations to secret sites, it will merely be stopping the clock, not setting it back, experts say.
"The North can freeze its plutonium program and claim it got something of value in return -- high-level dialogue with the United States and economic assistance from Japan," Mr. Spector said. "Kim Il Sung could decide the optimum outlook is to grab benefits while freezing the nuclear program. It can always be unfrozen later."

HEADLINE: Little Oversight for Big Tax Breaks, Albany Panel Is Told

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 14

 BODY:
New York State and its local governments grant as much as $500 million a year in tax breaks to businesses with strikingly little oversight to insure that such actions create jobs, the Republican State Comptroller and a Democratic State Senator charged today.
Their comments came at a hearing on the state's approximately 150 industrial development agencies, which under state law are granted broad authority to issue tax-free bonds and forgive state and local taxes to attract development. 
 While many of the projects these agencies finance may be beneficial to the communities involved, there are many others for which there is scant evidence that the taxpayer money helped either to create jobs or to attract or retain businesses that would not have come to the area otherwise, Comptroller Edward V. Regan, Senator Franz S. Leichter of Manhattan and several other witnesses said.
 
A Restaurant Relocation
 Among the questionable development agency-financed projects cited today was the relocation of an Italian restaurant from one Schenectady neighborhood to another and the construction of several large chain-owned supermarkets that, critics said, simply forced smaller local businesses to close and resulted in no net increase in jobs.
The agencies, which can be established with state lawmakers' approval in any community or county in the state, have been around for more than 20 years. But in a year in which New York's budget problems have led lawmakers to make unprecedented cuts, the system is expected to come under especially close scrutiny this year.
"This may turn out to be the biggest trough in the state, with hundreds of hogs feeding," said Blair Horner, legislative director of the New York Public Interest Research Group.
 
A Raceway Project
 One industrial development agency in Hempstead, L.I., was criticized in a report on Monday by the State Commission of Investigation for the way in which it put together $52 million in public financing to help a group of private investors buy Roosevelt Raceway in 1984.
The investors had said they wanted to continue operating the track, but they eventually shut it down, and the commission said the Hempstead agency had been "remiss in its obligation" to investigate the raceway project before it granted the funds.
Although it found no criminal activity, the commission recommended a thorough state review of the industrial development agency system. The hearing today, held by the Assembly and Senate committees on local government, focused on that topic but was scheduled well before the commission report was released.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Fills 2 Top Administration Posts

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins has chosen Emily Lloyd, the chief business strategist of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and a longtime transportation and environmental expert, to be New York City's sanitation commissioner, making her the first woman to hold the post.
The Mayor has also filled another vacancy in his administration, naming Herman L. Jenkins, 51 years old, a former college administrator and civil rights worker, to be the city's personnel commissioner, in charge of hiring, job testing and affirmative action policies. Both appointments are to be announced at City Hall today. 
 At the Sanitation Department, Ms. Lloyd, 46, will immediately face a number of problems in the city's giant garbage disposal system, from how to bolster floundering recycling efforts to how to shepherd politically charged plans for building perhaps three new garbage-burning incinerators. Ms. Lloyd, a former Boston city transportation commissioner, will succeed Steven M. Polan, who has resigned.
"She has a terrific sense of humor and she's a very good manager," said Anthony E. Shorris, deputy executive director of the Port Authority, where Ms. Lloyd has led reviews of new business activities for the bi-state agency since 1988, overseeing market research, strategic planning and economic analysis. She also studied regional recycling programs.
From 1984 to 1988, Ms. Lloyd was general manager of the Port Authority's aviation customer and public services division, developing noise-abatement programs for the three local airports. Before that she was a consultant, working on transportation projects in cities around the country.
 
Led State King Commission
 Mr. Jenkins, a former organizer and staff member for the Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s Southern Christian Leadership Conference in the 1960's, helped organize tenants' unions in Chicago and Cleveland.
From 1978 to 1985, he was an official at Queens College, eventually serving as vice president for external affairs, overseeing a major capital campaign and alumni fund-raising efforts. He later worked as an auditor for the Internal Revenue Service, and in 1989 and 1990 was executive director of the New York State Martin Luther King Commission, recommending state policies to further the philosophies of Dr. King.
Since 1990, he has been technical operations director of the Districting Commission, overseeing the computer experts and demographers who drew new lines to expand the City Council to 51 seats. He will succeed Douglas H. White, who has resigned.
Mr. Jenkins said the city's fiscal problems meant he would have to "approach personnel functions with a good deal of prudence."
Ms. Lloyd and Mr. Jenkins will each be paid $110,000 a year. Ms. Lloyd could not be reached for comment last night.

HEADLINE: Florio Urges a New Fund for Economic Recovery

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
In a speech that focused largely on New Jersey's economic recovery and the plight of the middle class, Gov. Jim Florio asked the Legislature today to back a series of plans to create more than 100,000 new jobs and to make it easier for middle-income residents to buy homes and to send their children to college.
"People need help, and they need hope," Mr. Florio said in his annual State of the State message. "Not next year. Not somewhere down the road. They need it now."
 
7 Points by Florio
 He outlined these seven major initiatives that he said his administration would pursue during the remaining two years of his term: 
 *The creation of the New Jersey Economic Recovery Fund, which would spur job growth by investing $200 million in public and private economic development projects.
*The elimination of restrictions on the state Transportation Trust Fund, which would free hundreds of millions of dollars for transportation construction projects.
*The creation of a New Skills Partnership, involving business, labor and higher education, to train 100,000 workers.
*The expansion of the $250 million first-time home-buyers' program, and the development of a home-buyers' tax-credit program, to help the middle class.
*The revision of the health care system to protect people who lack insurance, reduce costs and insure a greater focus on prevention.
*The expansion of the state's college assistance program for low- and moderate-income families.
*The adoption of legislation that would protect the New Jersey shore from overdevelopment.
 
Term Limits on Agenda
 The Governor also supported a constitutional amendment to allow initiative and referendum, or a binding public vote on certain issues. And he urged the Legislature to consider term limits.
Mr. Florio, a Democrat, delivered his second annual message in the Assembly chambers before a joint session of the Legislature, which two hours earlier had passed from Democratic to Republican control.
In the Republican response to the Governor's speech, Assemblyman Robert D. Franks, chairman of the state Republican Committee, accused Mr. Florio of trying to shift the blame for much of New Jersey's economic troubles.
"Over the last several weeks, Governor Florio has suggested that New Jersey's economy and its people are largely helpless victims of some mysterious outside forces the Governor could neither foresee nor control," Mr. Franks said. "You and I know that New Jersey's dramatic economic decline over the past two years was not a random event, but the predictable, unavoidable product of flawed policies and a government out of touch with the people."
The Assembly Speaker, Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, was less combative in his reaction. He said he agreed with Mr. Florio's goal of "getting New Jersey back on a sound economic course and getting people back to work," but added: "I have no doubt we will occasionally differ on ways to achieve these ends. I, for one, was disappointed that the Governor did not endorse our call for a rollback of the sales tax."
The Republicans, who campaigned against Mr. Florio's $2.8 billion tax increase, have said they will roll the sales tax back to 6 percent from 7 percent by July 1.
"Lowering taxes is the best way I know to jump-start the economy," Mr. Haytaian said. "It will be the cornerstone of our economic revitalization program."
The centerpiece of Mr. Florio's speech and his economic revitalization plan was the New Jersey Economic Recovery Fund, which would help finance such projects as the expansion of the Atlantic City Airport and construction of a performing arts center in Newark.
"The fund will allow us to invest in public-service economic growth projects all over the state," he said. "Even more important, our $200 million Economic Recovery Fund will leverage $800 million in private investments."
 
Selling Twin Towers Share
 The Governor said the fund would be financed with money received from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey's purchase of New Jersey's interest in the World Trade Center in lower Manhattan. The first payment is due by March, and Mr. Florio said he would like to have the fund established by then. Mr. Florio said the fund would create 20,000 new jobs in construction and 75,000 permanent jobs in fields from manufacturing to the arts.
Removing the restrictions from the Transportation Trust Fund would create 13,000 more jobs, he said. The five-year trust fund is supported by gasoline taxes, but there is a $365 million annual limit on how much the state can spend, and surplus funds go into a reserve.
At Mr. Florio's urging two years ago, the Legislature lifted the fund limit, providing $565 million a year for transportation projects. Without further legislative action, the limit will revert to $365 million on July 1, the beginning of the new fiscal year, and Mr. Florio said the state would be unable to finance about $200 million in projects.

HEADLINE: All Is Scarce in Trenton Except Republicans

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
A jubilant Republican majority took control of both houses of the New Jersey Legislature today, bent on undoing much of what Gov. Jim Florio and the Democrats accomplished over the last two years, including cutting at least part of their $2.8-billion tax increase. But behind the Republican euphoria lies a sobering fiscal reality: The new Legislature will probably have to find about $2 billion in new money just to keep the budget at this year's level, and the problem could get much worse.
The bleak fiscal outlook emerges from three factors: The economy is stagnant or declining, and the prospects for an upturn are bleak; politically, the Republicans are locked into a tax cut of at least $590 million, and $550 million in "one-shot" revenues that were in this year's budget won't be available again next year. 
 Moreover, one Democratic fiscal expert, Laurence S. Weiss, who led the Senate Revenue, Finance and Appropriations Committee before being defeated in the Republican sweep, predicts that even this year's revenues will fall $700 million short of meeting the $14.7 billion budget.
If that shortfall comes to pass, it will mean that the Florio administration will have to make $700 million in spending cuts, which will not leave much for the Republicans to cut in meeting the budget next year.
 
Counting on Washington
 But the new Republican Assembly Speaker, Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, said in an interview that he was counting on an upswing in the economy to bail the Republicans out. His optimism, he said, is based mainly on the belief that Washington will continue to prime the economic pump with initiatives like the recent 1 percentage point cut in the discount rate.
"We're talking about a budget that starts July 1 of 1992 and runs to June 30, 1993," Mr. Haytaian said. "I truly think we will have pump-priming by the Fed. I also believe we can cut the size of government."
Perhaps. But Governor Florio has already cut 5,000 state jobs, reducing the total to 65,000, and further cuts will be difficult.
Besides, administration budget makers also counted on an upswing this year, and that has not come, nor does it look as if it is going to any time soon. The state's unemployment rate reached 7.4 percent last month, the highest level since September 1983, when it was a little over 8 percent.
And Mr. Haytaian was considerably more somber in tone in his inaugural "State of the Assembly" address today, even going so far as to quote a Depression-era Republican Speaker who was sworn into office nearly six decades ago with a similar assault on "oppressive taxation."
 
G.O.P. Sales-Tax Cut Vowed
 Republicans, Mr. Haytaian has repeatedly vowed, will "absolutely" cut the sales tax by 1 percentage point, at a cost of $590 million. In his address today he also said the new majority would give tax credits to industry to spur research and development and would cut the capital gains tax to induce investment. Both programs would also cut revenues.
And he acknowledged in an interview that tax cuts would certainly mean a no-growth budget and very probably one that is smaller than the present $14.7 million. "We're going to have to do it," he said. "I don't see any alternative."
In addition to "downsizing" government, he said, the Republican majority will look at making some state functions private, like running jails and possibly automobile inspections. "Everything will be on the table," he said.
And he said that despite the ominous fiscal picture, the Republicans might even cut other taxes.
"I want to make something crystal clear," he said. "As far as I'm concerned the rollback of the sales tax is only a first step. During this term, we will look at many other ways to ease the tax burden."
 
Few Details of Repeal
 But while fiscal troubles are likely to dominate the agenda, Republicans also say they are going to attack and radically alter or repeal much of the legislative package Governor Florio and the Democrats pushed though the Legislature in the first half-year of his administration in 1990 -- the Quality Education Act, automobile insurance reform and the assault weapons ban, among other things.
Mr. Haytaian and other Republicans have been short on details of just how they will undertake these changes or repeals. The Quality Education Act, for example, was initially to have funneled some $1.1 billion in new aid to low- and moderate-income school districts, but revisions cut that figure to about $800 million, and caps on how much the schools could actually spend further reduced the total.
But the Republicans say they want to revise the distribution formula and also reconsider the caps. Just what such a revision would mean to individual districts is not clear, and is also clouded by the courts, which mandated additional state aid for poor urban districts in the first place.
 
Insurance Imponderables
 Until the new Republican majority unveils the specifics it has in mind, the same imponderables remain over such matters as Governor Florio's overhauling of the state's insurance system. It eliminated surcharges for many drivers but saddled others with added costs for bad driving records and kicked up a huge protest among the insurance companies, several of which announced that they were pulling out of the state altogether.
And while it is clear that the Republicans will push legislation that would at least water down the Governor's strong ban on assault weapons, it remains to be seen whether they will push for an outright repeal, or simply a bill that would ban certain weapons but allow those who already have them to keep them.

HEADLINE: P.L.O. Ties to Lebanon Are Formally Renewed

BYLINE: By IHSAN A. HIJAZI, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 14

 BODY:
The Palestine Liberation Organization is re-establishing formal links with the Lebanese Government, and has sent a representative to Beirut to reopen the organization's office, which has been closed since Israel invaded the country in 1982.
The P.L.O. representative, Chafik al-Hout, met with President Elias Hrawi on Monday, and said he delivered a message from Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman. The contents were not made public, but the P.L.O. representative said it stressed the need for Palestinian-Lebanese coordination at the Middle East peace talks. Both the Palestinians and Lebanon are taking part in face-to-face negotiations with the Israelis in Washington this week. 
 The P.L.O. official, who was elected to the organization's 18-member executive committee last September, returned here a week ago, apparently to take up his old post as chief of the organization's Beirut headquarters. The P.L.O. office here was closed after Mr. Arafat and his top aides were forced to leave Lebanon along with 12,000 Palestinian fighters after Israeli forces invaded Lebanon in 1982.
 
Low Profile Expected
 The P.L.O. is expected to keep a low profile in Lebanon since the defeat of its guerrillas in southern Lebanon at the hands of the Lebanese Army last July. P.L.O. officials have said the organization has dismantled its military machine in southern Lebanon, leaving refugee camps to be defended by lightly armed militiamen.
Lebanon's Defense Minister, Michel al-Murr, has announced that the authorities will soon collect light weapons from all residents, Lebanese and Palestinian alike.
"Now that it was has gained the upper hand over the P.L.O., the Lebanese Government can afford to be magnanimous about the Palestinians in Lebanon," said a Lebanese Government official who asked not to be identified.
 
Office to Help Palestinians
 P.L.O. officials said a reactivated office in Beirut will primarily try to help improve the living conditions of Palestinians in Lebanon. The Lebanese Government has yet to act on a P.L.O. memorandum demanding civil rights for Palestinian residents. The memorandum asked for easing of requirements for residence and work permits for thousands of Palestinians, many of whom are now facing economic hardship.
With the P.L.O.'s own financial resources dwindling, the organization's ability to assist needy families has dropped sharply, according to Palestinian officials. Oil-producing Arab countries like Saudi Arabia and Kuwait have discontinued subsidies to the P.L.O. because of the organization's support for Iraq during the Persian Gulf war.
Palestinian officials say they hope the Beirut office here will eventually be turned into an embassy, as P.L.O. offices are in other Arab states. P.L.O. bureaus in Arab capitals have been recognized as diplomatic missions for the Palestinian state that Mr. Arafat proclaimed two years ago.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: DEMOCRATS;
Clinton Seizes on Asia Trip To Depict Bush as Beatable

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Jan. 13

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, who was helped by encouraging early polls in New Hampshire and a spate of good press notices, is seizing on President Bush's flawed Japan foreign trade mission as evidence that the Republicans are beatable this year and that he is the one to do it.
In recent days, the Presidential contender has begun attacking the Bush Administration with new vigor, casting himself as the change-oriented candidate and -- as the chief beneficiary of the early political handicapping -- sparing little attention for his Democratic opponents. 
 Although the voters who came here to see Mr. Clinton seemed more curious than committed for the moment, many seemed receptive to the notion he is promoting that electability should be the deciding factor in choosing a Democratic nominee.
And the President's trip to Japan gave Mr. Clinton a handy club with which to drive his point home.
 
Trip as 'an Embarrassment'
 "The President goes to Japan with the heads of our auto companies -- the evidence of our own failures -- to complain to them that Americans are buying Japanese cars instead of American cars," Mr. Clinton said. "The message seems to be: 'Please don't send these cars over here anymore; our people just can't help themselves.' "
The entire trip was "an embarrassment," the Governor said. "It was an opportunity lost."
Mr. Clinton draws appreciative laughter and applause when he makes these digs at Mr. Bush to the highly partisan audiences he addresses in New Hampshire, which will hold the nation's first Presidential primary next month. Many of those who come to hear him speak say they have been attracted by his television advertising and the assiduous advance work of his New Hampshire staff, which blankets targeted voters with mailings and leaflets.
There is little doubt that New Hampshire voters, sobered by a strained economy and unmoved by a campaign that was slow to start, have begun paying attention now that political commercials for Mr. Clinton, Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska and former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts are being aired with regularity.
Staff members for Mr. Clinton, who broadcasts the telephone number of his Manchester headquarters in his advertising so voters can call for copies of his economic plan, said they had received 1,300 phone calls from interested viewers on the first two days the commercial was broadcast.
 
Issue of Electability
 There is little doubt that electability has become a deciding factor for many Democrats in New Hampshire and beyond.
"Basically, I want a winner," said Alan Lambert, a rare-books dealer from Hancock who came to see Mr. Clinton open his Keene headquarters on Sunday. Mr. Lambert said he supported Bruce Babbitt, the former Governor of Arizona in 1988.
But even those who are impressed enough with what they have heard about Mr. Clinton to attend his campaign events say they are not ready to commit themselves yet.
"I'm not terribly impressed," said Rick Levine, who runs a stereo business and lost a race for New Hampshire state representative last month. "From Day 1 they said Tsongas is unelectable, that we cannot even discuss another Greek liberal from the Northeast."
After hearing Mr. Clinton in Keene, Mr. Levine said the Governor did not seem serious enough to warrant all the favorable attention he had received. "I'm really aggravated that they're all treating him as though this is the de facto candidate and that after New Hampshire all of the other guys will fall by the wayside," he said "The media is spoon-feeding us a candidate."
The legendary political contrariness of New Hampshire voters is not the only potential problem awaiting Mr. Clinton. In a state where state-imposed taxes are considered anathema, he has stumbled on occasion when he begins talking about how to pay for improved education.
Arkansas uses state taxes to support local education, while New Hampshire relies on local property taxes. In his speeches, Mr. Clinton stops just short of criticizing New Hampshire's economic policies, but he points out the inequities he sees in a financing formula that allows people who live in more affluent areas to afford better schools.
Mr. Clinton's standing as the candidate to beat has been enhanced in recent days by attacks from his Democratic competitors. Mr. Kerrey, for example, has harshly criticized the Governor for offering only the broad-brush outlines of a health-care plan.

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales, Weak in '91, Keep Falling

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Sales of domestically made cars and light trucks remained at recessionary levels in early January, declining 4.1 percent from a dismal period a year earlier, the auto makers reported today.
The seasonally adjusted annual selling rate for the period was 5.3 million -- among the lowest figures reported in 1991 -- reinforcing a bleak outlook for the industry. 
 "It's hard to see anything positive in these numbers," said Scott Merlis, an analyst with Morgan Stanley. He said sales to commercial fleets overstated the sales reports, suggesting even weaker retail demand. Reflecting the sluggish market, the Ford Motor Company added $1,500 cash rebates on Lincolns; it extended sales incentives for some other models.
In the Jan. 1-10 period, auto makers with North American assembly plants -- which are considered domestic plants -- sold a total of 171,944 cars and light trucks. Car sales dropped sharply in the period, to 99,227, a decline of 10.8 percent from last year's early-January sales. The periods had eight selling days both this year and last.
Truck sales in the latest period rose 6.7 percent, however, to 72,717. The gain surprised some analysts, who had wondered whether big sales incentives on trucks in December might have raised sales then at the expense of 1992. Chevrolet and Ford compete every year for bragging rights to the title of best-selling truck; Ford won the contest for 1991.
"We are encouraged by the light-truck sales numbers," said Tom Webb, chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association.
Analysts held out hope that several factors, including lower interest rates and the stock market's strong recent gains, might result in positive sales reports in coming months. "With higher net worth, it's just a matter of time before that spills into replacing cars and trucks," said Ronald A. Glantz, an analyst with Dean Witter in San Francisco.
 Several dealers around the country reported mixed results through early January. Ramsay Gillman, who owns 13 foreign and domestic dealerships in Texas, said that his sales were growing but that the gains were almost imperceptible. "We're experiencing a slow and somewhat erratic increase in our business," he said. "There's no boom, no mini-boom, no great road to recovery here."
Mr. Gillman added that some of the improvements had been interrupted by news events, such as G.M.'s announcement last month of plant closings and layoffs, which further dented the confidence of consumers. But he said the new year had also inspired many people with jobs to believe they would remain employed. "They feel like they've been through the worst times," he said.
Business in early January was down 25 percent compared with the period a year earlier at the three Continental Motors dealerships in Fairfield County, Conn., said Joseph W. Hernandez, the general sales manager. Mr. Hernandez said he had noticed that buyers in the wealthy county were comparing dealerships to save $200.
Weekday showroom traffic has also dropped off considerably. "In the last two weeks, people are not coming in the door," Mr. Hernandez said. Continental Motors sells Saabs, Jeeps and Eagles, BMW's and Volvos.
 
 
G.M. Car Sales Off 16%
 In early January, the General Motors Corporation sold 46,355 domestically produced cars, a decline of 16 percent from early 1991. Light-truck sales dropped seven-tenths of a percent, to 29,893.
Ford Motor's car sales rose slightly in the period, to 30,118, a gain of 1.5 percent. The company'struck sales rose 3.6 percent, to 23,886.
The Chrysler Corporation's car sales dropped 27.3 percent, to 10,100, based on estimates by Ward's Automotive Reports. But Ward's estimated that Chrysler's light-truck sales, including mini-vans, rose 34 percent, to 16,800. Chrysler reports its sales on a monthly basis.
The Big Three posted an overall decline of 4.4 percent. Sales of Japanese cars made in North America declined only nine-tenths of a percent.

HEADLINE: U.S.-Japan Exchanges Spurred by Bush Trip

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

 BODY:
While most people were counting the automobiles and auto parts to come from President Bush's talks in Tokyo last week, some Americans and Japanese welcomed promises of increased cultural exchanges and specifically the promotion of Japanese language studies in this country.
American interest in Japanese has soared in the last five years as Japanese investment in, and trade with the United States have increased. In 1991, though, the growth in Japanese studies leveled off, mainly because of a national shortage of good teachers and of funds, according to a Japanese official in New York. 
 The Tokyo agreements reached by Mr. Bush and Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa include pledges on both sides to foster greater Japanese-language training in America through exchanges and grass-roots efforts. Academic exchanges at all levels would be promoted through groups like the Japan Foundation's Center for Global Partnership, which was recently set up by the Tokyo Government.
The official, Seigi Hinata, director of the Japan Information Center, remarked: "People only talk about auto trade, but they should also consider the pledges for the enhancement of mutual understanding and exhanges. "The new exchange program will be very important for American business."
 
Difficult for Americans
 Teachers and other specialists point out that it is much more difficult for an American student to learn Japanese than the Romance languages -- the result of a different and complex alphabet, as well as sounds that have no equivalent in English. Some of these specialists say it takes an American student roughly twice as long to learn Japanese as these languages.
Still, American high schools have shown interest in beginning Japanese language and culture programs, but have been blocked by a lack of teachers and funds, Mr. Hinata said. Under the cultural agreements, he said, his Government would be sending teachers to the United States starting in April, "on a request basis."
The study of Japanese is the fastest-growing language program in American colleges, nearly doubling from 1986 through 1990, said John Cross, director of foreign language programs at the Modern Language Association. He said he expected this to continue, although he acknowledged there were problems in finding trained teachers.
Another specialist said that upward of 12,000 American junior and senior high school students studied Japanese in 1990. But in Japan, all junior and senior high school students are required to take a total of six years of English; 95 percent actually do.
Japanese ranks as the fifth most popular foreign language in American college curriculums -- after Spanish, French, German and Italian.
At Columbia University, which has one of the strongest Japanese studies programs in the country, enrollment in language courses leveled off last year at 300 graduate and undergraduate students, after five years of rapid growth. Keiko Chevray, director of Japanese language training at Columbia, said this was the maximum the university could handle with present resources.
 
Endowments at Columbia
 Hugh Patrick, director of Columbia's Center on Japanese Economy and Business, welcomed the Tokyo accord and noted that in the last five years, Japanese companies had endowed professorships of Japanese literature, religion, economics and business.
"The explosive growth of interest in learning Japanese has been driven by professionals, business people and lawyers, who see it as a plus to their careers," said John K. Wheeler, vice president of the Japan Society, a New York-based private group.
The society's language classes, stretched to the group's limits, found special help last year from one of its supporters, the Toyota Motor Corporation. The company agreed to provide a grant of $1.25 million for the construction of classrooms, a language laboratory and library in an underground wing of the society's Manhattan headquarters. These facilities are to be opened some time this year.
At Berlitz a sharp inrease in enrollment in Japanese from 1987 through 1990 was followed by a decline last year, said Patricia Sze, the director of marketing.

HEADLINE: A.T.&T. to Provide Ukraine's Phone Links

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
A.T.& T. announced today that it would team up with the Ukrainian Government and the Dutch telephone company to build and operate a new long-distance telephone service in the newly independent republic.
The deal marks one of the first big business agreements between an American company and a former Soviet republic since the official dismemberment of the Soviet Union last month. It is also the first time that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company will own part of a long-distance network in a foreign country. 
 As part of the deal, A.T.& T. will own 39 percent of a new long-distance telephone company that will link cities within Ukraine, as well as provide direct connections between Ukraine and outside countries. The Ukrainian State Committee of Communications will own 51 percent of the venture, and PTT Telecom of the Netherlands will own 10 percent.
A.T.& T. officials refused to say how much they were investing in the new venture. But under the agreement, A.T.& T. will supply 13 large electronic switches that it said were worth "in the tens of millions of dollars."
These switches, the bulk of its investment, will be used to route calls over a new nationwide network that will reach about 60 percent of Ukraine's population, company officials said. Once installed next month, the first switch will make it possible for the first time to dial telephone numbers directly in Ukraine, without having to first be connected through Moscow's antiquated and overloaded telephone system.
"We are looking at a market where there is a great deal of pent-up demand," said Randall Tobias, vice chairman of A.T.& T. With a population of 52 million in Ukraine, he said, "we are dealing with a market here, in terms of geography and population, that is just about the size of France."
Industry analysts said A.T.& T.'s gamble was small, relative to its size, and a good one on balance. "The significance of this lies not in its immediate financial impact, because neither the investment nor the possible profits are likely to shift earnings much in either direction," said Gregory Sawers, a telecommunications analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. "The significance is that this is the first concrete step by A.T.& T. outside the equipment business to globalize its business."
 
Looking for More Deals
 Mr. Tobias made it clear that A.T.& T. was eager to attract similar business with other parts of the former Soviet Union and said his company had been in discussions "for a long, long time" with other republics, and both the old and new central governments. Asked if other deals were possible, Mr. Tobias said, "I certainly wouldn't rule that out."
Although A.T.& T. is one of the world's biggest providers of international telephone service to and from the United States, it has thus far had little presence as a service provider within other countries. In large part, that is because most countries have until recently controlled their telephone industries through state-owned monopolies.
Increasingly, however, the regional telephone companies in this country and foreign telephone companies, like Cable and Wireless P.L.C. of Britain and BT, formerly British Telecom P.L.C., have begun investing in cellular franchises, long-distance services and newly privatized telephone companies being sold in Eastern Europe, Asia and Latin America.
A.T.& T. has long been eager to move into those markets. Last October, it signed a deal with the Government of Armenia to supply a switch that will let people make international calls directly into and out of the republic. The company is also building a similar switch in Poland for the Polish telephone company.
In addition to providing long-distance service, A.T.& T. said it hoped to provide much of the equipment that the Ukrainian Government had said it wanted to buy to expand its local telephone network. The Government wants to double the number of telephone lines in the country over the next several years, from 7 million to 13 million.
The Ukranian venture does pose risks. For one thing, much of the venture's income will be in rubles, which have been weakened by the ailing economies in the republics. Although A.T.&T. officials said they will earn hard currency, they refused to explain how. "We have worked out arrangements that will meet our needs," Mr. Tobias said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
McDonald's Executive Named Vice Chairman

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG

 BODY:
A number of McDonald's employees are fond of saying that Jack M. Greenberg spent the last 18 months "getting ketchup in his veins" -- flipping hamburgers, scooping french fries and serving up extra-thick milkshakes. Now, having learned firsthand what it is like to be a McDonald's operator and regional supervisor, Mr. Greenberg has been named to the second-biggest job in the company.
The McDonald's Corporation said yesterday that Mr. Greenberg, who was chief financial officer, had been promoted to the new position of vice chairman at the company, which is based in Oak Brook, Ill. 
 While the 49-year-old Mr. Greenberg, a tax accountant by training, will continue to run the company's finances, he will also begin overseeing the company's legal department, government relations, insurance, licensing, personnel, purchasing, real estate and construction. And his promotion puts him in line to succeed McDonald's chairman and chief executive, Michael R. Quinlan, although Mr. Quinlan is only 47.
For now, though, Mr. Greenberg must focus on reinvigorating McDonald's American business, which is growing more slowly than it has in the past. Part of the sluggishness is a result of the weak economy and intense competition from lower-cost drive-through-only burger chains like Rally's Inc. and mid-priced table-service restaurants like Baker's Square.
In a telephone interview yesterday, Mr. Greenberg said McDonald's decision to reduce some prices and sell combinations of menu offerings, like the $1.99 "Happy Meal" for children, at promotional prices had helped to bring in more customers.
"Things have improved," he said, "but I wouldn't change the message. It is a highly competitive business that we are in and we have an economic environment that has been difficult for retailers in general."
Mr. Greenberg said one of his chief priorities would be to improve McDonald's drive-through service. He said this would require the company and its franchisees to reduce the number of bungled orders, cut the waiting time and open more drive-through windows where customers could talk to a person face-to-face rather than through an intercom.
To make McDonald's employees inside restaurants focus more on customer service, Mr. Greenberg said the company would experiment more with things like paying bonuses to workers who go the extra mile to help customers.
Increasing the company's foreign business will be the other big focus, Mr. Greenberg said. He noted that not only could McDonald's restaurants abroad continue their double-digit sales growth, but their profitability could improve significantly as the company achieved economies of scale in purchasing and distribution outside the United States.
"The opportunities for us internationally are enormous," said Mr. Greenberg, who became chief financial officer in 1982 after being one of the partners in charge of McDonald's accounting at Arthur Young & Company.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Recession Is Foregoing Link Between Newspaper Groups

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
In the American newspaper industry, the right hand, at long last, is about to grasp the left.
The two largest associations in the industry, one representing its business and editorial interests, the other its advertising sales efforts, announced yesterday that they intended to combine forces after more than four decades of separate operations. 
 The decision, disclosed at a news conference at the Pierre Hotel in Manhattan, would merge the American Newspaper Publishers Association, founded in 1887 and based in Reston, Va., with the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, founded in 1913 and based in New York. The boards of both associations, meeting in New York yesterday and Monday, agreed in principle to the merger, subject to the approval of their members.
Cathleen Black, the former publisher of USA Today, who has been chairman and chief executive of the publishers' association since June, has been named chairman and chief executive of a joint management organization that will run the two associations until the merger is concluded.
If, as expected, the members approve the merger, which is planned to take effect on July 1, Ms. Black, 47 years old, would become president and chief executive of what would be called the American Newspaper Association (a set of initials already claimed in the world of advertising and media by the Association of National Advertisers). Leonard P. Forman, 47, who has been president of the ad bureau since February, would at that time become chief operating officer of the new association.
For many years, the two organizations, as well as others in the fractionated industry, whose members belong to more than a half-dozen other marketing, advertising and research associations, have discussed amalgamating. But it took the industry's worst financial results in 50 years, in large part because of a plunge in ad sales not seen since the 1930's, to hasten this merger.
"I've often said that if the newspaper industry were the Balkans, we'd be in World War III now," said John Morton, newspaper analyst for Lynch, Jones & Ryan, a brokerage, in Washington. "They've always had all these separate organizations," he added, "which is outdated in this day and age."
The industry's recession, and the cost savings the merger would bring members in expenses like dues, were not the only reasons behind the merger, J. Stewart Bryan 3d, chairman of the ad bureau, told the news conference.
"The newspaper business has determined that it wants to speak with a single voice," said Mr. Bryan, who is also chief executive of Media General Inc.
Among the issues to be addressed by the new organization, said Robert F. Erburu, chairman of the publishers association, and chairman and chief executive of the Times Mirror Company, will be marketing, First Amendment rights, public policy, technology and diversity in the newsroom.
"The idea that you could pursue advertising excellence apart from circulation excellence, editorial excellence or production excellence, is insane," Mr. Morton said. "These are all interlinked."
Still, the financial issues behind the merger cannot be ignored. The publishers' association now has 1,323 members, Ms. Black said, about 150 fewer than five years ago; Mr. Forman said that the ad bureau, with 633 members, had suffered a similar decline. Though about a third of the membership hemorrhage was attributable to newspapers merging or closing, the rest was because of resignations by members.
While new dues structures are still being determined, Ms. Black said, "for a newspaper that belongs to A.N.P.A. and N.A.B., dues will drop."
Ms. Black said it had not been determined where the new organization would be based. Mr. Morton, the analyst, predicted that it would be in Reston, with an ad sales office in New York. Ms. Black added that staffing decisions had also not been made; the publishers' association has about 150 employees, all in Reston, and the ad bureau about 100 -- 80 in New York and the rest in sales offices around the country.
The proposed combination pre-empts a decision announced last year to merge, effective in July, the ad bureau and six other marketing and research organizations, into an organization called Newspaper Marketing Inc. While details have not yet been worked out, Mr. Forman said, the intent is to have the activities now performed by the six, as well as the bureau, performed by the new association. Among the six are the Association of Newspaper Classified Advertising Managers, the International Newspaper Advertising and Marketing Executives and the Newspaper Research Council.
The merger is the latest significant change in a realm of industry associations and organizations that have been hit hard by the sour economy. The Television Bureau of Advertising, for example, which is that medium's equivalent of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, has spent the last year drastically reorganizing to narrow its focus and reduce costs.
When the newspaper ad bureau was founded in 1913, it was called the Bureau of Advertising and was part of the publishers' association. It became a separate organization in 1950 and was renamed in 1973.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Experts Talk, But Who Listens?

BYLINE: By Robert D. Hershey Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WEEK after week, many of America's best-known economists are being summoned before Congressional committees for expert advice on what to do about the economy. But while given respectful hearings, their counsel is almost certain to be rejected, to the continued frustration of a profession that has long suffered such indignities.
A tax cut for the middle class? A bad idea, say an overwhelming majority of economists of various political inclinations. A tax credit for capital investments? It distorts capital flows, they respond, particularly if the credit is temporary. 
 So, not surprisingly, these items are odds-on favorites to be important components of whatever "growth" bill -- the certainties are that it will sport a highfalutin name and voter-friendly provisions -- gets enacted this year.
For years, the economics fraternity has suffered from the perversity by which the Government both overpraises and ignores it and in doing so often creates policies that are wasteful and counterproductive.
In fact, there is a form of Murphy's Law that asserts, as propounded by Alan S. Blinder, professor of economics at Princeton University: "Economists have the least influence on policy where they know the most and are most agreed; they have the most influence on policy where they know the least and disagree most vehemently."
Amid the rhetoric, especially in election campaigns, when liberal and conservative economists gravitate to their respective camps, it is easy to think that these economists are professionally poles apart. But they are not. They generally agree on most matters, such as that free trade is better than protectionism, and that government price-setting, whether of air fares, wages or rents, lowers a society's standard of living.
"If you asked economists whether price controls are a good thing, about 90 percent of them would say no," Milton Friedman, the prominent conservative, once contended. Moreover, he said that much of what appeared to be disagreement really was not, because it involved others -- sometimes journalists -- talking like economists.
Even many politicians agree, at least intellectually, with economists on numerous issues. Their practical calculus, however, is different. The incentives for them are to respond to two groups: sloganeering opponents and well-financed and well-organized special interests.
The economists have won some victories, especially since the late 1970's, when deregulation of airlines and trucking -- Professor Blinder, an unabashed liberal, calls these "stunning triumphs of the public interest over entrenched vested interests" -- was initiated, along with decontrol of oil and natural gas prices. Then, seemingly against all odds, came the Tax Reform Act of 1986 and the 1990 agreement to reduce the budget deficit over five years.
But this year Congress may well administer the ultimate humiliation, ignoring what the economists say about both macroeconomic policy -- the big picture on which they are in rare relative prescriptive agreement -- and the so-called micro issues, such as the wisdom of extending unemployment benefits, on which they usually agree. This reflects both past expediency and election-year politics.
"It's too late for sound economic policy," observes Lincoln F. Anderson, an economist for the Fidelity Management and Research Company who was a senior Reagan Administration official. "Now we're reaching for quick fixes."
Indeed, many Washingtonians believe, political maneuvering will overwhelm economic analysis in the legislative arena, resulting in more incentives for current consumption and little attention to raising investment in the future. It is an acknowledged problem that what will help the economy in the short run tends to be bad in the long run.
Why, folks ask, should a Democratic Congress be expected to help end what they can point to as George Bush's recession? Why should the Democrats not succumb to a strategy that calls for passing bad but plausible-sounding legislation that will resonate on the stump and force the President to choose between their plan and a veto?
And why should Republicans, already a diminishing minority in Congress, eschew their own election-year plan to cut taxes for the ubiquitous middle class, a category into which almost every solvent American believes he or she fits?
Amid the search for a panacea -- a policy that helps the economy in both short term and long term, maintains budgetary discipline and is seen as fair -- the Joint Tax Committee issues a warning: "One needs to be clear about the ills to be attacked because a package of actions cobbled together could end up with individual elements working at cross purposes to one another."
The committee is probably prescient. It's enough to make a grown economist cry.
