HEADLINE: Book Notes;
Kitty Kelley Draws a Bead on the Royal Family

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN

 BODY:
The House of Windsor is in for what the Queen herself might call a bit of bother. Kitty Kelley, who has written best-selling unauthorized exposes of the American royals Frank Sinatra, Nancy Reagan and Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, has agreed to write a book about the British royal family, which Warner Books plans to publish in 1995.
Flush with money from the success of "Scarlett," the record-breaking best-selling sequel to "Gone With the Wind," Warner was looking for an equally dazzling book to bolster its nonfiction reputation. When Simon & Schuster, which published Ms. Kelley's most recent book, "Nancy Reagan: The Unauthorized Biography," did not come up with as much money as the author and her agents at International Creative Management thought she deserved, Warner did. 
 Simon & Schuster, which is about to publish the paperback edition of the Nancy Reagan book, had vigorously pursued Ms. Kelley. But what people with inside knowledge of the negotiations described as a multi-million-dollar offer was apparently not multi enough.
Warner is officially announcing today that it signed the Kelley book but would not confirm or deny that the royal family was in for the royal business and would not comment on how much Ms. Kelley is being paid.
"When negotiations broke down with S&S, I.C.M. came to us because they knew that we were the kind of house that would be very interested in Kitty Kelley," said Laurence J. Kirshbaum, the president of Warner Books. "Frankly, 'Scarlett' has given us a little momentum and also a little working capital that we can plow back into the business. Given the tough economic times, we saw it as an opportunity to land a blue-chip author."
 
A Cut at the Top
 Facing serious financial difficulties, Farrar, Straus & Giroux has laid off 15 employees, and among those leaving is Linda Healy, vice president, associate publisher and executive editor.
Ms. Healy and Roger Straus Jr., the president of the company, said Ms. Healy was leaving by mutual agreement because the publisher could no longer make a commitment to the journalistic nonfiction books it hired her to pursue and publish.
Farrar, Straus is just one of many publishing houses that have cut their staffs as they realized that publishing is not immune to dips in the economy, as it was once thought to be. Among others that have made cuts recently is Penguin U.S.A., which dismissed 29 people in a cost-cutting measure in November.
But people in publishing expressed concern that the departure of Ms. Healy was a sign the house of Tom Wolfe, Scott Turow, Joseph Brodsky and John McPhee was in more serious financial trouble than was thought.
"Farrar, Straus & Giroux is a fine publishing house, with which I have been pleased to be associated," Ms. Healy said. "I am confident that the house will weather this temporary economic setback. Unfortunately, circumstances make it impossible for me to continue the broad publishing program of nonfiction which I came here to build."
Mr. Straus said that Ms. Healy was hired as part of an expansion begun four years ago and that the company's growth collided head on with the recession. He said Ms. Healy's nonfiction list, which includes Thomas Geoghegan's "Which Side Are You On? Trying to Be for Labor When It's Flat on Its Back," which was nominated this week for a National Book Critics Circle Award, did not fit into the company's economic plans or its general literary character.
"This unfortunately is a cloth we have to cut from our coat to wear for next year," he said.
 
Curbing Book Returns
 Random House Inc. has decided to try a new carrot-and-stick approach to reduce the many books that stores and wholesalers buy, don't sell, then return to the publisher for what has traditionally been full credit.
This season, Random House Inc., which includes among its imprints Alfred A. Knopf, Random House, Crown and Pantheon, became the first publishing house to penalize wholesalers with high rates of return, saying that difficult economic times made it impossible to continue the blanket return-for-full-credit policy.
The publisher is calling it a wholesaler incentive program. Like a peppy grade-school teacher, Random House is encouraging wholesalers to plan better and earn bonus money. From now on, a wholesaler who keeps its overall return rate below 30 percent for the calendar year will receive credit for the returned books and a rebate of 1.25 percent on the full retail price of the order. Those who return more than 30 percent will get no rebate and will receive less than they paid for the books.
For example, a wholesaler who orders $10,000 worth of books at the retail price will be billed $5,100, given the company's 49 percent discount to wholesalers and stores. If during the year the wholesaler returns 25 percent of those orders, it will receive a credit of only $1,175 instead of the $1,275 it paid for them. But since the wholesaler's returns for the year are below 30 percent, the wholesaler will receive a rebate of $125, a $25 carrot from Random House Inc.
So far, Random House is confining the new policy to wholesalers because they have been the worst abusers of the liberal return policy, said Bruce Harris, the sales director for Random House Inc. The publishing house also does not want to penalize stores, which might then shy away from buying a risky book for fear they will lose money if it doesn't sell, said Alberto Vitale, the president of Random House Inc. Since wholesalers fill the needs of stores, their overordering is usually due to protective hoarding rather than eclectic buying.
"High returns are the enemy of productivity," said Mr. Harris, adding that some wholesalers had a return rate of over 80 percent.
Wholesalers are still evaluating the move, but at least one has voiced its support. Western Merchandisers, a Southwest wholesaler, sent a note of congratulations to Random House, saying, "Efficient wholesalers have been subsidizing the inefficient ones for a long time."
 
Filling a Hole
 Simon & Schuster is holding its breath, waiting to announce that Carolyn Reidy, the president and publisher of Avon Books, will join the company as president and publisher of its trade division.
The Hearst Corporation, the parent company of Avon, has apparently been slow to negotiate the terms for Ms. Reidy's departure, said people informed about the bargaining.
The position at Simon & Schuster has been vacant since last summer, when Charles E. Hayward left the company and took over as president and chief executive officer of Little, Brown & Company. Editors and executives at Simon & Schuster have been troubled by the hole at the helm of their flagship trade division and are eager for Ms. Reidy to conclude her talks with Hearst.

HEADLINE: New 'Lost Generation': The Cooking Illiterate

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL

 BODY:
WITH an entrenched recession and a greater emphasis on simple, inexpensive pleasures, Americans say they would like to do more cooking at home.
But once they arrive in the kitchen, will they know what to do? 
 Food marketers and researchers say that despite the desire to cook, the cooking skills of Americans have declined precipitously. Even more striking, they say, Americans don't even know that they don't know how to cook.
In the last decade, cooking has evolved into an optional activity, like skiing or playing chess. Many young adults never learned how to cook, or they simply don't bother, because there are so many other choices, like fast food, takeout or frozen dishes that can be microwaved.
But if people want to eat healthfully, save money or entertain -- all desires being espoused in many public-opinion polls -- they may have trouble if they lack basic cooking techniques.
"For the first time in a long time, we're starting to see people concerned with the cost of food," said Marlene Johnson, the director of product communications at Pillsbury in Minneapolis. "If they can't cook, their choices are going to be extremely limited. They will turn to convenience products that may not be as nourishing."
When the National Pork Producers Council in Des Moines gave a cooking test last year to a nationally representative sample of 735 adults, nearly three-quarters of them flunked, missing 30 percent or more of the 20 questions. It found that 50 percent of the respondents didn't know how to thicken gravy correctly, 75 percent didn't know that broccoli should be cooked uncovered to maintain its color, and only 55 percent knew there are three teaspoons in a tablespoon. The test was contained in a mailed questionnaire sent out for the council by National Family Opinion Research Inc. in Toledo, Ohio.
Despite the vast gaps in cooking knowledge, 63 percent of the respondents described themselves as excellent or very good cooks. Men in general, and young adults 25 to 30 years old had the least cooking knowledge. These respondents said they would cook from scratch more often if they knew what to do in the kitchen.
Similar sentiments have been found by other researchers. "We hypothesize that young folks feel they do not have the appropriate skills," said Barbara Caplan, a vice president of Yankelovich Clancy Shulman, a market-research company in Westport, Conn.
When these young adults were growing up, she said, women were entering the work force in great numbers and did not have the time or energy to show their children how to cook. "In order to develop skills, they must be culturally desirable," she said, "and there must be adequate role models."
For years, going back to the 1920's, food companies have tried to persuade women that it was better to buy prepared food than to cook from scratch, said Joan Gussow, a professor of nutrition and education at Columbia University's Teachers College. Women allowed themselves to lose their cooking skills, she said, partly because no value was placed on cooking. "They were told that smart women don't cook," she added.
Cooking gained cachet in the late 1970's and early 80's as many Americans were discovering new and different cuisines, but the fad has passed. Irena Chalmers, the head of the International Association of Culinary Professionals in Louisville, Ky., said there were 800 cooking schools 11 years ago; now there are only 23 significant ones. "We are raising the first cooking-illiterate generation," she said. "They neither smell nor taste nor stir nor touch the food."
Whether or not they spend time in the kitchen, more Americans now consider cooking a worthwhile activity. In a 1990 Yankelovich poll of 2,500 people, conducted in person, only 34 percent said that cooking was creative and satisfying; in a survey of a different group in 1991, that number rose to 41 percent. The margin of sampling error is plus or minus 2 percentage points.
Mona Doyle, the president of the Consumer Network Inc., a consulting and research company in Philadelphia, has done two large studies on cooking in the last two years. Because of economic pressures and changing values, she said, people would like to do more cooking and baking, relying less on restaurants and prepared foods.
But they don't find cooking fun, and they especially don't like cleaning up. "The mess is the big reason propelling the decline of traditional cooking," Ms. Doyle said.
In one study of 1,450 consumers done in three stages last year, she found that more than two-thirds of the respondents, and almost 90 percent of those under 30, would enjoy cooking more if someone else cleaned up. Homemakers, rather than employed men or women, were more likely to express that feeling. What people do like about cooking is getting praise and having something succeed.
Lisa Kolrud, 27, who works for a public-relations company in Minneapolis, said she never spent much time in the kitchen with her mother, who held a job and ran the household. In college, she ate only processed foods, especially pizza. But now, partly because she is trying to save money because of the uncertain economy, she is learning how to cook.
On Jan. 5, she did the cooking for a dinner party. "I put lasagna on the table for nine people," she said. "It was the first time I'd ever done it. I got a standing ovation."
The route to the table, though, was traumatic. She put the uncooked noodles in the pan and topped them with sauce before she realized the noodles needed cooking. Fortunately, she had another box ready, in case of disaster. "I'm still at the stage where I buy two of everything," she said.
When children watch parents cook, they absorb technique by osmosis and gain confidence. Cheryl Camp, a 22-year-old actress who works at the New York Foundation for the Arts, said her mother cooked a great deal, and so does she. Roasted chicken, potato-dill soup, poppy-seed cake, apple pie, she's made them all. Describing a tortellini soup she and her roommates frequently make, she said, "you spice it with basil or rosemary or oregano, whatever you happen to have around."
Such comfort and flexibility in the kitchen are increasingly rare. Because Americans know less and less about technique, food companies and cookbook authors say they must make recipes extremely clear, explain every little step, and give no choices that could scare people. Many words commonly understood in the past can no longer be used.
Words like dredge, flute, braise, carmelize and butterfly are no longer understood by most people, said Katherine E. Smith, the vice president of consumer affairs for the Quaker Oats Company in Chicago, which recently commissioned a large study on cooking habits. All of those words are less likely to be understood by younger Americans.
On the other hand, cooking illiterates who only know how to steam vegetables may be healthier than their grandmothers, who knew how to flute a heavily larded pie crust and carmelize the top of a gooey dessert.
From observing consumers in its test kitchens, Quaker Oats has found that half the people don't even read the instructions on the package. "Some will have very thin oatmeal and think that's just fine," Ms. Smith said. "Our products have to be very tolerant. They have to taste good regardless of what you do to them."
Cindy Ayers, who oversees the test kitchen and recipe development for the Campbell Soup Company, said consumers want to be told the most basic things: when the food is done, for example. "They don't feel comfortable with their judgment," she said. "I think their confidence is down because their cooking skills are less."
These days, the company gives people few choices. In Campbell's 1978 cookbook, "The Creative Cook," a recipe for Easy Pot Roast said: "In large heavy pan, brown meat on all sides. Use shortening as necessary." The new edition of the cookbook, "Deliciously Easy Recipes," to be published by Campbell this month, is far more specific. Its recipe for Savory Pot Roast gives these directions: "In six-quart Dutch oven over medium-high heat in hot oil, cook roast until browned on all sides." In the list of ingredients, the recipe specified two tablespoons of oil for the cooking. The new cookbook, unlike the old, has pictures with every recipe.
Susan Friedland, a senior editor at HarperCollins in New York, has commissioned two beginner cookbooks for the first time in her 10 years as a cookbook editor. The books, on Chinese and Italian cooking, will come out in the spring. "I think there are a lot of people who got used to good eating and can't afford those restaurants anymore," she said. "They want to cook this food at home."
Harry Balzer, a vice president of the NPD Group, a market-research company in Park Ridge, Ill., said that people are eating more meals at home than they did a few years ago, but often, they're not cooking dishes from scratch. Instead, they're assembling foods that have been already prepared. Meals that include a homemade ingredient declined from 48 percent in 1984 to 42 percent in 1991, Mr. Balzer said.
The percentage of meals made at home requiring use of the stove top continues to decline, from 54 percent in 1984 to 42 percent last year. But the use of the microwave oven, which is mainly used for heating prepared foods, went from 9 percent to 20 percent in that time, he said. The use of the ordinary oven has dipped slightly, from 17 percent of all meals in 1984 to 16 percent last year.
Still, researchers say people have strongly expressed the desire to spend time with their families doing simple activites like cooking. Nobody thinks, though, that a return to the kitchen will mean a revival of cooking from scratch.
"Maybe they're cutting up a few more vegetables with the kids," Ms. Ayers said. "It has to be simple and fun."
 
TESTING YOUR SKILLS

HEADLINE: In a Belt-Tightening Age, a $5.2 Million Restaurant Is Born

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
While the rest of the United States has been battening down the hatches, Terry Peay and Mark Miller have been spending money like sailors on shore leave. In this age of austerity, their new $5.2 million restaurant, Red Sage, stands out.
Not since Warner LeRoy opened the $10 million Potomac in the heady mid-80's has Washington seen such a fantasy. The difference is that the LeRoy enterprise looked like fin de siecle bordello and served bordello quality food. The Red Sage has been done with panache, and Mark Miller, considered among the country's most imaginative chefs, knows how to cook. The restaurant opened on Monday, and it's already heavily booked. Dinner will be about $30. 
 Even the jaded Washington food establishment is agog. Earlier this month, they got their first glimpse of the silver-and-gold, teal-and-oxblood color scheme; the $18,000 hand-blown chandeliers; the $36,000 food smoker and the $375 custom-made chairs. And yes, they like the food, too.
"A wonderful combination of the whimsical and the stunning," Ellen Brown, a food and restaurant consultant, said of the space. "Lavishness is the owner's prerogative as long as I don't have to pay for it."
Mr. Peay, the financial partner in the venture, is also in business with Mr. Miller at the Coyote Cafe in Santa Fe. "You cannot get this kind of environment without spending money," he said. But he added that he never would have made the gamble with any other chef.
Mr. Miller, 42 years old, is an anthropologist and art historian by training; you might say he became a cook by accident when Alice Waters asked him to fill in temporarily at Chez Panisse in Berkeley, Calif. He ending up staying there three and a half years, and in 1979 went out on his own to open the Fourth Street Grill and Santa Fe Bar and Grill in Berkeley. He sold them to open the Coyote Cafe in 1987.
His training still informs his cooking. "Most of my life I have been involved in primitive art," he said. "I am not looking for symphonics, as in French; I'm looking for expressiveness. It's the difference between Louis XIV furniture and African primitive art. The flavors are immediate, expressive, intense. People's thinking dominates the way they cook."
Like the Red Sage's decor, there is nothing retiring about Mr. Miller's food, which he said has some basis in Native American cooking. There is a lot going on in each dish, but because Mr. Miller knows his ingredients, the subtle combinations explode with flavor. He is a master of chilies -- he understands their complex nature and their synergy.
His oyster corn chowder, for example, pairs the smokiness and sweetness of roasted poblano chilies with the freshness of anaheims. These enliven the sweetness of the corn, the saltiness and freshness of the oysters. Or, to put it in Mr. Miller's words, "The combination creates movement in the mouth, gives you a rhythm in the dish." That's the art historian talking.
"When people look at Native American food," Mr. Miller said, "they are looking at the remnants of Indian civilization." That's the anthropologist talking.
But what he is cooking at Red Sage is much broader than Native American. It is, according to him, the West of the Great Plains, and its boundaries are the Rio Grande, the Grand Tetons, the Rockies and the Mississippi. "It's meant to be ambiguous," Mr. Miller said. "It's inspired by the Pueblo, Iroquois and Plains Indians, by the Mexican and Spanish, by the European immigration: the German, the English, the Scandinavian.
"It's an area that would have had a ranch, that would have had cultivated food and wild food. I have combined these influences with my techniques, which are European."
Ms. Brown, for one, is not convinced. "The idea of Western cuisine versus Southwestern -- I think we are splitting hairs, be they horse hairs or calf hairs," she said.
All these elements are at play in the restaurant's design. "This is a mythical Western theme," said the designer, Stephen Samuelson of Studio Arquitectura, a Santa Fe concern. "It's not Spanish, Mexican, cowboy, Southwest. It is turn of the century. We tried to evoke what it was like when settlers went West, the grand ranches, the architecture brought in on trains, the Victorian design brought out to the Southwest."
Whatever its design period, Red Sage has been done within an inch of its life. Most of the more than 100 craftsmen who worked on the 18,000-square-foot, 350-seat restaurant were imported from Santa Fe.
Were they worried about such an extravaganza in a shrinking economy? "To do something less than the full creative range is not something we wanted to get involved with," Mr. Peay said. "You cannot get this kind of environment without spending money."
And besides, he added, the Swedish and Dutch investors in the building in which the restaurant is located, "have hundreds of billions of dollars." Who cares if only four floors in the $80 million, 11-story building are rented?
Actually, the owners did consider costs. "We curtailed it quite a bit," Mr. Peay said. "In one day we cut out $700,000." It's hard to see where they would have put the trout lakes with weeds and grass, or the holograms.
Despite the cutbacks, the multilevel restaurant kept the custom-made 3-D clouds; hand-etched glass; nickel and silver medallions imbedded in the tile; the 12- by-16-foot mural; hand-rubbed, beeswax-finished frescoed walls; the hammered wrought-iron stair rail; the water channel (known in New Mexico as an acequia); bandana-shaped hand-woven rug; hand-painted tile mural of chickens and cactus; bullseye wall sconces held in place by Indian-head nickels; wrought-iron lizard door handles, and so on.
But the $5.2 million was spent on more than a restaurant and a chili bar. Red Sage is a small food company that also expects a return on its investment from the private dining rooms, the carry-out, bakery and dry goods shop, and catering facilities.
To earn back the money, the company will need to net about $1 million a year in what Ms. Brown accurately described as a "fairly dead part of downtown Washington."
Raise the specter of poor location -- 14th and F Streets Northwest -- in a city in which hardly anyone comes downtown at night anyway and the partners pull out their extensive demographic studies and snow you with statistics. "Another 8,000 high-end residential units within four or five blocks . . . the opening of 10 new movie theaters . . . 10,000 hotel rooms within a seven-block radius . . . 12,000 lawyers in a 10-block radius. . . ."
Assuming that the demographics are correct, how will this European-oriented city, where gray is the color of choice, react to a vibrant recreation of a mythic American West?
"You know, half the people in this town won't get it," said Bill Plante, the State Department correspondent for CBS News, who attended one of the recent preview dinners. "The other half will go crazy for it."

HEADLINE: Albany's Leadership Void

 BODY:
The experts had predicted it. But somehow this week's downgrading of New York State's safest bonds hit like a punch in the stomach. The downgrading will not only cost the taxpayers millions of dollars in added interest costs. It is the loudest signal yet that New York's political leaders are intolerably ineffective in resolving the state's worsening fiscal crisis.
There is a desperate need for leadership on all sides in Albany. Not the same old partisan politics -- not Republicans versus Democrats, or upstate versus downstate, or the cities versus the suburbs -- but broad and unselfish leadership that puts the public's well-being ahead of narrow political gain. 
 For nearly two decades a Democratic-controlled Assembly, Republican-dominated Senate and Democratic Governor have managed to make budget decisions -- but only because the economy cooperated. In good or normal times, the two sides could compromise because there was enough money to spread around to satisfy everybody. But when the national recession hit and resources shrank, partisanship intensified.
Now Gov. Mario Cuomo urges the Senate Republicans to consider his solutions while the Senate majority leader, Ralph Marino, irresponsibly refuses to budge. For two months they have been unable to close a gap of $875 million in this year's budget, and the anticipated gap next year is at least $4 billion.
The stalemate has already caused serious damage. Moody's Investors Service downgraded the state's appropriation-backed bonds last week, and this week Standard & Poor's took the more drastic step of dropping the rating on New York's general obligation bonds, those backed by the state's full faith and credit, to A-, the lowest level in the state's history and the second-lowest general obligation bond rating in the country.
The downgrading does not imply that New York State is likely to default on its most secure obligations. But it does mean that New York will be paying out millions of additional dollars in higher interest rates on the sale of new bonds, and that scores of local school districts will no doubt be forced to pay higher interest rates on their bonds, eating into educational programs or driving up property taxes.
The rating agencies acted because the state's finances are in bad shape and show no immediate prospect of improvement. Citing a fifth consecutive operating deficit, Standard & Poor's complained about "continued economic deterioration," "chronic operating deficits" and "the legislative stalemate in seeking permanent and structurally sound fiscal operations."
Mr. Marino and the Senate Republicans on one side, Mr. Cuomo and the Assembly Democrats on the other, have fundamental differences on how to resolve the crisis. Mr. Marino wants to take most of the necessary budget cuts out of welfare and Medicaid and leave school aid -- bread and butter to his suburban constituents -- largely intact. The Governor acknowledges the need for cuts in social welfare spending but would spread the pain more evenly. The details should be in Mr. Cuomo's budget for the next fiscal year, due later this month.
Albany's players can no longer wait for an economic recovery to bail them out. The state needs fundamental fiscal reforms -- and leaders willing finally to rise above partisanship and confront a crisis that they collaborated in causing.

HEADLINE: DIALOGUE: Should Congress Investigate the 'October Surprise'?;
Don't Waste Time On This Wild Tale

BYLINE: By Mitch McConnell; Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, is a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
For 10 years, arms smugglers, convicted felons, frauds and fugitives from justice have unsuccessfully peddled allegations of a so-called October surprise to the Iran-contra independent counsel, Iran-contra Congressional investigating committees, Senate Intelligence Committee and the public.
After hearing detailed testimony from Gary Sick, the Senate properly rejected a bill to spend $600,000 to pursue charges that he is now selling in a book. Some will argue an investigation should be conducted just to lay the issue to rest. But what would a new investigation do, on top of the ones already undertaken? There will always be one more conspiracy-minded partisan who will come up with another titillating date, detail or account of events, particularly in an election year. 
 What apparently troubled Mr. Sick into spinning his web was the breakdown of negotiations between the Carter Administration and Iranian leaders on the release of the hostages. After a series of high-level secret meetings, Mr. Sick argues, the Iranians abruptly and inexplicably suspended contact in September 1980. To him, the timing suggests a secret deal must have been struck between aides of Ronald Reagan and Iranians.
But two senior officials in the hostage talks -- President Jimmy Carter's counsel, Lloyd Cutler, and Deputy Secretary of State Warren Christopher -- have suggested that the Sept. 22, 1980 Iraqi attack against 10 military bases and invasions by six divisions on three fronts distracted Iranian leaders. In retrospective analyses, Mr. Cutler and Mr. Christopher have said they were convinced that the life-and-death decisions those leaders faced together with the intense rivalry for control after Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's return to Teheran made Iran unwilling to resolve, or incapable of resolving, the hostage crisis in 1980.
The frenzied anti-American demonstrations, especially after the failure of the U.S. helicopter rescue attempt in 1980, suggested little interest from Iran in helping Jimmy Carter. He learned the hostages were to be freed only within hours of Jan. 20, 1981, Ronald Reagan's Inauguration Day.
Dismissing Mr. Cutler's and Mr. Christopher's views, Mr. Sick turns to stories told by figures from the world of black-market arms sales. If he did not enjoy some professional credibility from his days as a National Security Council staff member in the Carter Administration, these people would have remained where they belong -- in the shadows.
Mr. Sick has written and testified that he relied on six sources to confirm his central and most disturbing charge: William Casey, Mr. Reagan's campaign manager, negotiated with Hojatolislam Mehdi Karrubi, an Iranian cleric, in two meetings in Madrid in July 1980 to extend the hostages' suffering deliberately and ruthlessly. Mr. Sick says Mr. Casey held later meetings in Paris in October. Of the six, Mr. Sick says, Jamshid Hashemi, an Iranian arms trafficker, was the only eyewitness at the meetings. Mr. Sick, who knew Mr. Hashemi from his N.S.C. days, claims confidence in Mr. Hashemi's credibility even though he confessed willing involvement in a deal that would betray Mr. Carter.
For confirmation that these meetings took place, Mr. Sick also depended on Ari Ben-Menashe, an Israeli arms dealer whose story was dismissed by the Senate Intelligence Committee. Although not at any meetings, he told Mr. Sick he had read about them in Israeli cables. Mr. Sick admitted not asking to see those cables, nor seeking any other supporting documents: he just trusted Mr. Ben-Menashe. The credibility of the remaining sources is even weaker. Ahmad Madani, a former Defense Minister whom Mr. Hashemi had promoted for president of Iran in the late 1970's, said he was not at the Madrid meetings but that if his friend Mr. Hashemi said they had taken place, they must have. Of the other so-called sources cited, not one actually attended any meetings nor produced any supporting evidence of any sort proving they had occurred. These dubious sources included Arif Durrani, a Pakistani arms smuggler; Richard Babayan, an American arms dealer, and Heinrich Rupp, an associate of the discredited Richard J. Brenneke, who claimed to have been a C.I.A. agent -- a claim the C.I.A. has denied.
Mr. Sick testified he had relied on the hearsay of unidentified journalists for the stories of Mr. Durrani, Mr. Babayan and Mr. Rupp -- that he had never spoken directly with them. In peddling his conspiracy story, Mr. Sick is joined by the former President of Iran, Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, who has changed the important details of his story at least five times, as well as by Mr. Brenneke.
The conspiracy theory is as credible as its promoters, who claim Mr. Casey was not at the Anglo-American conference on the history of World War II in London on July 28 and July 29, 1980; they allege that he was in Madrid instead. What is truly credible are the recorded notes possessed by the British Imperial War Museum detailing his participation in the conference. Each time that records unequivocally establish the whereabouts of a U.S. official whose name comes up in Mr. Sick's theory, his sources revise their stories and alter the dates and places.
During the Congressional Iran-contra investigations, allegations of the October surprise came up, but the committee's report dismissed them. The taxpayers have already spent more than $50 million on committees and counsels investigating plots relating to Iran. America cannot afford another expensive investigation without a credible basis for proceeding.
We lack the facts. We should forgo the fantasy.

HEADLINE: Detroit's Real Competitors Are Ohio, Illinois . . .

BYLINE: By Robert W. Crandall; Robert W. Crandall is senior fellow at the Brookings Institution.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Ford, G.M. and Chrysler would have us believe that their main problem is lack of access to the Japanese market. As last week's debacle in Japan helped demonstrate, no one seriously believes that the Big Three can sell more than a handful of cars there under any rules. Even Honda has to scramble to hold on to a 10 percent market share in Japan.
The real problem is that the Big Three can't compete in the U.S. against cars produced by Japanese-owned plants in Kentucky, Tennessee, Ohio, Illinois and Indiana. These plants sprang up in part because of quotas on Japanese imports that the Big Three requested in the early 1980's. 
In effect, the Japanese are being told to slow the growth of the auto industry in those four states in order to preserve producers in and around Detroit who offer cars that many Americans view as inferior to those made further south.
Using U.S. labor, steel and myriad U.S. parts, these factories turn out the Camry, Accord and Sentra, which are so much better than G.M., Ford and Chrysler cars that they cost about 15 percent more than Detroit models with similar attributes. Moreover, they depreciate much more slowly in the used car market than American models do.
The Honda Accord, produced in Ohio, has been the hottest-selling American car for two years. Honda can produce about 500,000 cars a year in Ohio, and has been rapidly expanding its Ohio assembly, stamping and engine production operations. Toyota is doubling the size of its Kentucky plant and could expand even further. Mitsubishi bought out its partner, Chrysler, and is thus the sole owner of a plant in Illinois that produces high-quality sporty sedans.
Japanese plants in America account for about 14 percent of total passenger car sales in the U.S. Adding the imports, Japan's share of those sales is more than 30 percent. Detroit can expect that Honda, Toyota, Nissan, Mitsubishi and others will increase their share of the U.S. market to some 36 percent by the mid-90's.
With the Japanese now expanding into bigger cars, it is possible that American consumers will be buying 40 percent or more of their new cars from Japanese companies by 1995 or 1996. One reason is that the big Japanese cars -- the luxury Infiniti, Lexus and Acura models -- may well increase the gap in quality with their U.S. counterparts.
This loss of market share would force the Big Three to close yet more plants. Nonetheless, there is no sound reason why Japanese producers should slow their investment in the U.S. because Detroit cannot compete with them. If our Government does nothing -- it should do nothing -- the Big Three will continue to lose its market share to the Japanese simply because U.S. consumers had unhappy experiences with U.S. cars in the 1980's and were much more satisfied with Japanese models.
Lee Iacocca, Chrysler's chairman, himself admitted in the Jan. 6 issue of Automotive News, a trade newspaper, that Chrysler may have brought its plight on itself by selling "some crap" that customers will now replace with better Japanese cars.
Chrysler now makes about as many passenger cars as Honda, North America. G.M. has lost one-fourth of its U.S. passenger car market in the past decade, mostly to Japanese plants in America. Only Ford, with its Taurus and big-car lines, appears to be holding its market share, but even its stability is at risk from the new Japanese products.
For the U.S. economy to grow, efficient, high-quality producers must replace less-efficient, low-quality producers. This process has been under way for two decades in the auto industry. The Big Three have not been able to adopt a long-term strategy that would make them efficient producers of high-quality cars. Because of that failure, they will probably never recapture the market share they have lost to Japan.
The only question is how much further they must pare production in the next decade. They have only themselves to blame. Consumers are entitled to buy the best cars they can get for their money.

HEADLINE: Importing Immigrants, Exporting Jobs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Accepting the Harsh Truth of a Blue-Collar Recession" (front page, Dec. 25), on the loss of more than one million blue-collar jobs in the current recession, correctly points out that not all of those jobs will return after the recession is over. While some have been lost because of increased efficiency, many are non- and low-skill manufacturing jobs. Where have those jobs gone? 
 They, like hundreds of thousands of such jobs during the 1980's, have been exported to the third world because the work can be done there at less cost. While this is just good economics, it does raise a question about our immigration policy.
Most of the 800,000 legal immigrants entering the United States each year would normally take non- and low-skilled manufacturing jobs. But the very jobs the new immigrants need are the ones that have been leaving the U.S. and going to the countries from which the immigrants come. How then are the new immigrants to find work, and what do they do if they cannot?
The answer to that question is to be found in your Dec. 3 report that in California 40 percent of newly arriving immigrants end up on welfare. Obviously, under current immigration policy, there is a mismatch between the skills needed to find work in the United States today and the skills of new immigrants. We need an immigration policy that recognizes that fact.
 
ROBERT KNOWLES
New York, Dec. 29, 1991

HEADLINE: Boston's New Mayor Faces Painful Task on Police Chief

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Raymond L. Flynn, one of the most popular mayors in the city's history, was placed in an agonizing position today when a special panel advised him against retaining the police commissioner, who is a boyhood friend of the Mayor and one of his closest associates.
The special commission, which was appointed by the Mayor himself to look into Police Department procedures, recommended that the commissioner, Francis M. Roache, be replaced when his term expires in April. The panel also sharply criticized the handling of civilian complaints by the police. 
 Compounding Mr. Flynn's difficulty, the panel's report came on the day that the Mayor delivered his state of the city address, in which he announced a major program to combat the effects of the recession in Boston. But his plan, to borrow $70 million to create jobs by building parks, schools, roads and sidewalks, was almost overshadowed by the attention given to the commission's report.
 
Complaints on Management
 Mr. Flynn appointed the commission, headed by James D. St. Clair, a nationally prominent lawyer, last May after several incidents raised concern that the police department was out of control. Some of the complaints involved the bungled investigation of the 1989 death of Carol Stuart, a white pregnant woman whose husband was later implicated in her slaying, but for which a black man was initially blamed. Other complaints had to do with the killings of five people by police officers in 1991. And in a drug investigation in which a police officer was killed, it came out in testimony in court that the police had manufactured an informant's evidence, and the suspect was acquitted.
At a crowded news conference in City Hall today, Mr. Flynn said he would act on several of the commission's recommendations. But he declined to discuss the proposal involving Mr. Roache, a position he repeated in his speech tonight.
Responding to accusations in the report that Mr. Roache had poorly managed the Police Department, Mr. Flynn recalled that when he appointed Mr. Roache in 1985, the major problems in Boston involved racial tensions and police corruption, not management techniques in the Police Department.
"If I'm giving a grade today in the area of management, maybe both Mickey Roache and I don't do very well," said Mr. Flynn, who was recently elected to a third term with a record 75 percent of the vote.. "But let me tell you, I give Mickey Roache an A-plus in the area of integrity and bringing together the people of the city of Boston racially."
Today's report found that "Commissioner Roache's personal integrity and honesty are exemplary." The commission also praised him for cooperating fully with a Federal investigation into corruption in the Boston police department in the mid-1980's. But the report said, "We found poor morale among the police force and a growing impatience in the community with business as usual."
It continued, "Commissioner Roache has failed to develop and articulate a shared vision or strategic plan to guide the department's operation. Instead, the department has adopted a purely reactive posture, and drifts from crisis to crisis."
 
'Turf Wars'
 The result has been several "divisive turf wars between different segments of the department," the report said.
The panel said the police department's handling of complaints from civilians was "particularly troubling." A study of 250 complaints made in 1989 and 1990 found that the Internal Affairs Department had upheld less than 6 percent of the charges, the commission found.
"Our study revealed an investigative and hearing process characterized by shoddy, halfhearted investigations, lengthy delays and inadequate documentation and record keeping," the report said, with the result that the process is "unfairly skewed against those bringing a complaint."
As a consequence of these policies, the report said, "there is a small group of problem officers," some with records of alleged physical abuse of citizens, who are responsible for many of the complaints.
The seven-member commission recommended the creation of a Community Appeals Board, with a majority of civilian members, to review police investigations of complaints. The Boston police and Mayor Flynn have long opposed such a board.
The panel also recommended that the Boston police immediately shift to a community-based policing strategy, in which officers get out of their patrol cars and become actively involved in neighborhoods to try to prevent young people from becoming criminals. Mr. Roache has said he has launched such an approach, but Mr. St. Clair today derided Mr. Roache's effort, saying, "There was no plan."
Today's report comes at a time when violent crime in Boston has dropped to its lowest level in six years, or roughly the period before the spread of crack cocaine. The city's murder rate fell 22.6 percent in 1991 and there was an ll percent decrease in rape and attempted rape. Overall, Boston has long had one of the lowest crime rates of any major city.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 16, 1992, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A headline yesterday about a Boston commission's recommendation to Mayor Raymond L. Flynn against keeping the city's police commissioner referred to the Mayor incorrectly in some copies. He was recently re-elected to a third term; he is not new.

HEADLINE: Theater in Review

BYLINE: By MEL GUSSOW

 BODY:

Job: A Circus
One Dream Theater
232 West Broadway
Manhattan
Through Feb. 2
 
 Conceived and directed by Elizabeth Swados; producing director, Wickham Boyle; clown routines created by Gabriel Barre, Mary Dino, Michael Gunst, Jeff Hess, Alan Mintz and Stephen Ringold; music by Ms. Swados; vocal arrangements by Ann Marie Milazzo, Cathy Porter and Michael Sottile; production stage manager, Tori Evans; set and costumes designed by Nephelie Andonyadis; lighting by Kristabelle Munson. Presented by Under One Roof.
WITH: Ms. Dino, Ms. Evans, Mr. Gunst, Mr. Hess, Ms. Milazzo, Mr. Mintz, Mr. Neiden, Paul O'Keefe, Mr. Ringold and Mr. Sottile.
 
Stories from the Old Testament have provided Elizabeth Swados with a mosaic of musical material, as in her "Haggadah" and "Jerusalem." For her new chamber musical, she has turned to the Book of Job, but instead of writing a dramatic oratorio she has created an informal clown show, with moments of audience participation. The result, "Job: A Circus," is a freewheeling cavalcade of songs and sight gags.
The idea is to approach Job as a Chaplinesque soul who endures a diversity of woes and never knows where the next slapstick or custard pie will come from. As the show stands, and as Job pratfalls, this is an up and down, fragmented affair. But it is light enough in spirit to justify its role as a family show, a brief entertainment with a moral but not too heavy a message.
As director, Ms. Swados has de-emphasized scenic design and given her company of energetic young actors free rein to improvise routines and to mime, juggle and tumble. Along with the music, the clowning is the most enjoyable aspect of the show.
With a ringlet of hair sprouting from his head, the show's Job, Stephen Ringold, looks like a tall Tintin. He is downcast, deadpan and undiscouraged. Wherever he turns, someone takes advantage of him, but, in keeping with his biblical origins, he remains a righteous man.
As the engaging ringmaster, Jeff Hess is a quick-thinking skirmisher who is unabashed about the more awkward episodes in the show. Alan Mintz is wry as a mock-sinister Satan who in this pompadoured version looks and sings like the ghost of Elvis. In keeping with the circus setting, God is the unseen Great Magician and the world is an improvisational vaudeville. In characteristic Swados fashion, the music is an eclectic blending of calypso, ballads, country and rap. Occasional liturgical strains are sung in Hebrew, with lively accompaniment on piano and guitar.
To expand the repertory of afflictions, Mr. Hess asks for the audience's assistance in bedeviling the put-upon protagonist. At Sunday's matinee, volunteers shunned the thought of fire and flood and suggested that Job be hit with a recession and be made to ride the New York subway. Both punishments were meted out by the actors with a fierceness that can only come from experience on the urban firing line.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 16, 1992, Thursday

HEADLINE: Push for Better Schools In Memphis Takes On Importance for Nation

SERIES: Memphis 2000: An occasional visit to a city working to change its public schools.

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEMPHIS, Jan. 8

 BODY:
If President Bush's vision of the future of American schools has a shape, it is beginning to emerge in Memphis.
Memphis was the first major city to answer President Bush's call to become an "America 2000" community by drawing up a plan to fix its schools. Slowly and laboriously, parents, educators, business leaders and civil rights advocates are working to build sturdy coalitions for change. To win agreement, they have already had to jettison one of Mr. Bush's key planks -- public money for private schools -- and add several different goals to make Mr. Bush's plan their own. 
 How Memphis and the thousand or so other communities that so far have embraced the America 2000 challenge fare may help gauge whether the President's education strategy will inspire other Americans to improve their schools or will end as a futile public relations exercise.
With its high poverty and welfare-dependency rates and students who fall below national averages on test scores, Memphis mirrors the problems of urban school districts across the country.
"The reason Memphis is important is the possibility of teaching the nation just how this might work," said Ron Register, an urban anthropologist who heads a task force on parental involvement, one of eight task forces examining different educational problems with the aim of producing an education plan for Memphis schools by next fall.
 
Problems at the Start
 Although the campaign, dubbed "Memphis 2000," was only begun in July, its organizers have already had to confront several sensitive issues: how to involve both blacks and whites in a city with its share of racial tensions, how to counter the perception that this is a white Republican effort that offers high-sounding ideals but no money, and how to win agreement from people with different ideas of what is wrong with schools and how to change them.
The problems facing Memphis are stark -- and like many cities, social and economic ills are enmeshed with educational ones. Memphis has the highest percentage of people living in poverty and on welfare among cities with populations of more than 500,000, according to the Mayors of Memphis and neighboring Shelby County. Last year, Memphis 10th graders scored in the 36th percentile in reading and the 40th percentile in mathematics nationwide. Spending per pupil is $3,568, well below the national average of $5,237.
White parents have largely fled the public schools, leaving them 80 percent black, and, Memphis civil rights leaders say, even more vulnerable to budget cuts as a result. A growing number of taxpayers are elderly people on fixed incomes who regularly vote against more money for schools.
"Their sense is kids over there are drinking, smoking, sniffing and having sex, and are not interested in learning," said William N. Morris Jr., Mayor of Shelby County, which includes Memphis and provides much of the financing for the city's schools.
 
Met His Old Boss
 Memphis's latest attempt to tackle these problems began last April when Bill Gibbons, a prominent local lawyer, ran into his former boss, Lamar Alexander, now the United States Secretary of Education. When Mr. Alexander was Governor of Tennessee in the late 1970's and early 1980's, he placed Mr. Gibbons in charge of a huge Memphis jobs conference that helped revitalize the city economically, the way Mr. Alexander hopes America 2000 communities will revive American education. President Bush had just unveiled an education strategy that relied largely on local efforts, and Mr. Alexander suggested that Memphis join in.
Drawing on past experience with community organizing, Mr. Gibbons and other Memphis leaders set out to defuse possible political and racial tensions by seeking wide participation and adapting the goals of America 2000 to Memphis's needs and politics.
Mr. Gibbons, a Republican, recruited as co-leaders of Memphis 2000 a white businesswoman, Nancy E. Bogatin, an outspoken Democrat, and a black lawyer, Allan Wade, who is a political independent. They persuaded six Memphis businesses to donate $25,000 each and established a timetable. On July 23, Mr. Alexander flew to Memphis for an elaborate press conference on Memphis 2000.
But many remained skeptical, even hostile. "I think it was politically motivated that Memphis was the first site," said Willie Herenton, who is Memphis's first black Mayor and was Superintendent of Schools for 12 years. "I was then running for Mayor against a Republican incumbent. Everyone on that podium was all white, all male, and here Memphis is an 80 percent black school system. I saw it as a political farce which I was not going to endorse."
 
Local Goals Added
 Continuing suspicion among educators as well as local politicians prodded Memphis 2000's organizers to try to differentiate their effort from America 2000. Memphis added two local goals -- eliminating gaps in educational opportunities among children and fostering parental involvement -- to the six national education goals America 2000 communities are supposed to adopt.
These six goals include insuring that all students are healthy and intellectually stimulated enough to start school and that they leave school competent in five basic subjects, raising the high school graduation rate to 90 percent, making American students lead the world in mathematics and science, erasing adult illiteracy and making schools safe and drug-free.
To win over educators like Elsie Lewis Bailey, principal of Booker T. Washington High School, Mr. Gibbons pledged that Memphis 2000 would not endorse a crucial plank of the Bush platform -- school "choice" for private schools, a voucher-like program in which money could follow students to whatever school they chose, public or private.
These efforts mollified several people, including Mayor Herenton. "I'm willing to work with them as long as I can be convinced it is not business as usual, a public relations approach to addressing education reform where nothing happens," the Mayor said.
On Oct. 23, Memphis 2000's leaders convened a citywide educational symposium that drew more than 750 people. Now, in school-district office basements and public libraries, the task forces are embarking on the sometimes frustrating, sometimes electric process of defining what is wrong in Memphis and what to do about it.
The other night, three task forces with about 40 people each met and filled the walls of their meeting rooms with lists of problems. "Lack of real (proper) role models" and "too many students per teacher" were on one list at the task force on equalizing educational opportunities.
 
Trying to Be Honest
 Amid the unavoidable tedium, however, flashes of emotion broke through, as members of the racially mixed panels struggled to talk honestly about sensitive issues.
"We are so diverse, and people are shy about saying what they really feel about children of another race," said Carole Hall Hardeman, dean of the faculty at LeMoyne-Owen College in Memphis.
The participants in Mr. Register's task force on parental involvement spent much of the evening talking about the parents who were not there -- poor black parents -- and how to reach them. They plan to move the meetings to churches or housing projects, away from what Mr. Register called "white middle-class settings" where many parents may not feel comfortable.
Indeed, many blacks remain wary. "I talk to black kids and they say, that's some white honky middle-class deal," said Mr. Wade, the black lawyer who is a co-chairman of Memphis 2000. "You've got to get beyond that and say, 'You've got to do something.' "
The challenge for Memphis 2000 is to synthesize these diverse views into a coherent plan. Ask different people in Memphis and they give different reasons why the schools are struggling and offer different wish lists.
Johnnie B. Watson, Deputy Superintendent of Schools, wants better early childhood education, and more money for smaller classes and alternative schools for disruptive children. Stephanie Rodda, one of the few white parents who chose to enroll her children in public schools, believes the word has not gotten out that some of Memphis's 158 schools are good.
Janet Robbins, a fourth-grade teacher at Mrs. Rodda's children's school who is sharing a classroom with another teacher and 50 children while new classrooms are being built, says she needs parental involvement and community support even more than new buildings.
Mrs. Bailey, the high school principal, talks of students who stay home to take care of baby siblings because their mothers are on drugs, of poor academic skills and low motivation, and of teen-agers from housing projects with nowhere to go after school.
 
Is Racism the Problem?
 For Maxine Smith, the new president of the Memphis school board and the executive director of the Memphis branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, the same sickness afflicts both Memphis and its schools. "Memphis is a very racist city," she said. "This is a neglected, underfunded system.
"We need early childhood and prenatal programs," she continued. "We've got to get parents involved. Over 70 of all black babies here are born to single parents. We have to address the needs of a deprived -- which has become a depraved -- population. I won't shy away from that. I think Memphis 2000 has the will to get it done."
But many of these efforts will cost money, another potentially divisive issue for Memphis 2000. Gov. Ned McWherter, a Democrat, has just proposed an income tax to finance education, and state legislators have fallen all over themselves repudiating the idea. Some members of Memphis 2000 strongly endorse it; others do not.
"The initial reaction to us was, 'A lot of talk and not much money,' " Mr. Gibbons said. "But we're never going to get any more money until we have an understandable plan in place that the public supports."
That task lies ahead, but Mr. Register believes Memphis 2000 has more chance of success than any previous effort, partly because the process crafted to develop the plan includes so many diverse voices, and partly because Memphis itself is changing. The city now has its first black Mayor, a new school board, a largely new City Council, and a new superintendent of schools starting this summer.
"If it does not happen now, when does it happen?" Mr. Register said.

SEALING YUGOSLAVIA'S FATE
 The European Community recognized Croatia and Slovenia, putting its official seal on the breakup of Yugoslavia, the multi-ethnic nation born in 1918. But while Slovenia looks forward to relative prosperity, Croatia is haunted by the specter of Yugoslav troops. A1

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Chevron to Cut Back At Big Texas Refinery

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Hurt by weak demand and low prices for natural gas and gasoline and rising costs for environmental regulations, the Chevron Corporation today announced a program to cut costs, including a plan to reduce or possibly end output at the Chevron refinery in Port Arthur, Tex. -- the company's biggest.
The decision follows moves last year by other large refiners like Shell and Amoco to sell or close refineries and suggests that the nation's gasoline refining capacity will fall by approximately 100,000 barrels a day, or about 4 percent, in coming years. 
 Michael Mayer, an analyst at Wertheim Schroder & Company, said the cutbacks should bolster the poor profit margins of refiners even if the economy and gasoline demand do not improve.
Kenneth T. Derr, Chevron's chairman and chief executive, said: "Nobody is projecting any major, volumetric changes in refined products for this country in the next few years. Cost is one thing you have more control over than what the price of crude oil will be."
Chevron, based in San Francisco, said it would take an after-tax charge of $270 million in the fourth quarter of 1991 because of the cutbacks. Of that total, about $180 million is related to shedding a third of the refining capacity at the Port Arthur plant, or 100,000 barrels of crude oil a day. At least 500 people at the plant will be cut from the payroll.
The company said it would decide later this year whether to operate the refinery at lower capacity, seek a buyer or joint-venture partner or close the operation.
Another 2,000 jobs will be eliminated through a combination of sales of oil-and-gas reserves and other assets, and changes in operations and organization structure, the company said. Salaries of all nonunion employees will be frozen for at least three months, and fewer new employees will be added.
Most of the actions hasten a restructuring that Mr. Derr set in motion two years ago. In an interview, Mr. Derr said that nearly $1 billion in improvements necessary at the Port Arthur plant to meet new standards set by the amended Clean Air Act was "not a very appealing prospect."
Over all, the company faces more than $2 billion in costs to meet new environmental regulations over the next five years.
On the New York Stock Exchange, Chevron shares lost 50 cents today, closing at $68.375.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The F.C.C. will propose opening up a big swath of radio frequencies for "emerging technologies," hoping to speed the development of new mobile communications, from cheap and tiny wireless telephones to electronic notebooks that send and receive data. It will recommend reallocating frequencies now used by railroads, utilities, and police and fire departments. [Page A1.] 
 Domestic oil production "has begun a precipitous decline," the American Petroleum Institute said. Consumption fell, it said, so imports also declined. [D1.]
Business sales crept up just 0.1 percent in November, providing little spark for new jobs, a Government report showed. [D2.]
New York City's real estate market is still losing value, but more slowly, tax rolls show. [B3.]

HEADLINE: Bad Loans Easing Grip On Banks

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
It is too early to dance on banks' doorsteps, but recent earnings reports by several large banks suggest that the recession is loosening its grip on the Northeast.
While many banks in the region have been able to recover more quickly than the economy by sharply reducing interest rates paid on deposits and squeezing out other costs, they are also reporting fewer troubled loans, or at least a sharp slowdown in the growth of them. Troubled loans, those that are far behind in payments or are not expected to be repaid in full, doubled and tripled at many banks as the economy turned downward in 1990 and 1991. 
 The decline in such loans, in fact, was seen as one factor as one New England banking company, Shawmut National, ended merger talks with the Bank of Boston. [Page D14.]
 
More Lending Seen
 Gary Ciminero, the chief economist for the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group, said yesterday that declines in banks' problems with bad loans would make them more willing to lend "and alleviate the credit crunch that exacerbated the region's economic downturn."
But he warned that it was too early to say that the recession was over.
Joel B. Alvord, the chairman of the Shawmut National Corporation, which owns the Connecticut National Bank, the largest in the state as well as a leading bank in Massachusetts, said he was "guardedly optimistic" that the region's economy would hit bottom in the first or second quarter of the year.
He said recent declines in interest rates and the anticipation of some tax cuts should "help turn consumer confidence upward."
Mr. Alvord noted that the deterioration in the region's economy had slowed to the extent that Shawmut would soon announce a significant decline in its most severely troubled loans and would earn more in the fourth quarter than the paltry $2.3 million earned in the third quarter.
The improvement is an important reason, he said, why Shawmut ended the talks with the Bank of Boston Corporation, which also said yesterday that it expected to annouce improved earnings and a decline in its troubled loans.
At Fleet/Norstar, the largest New England-based banking company, badly troubled loans and real estate held because of foreclosures rose only about $89 million, the smallest increase since the first quarter of 1989. Fleet's bad loans and foreclosed real estate are now four times as high as the end of 1989.
 
Bond Investments Pay Off
 Because of $222 million in profits from its bond investments, Fleet earned a profit of $35.2 million, or 22 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, compared with a loss of $58.8 million in the comparable quarter of 1990 and a profit of only $9 million in last year's third quarter.
Despite the $73 million after-tax cost of combining the failed Bank of New England with its other banks, Fleet earned $97.6 million, or 67 cents a share, in 1991, compared with a loss of $73.6 million in 1990.
Fleet's results were positive enough to cause its stock price to rise $3.375 a share, to $29.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.
"Things appear to be bottoming, and in some areas, like Rhode Island, appear to be improving," said John W. Flynn, the chief financial officer.
At the Bank of New York Company, its fourth-quarter profits rose slightly, to $65.9 million, or 82 cents a share, compared with $65 million, also 82 cents a share. Badly delinquent loans and holdings of foreclosed real estate fell by $214 million from the third quarter, to $1.35 billion, as some loans improved and others were sold.
For the year, the Bank of New York earned only $122 million, or $1.28 a share, because of heavy loan losses earlier in the year, down from $308 million, or $3.98 a share, in 1990. Its stock rose $3 yesterday, to $36.625, on the Big Board.
 
First Fidelity Up
 In New Jersey, another state where the economic slump has caused heavy losses for many banks, the First Fidelity Bancorporation in Newark said its nonperforming assets fell by $42.9 million, to $928.9 million. The decline helped the company report a fourth-quarter profit of $57.8 million, or 85 cents a share, up 9 percent from $53 million, or 84 cents a share, a year ago.
For all of 1991, First Fidelity, the state's largest bank, earned $221.2 million, compared with a loss of $6.1 million in 1990.
"The economic recovery will obviously take longer and follow a more shallow curve than had been generally predicted," said Anthony P. Terracciano, the chairman. "But we also believe there will be increasing opportunities for good business as we progress through 1992."

HEADLINE: Robert B. McNee, Instrumental In Geography Theory, Dies at 69

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Robert B. McNee, a prominent geography professor who once headed the American Geographical Society, died Jan. 8 at the U.C.L.A. Medical Center. He was 69 years old and lived in Los Angeles.
He died of complications of lung cancer, his family said. 
 Dr. McNee helped expand the location theory of geography, which holds that things are where they are because of natural and manmade factors alike, including climate, topography, natural resources, transportation services and population. His research focused on international corporations' economic influence on the development of third-world nations.
He also studied urban development and in that role was a consultant to the Ford Foundation. He wrote numerous articles and several books, including "A Primer on Economic Geography" (Random House, 1971).
Born in Big Timber, Mont., he grew up there and in Spring Valley, Minn. He earned a bachelor's degree at Wayne State University and master's and doctoral degrees in geography at Syracuse University. He won a Fulbright fellowship.
He taught geography at City College in Manhattan from 1952 to 1963 and then went to the University of Cincinnati, where he was chairman of the geography department from 1963 to 1973, chairman of the faculty senate and faculty representative on the board of trustees.
He returned to Manhattan as director of the American Geographical Society from 1973 to 1976, a period of financial stress for the organization. Under a restructuring that he helped to plan, the society sold its headquarters on Audubon Terrace, closed its map department and transferred its library, considered one of the most important of its kind, to the University of Wisconsin.
After leaving the society, he went back to the University of Cincinnati where he taught until retiring in 1987.
He volunteered for years as a civil rights advocate for blacks, the homeless, women, the people of Appalachia and homosexuals. Late in his career he publicly acknowledged his own bisexuality, and some called him the honorary mayor of Cincinnati's gay and lesbian community.
Surviving are his wife, the former Doris Smithers, of Worthington, Ohio, from whom he was separated; two sons, Robert McNee of Westport, Conn., and William McNee of Old Greenwich, Conn.; a daughter, Margaret McNee Trikoupis of Worthington, Ohio; two stepsons, Douglas Outterson of Bettendorf, Iowa, and George Outterson of Chapel Hill, N.C., and nine grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Southwestern Bell's Moves Pay Off

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS

 BODY:
When the "Baby Bells" were created by the breakup of A.T.& T., Southwestern Bell won few friends on Wall Street by saying that it planned to stick to its knitting. Analysts favored the glowing talk of the other Baby Bells about opportunities in unregulated businesses.
In the following years, several of the seven Baby Bells stumbled badly in ventures ranging from real estate to computer retailing. Southwestern, meanwhile, demonstrated a knack for moving occasionally but boldly into more closely related businesses, like cellular telephones, paging and investments in overseas phone companies. Now, even though Baby Bell shares have risen handsomely, the former wallflower, Southwestern Bell, trades at an earnings multiple several points above the average for the group. 
 "They've taken some very good calculated risks," said Joel Gross, who follows the phone companies for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "They do a good job of thinking things through and using their money judiciously."
 
A Prosperous Look
 Recently, the recession has dented profits, and the company is still burdened by the weight of its inherited bureaucracy. But a new 11-story computer center under construction next to the company's headquarters here in Missouri's tallest building is a prominent sign that the company is looking forward to continued growth.
Edward E. Whitacre Jr., Southwestern's chief executive, takes obvious delight in showing a visitor a more compact token of things to come: a prototype of a new pocket phone Southwestern is developing with Matsushita of Japan that will allow business executives to be reached at the same personal phone number whether they are wandering around their offices or driving in their cars.
"The time is coming when you won't be able to tell land lines from cellular service," said Mr. Whitacre, a lanky 50-year-old Texan who joined Southwestern in 1963, a year before completing his industrial engineering studies at Texas Tech. "I think it will happen fast."
Southwestern's most adventurous move came in 1986 when Mr. Whitacre's predecessor, Zane Barnes, stunned Wall Street by offering $1.4 billion to acquire the cellular and paging operations of the Metromedia Company. Analysts carped that Southwestern had overpaid by spending nearly $50 for each potential cellular customer. Southwestern proved the analysts wrong as prices for prime territories soared. Although the market has recently weakened, analysts say that Southwestern's properties would fetch more than $300 per potential customer today. Moreover, Southwestern proved more adept than others at turning the growth of cellular services into profits.
Analysts now recognize that Southwestern saw the cellular market as a series of niches requiring a wide variety of marketing plans, products and distribution channels. By the third quarter of last year, it had signed up about 2.5 percent of its potential customers, compared with an average of less than 1.8 percent for the other Baby Bells. More recently, the company has been praised for acquiring rights to rural areas adjacent to its cellular service zones so that cellular phone customers traveling from Chicago to St. Louis, for example, will be customers of Southwestern Bell Mobile Systems Inc. for most of the trip.
 
Invests in Mexico
 In 1990, Mr. Whitacre engineered Southwestern's second diversification coup. The company joined forces with a consortium of Mexican businesses and France Telecom to purchase a controlling interest in Mexico's national phone company. Southwestern emerged with a 5 percent stake for $486 million. It recently exercised an option to double that stake for $467 million.
Once again, analysts initially felt that Southwestern had overpaid. But the stock price of Telefonos de Mexico, or Telmex, has soared since the initial investment, giving Southwestern a paper profit of about $1.67 billion. Better still, Telmex started contributing to actual profits sooner than expected because Southwestern's share of its earnings exceeded the costs of financing the deal within the first year. Now Southwestern is looking to participate in the privatization of other national phone companies.
"The challenge is to find good partners," said Thomas M. Barry, senior vice president in charge of strategic planning. "It's a management issue rather than a technology issue."
Southwestern's business is still concentrated in regulated local and interstate phone services for 9.3 million customers in Texas, Oklahoma, Kansas, Arkansas and Missouri. But it is also pulling in growing profits from cellular operations in distant cities, including Chicago, Washington and Boston; paging services in most of the nation's largest cities, and its investment in Telmex. Other subsidiaries market residential and business phone equipment, publish directories, print products ranging from directories to greeting cards and operate cable television in Britain.
 
A Cautious Approach
 The company expects 30 percent of earnings to be from unregulated businesses by 1993, and possibly more than 50 percent by 1997, Mr. Barry said. "We have lots of opportunities outside the five-state area," he said.
It would be unlike Southwestern, though, to be impetuous in pursuing such opportunities. Southwestern executives say they have broadened the company's definition of its core business but they still favor a cautious approach to diversification. And the company has been quick to pull the plug on unsuccessful new ventures, like its ill-fated effort to compete with other Baby Bells by publishing Yellow Page directories nationwide and its unprofitable attempt to develop a special "Silver Page" directory with advertising for the elderly.
The most important reason to move cautiously, Mr. Whitacre said, is that the weak economy is pinching profits. So are new rate structures in states that account for 85 percent of the company's phone business. Under these "incentive" plans, Southwestern has agreed to reduce charges for the right to higher profits in the future if it can generate savings from new technology and cost-cutting measures. Like the other Baby Bells, Southwestern also worries that regulators will not allow it to adjust pricing and other services to respond to a host of new competitors, ranging from national start-up companies like Metropolitan Fiber Systems to local power companies. The Baby Bells say that the new entrants skim off the most lucrative local phone business without extending their state-of-the-art systems to residences.
 
Complaint on Regulators
 "Regulators want to keep subsidies for residential users but they want competition, too," Mr. Barry said. "It's not economically and technologically possible to do both, but the regulators won't accept that."
Operating profits will be up when Southwestern reports 1991 results next month, but the company might report its first decline in net income. The meager operating gains may not be enough to compensate for an $80.7 million special charge to cover the costs last spring of substituting new lower-interest debt for older borrowings, and the yet-to-be-announced costs of an early retirement program that will eliminate more than 3,000 of 16,000 management positions.
Still, Southwestern executives are upbeat. Many of this year's costs are laying the groundwork for bigger profits in the future, and the recession has yet to come close to the severity of the oil bust they rode out in Oklahoma and Texas in the mid-1980's, at the same time that
a grain glut hurt the economies of Kansas and Missouri. Mr. Whitacre says that the worst of the employee cutbacks are done, but that he still needs to chop away at "the level of bureaucracy."

HEADLINE: Food Stamp Enrollment Continues Sharp Rise, U.S. Agency Reports

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15

 BODY:
The number of Americans receiving food stamps continues to grow sharply, Federal figures show, and more than half the children who eat school lunches receive them free or at reduced prices.
According to the Agriculture Department's latest figures, enrollment in the food stamp program totaled 24.16 million people in October, up 400,000 from a month earlier and up 3.23 million from a year earlier. 
 It was the seventh time in eight months that an enrollment record was set for the program, which reaches nearly 1 in 10 Americans.
The number of children eating a free or reduced-price school lunch at Government expense also continued to rise in October. There were 12.7 million children from impoverished or low-income families receiving the lunches, as against 12.2 million in October 1990.
The department said that 44.1 percent of the 24.9 million school lunches served in October were free and that 7.1 percent were sold at a reduced price. A year earlier, 42 percent of the lunches were free and 7.4 percent were at reduced price.
About 75 percent of elementary school pupils, 64 percent of junior high students and 50 percent of high school students participate in the school lunch program. To qualify for a free lunch, annual income for a family of four cannot exceed $16,510; to qualify for a reduced-price meal, a family's income cannot exceed $23,495.
Annual net income cannot exceed $13,404 for a family of four to qualify for food stamps.
Representative Tony P. Hall, the Ohio Democrat who is chairman of the House Select Committee on Hunger, said Tuesday that the surging enrollment in the Federally financed programs was "the monthly body count of the recession."
A spokesman for the Food and Nutrition Service, the Agriculture Department agency that administers the programs, said the increase in people in the food stamp program could be attributed to changes that make it more accessible to immigrants and others as well as to the slumping economy.
Total Federal spending on the program in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30 was $18.8 billion, while this year's budget is $22.3 billion. The total excludes state costs. The cost of the school lunch program rose to $526 million in October 1991 from $491 million in October 1990.
