HEADLINE: For Arizonans, the Political Circus Is Back in Town

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHOENIX, Jan. 10

 BODY:
In this state where politics has become theater, the latest act stars the new Governor, J. Fife Symington 3d, who faces a Federal lawsuit for his role in a failed savings and loan.
After a four-year run of political embarrassments, said a prominent poll taker, Earl de Berge, "I think people have reached the point where they are not surprised by anything, and the anti-incumbency mood is as deep as I've seen it in 25 years." 
 Mr. Symington was among 12 former directors of a Phoenix savings and loan accused of negligence and self-dealing in a $140 million lawsuit filed last month by the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency in charge of the savings and loan bailout.
The Republican Governor, a successful 46-year-old developer who has been in office less than a year, is fighting back, asserting his innocence, accusing the Government of "Gestapo-like tactics" and threatening to investigate the Federal agency right back.
 
Attacking the Government
 "Besides setting the record straight, we are going to call to account the leakers and liars who abused the process," Mr. Symington said at a news conference after the suit was filed. "The Government bureaucrats responsible for this injustice must pay a price for their recklessness."
Many Arizonans sat back to watch the show. "We don't need soap operas," Louis Rhodes, executive director of the Arizona chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union, said recently. "We just read the morning papers and turn on the talk shows."
Former Gov. Bruce Babbitt, whose term of office in the early 1980's preceded the state's run of bad luck, said this attitude was part of a vicious cycle of cause and effect that had degraded the quality of government.
"When people don't take government seriously, when society has a sort of caricaturist view of government, it tends to be self fulfilling," he said. "There is a sense that government is always bad and politicians are always bad, and maybe the best way to get rid of government is to elect a bunch of people who are circus performers."
 
Years of Entertainment
 Arizonans have had more than their share of eye-opening political entertainment in recent years, beginning with the impeachment of Mr. Babbitt's successor, Evan Mecham, in 1988 for financial irregularities. Mr. Mecham became the first American governor in 59 years to be impeached and removed from office.
A series of political embarrassments followed.
Both the state's United States Senators, Dennis DeConcini, a Democrat, and John McCain, a Republican, were criticized by the Senate Select Committee on Ethics last year after a long and highly publicized investigation into their intervention with regulators on behalf of Charles H. Keating Jr. and his Lincoln Savings and Loan Association.
Early last year, eight state legislators were indicted for receiving bribes in a sting operation in which they were shown in a videotape joking cynically about government and catching wads of cash that were tossed to them.
And Arizona continues to suffer embarrassment and loss of sports and convention revenue for remaining the only state not to have enacted a paid holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
Mr. Symington is not generally viewed as one of the "circus performers" described by Mr. Babbitt. But some analysts say his situation has simply confirmed to many Arizonans that if something can go wrong in politics, sooner or later it will.
"I've looked around the country and I've seen bizarre politics everywhere," said Rob Melnick, director of the Morrison Institute for Public Policy, an independent policy research group associated with Arizona State University.
"But we had one individual here who was so extraordinary, a truly remarkably crazy individual," Mr. Melnick said of Mr. Mecham, "and his legacy has left a spotlight on what would otherwise be normally weird political behavior and made it seem abnormally weird."
Mr. Melnick noted that with a new session of the Legislature opening this week and with a budget debate and legislative reapportionment on the menu the public was likely to be treated once again to the less pretty side of government.
Although Mr. Symington has met with difficulties in his attempt to run government like a business, he is generally described as a bright leader whose political success may ultimately hinge less on his legal problems than on his navigation of the hardship's of the recession.
In the lawsuit against former officers and directors of the Southwest Savings and Loan Association, Federal regulators accuse Mr. Symington of improperly investing $8 million in development fees from a real estate deal.
"If Fife Symington does a good job as Governor of the State of Arizona and can put some of this personal stuff off to the side and let it take care of itself, the people will know that and appreciate that," said Burton Barr, a former majority leader in the state House of Representatives who is now a political consultant.
Mr. Symington has also taken a strong position in favor of instituting a holiday to honor Dr. King, which some analysts say is likely to help his political standing. Creation of a holiday was defeated by voters last fall, but will be on the ballot again this November.
"I think it's premature to write his obituary," Mr. Babbitt said of the Governor, who took office last March and does not face re-election until 1994.
 
Bribery Case in Limelight
 For one thing, a year-old legislative sting scandal, known as Azscam, is set to recapture some of the limelight with the upcoming trial of Senator Carolyn Walker, a Phoenix Democrat. She is one of the legislators who was displayed on videotape in what the authorities say was accepting a bribe from a con man working as an agent for the police. The agent said he was seeking legislation to allow him to open a casino.
While the other seven legislators pleaded guilty and were removed from the Legislature, Ms. Walker has fought the charges, saying she would have voted to legalize casino gambling with or without a bribe.
Nevertheless, she offered one of the highlights of the videotaped civics lesson when she was shown leaning forward to pocket some cash and saying, "We all have our prices." She is accused of taking $25,880 in bribes.
After the Azscam embarrassment, a number of political analysts here voiced their admiration for the group of new legislators who have replaced those removed from office.
All of these new legislators will be up for election this year. But Mr. Babbitt noted that they were not the product of an election but were appointed by county commissioners.
"From the left to the right, political observers see the new crop as an outstanding bunch," Mr. Babbitt said. "It's almost as if it's the final proof of the failure of elected politics."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Down in Hectic Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell still lower in hectic, volatile trading yesterday.
According to market participants, money managers who chose not to realize profits at the end of last year are now selling securities. Some of those accounts are moving a percentage of their fixed-income portfolio into German assets, they said. German interest rates are high relative to American rates, and with Germany appearing to be heading toward recession, money managers are expecting a rally in the German bond market. 
 In addition to profit taking, traders said that talk about a budding economic recovery and what policy makers in Washington might do to spur growth continued to circulate through the debt market. That sort of speculation provided an additional incentive to sell Treasury securities, they said.
 
'Taking Profits, Not Chances'
 "People are taking profits and not taking chances," said Jay Goldinger, a principal at Capital Insight, a bond brokerage firm based in Beverly Hills, Calif. "Right now, the market is a little bit panicked."
The continued rise in the stock market, and particularly in the share prices of major money-center banks, is being seen by some traders as indicating that recovery may not be far off and that the worst of the "credit crunch" may be over.
"Citibank has really been trampled, and now its stock is up about 80 percent from the lows," the trader said. "That tells me the stock market seems to believe the pressure on the financial system is off."
The flow of new corporate debt issues remained strong yesterday, and market participants said the need remained to cover corporate positions by selling Treasury issues.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 1051/32 late yesterday, down 13/32 , to yield 7.57 percent, compared with 7.53 percent late Tuesday.
Among note issues, the 7.50 percent 10-year notes were offered at 103 1/8, down 1/4 point, to yield 7.05 percent. And the 6 3/8 percent seven-year notes were offered at 9723/32 , down 5/32 , to yield 6.79 percent.
Late in the session the Treasury announced it would sell $13.75 billion worth of new two-year notes on Jan. 22 and $9.25 billion worth of new five-year securities on Jan. 23.
In when-issued trading following the announcement, the two-year notes were offered at a price to yield 5.09 percent. The five-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 6.39 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were unchanged to up slightly.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.80 percent in late trading, unchanged from late Tuesday. Six-month bill rates rose by 3 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to a late rate of 3.89 percent. And one-year bill rates rose by 4 basis points, to a late offered rate of 4.00 percent.
 
Rhone-Poulenc Offering
 Among the corporate debt securities priced yesterday was the first offering in American financial markets for Rhone-Poulenc S.A..
The big French chemical company offered $500 million worth of 7.75 percent 10-year notes. The securities were priced at $99.313 to yield 7.85 percent, 80 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7.50 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
Bear, Stearns & Company acted as lead manager for the underwriting. The securities, which are noncallable for life, are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
A competitive offering of $250 million worth of 10-year notes from Paramount Communications Inc. was won by a bid from an investor group led by the First Boston Corporation.
The securities were reoffered to investors with a coupon of 7.50 percent at a price of $98.281, to yield 7.75 percent, 75 basis points above the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7.50 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated A-2 by Moody's and A by S.& P.
Safeway Stores Inc. offered $250 million worth of senior subordinated notes to investors in the high-yield junk-bond market.
The 9.65 percent securities, which mature Jan. 15, 2004, were priced at $100, or par.
Goldman, Sachs & Company acted as lead manager for the underwriting. The securities are rated Ba-3 by Moody's and B+ by S.& P.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 12.30 as Records Keep Tumbling

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Records kept coming yesterday in the stock market in a rush of trading that made the session one of Wall Street's busiest ever. A day after a 60-point surge, the Dow Jones industrial average plowed ahead, gaining 12.30 points more, to 3,258.50, its ninth record in 13 days. And other indexes kept rewriting their records as well.
The engine driving this heady advance apparently remains the same, and remains potent: a combination of low interest rates and a strong belief that the economy is recovering. 
 "The real nut came when depositors at the banks had to start accepting less than 4 percent," said Peter G. Grennan, senior vice president and head of stock index futures trading for Shearson Lehman Brothers.
 
Early Drop Erased
 Prices fell earlier, but those losses were quickly erased, with some analysts saying the early decline may have pulled the market back enough to attract investors for yet another advance.
He called the market's performance "unbelievable," as the money continued to pour into equity mutual funds from banks and certificates of deposit rolling over.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange was a bustling 312.8 million shares, the 13th-busiest day ever. No. 12 was Dec. 20, when 313.8 million shares changed hands the day after the Federal Reserve cut the discount rate one full percentage point. Tuesday's volume was 265.9 million shares. Gainers held a wide lead over losing issues, 1,153 to 652.
Analysts said volatile trading was characterized by a shift of cash into cyclical stocks from defensive stocks as investors continued to bet on an economic recovery.
"There is a tremendous amount of portfolio realignment being done by institutions who are positioning themselves to take advantage of an economic recovery," Mr. Grennan said.
One group of stocks hit particularly hard yesterday were the pharmaceuticals. "Selling was so frenzied in the pharmaceuticals that it smacked of speculation that the economy will turn the corner," said Eugene E. Peroni Jr., director of technical research for Janney, Montgomery Scott. A strong dollar has also hurt these stocks since it has a negative impact on foreign currency translation of revenue from overseas.
Merck fell 4, to 156 1/8; Johnson & Johnson was down 5 1/4, to 108 3/8; Pfizer fell 4 1/8, to 79 3/8; Syntex was down 2 7/8, to 51 1/4, and Glaxo Holdings was down 1 1/8, to 32 3/4.
Some of the key cyclicals benefiting from the shift included the Aluminum Company of America, whose shares jumped in spite of lower earnings. Traders said investors took the company's performance during the sharp recession as a harbinger of strong improvement in case of an economic upturn. The stock rose 4 5/8, to 67 1/8. Others included I.B.M., up 3, to 95 3/8; International Paper, up 2 1/2, to 72 1/8; Caterpillar, up 2 1/2, to 45 1/8, and Walt Disney, up 2 1/2, to 133 1/4.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 0.33 point to make its new high of 420.77. The American Stock Exchange index rose 1.67 points to finish at 414.30, also a high.
Strength in secondary stocks pushed the Nasdaq index up 5.07 points, to a new high of 630.82, as the Russell 2,000 rose 0.96 to a new high of its own, 204.29. The Big Board composite, not to be outdone, rose 0.28 point, to a record 231.85.
"The market's inability to immediately follow up Tuesday's strong advance with a strong opening should not be surprising," said Ricky Harrington, director of equity investments for Marion Bass Securities. "During the last few years a gradual change has taken place in the market. Rallies that were once fueled by small investors are now dominated by large institutions and they can accomplish what they have to do in one session."

HEADLINE: Iraqis Could Pose a Threat Soon, C.I.A. Chief Says

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15

 BODY:
President Saddam Hussein could rebuild Iraq's ability to make nuclear, chemical and biological weapons and its ballistic missile program within a few years, Robert M. Gates, the Director of Central Intelligence, said today.
The timing of Mr. Gates's testimony before the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, on the eve of the first anniversary of the start of the Persian Gulf war, may have been coincidental. But the message was clear: Despite allied success in damaging Iraq's special weapons programs, the country, he said, "is still a great challenge" to nations and organizations that have attempted to disarm it. 
 "In our opinion Iraq will remain a primary proliferation threat at least as long as Saddam Hussein remains in power," Mr. Gates said. He added that "the cadre of scientists and engineers trained for these programs will be able to reconstitute any dormant program rapidly."
Mr. Gates's bleak assessment provided a rationale for continuing stringent economic sanctions against Iraq and intrusive inspections by the United Nations, which, he said, will severely hamper the country's efforts to rebuild its weapons programs. But it also implicitly gave weight to criticism of the Bush Administration for failing to achieve a number of American goals of the Persian Gulf War, including the total destruction of Mr. Hussein's ability to rebuild his weapons arsenal.
Almost a year ago, President Bush proudly told the American people that allied bombers had "put Saddam out of the nuclear-bomb-building business for a long time to come." Since then, teams of United Nations inspectors uncovered secret nuclear installations, programs and equipment.
By expressing his views so openly, Mr. Gates may have been seeking in part to address and rebut criticism raised in his stormy confirmation hearings that he had slanted intelligence to please his bosses.
His testimony also tended to support the creation a few months ago of the Central Intelligence Agency's Non-Proliferation Center, which is charged with tracking the sale, export and production of weapons of mass destruction.
In a wide-ranging overview of weapons proliferation problems, Mr. Gates said Iraq is believed to possess "several hundred" Scud missiles and a substantial quantity of production equipment to make both Scud and Condor missiles. During questioning by Senator John Glenn, the Ohio Democrat who is chairman of the committee, he said, "We're having some difficulty finding them."
Mr. Gates also told Senator Glenn, the only member of the committee present during the hearing, that because Iraq had hidden critical equipment for making biological weapons, it could begin new production in a matter of weeks once sanctions were lifted. Iraq could produce "modest quantities of chemical agents" almost immediately and could recover its pre-war capability in a year or more, he said.
As for Iraq's nuclear weapons program, Mr. Gates said much of the infrastructure for the production of weapons-grade materials must be rebuilt before Iraq can produce nuclear weapons. But he added, "We measure the time required in a few, rather than many, years."
In other testimony, Mr. Gates told Senator Glenn that the intelligence community could not corroborate reports that nuclear, chemical and biological weapons experts and military officials from the former Soviet Union had begun to sell their services abroad. But he added that the possibility of a nuclear "brain drain" was more serious than the possibility of seepage of nuclear-related materials.
Reflecting the conclusions of a recent classified report prepared by the C.I.A. and other intelligence bureaus and agencies, he predicted that countries like Cuba, India, Syria, Egypt and Algeria, which collaborated extensively with Soviet science in the 1980's, were "most likely to have the contacts and resident scientists to assist emigrating Soviets.
Mr. Gates also described what he called Iran's "across-the-board effort" to develop its military and defense industries.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
Both Kerreys Searching For Campaign Strategy

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Jan. 15

 BODY:
Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska strides out onto an empty ice rink, drapes his elbow over a hockey net and gazes earnestly at the camera.
"What's happening in the world economy is like a hockey game," he says, "where others guard their goal to keep our products out, while we leave our net open. 
 "We're becoming a low-wage nation, and all George Bush does is go to Japan and beg for a few concessions," Mr. Kerrey continues. "I'm Bob Kerrey, and if I'm President, the time for begging is through."
This is the new Bob Kerrey: direct, plain speaking, politely pugnacious. New Hampshire voters are meeting this Bob Kerrey through a television advertising campaign that started on Friday and has already, even advisers to other candidates say, perceptibly lifted the Senator's standing.
This is not, however, the same Bob Kerrey whom New Hampshire voters are meeting when they go to hear the candidate at a local high school. That Bob Kerrey is still the old Bob Kerrey: quirky, indirect and diffident.
Earlier this month, Mr. Kerrey hired a new campaign director and a new media team to impose a sense of direction on a campaign that seemed to be wandering. Since then the campaign, as evidenced by the television spots, has indeed begun to plot a new course. But the candidate, it seems, does not necessarily intend to follow it. And with just five weeks to go before the New Hampshire primary, Mr. Kerrey and his advisers still seem to be struggling to find a strategy they all can live with.
"I like the fact that he's not some programmed Ken doll that you can just wind up and send out there," one adviser to Mr. Kerrey said. "But living with the consequences of that is tough."
The difficulty of reconciling who Mr. Kerrey is with the candidate his advisers would like to project is a reflection of the same idiosyncrasies that have made the Senator alternately the darling and the disappointment of the Democratic primary season.
Mr. Kerrey did not set out to be a career politician; he was a businessman who was elected Governor of Nebraska and then Senator without having served any of the apprenticeships usually required for such posts. His biography, including his heroic service in Vietnam, made him seem the perfect candidate for a country openly disgusted with professional politics.
 
Not Afraid of Unpopular Stands
 In the campaign, Mr. Kerrey has put his apparent ambivalence toward politics to good use as a sign that he is not afraid to take unpopular stands for the good of the country.
"I'm not concerned about Bob Kerrey's political career," he said in response to questions about a recent poll. "I'm concerned about the economic status of the United States of America. We're going to have to be bold and we're going to have to be courageous. We're going to have to come politically prepared to risk having polling data show that we're flat."
But political analysts and even associates of Mr. Kerrey say that his unconventional career has prompted him to place too much confidence in the appeal of an independent personality. "That personal appeal has obviously been at the core of his success so far," said Ann Lewis, a political consultant based in Boston. "But it doesn't translate to the Presidential campaign."
At first, Ms. Lewis said, Mr. Kerrey was plagued by the perception that he had not lived up to his resume. Now, she said, he faced the problem of being measured against his television spots. "The question still is, can he in person live up to what people know and hear about him?" she said.
Before arriving at the advertisements Mr. Kerrey now has on television, the campaign's original media consultant, Joe Rothstein, shot almost a dozen commercials, most of them showing the candidate talking with New Hampshire voters. Several advisers saw the spots as too fuzzy for a campaign that was already being criticized for a lack of focus, and they successfully urged Mr. Kerrey to reject them.
 
Quoting From Ads
 The new commercials were shot by Doak, Shrum, Harris, Sherman & Donilon, a media consulting firm that Mr. Kerrey, after much agonizing, hired to replace Mr. Rothstein. The new advertisements -- in addition to the hockey spot, there is one on national health insurance -- were shot after Mr. Kerrey had met with his new consultants for just a few hours. They were on the air within two days.
Mr. Kerrey seems genuinely enamored of his advertisements, so much so, in fact, that he began to quote from them in a recent interview. "We've got to look Japan in the eye and say what's going on in the world economy is like a hockey game," he told an interviewer on WMUR-TV, a Manchester station. "They're blocking their markets while we've got ours wide open."
But in person, the Senator remains much more complicated and more distant than the straightforward, aggressive politician who appears on television. Talking to a group of workers here on Tuesday, Mr. Kerrey spoke not about getting tough with Japan, but about "the urgent need in America to develop an industrial policy that expresses a preference for high value-added jobs." His prescription for the economy includes several new agencies with bureaucratic-sounding names, like the Industrial Extension Service, and a five-year plan to support what he calls "generic technologies."
At this point it is unclear how much Mr. Kerrey's new campaign team, including his new manager, Tad Devine, will try to change the candidate's style on the stump. So far, most of the candidate's top advisers have remained in Washington while he has been traveling around New Hampshire. And those who have known Mr. Kerrey for many years warn that he is not likely to submit to handlers who want to tinker with his persona.
"What has worked for him politically is spontaneous combustion," one adviser said. "He doesn't want to be slick."

HEADLINE: Boy Is Raped and Neighbors Ponder the Horror

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY

 BODY:
In all the fear and confusion felt by parents and neighbors who learned that an 11-year-old boy was abducted and raped at 8 A.M. on Tuesday on West 77th Street and that a man with H.I.V. had been charged, there were really only two gut reactions. Some people tried to reassure themselves that so horrible a crime in their quiet gentrified neighborhood was aberrational. Others talked of moving out of town. All agreed that the incident was any parent's worst nightmare.
"What is the magic age at which you can envision letting your child go to school by himself?" said Allan Ripp, whose 6-year-old attends Public School 87, next to Intermediate School 44, the victim's school on West 77th Street. "God, this isn't about our schools, this is about what is happening in this city." 
 What happened in Mr. Ripp's neighborhood was a crime that combined some of the most horrifying elements of city life. It occurred while New York City was already at fever pitch over a series of race-baiting attacks on children, including an incident in which the faces of black and Hispanic children were smeared with white liquids and a 15-year-old was raped by two black men, who, she said, told her that they attacked her because she was "white and perfect."
While parents and children on a genteel block of the Upper West Side grappled with the 11-year-old's kidnapping and his exposure to the AIDS virus, gay groups in the city expressed concern that the suspect's right to confidentiality about his infection had been violated by the police.
The police said the boy was walking by himself to I.S. 44 between Amsterdam and Columbus Avenues, when an unemployed 27-year-old, Troy A. Rivera, grabbed and forced him into Mr. Rivera's apartment at 172 West 77th Street, a brick apartment building a few doors west of the school.
The District Attorney's complaint laid out the child's ordeal in chillingly plain words. "The defendant told the informant to take off his clothes and threatened to beat him if he did not," the statement said. "Informant refused and defendant forcibly removed the informant's clothes and his own clothes."
The complaint says that Mr. Rivera ordered the child to perform oral sex on him and that when the child refused, Mr. Rivera threw him on the bed and raped him. Afterward, when Mr. Rivera went to the bathroom, the victim gathered his clothes and ran to his school. Officials there sent him to the Roosevelt Hospital emergency room and contacted the police.
District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau charged Mr. Rivera with second-degree kidnapping and first- and second-degree sodomy. A spokesman for the Mr. Morgenthau, Gerald McKelvey, said the prosecutor was still investigating whether to file additional charges "relating to his knowingly exposing the child to the H.I.V. virus."
Several states have enacted laws making such an act a crime. New York has not.
 
Risk of Infection Low
 The risk of contracting the virus that causes AIDS after one exposure is low, but is impossible to calculate accurately, experts said yesterday. A spokesman for the Federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta, John Taylor, said that in cases of a one-time contact during anal intercourse between men "the risk of transmission ranges from 1 in 19 to 1 in 50."
A seventh grader at I.S. 44, Meghan Andrews, 12, said she used to complain to her father that she was too old to be walked to her bus stop, but not any more. "I'm scared," she said outside the school building. "I feel a lot different. I'm never going to walk alone again."
Parents felt just as helpless. "We have been talking about moving out of the city for quite a while," said Keiko Narahashi, a mother of two whose eldest child attends P.S. 87. "When they're young you can be on top of them all the time, but not when they are older."
After his arrest, the police revealed that Mr. Rivera had told them that he had AIDS. The police did not test him, but said they would most likely subpoena his medical records.
"How did the police learn he was H.I.V. positive, and why did they release it?" asked William K. Dobbs, a lawyer and member of Act Up, a group that lobbies for AIDS patients' rights. "I am concerned about sensationalism and homophobia in the press coverage and the prosecution."
Capt. William K. Rowe of the Manhattan detective bureau said a friend of the suspect who had been present at the arrest told the police that Mr. Rivera was H.I.V. positive. Based on that information and officers' observations of "an awful lot of prescription drugs in his apartment, literally 30 to 40 bottles, all made out in his name," Captain Rowe asked Mr. Rivera whether he was H.I.V. positive.
Captain Rowe said Mr. Rivera had said yes and said that the disease was diagnosed in 1987, while he was in prison. Captain Rowe said Mr. Rivera had volunteered that he has full-blown AIDS. "I said, 'What is your condition now?' " Captain Rowe recounted. "He said, 'Not too good.' He said he had problems with his chest and had other ailments. He said he had herpes and things of that nature.
"He told me he had a lot of sexual encounters with male teen-agers. I inquired how old they were. He said 17 and above."
 
Paroled in November 1990

 Mr. Rivera has two convictions. He was arrested in Manhattan in 1980 and charged with attempted grand larceny. He pleaded to a lesser charge of disorderly conduct and served no prison time. In 1982, Mr. Rivera was arrested again. He was charged with sodomy and robbery with injury. He pleaded guilty to the robbery charge and was sentenced in 1984. He served six years of his 6-to-18-year sentence and was paroled in November 1990.
A neighbor in Mr. Rivera's building who insisted on anonymity said he helped Mr. Rivera find his apartment last summer. The neighbor said he saw a note from Mr. Rivera saying he was homeless and had AIDS on a bulletin board at the Gay Men's Health Crisis. The neighbor said he responded to the note and put Mr. Rivera in contact with the broker of the apartment. The neighbor said that Mr. Rivera's $850-a-month rent was being paid with the assistance of the City Human Resource Administration's division of AIDS services and that Mr. Rivera was in touch with a caseworker there.
Parole officials confirmed that the welfare agency was giving Mr. Rivera rental assistance.
The neighbor also said Mr. Rivera continually took young male children to his apartment and estimated their ages to be 14 and 15, but said they never appeared as young as 11.
 
'They Looked Embarrassed'
 "They didn't look like they were there forcibly," the neighbor said. "But they looked embarrassed. They wouldn't look at you."
The neighbor said he called the police four times in the summer with his concerns about the boys and gave the police Mr. Rivera's name. He declined, however, to give the police his own name and said he was told that an adult's being seen with young boys was, in and of itself, not a crime.
Asked about the neighbor's account, Captain Rowe said, "I don't have any knowledge of the calls coming in previously."
Mr. Rivera has seen his parole officer 13 times since the end of September, officials said, and there was no indication that he had violated his parole before Tuesday.
The morning after the rape, school officials ordered uniformed guards to patrol the block around the school and tried to deal with the rape.
"They were asking if the boy was now H.I.V. positive," Meghan Andrews, said of her classmates in a sex-education class yesterday morning. They did not receive an answer.
"We are sort of pleading ignorance on the H.I.V. questions," said Steven Siegelbaum, director of the Computer School, a magnet school in the I.S. 44 building. "We don't want to fan the flames."

HEADLINE: METRO-NORTH JOURNAL;
Suddenly, Travelers at Grand Central Miss a Funky Old Friend

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO

 BODY:
It wasn't B. Altman or the Horn & Hardart Automat, both major landmarks recently vanished from the New York retail firmament.
But for thousands of commuters who passed the Commuter Book Centre in Grand Central Terminal day after day, its sudden disappearance has left perhaps as great a void. 
 The oldest retail establishment in the terminal -- there since 1961 -- the bookshop had nothing in common with antiseptic chain bookstores. For one thing, the staff seemed to know a lot about books. The selection was eclectic and broad, straying far from the trashy novel and best seller. And the volumes were often in the wrong place on the shelves, and that made for good browsing.
Over the years many commuters had worked the store into their daily routines. Metro-North riders not only went there to pick up a good read for the trip home to Westchester County or Connecticut; they depended on the cluttered aisles as an oasis amid the sometimes menacing atmosphere of the terminal.
"In Grand Central, there were two things you could do if you missed your train and were waiting for another," said Harold Holzer, a commuter from Rye. "You could go to the Commuter bookstore and browse or you could dodge the people at Grand Central who weren't waiting for a train.
"It was a haven, a literary haven," added Mr. Holzer, executive vice president of the state's Urban Development Corporation.
City residents who use the subways were also hooked on the store's raffish charm -- and equally dismayed when it closed without warning on New Year's Eve.
"I am absolutely stunned," said Marge Baxter, a Chelsea resident who works for a midtown outplacement firm. She paused in front of the store's papered-over windows, her face broadcasting bewilderment.
"I spent 20 bucks a week there for three years," she said. "I knew where all the books were. I got a Latin dictionary for my son there, for God's sake."
Perhaps most stunned of all were officials of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad. The owner of the bookstore, Marvin Weiss, owed Metro-North a year's worth of rent, or $182,000. Most of that applied to the bookstore, but some was for two other stores at the terminal, a card shop and a sporting goods store.
The lease for all three stores, on the upper level near the corner of 42d Street and Vanderbilt Avenue, had been in Mr. Weiss's name for 30 years. All closed for good on New Year's Eve without any notice to customers or to Metro-North.
A Metro-North spokeswoman, Marjorie Anders, said the railroad did not know where Mr. Weiss is. A collection agency is trying to find him so Metro-North can sue for the unpaid rent.
"They took all the stock of value -- all the hardcovers," Ms. Anders said. Still in the store are some greeting cards and paperbacks whose covers were ripped off, apparently so they could be sent to wholesalers for refunds. Some empty champagne bottles were left behind, too: vestiges, perhaps, of a very private going-out-of-business celebration.
Oddly, the store appeared to be doing a handsome business. Richard Hollender, a 46-year-old Scarsdale resident who had bought the poetry of Frost and Coleridge there, never imagined it to be in financial straits. "With the economy the way it is, however, I shouldn't be surprised," he said. Metro-North is seeking a new tenant for the store.
Patrons say they will most remember the store's character and convenience, two traits that seldom intersect these days.
Al Sulenski liked the convenience. "Sometimes you'd need a card to take home for an occasion you forgot about, like an anniversary or birthday," Mr. Sulenski said.
Gerald Paul, a partner in the law firm of Flemming, Zulack & Williamson and a Rye resident, liked the character.
"The place had a certain homeyness," he said. "The aisles were impossibly narrow. The signs for fiction and biography looked like a fourth-grade class project. There weren't a lot of staff people walking around wearing badges with their names on them."
Many commuters now wonder where they'll bide the minutes till the next train. "I don't know what I'll do," said Max Friedman, a pharmaceutical company executive who commutes from Larchmont. "I guess I'll wait in Zaro's and eat bagels and just get fat instead of getting smart."

HEADLINE: New Sanitation Chief Hopes To Push Recycling Business

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Emily Lloyd, who will become New York City's Sanitation Commissioner next month, said yesterday that she hoped to develop new recycling markets that would attract new businesses and jobs to New York City and to encourage communities and businesses to share in keeping the city's streets and sidewalks clean.
Ms. Lloyd, the chief business strategist for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, will be inheriting an agency racked by budget cuts that have savaged the city's recycling, street cleaning and dumping enforcement programs. But Ms. Lloyd, 46 years old, who is also an expert on transportation and environmental issues, expressed optimism yesterday that the sanitation agency would find new ways to manage the city's mounting waste problems in the wake of growing fiscal restraints. 
 "It's obviously more fun to do this type of work when you can throw a lot of money at the problem," Ms. Lloyd said, but the Sanitation Department staff has hard-working people who can make a difference.
At a City Hall news conference in which Mayor David N. Dinkins announced her appointment yesterday , Ms. Lloyd said the city, a large supplier and user of recyclable materials like newsprint, office paper, tires and corrugated boxes, could work to get more businesses to participate in the recycling program.
In addition, she said, neighborhood clean-up programs sponsored by businesses and community groups have been very successful and that she planned to encourage more of them. "We tend to be a little cynical in New York about people pitching in," Ms. Lloyd said. "But it really does work."
Ms. Lloyd said she was still studying the the city's decision to build huge garbage-burning incinerators to dispose of trash as remaining landfills reach capacity.
Ms. Lloyd, a former Boston Transportation Commissioner, currently heads the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey's Office of Business Development.
Environmental advocacy groups praised Ms. Lloyd's appointment yesterday. James T. B. Tripp, general counsel for the Environmental Defense Fund and chairman of the Citywide Recycling Board, said: "To have someone at the Sanitation Department who is both familiar with waste management and economic development is very exciting." Eric A. Goldstein, a lawyer with the Natural Resources Defense Council, said Ms. Lloyd has "an interesting mix of talents and we are keeping our fingers crossed that she will be able to make a breakthrough on recycling."
When not working, Ms. Lloyd, who lives in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, said that she enjoys playing tennis and skating with her two children.

HEADLINE: Sea Bright Is Still Reeling from Halloween Storm

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEA BRIGHT, N.J.

 BODY:
It's a sight that Sgt. Steve Spahr says he'll never forget: A steel dumpster floating down Ocean Avenue, the main thoroughfare here, as floodwaters and flotsam from the normally benign Shrewsbury River crept toward the steps of police headquarters.
"That was a long night," he said, recalling Halloween, when local volunteers and National Guardsmen in 2 1/2-ton trucks helped evacuate nearly a dozen families from this Monmouth County shore community after a storm that caused some $72 million in damage along the New Jersey coastline. "And the worst of it," said Sergeant Spahr, the borough's emergency management coordinator, "is that I think we're in for a few more long nights."
 
U.S. Decision Attacked
 Traditionally, Atlantic Coastal storms with high-velocity winds and tides that surge two to three feet above normal besiege this region from late January through early March. The October storm and a similar but milder one that passed through here on Jan. 4 were unexpected, and many longtime residents view them as a preview of what's to come. 
 But beyond such fears, say residents and borough officials, they are increasingly bitter about the Federal Government's decision to deny the community disaster relief, though damage from the October storm has been estimated here at nearly $2 million.
"You have to be blind not to see the damage all through here," said Mayor Charles Rooney Jr., a retired factory worker. "With all the erosion we've had here, we're literally standing naked against the next storm." He added: "When you have storms of the intensity like we've seen, tons and tons of sand get washed out to sea, and that can't be replaced. We've got pilings on buildings exposed here and boulders jutting out of the shoreline."
Mr. Rooney said that his efforts to obtain Federal relief funds have caused him exasperation beyond words. "We were told that the damage here and along the rest of the Jersey Shore wasn't severe enough," he said. "But I tell you one thing, if this were the Japanese coast being pounded away, you wouldn't be able to count the amount of money flooding in."
Frank Pallone Jr. of Long Branch, the Democratic Congressman who represents Sea Bright, said he shares the Mayor's frustration. The Federal Emergency Management Agency turned down the aid request in part, he said, because beach replenishment does not qualify for such funding. The state, said Mr. Pallone, has appealed the denial, and Federal inspectors are touring shore points to re-evaluate claims from many hard-hit towns. The inspectors are expected in Monmouth County next week.
"I tell people that the Jersey Shore is just like a car," said Mr. Rooney. "If you don't maintain it, look after it, give it the care and attention it deserves, you won't have it around, for business or for pleasure."
 
'No Beaches, No Tourists'
 Sea Bright, like many shore towns from Sandy Hook to Cape May, is dependent on tourist dollars. Its population swells during the summer from about 1,800 to just over 5,000. Nearly four million tourists enjoy its beaches annually, officials say. For many business owners, beach erosion means a loss of revenue, and loss of revenue, they say, means business closings.
"No beaches, no tourists," said Mr. Rooney. "You don't have to be a genius or a Trenton legislator to draw your own conclusions."
At Steve's Luncheonette on Ocean Avenue, the talk over steaming cups of coffee these days is of recovery, both from the storms and from the economic doldrums.
"I've seen it worse," said Stephen A. Garelli, the luncheonette's owner, as he turned a mound of hash browns on a sizzling grill. "Back in '84, when a nor'easter came through, there was three feet of water in here and the windows and the roof blew out. But we came back, just like a lot of people around here, and we expect to stay."
 
Goods Raised Above Ground
 Michael E. Clayton of Fair Haven, who owns a restaurant supply business on River Street, agrees. "Over the years, we've learned to stack merchandise off the ground, way off the ground," he said. But, he admitted, "back on Halloween, I got hit bad, about $24,000 in damage."
Mr. Clayton's losses were covered by insurance, but borough officials say that many of Sea Bright's senior citizens were not so fortunate. Because they subsist on meager pensions or Social Security, they often do without flood insurance, the officials said. Though such insurance is now mandatory for new construction, longtime residents say that high premiums preclude it.
Dorothy L. Nelson, who is 68 years old and a lifelong resident of Sea Bright, says she is well aware of the risks of living at the shore without flood insurance. The Halloween storm was "the second worst I have had to endure," she said, but her Center Street home narrowly escaped damage because 14 years ago, when she bought it, she had it raised four feet onto concrete blocks. "It was an expensive thing to do back then," she said, "but I've gotten my money's worth."
"Many of us around here gamble with the weather," Mrs. Nelson mused. "Most times you win; sometimes you lose." Despite the risks, she finds Sea Bright's lure inescapable: "When the weather is calm, such as the spring and summer, there's no place I'd rather be, even if there is a price to be paid."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Campbell Soup Taps P.& G. for Executive

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
When Frank E. Weise 3d leaves the $27 billion Procter & Gamble Company for the $6.2 billion Campbell Soup Company, he will actually be departing for a company that is nearly twice as big as his present employer.
Now the chief financial officer at P.& G.'s food and beverage products division, a $3.5 billion business, Mr. Weise will become, effective Feb. 3, the senior vice president and chief financial officer for all of Campbell Soup. 
 Now 47 years old, he will also presumably have a fair shot at becoming chief executive, when David W. Johnson, 59, the president and chief executive officer -- and the man who recruited him -- retires or moves on.
Mr. Weise's hiring comes at a significant time for Campbell Soup, which possesses one of the world's most recognized brand names. In 1989, the company was the object of intense takeover speculation on Wall Street because the once-restive Dorrance family, which owns about 57 percent of the company, had been unhappy with Campbell's pallid earnings and faltering revenues.
But Mr. Johnson, a turnaround specialist hired away from the Gerber Products Company, has since made peace with the dissident Dorrance family members, while paring down costs and seeking to eliminate unprofitable operations. In the year that ended on last July 28, Campbell earned $3.16 a share, up from 3 cents a year earlier.
Campbell's stock closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at $39.25, down $1.375 a share, compared with $43.875, its 52-week high.
Mr. Weise replaces Edwin L. Harper, who resigned last July to pursue other interests.
He brings a rich background from Procter & Gamble, one of the world's premier consumer-products companies. In 1967, he joined P.& G. right after a five-year program in business and economics at Lehigh University.
He was good at mathematics and was originally intent on becoming an engineer, but moved away from the field because it seemed too narrow and solitary. Finance fascinated him.
"Data itself is not boring; it's what you do with it that's important," Mr. Weise said in an interview yesterday. "I get my kicks out of data."
His first P.& G. job was analyzing the advertising spending for such products as Scope mouthwash, Crest toothpaste and Head and Shoulders shampoo. Later, he worked for the company in England and Belgium, before returning to the United States in 1983.
He was the top officer overseeing Olestra, the company's long-awaited fat substitute that it hopes can revolutionize cooking the way Nutrasweet has revolutionized sweeteners. In 1987, he took over as the chief financial officer for the food and beverage division, which produces Crisco oil, Folgers' coffee and Hawaiian Punch fruit drink, among others.
When a headhunter spoke to Mr. Weise in September about the Campbell job, he agreed, somewhat reluctantly, to meet Mr. Johnson for dinner at a hotel. They wound up talking for four hours. "We never did get around to eating; I had to catch a plane," Mr. Weise recalled.
At Campbell, Mr. Weise plans first to study the company intensively and identify growth areas. "I learned a lot, and I owe a lot to Procter & Gamble," he said, "but this place is just seething with opportunity."

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Yields Are Down Sharply for Money Funds

 BODY:
The money funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report continued to show lower yields yesterday for both tax-exempt and taxable funds.
"Now we are seeing the full effect of the Federal Reserve's recent easing of interest rates showing up in money fund yields," said Walter Frank, economist for the organization. "Earlier this year, the effects were masked somewhat by year-end influences. We will see some further decline in money fund yields. But until we get some further action from the Federal Reserve, the bulk of the decline in short-term yields is behind us." 
 For the tax-exempt funds, the seven-day compounded average yield dropped to 3.04 percent from 3.89 percent, while the seven-day simple yield dropped to 3.00 percent from 3.82 percent, continuing the recent sharp decline in yields. During the same period, the 30-day compounded yield also fell, declining to 3.84 percent from 4.01 percent, and the 30-day simple yield dropped to 3.77 percent from 3.93 percent.
The top Connecticut fund was Fidelity Connecticut Municipal Money Market Portfolio, which reported a seven-day compounded yield of 3.54 percent, compared with the 4.50 percent yield of the previous week's leader.
In New Jersey, the top fund was Prudential N.J. Muni Money Market Fund, with a yield of 3.58 percent, compared with a 4.40 percent yield reported by last week's leader.
In New York, the top fund was once again Salomon Brothers N.Y. Municipal Money Market fund. It had a seven-day compounded yield of 3.83 percent, compared with 4.47 percent a week ago.
 
Increase in Assets
 Assets of the tax-exempt funds rose this week by $2.3 billion, to $97.4 billion.
Donoghue's said the average number of days to maturity of securities held in the tax-free portfolios dropped by two days, to 53 days.
Of the funds monitored by IBC/ Donoghue's with assets larger than $100 million, the Strong Municipal Money Market Fund of Milwaukee continued to lead the way once again with a seven-day compounded yield of 4.29 percent, down from 4.91 percent the previous week.
Meanwhile, assets of the taxable funds rose by $11.8 billion, to a new record total of $495 billion, up from the previous record of $483.2 billion set last week. The average number of days to maturity of holdings in the taxable funds rose by one day, to 57 days.
The average seven-day compounded taxable yield dropped 21 basis points, to 4.28 percent, from 4.49 percent the previous week, while the seven-day simple yield fell by the same number of basis points, to 4.19 percent from 4.40 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
At the same time, the 30-day compounded yield declined to 4.51 percent from 4.62 percent, and the simple yield went down to 4.41 percent from 4.52 percent.
The taxable fund with the best seven-day compounded return for the week was Fidelity Spartan Money Market Fund, with a yield of 5.28 percent.
By comparison, the average bank money market account, a prime competitor of money funds, was at 3.99 percent, compared with 4.06 percent a week ago, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index.

HEADLINE: A Republican Speaker Takes Politics to Heart

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, who took over the gavel this week as the new Speaker of the Assembly and the undisputed leader of an ironclad Republican majority, is a man for whom taking politics to heart is a family tradition.
Mr. Haytaian, the son of Armenian immigrants, grew up in the Bronx and remembers his father as an uncompromising Democrat. 
 "My dad was not actively involved in politics," Mr. Haytaian recalled recently during a break from the Assembly floor, where, as usual, he was harrying the Democrats for what he saw as something akin to an assault on the future of the state in the waning hours of the lame-duck session.
 
Father 'Lost Everything'
 "But he was a very staunch Democrat," Mr. Haytaian said. "He had lost everything in the Depression; he had owned a restaurant, owned some land in Bergen County, but he lost everything.
"I was 14 or 15, and my mother bought a Hoover vacuum cleaner and put it in the closet. My dad saw the box, Hoover, and said, 'What's this?' and she said, 'It's a Hoover vacuum cleaner,' and he said, 'Get it out of the house.'
"She said, 'David, you're crazy, it's a vacuum cleaner!' and he said, 'I don't care what it is, it's got Hoover's name on it. Get it out of the house.' "
His mother dutifully returned the offending appliance to the store.
 
A Fiscal Demon
 Mr. Haytaian (pronounced high-TIE-yan) brought something of the same single-mindedness to his eight years as a minority and majority leader for his party, the Republicans. He began shifting toward Republicanism in his teens, and by the time he graduated from the University of Alabama with a degree in electrical engineering in 1961 -- he was leaving just as a fellow named Joe Namath was entering -- he was convinced that what the Democrats mostly did was, as he loves to say today, "tax and spend, tax and spend, tax and spend," as if by repetition he can exorcise the fiscal demon.
Demon or not, he is doing very well at exorcising Democrats. Along with Assemblyman Robert Franks, who is also the Republican state chairman, Mr. Haytaian was a leading architect of the Republican campaign assault in the Nov. 5 legislative elections in which every Republican candidate in the state, courthouse to statehouse, ran on a single theme: opposition to what they relentlessly labeled "the Florio-Democrat $2.8 billion tax increase."
It was Mr. Haytaian who set the theme in motion 19 months ago by instructing every single Republican in the Assembly to vote against the tax increase, which was rammed through the Legislature in the wee hours of the morning by the Democratic majority.
 
Symbolic Bandannas
 It was also Mr. Haytaian, acting gleefully on the suggestion of a fellow Republican Assemblyman, Richard Kamin, who was the principal stage director for a piece of legislative theater that got good photo play across the state during the tax debate in 1990. Mr. Haytaian and his Republican colleagues showed up on the Assembly floor wearing bright red bandannas across their mouths, symbolizing what they said was the "gagging" of debate by the Democratic majority.
Mr. Haytaian, who chuckles often, still chuckles about that.
The aggressive Republican assault on the tax increase, with Mr. Haytaian as often as not leading the charge, devastated the Democrats.
After the dust cleared, the Republicans had won control of both houses of the Legislature for the first time in two decades, and they had done it by winning veto-proof, two-thirds majorities in both houses, 27 to 13 in the Senate and 58 to 22 in Mr. Haytaian's Assembly. He was elected Speaker by acclamation.
But the political gamesmanship did not end there. Disgruntled Democrats, still in the majority, promptly came up with a put-up-or-shut-up strategy, introducing legislation to pull back all $2.8 billion of the tax increase, which was what the Republicans, including Mr. Haytaian, had been calling for before the election.
 
Sidestepping Disaster
 The Democratic strategy was confusing to some voters but quite clear to politicians on both sides of the aisle. Although the Republicans had been screaming about the huge tax increase, it was obvious to anyone who looked at the numbers that a blanket repeal would create a governmental disaster. By one measure, for example, it would mean eliminating every one of the 65,000 employees in state government.
That meant that if the taxes were rolled back, the incoming Republican majority would have to reinstate all or most of them, or let government collapse.
The repeal legislation zipped through the Senate and was dumped in Mr. Haytaian's lap in the Assembly. He instructed the Republicans to boycott Assembly sessions and to caucus instead in a diner. The Democrats, troubled by illnesses and vacancies, could not achieve a quorum, so no business could be conducted.
Although Mr. Haytaian had called for total repeal and in fact told the Democrats proposing it, "Go ahead, make my day," he said he saw no hypocrisy in the about-face.
With the failure of the Democratic rollback proposal, all $2.8 billion in tax increases remain on the books as Mr. Haytaian takes office, and whatever cutting is done will be done by Republicans.
Now, he said, he will push ahead with a Republican plan to roll back about a quarter of the tax package, reducing the sales tax to 6 percent from 7 percent. He insists that he is not ruling out other cuts, even in the face of declining revenues amid a recession.
 
Clouding the Issue
 "We will absolutely cut the sales tax, and I feel strongly about the other taxes being on the table," Mr. Haytaian said. "But all this discussion about a total repeal has clouded the issue, people calling me a hypocrite because I'm not for repeal. That's wrong. I am. But I don't believe for a minute that you can repeal revenues without repealing the programs."
Now that he holds the third-highest position in state government, behind the Governor and the Senate President, Mr. Haytaian insists that his days as a political bomb thrower are over.
"I threw bombs politically because I had a bomb thrower's positions; my positions as minority leader and majority leader were very partisan," he said. "As Speaker, I won't be as partisan."
Indeed, he says he and the incoming Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, a Republican, will work closely with the Democratic Governor, Jim Florio, whom they have previously battered zealously.
"It's Machiavellian," Mr. Haytaian acknowledged. "If Governor Florio succeeds, we succeed. If he fails, we fail. If we fail, he fails. So it is important that we work with the executive, and people will be surprised that we agree more than we disagree."
At the same time, Mr. Haytaian concedes that he is taking aim at some of the Governor's keystone programs. He plans to rearrange the aid formulas under the Governor's Quality Education Act, which funnels state aid to 30 poor "special needs" urban school districts and a number of moderate-income districts at the expense of the wealthy ones. He also wants to revise the automobile insurance program set in place amid enormous difficulty and to further "downsize" government.
But in doing so, Mr. Haytaian, who is generally well liked personally on both sides of the aisle -- even his Democratic predecessor as Speaker, Joseph V. Doria Jr., with whom he squabbles endlessly, describes him as "a genuinely nice person" -- insists that he will not use the bulletproof Republican majority to hammer the Governor.
"People want an executive branch and a legislative branch, and with override, we can be both of them," he observed. "But people don't want that. I hope we never get into a situation where we have to override the Governor."
So has he turned aside politics to become totally a statesman?
"Good government is good politics, and good politics is good government," he said. "I don't think anyone is ever going to say Haytaian is a statesman."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "All this discussion about a total repeal has clouded the issue, people calling me a hypocrite because I'm not for repeal," said Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, the New Jersey Assembly Speaker. "That's wrong. I am. But I don't believe for a minute that you can repeal revenues without repealing the programs." (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Oil Up on OPEC Reports; Copper and Silver Advance

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Oil prices jumped yesterday on reports that a third OPEC member will reduce the amount of oil it pumps to bolster the sagging market.
Nigeria was reported to be the latest member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries planning to cut its oil production, although executives at Nigerian oil companies could not confirm any reduction. They said, however, that a cut would not surprise them. 
 Venezuela and Libya had said they would make small cuts, and the Venezuelan Energy Minister, Celestino Armas, expressed confidence that the other OPEC members would agree to siphon off production to ease the world oil glut.
February crude oil rose 38 cents, to $18.85 a barrel, and February unleaded gasoline gained 0.81 cent, to 53.34 cents a gallon, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. February heating oil, supported by a sudden fall in temperatures in the Northeast that will likely increase demand, added 0.98 cent, to 54.05 cents a gallon.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, copper and silver prices posted strong advances.
Traders cited pent-up speculative demand for the precious metals, particularly with optimistic investors foreseeing a turnaround in the world economy that would increase demand from industry.
"All the base metals have been firm," led by the London aluminum market, which was up $50 a metric ton at one point, said Fred Demler, an analyst for Paine Webber Inc.
March copper rose 1.15 cents a pound, to 95.85 cents, while March silver gained 6 cents, to $4.16 an ounce.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, soybean prices rebounded in what analysts termed a technical rally, as wheat prices extended their gains.
Heavy buying from commodity funds brought the 10.75-cent rise in March soybeans, to $5.71 1/4 a bushel.
A request for 340,000 metric tons of wheat by Egypt under a United States subsidy program kept the rally in wheat going, and the March contract closed 3.75 cents higher at $4.16 3/4 a bushel. Harsh winter weather in the Great Plains states added to concerns about wheat supplies later this summer, and the July contract rose 7.25 cents, to $3.78 1/2 a bushel.

HEADLINE: Business Sales Increased By Only 0.1% in November

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Business sales crept up just a tenth of 1 percent in November, providing little spark for greater production and new jobs, a Government report showed today.
Businesses increased their inventories by two-tenths of 1 percent in November, but that pace was slower than the gains of four-tenths of 1 percent in each of the previous two months, according to the Commerce Department's figures. 
 "The critical question is whether the inventory buildup is voluntary or involuntary," said Samuel D. Kahan, an economist at Fuji Securities in Chicago.
 
'Picking Up From Lean Levels'
 If it is voluntary, he said, inventories should remain relatively lean until demand picks up. But if it is involuntary -- caused by a lack of demand -- factories and stores will cut back on orders and further depress the economy.
Mr. Kahan said much of the recent inventory rebuilding was "just a normal picking up from lean levels." Inventories had fallen for seven straight months through August.
But both Mr. Kahan and Michael P. Niemira, an economist at the Mitsubishi Bank in New York, expressed concern over whether companies would continue to rebuild their inventories.
"There's no indication of businesses picking up the pace of inventories, which we need to see the recovery continue," Mr. Niemira said. But he suggested that there would be "a little better activity on the demand side" by spring and that inventory rebuilding would resume then.
 
The Recession's Effect
 The Commerce Department said inventories totaled a seasonally adjusted $814.3 billion, up from $813 billion a month earlier. Before increasing in September, inventories had fallen for seven months as the recession dampened demand.
Sales totaled $543.6 billion after seasonal adjustment, up from $543 billion in October, when they rose four-tenths of 1 percent. Sales had inched up two-tenths of 1 percent in September after a three-tenths of 1 percent decline a month earlier.
Still, the ratio between inventories and sales remained at 1.50 for the third straight month. That meant it would take 1.5 months to exhaust the backlog at the November sales pace.
Mr. Niemira said that the ratio was not worrisome, but that it provided no incentive for businesses to pick up the pace of inventory rebuilding.
The ratio, which jumped to 1.74 during the last recession in 1981-82, averaged 1.49 in 1990, economists at Fuji Securities said.
The report said retail inventories edged up a tenth of 1 percent in November following a nine-tenths of 1 percent gain a month earlier. At the same time, retail sales fell half a percent after a tenth of 1 percent drop in October.
The department reported on Tuesday that retailers posted a four-tenths of 1 percent decline in December.
On the other hand, manufacturing sales rose half a percent in November after a 1.2 percent advance a month earlier. Inventories were unchanged following a two-tenths of 1 percent decrease in October.
On the wholesale level, sales crept up a tenth of 1 percent after falling four-tenths of 1 percent the previous month. Inventories increased six-tenths of 1 percent in November on top of a nine-tenths of 1 percent gain in October.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Inventory-Sales Ratio" shows total month-end business inventories divided by total monthly business sales from June '90-Nov. '91. (Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Jumps Against Mark; Peak for German Rates Seen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar staged a strong advance yesterday, posting particularly sharp gains against the German mark amid a perception in the market that German interest rates have peaked.
Gold prices slipped in domestic trading after rising overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $354.10 an ounce, off 50 cents from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank said gold had fallen 60 cents an ounce, to a late bid price of $354. 
 Dollar-buying has been encouraged all week, traders said, by a growing sense that European interest rates have peaked, coupled with the contention that interest rates at home are not likely to fall further.
These so-called interest-rate differentials are turning in favor of the dollar. High interest rates have made fixed-income securities like German Government bonds attractive to investors, thereby increasing their need for marks.
But it appears that "the German economy is headed for a bit of a downfall, and there's talk of a possible ease in their rates in the next month or so," said Kevin Lawrie, chief dealer at the Bank of Boston. Bonn reported yesterday that Western Germany's economy cooled markedly in 1991, posting little or no growth in the last three quarters.
The dollar jumped more than two pfennigs against the mark, even though any rate changes remain a matter of speculation and many economists believe that the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, will hold steady on rates to fight inflation. In New York trading, the dollar rose to 1.6250 German marks, from 1.5930 on Tuesday.
Curtis Perkins, a trader at Chemical New York Capital Markets Group, said the dollar-buying stemmed more from an "I don't want to miss the boat" mentality than any serious fundamental reason.
In Tokyo, markets were closed for Coming of Age Day, a national holiday. In London, the dollar was quoted at 128.40 yen, up from Tuesday's close in Tokyo of 126.05 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 128.66 yen, up from 126.85 yen on Tuesday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.7560, from $1.8150 late Tuesday. In New York it cost $1.7520 to buy one pound, less expensive than Tuesday's $1.7840.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.4455 Swiss francs, up from 1.4125; 5.5435 French francs, up from 5.4330; 1,224.25 Italian lire, up from 1,201.00, and 1.1536 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1503.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Strategies for Selling More When Shoppers Want Less

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
"THE 'less' decade" is here, according to Carol Farmer, a retail consultant. The "era of excess" of the 1980's is history, she insists, and marketers must catch on to that quickly.
She was speaking as part of a panel of advertising, marketing and media executives who urged the nation's retailers to revamp drastically how they communicate with customers or suffer the loss of their businesses. 
 "The marketing challenge of the 90's will be to sell more in an era of less," she told more than 400 people who attended the presentation, called "The New Normalcy: Marketing to Recession Reality." "This is where you guys are missing it, and it makes me so nuts. You better get with the program."
The panel, at the New York Hilton on Tuesday, was sponsored by the Newspaper Advertising Bureau in conjunction with the National Retail Federation's annual convention in New York this week.
Ms. Farmer, president of Carol Farmer Associates, a consulting firm in Boca Raton, Fla., warned the audience that shoppers' refocused attitudes meant they must end their obsession with evanescent fashion.
"It will be the downfall of retailing if you don't cut it out," she said, adding that the outfit she was wearing was five years old, "and if you don't like it, tough."
Both Ms. Farmer and a second panelist, Laurel Cutler, the vice chairman and worldwide director of marketing planning at FCB/Leber Katz Partners in New York, likened the sharp shifts in consumer behavior during the recession to the emotional process by which people cope with loss. They invoked the stages of behavior in reacting to death, as described by the psychiatrist Elisabeth Kubler-Ross, from denial to anger to depression to introspection to acceptance.
At the moment, Ms. Farmer said, consumers are angry, and they think "less equals loss." But "somewhere along the way," she added, because "the American personality is optimistic, we will convince ourselves that less is better."
As part of that process, Ms. Cutler said, "the consumer becomes an investor," prudently and cautiously guarding "what little is left of his or her disposable income." That is a key reason, she added, for the sharply rising popularity of "value brands," products that promise good quality at reasonable prices.
Ms. Cutler listed, as successful purveyors of such brands, the Gap; the designer Donna Karan, with her lower-priced DKNY apparel, and the designer Giorgio Armani, with his new A/X: Armani Exchange casual clothing. Even expensive goods can qualify as good values, she said, citing how Toyota marketed its Lexus line of luxury cars as a lower-priced alternative to Mercedes-Benz.
All of those marketers are shrewdly capitalizing, she said, on shoppers' decisions "not to make trade-downs, but to make trade-offs." The recession "is nature's way of telling us it's time to change," she added, "and giving us permission to change."
Ms. Farmer also cited the Gap, along with Smith & Hawken, the catalogue retailer; Patagonia, a retailer specializing in practical outdoor apparel, and the Costco Wholesale chain of warehouse stores.
Another panelist who stressed that retailers must shift their emphasis from sales to value -- "the V-word," as she termed it -- was Ann C. Hunt, vice president of retail market development for the ad bureau. She chastised companies that insist on advertising and marketing "as they always did, patiently waiting for a recovery."
Rather, Ms. Hunt advised boldness and experimentation, saying: "Take the risk. While many companies have hunkered down with the tight-fisted consumer, some took risks and got noticed." Examples she gave included Range Rover, which is running advertisements by Grace & Rothschild, chiding consumers to "Buy something," and the Target discount-store chain, which ran ads for shirts and ties that featured men wearing pants they already owned.
The media must also change their ways, said Ray Gaulke, the ad bureau's executive vice president and chief marketing officer. "Our mission must be to become more than vendors of blank pages," he said, and to assume a role as "a review board for your advertising."
"If we see things that we don't believe will work," he added, "we have to tell you."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Alcoa Loss Widens In Quarter

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The Aluminum Company of America, the world's largest aluminum producer, yesterday reported a bigger fourth-quarter loss than a year earlier because of lower prices for virtually all of its products. But another aluminum producer, the Reynolds Metals Company, posted a 57 percent gain for the quarter.
 Alcoa, based in Pittsburgh, said it lost $191.4 million in the quarter, compared with a loss of $140.4 million, in the 1990 quarter. Sales for the quarter dropped to $2.45 billion from $2.75 billion. 
 But investors bought Alcoa shares anyway, sending the shares up $4.625 to $67.125 on the New York Stock Exchange. Analysts said investors were buying many of the so-called cyclical stocks, betting the issues would benefit from an economic upturn.
A worldwide surplus has depressed the aluminum market, pushing ingot prices to 51 cents a pound, about half their high in 1990.
Alcoa said in its earnings report that profit margins had declined across its product line in 1991.
Aluminum shipments in 1991 rose 4 percent from a year earlier, the company said, because of strong demand for aluminum used in packaging. It shipped 2.84 million metric tons, up from 2.72 million tons in 1990.
For the year, Alcoa's earnings fell 78.8 percent, to $62.7 million, or 71 cents a share, from $295.2 million, or $3.40 a share, in 1990. Sales dropped 8.2 percent, to $9.98 billion, from $10.87 billion in 1990.
 
Reynolds Metals
 The Reynolds Metals Company reported a 57 percent gain in fourth-quarter earnings, but its profits for all of 1991 were down sharply.
The company, based in Richmond, said it earned $23.7 million in the final quarter of last year, or 40 cents a share, compared with a profit of $15.1 million, or 25 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales fell 9.4 percent, to $1.45 billion, compared with $1.60 billion.
Reynolds said its full-year earnings slumped 48 percent, to $154.1 million, or $2.60 a share, from $296.6 million, or $5.01 a share, in 1990. Sales fell 4.9 percent, to $5.78 billion from $6.08 billion.
The results included an after-tax charge of $94 million for anticipated environmental costs.
The Reynolds chairman, William Bourke, attributed last year's disappointing results to the "obstinate recession." He said that the worldwide oversupply of aluminum had "pushed ingot prices, in real terms, to their lowest levels ever."
Reynolds said its 1991 aluminum shipments rose to 1.47 million tons from 1.42 million in 1990.
The Reynolds share price was up $4.25 yesterday, to $55, on the New York Stock Exchange.
