HEADLINE: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger Passes Times Publisher's Post to Son

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman and chief executive officer of The New York Times Company and for 29 years publisher of The New York Times, relinquished the publisher's title yesterday to his son, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger Jr.
As publisher, Mr. Sulzberger Jr. will oversee all aspects of the newspaper, including its editorial-page policy. He will report to the elder Mr. Sulzberger, 65 years old, who intends to continue active participation in the overall company day to day as chairman and chief executive. 
 Mr. Sulzberger Jr., 40, has been deputy publisher since 1988. He represents the fourth generation of his family to head The New York Times, and he is the fifth member to serve as publisher in the 96 years since the family acquired the newspaper. Through several trusts, the family controls about 84 percent of the stock that elects 9 of the Times Company's 14 board members.
 
Forming Management Team
 In a statement yesterday after a meeting of the board, the elder Mr. Sulzberger said: "This promotion is another important step in forming the management team that will lead The New York Times in the years ahead. The appointment will allow me more time to work directly with our other lines of business and to concentrate on the further development of the company."
In an interview, Mr. Sulzberger said: "If you believe in the process of an orderly transition, then you have to 'tran-sit.' It gives me great fatherly pride to turn the publishership over to someone not only qualified, but a son."
Mr. Sulzberger Jr. has worked at The Times since 1978 in many departments, including news, advertising, production and strategic planning. His appointment has been expected throughout the industry as Mr. Sulzberger neared his 66th birthday, on Feb. 5.
 
Planning New Printing Plant
 In recent years, Mr. Sulzberger Jr. has taken a leading role in shaping the paper's future -- helping, for example, to plan the $450 million color printing and distribution plant in Edison, N.J., which is expected to open this year. Mr. Sulzberger Jr. took part in creating the paper's redesigned sports and metropolitan news sections, and has been one of the newspaper industry's most outspoken advocates of diversity in the workplace.
In a letter to the paper's staff, Mr. Sulzberger Jr. said, "I pledge my devotion to the precepts that make this paper great: the fairness and honesty of its journalism, the integrity of its business practices, and the decency of its treatment of all individuals."
Reporting to Mr. Sulzberger Jr. will be Max Frankel, The Times's executive editor; Lance R. Primis, the paper's president and general manager, and Jack Rosenthal, editorial page editor.
Founded in 1851, The Times was on the verge of bankruptcy when it was acquired in 1896 by Adolph S. Ochs, a former printer in Tennessee who had become the successful proprietor of The Chattanooga Times. Mr. Ochs, at 38, became publisher of The New York Times and moved north, to live with his wife and daughter, Iphigene. Mr. Sulzberger Jr. is Mr. Ochs's great-grandson.
Upon Mr. Ochs's death in 1935, Iphigene's 43-year-old husband, Arthur Hays Sulzberger, was named publisher. He served until 1961, when the publisher's chair passed to Orvil E. Dryfoos, 48, whose wife, Marian, was the oldest child of Arthur Hays and Iphigene Sulzberger. The Sulzbergers had four children; the youngest, and the only son, was Arthur Ochs Sulzberger.
In 1963 Mr. Dryfoos died. Arthur Ochs Sulzberger -- known all his life by the nickname Punch -- became the paper's president and, at age 37, its youngest publisher. He was elected chairman and chief executive of the paper's parent company in 1973.
In 1979, the company gave the title of president and chief operating officer to Walter E. Mattson. Mr. Mattson, 59, retains responsibility for the operating groups of the Times Company, which now includes numerous broadcast, magazine and newspaper properties, and will continue to report to Mr. Sulzberger.
 
Career Marked With Landmarks
 As publisher, Mr. Sulzberger has steered the paper through an era marked by some of the most significant journalistic achievements in the paper's history, including Times v. Sullivan, a landmark First Amendment decision by the United States Supreme Court shielding journalists against many libel suits by public officials. And it was Mr. Sulzberger who made the decision in 1971 to publish the secret Government history of the Vietnam War known as the Pentagon Papers, and who led the company's successful Supreme Court defense of that decision. He said he took particular pride in the 31 Pulitzer Prizes -- out of the paper's 63 -- awarded during his tenure.
The Times has also expanded considerably as a business, with revenues of $1.7 billion in 1991, compared with $100 million in 1963. Weekday circulation is now 1.1 million, compared with 714,300 in 1963, and Sunday circulation grew to 1.7 million, from 1.4 million, making the Times the nation's largest Sunday paper.
Mr. Sulzberger has been a quiet but active force in the industry and served as chairman of the American Newspaper Publishers Association and on many other industry boards.
Yesterday, assessing Mr. Sulzberger's contribution to publishing, Katharine Graham, chairwoman of The Washington Post Company, said: "Above all, he took the quality of the product up to an entirely new level. I think he's been an outstanding publisher and a modest and wonderful man -- and he's really funny."
Both those who worked closely with Mr. Sulzberger and members of his family cited as perhaps his greatest overall achievement a refusal to abuse the power that went with being publisher of The Times. While taking his responsibility seriously, they said, he also bore it with a lightness, warmth and and self-deprecating wit that made him a beloved figure throughout the paper.
"It was like inheriting the White House," said A. M. Rosenthal, who served as The Times's executive editor during much of Mr. Sulzberger's tenure, "and he has never used the paper for personal, family, political or financial advantage, ever. That's his monument."
Susan W. Dryfoos, daughter of Mr. Sulzberger's predecessor Orvil Dryfoos, said: "He is so modest, so understated and so wise. It never went to his head." She described the Sulzberger family as "bursting with pride" at Mr. Sulzberger's performance as steward of the family's great jewel.
 
'Shellshocked' Upon Taking Job
 When Mr. Sulzberger became publisher in 1963, The Times and the city's other papers were still reeling from a prolonged strike. And though Mr. Sulzberger was working as an executive at The Times, he was regarded even by some within the family as unprepared for such demanding responsibilities.
In an interview yesterday, Mr. Sulzberger recalled being "shellshocked" by having to assume the job.
"My sister Ruth called me after my first day as publisher and asked me how it had gone," he recalled, "and I said, 'I've made my first executive decision. I've decided not to throw up.' "
Gradually, Mr. Sulzberger negotiated critical agreements with unions that effectively opened the door to a new era of using high technology to make the paper's operations more efficient, a process that continues today in the form of the new Edison plant.
But in the early 1970's, The Times faced a financial crisis that the company viewed as a threat to the paper's very existence.
The Arab oil embargo had plunged the nation into recession, and New York City, after years of free spending, was on the verge of bankruptcy. Advertising at The Times plunged by 25 percent from 1969 to 1974.
Mr. Sulzberger's predecessors had fought their way out of similar fiscal emergencies by investing in improvements and by expanding the paper rather than slashing costs in ways that damaged journalistic quality. During World War II, for example, when newsprint was rationed, newspapers had had to choose between reducing space for news or advertising. The Times elected to reduce advertising, which hurt immediate profits but attracted news-hungry readers who remained with the paper when rationing was lifted. The New York Herald Tribune, then The Times's main competitor, reduced its news coverage and never recovered the resulting loss of readership, ceasing publication in 1967.
Taking his family's example, Mr. Sulzberger elected to solve The Times's financial problems by attracting new readers -- and thus advertisers -- by investing heavily in new sections, to broaden the paper's appeal.
The daily paper went from two parts -- a front section and a Metro section -- to four. Each weekday edition was given its own special section: SportsMonday, Science on Tuesday, Living on Wednesday, Home on Thursday and Weekend on Friday. In addition, a daily business section -- Business Day -- was begun. Each of the sections not only had audience appeal, but also offered a new environment for specialized advertising, like financial ads for the business section. Circulation and advertising -- and profits -- rose accordingly.
Mr. Sulzberger also accelerated the policy of acquiring compatible businesses to diversify the company's sources of income.
The Times Company, which he continues to direct, now includes 32 regional newspapers; a one-half interest in The International Herald Tribune, based in Paris; 17 consumer and trade magazines including Family Circle, McCall's and Golf Digest; five television stations; an AM and an FM radio station, WQXR in New York; a news service and other information services, and interests in three paper mills.
 
Finding Lesson In Paper's History
 Mr. Sulzberger Jr. assumes the paper's helm at a time when the New York region is in deep recession and advertising has declined steadily for several years. The company has projected earnings of 55 cents to 60 cents a share for 1991 compared with 85 cents a share in 1990.
But in an interview, he said the fundamental lesson in the paper's history was that "if you have quality information, profit will follow," and he pointed to the recent investments in expanded sports and metropolitan coverage as an indication of his approach.
While Mr. Sulzberger Jr. said the paper would continue to evolve, he said he planned to make no executive changes in the foreseeable future and predicted that The Times would look essentially the same a year from now, except for color in some Sunday sections after the Edison printing plant opens.
As publisher, Mr. Sulzberger Jr. plans to confer daily with Jack Rosenthal, the editorial page editor, as his father did. He said that he and his father were in virtually total agreement about the paper's editorial positions, and that he intended to consult with his father on editorial policy. Indeed, Mr. Sulzberger Sr. said he would continue to write occasional editorials.
 
Father and Son Grew Closer
 The new publisher was born in Mount Kisco, N.Y. While he was still a child, his parents divorced. He lived with his mother, the former Barbara Grant, and his stepfather.
At 14, with his mother's blessing, he elected to live with his father, who had since married Carol Fox Fuhrman. Mr. Sulzberger Jr. said he had made the change to come to know his father better, though their relationship was somewhat strained when the younger Sulzberger adopted the trappings of the 1960's, including wearing his father's old Marine Corps jacket on all occasions.
But he said his father's "civility of spirit" was such that he allowed his son to go his own way largely without criticism, and the two grew very close and remain so. For instance, in his statement on today's editorial page, Mr. Sulzberger Jr. said of his father, "It gives me great comfort to know that his presence and counsel will continue for years to come."
In 1970, Mr. Sulzberger Jr. entered Tufts University, outside Boston, where he studied political science and spent several vacations working at various newspapers, including The Boston Globe and The Vineyard Gazette. He said he had already concluded that his essential life ambition was to follow his father's footsteps as publisher of The Times.
"I do not recall ever having that debate with myself, which I consider lucky," he said. "I was not pushed to do it either by myself or some strange sense of responsibility." He added, "It was something I wanted to do as long as I can recall."
Upon graduation in 1974, Mr. Sulzberger Jr. took a job as a general-assignment reporter at The Raleigh Times in North Carolina. The paper, which has since closed, was operated by the Daniels family, which continues to publish The News & Observer in Raleigh.
While in Raleigh, Mr. Sulzberger Jr. married Gail Gregg, whom he met on a visit to his mother in Topeka, Kan., Ms. Gregg's hometown. She was also a journalist, and worked for The Associated Press at the time. The couple have two children.
After two years, Mr. Sulzberger Jr. became a correspondent for The Associated Press in London.
In 1978, when Mr. Sulzberger Jr. finally joined The Times as a reporter in the Washington bureau, he said, he felt he knew what he was doing.
"I wasn't the greatest reporter in the world, but I wasn't starting at zero," he said.
In Washington, Mr. Sulzberger worked on a wide array of subjects ranging from the long-term impact of nuclear testing to the decisions of the Federal Trade Commission. He recalls with some pride an article he wrote about the Panama Canal treaty that "led the paper," meaning that it appeared in the upper-right corner of the front page, the position reserved for the day's most important news article.
In the early 1980's, the family moved to the Upper West Side of Manhattan, the neighborhood where they have lived since then.
As a member of the metropolitan staff, Mr. Sulzberger Jr. worked as a general assignment reporter and covered City Hall. He then became an assignment editor for a year, which he described as "the single most exhausting job I ever had." This was his first management experience.
"I was not a great manager, but I walked around a lot, often without shoes on, and that walking around will cover a multitude of sins," he said, adding that he concluded that the fundamental role of a good manager is motivation.
"It's no different from now," he said, and, indeed, he still walks around a lot, speaking to people in the newsroom, but wearing shoes.
In 1982, Mr. Sulzberger Jr. transferred to the advertising department, where he sold advertising and supervised an advertising sales team.
Mr. Sulzberger Jr. said it was during this period that he began to think carefully about his own management style, which he characterized as a belief in group decision-making that taps the energy and insight of a wide array of participants.
"I don't think leadership demands yes or no answers; I think leadership is providing the forum for making the right decision, which doesn't demand unanimity," he said.
 
Not Afraid Of Mistakes
 This month, in keeping with his management views, he oversaw changes in the paper's business management organization intended to streamline decision-making and encourage innovation and accountability.
After advertising, Mr. Sulzberger Jr. moved to corporate planning, where he learned more analytical skills, and there followed a period in production, including two nights each week as night production manager overseeing the presses at the paper's Times Square plant.
In time, Mr. Sulzberger Jr. said, the threads of his multifaceted training began to come together and he was named deputy to his father.
While he said the paper would continue to have "the honesty of its journalism and the honesty of its business practises" as its guiding principle, he said he was not afraid of experimenting and making mistakes.
"If you don't occasionally make a mistake, you aren't trying hard enough," he said.
The appointment of Mr. Sulzberger Jr. as publisher was announced after a meeting of the company's board, which includes the elder Mr. Sulzberger's three sisters -- Marian S. Heiskell, Ruth S. Holmberg and Dr. Judith P. Sulzberger.
The chairman said that while his son's appointment was not subject to board approval, the members had expressed enthusiasm for the change.
The news also seemed well received by the industry. "Arthur is clearly a very worthy successor to Punch as publisher," said Robert F. Erburu, chairman of the Times Mirror Company.
Yesterday afternoon, at a gathering of hundreds of staff members in the newsroom, Max Frankel, the executive editor, toasted the Sulzberger family for its long commitment to the paper's independence and excellence.
 
A Generation Remains Close
 As a child, during weekend visits with his father, Mr. Sulzberger Jr. often went to Hillandale, the Connecticut estate of his paternal grandparents -- Arthur Hays and Iphigene Sulzberger, whom he and the other 13 Sulzberger grandchildren called Bumpy and Granny.
His generation of cousins remain close, Mr. Sulzberger Jr. said, attributing the friendship in part to their time together as children at Hillandale, where the family's heritage was lightly but constantly present. That generation has created a charitable trust, the Hillandale Group, to which they all contribute.
Four of Mr. Sulzberger Jr.'s first cousins also work at the Times Company: Stephen Golden, Ruth Holmberg's son, is vice president for forest products; his brother Michael Golden is senior vice president and general manager of the women's publishing division; Daniel Cohen, Judith Sulzberger's son, is director of sales development in the circulation department of The Times, and Susan W. Dryfoos, Marian Heiskell's daughter, is director of the Times History Project, a continuing video documentary of the paper and the company.
Speaking of his family generally, Mr. Sulzberger Jr. said, "The New York Times is inherent in what we are, but not worn as 'what we are'; it's important and crucial to all of us, but not something that was drilled in, in any specific ways."

HEADLINE: BUSH WOULD TRIM TAX FOR FAMILIES OVER $50,000 LEVEL

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16

 BODY:
The income-tax cut President Bush plans to propose this month would make families with incomes of more than about $50,000 the biggest winners, drawing a new line in his election year battle with the Democrats over who can develop the more attractive tax breaks for the middle class.
The Democrats, in Congress and on the Presidential campaign trail, have not found a tax policy they can all support, but most of their proposals aim lower on the income ladder than the President's. 
 Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic leader, assailed the President's policies in a speech today. But pressed by reporters afterward, he declined to say what specific tax policy he would support.
 
An Economic Stimulation
 On the heels of Mr. Bush's campaign trip to New Hampshire on Wednesday, the first of the election year and where he tried to find a firmer footing on domestic and economic issues, new details began to emerge about the budget package he will send to Congress Jan. 29. For example, he plans to propose increasing the personal exemption for a family of four by a total of about $2,000, which would amount to a tax cut of up to $620.
Mr. Bush is expected to argue that a tax cut, which would be immediately reflected in withholding tables, would generate additional spending and stimulate the flagging economy. Democratic politicians tend to accept that view.
But most economists, regardless of their politics, say a tax reduction of $1 or $2 a day would do little to help the economy and would be an especially bad idea if it worsened the budget deficit.
Within the Administration, moderates like Richard G. Darman, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady seem to have won out over conservatives like Vice President Dan Quayle and Jack F. Kemp, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, who want much deeper tax cuts and much more costly investment incentives.
"The pro-growth wing of the Administration is not very happy about the growth package," said an Administration official who considers himself part of the conservative wing. "It's anemic." The official said that bold proposals had been "rejected by the Treasury for green eyeshade reasons."
But another official said that Mr. Bush believed the conservatives had no real choice but to back him and that he was more concerned about losing the middle class to his Democratic challengers.
Budgets are always political documents, and that maxim is even more true in election years. For President Bush, the budget this year is crucial to the image he is trying to sell to the American people.
He clearly hopes to use the budget to make several points to voters: that he is sensitive to how squeezed middle-income Americans feel, that he has a well-formed policy in areas like health and education to which his Administration until now has paid relatively little attention and that he recognizes that the collapse of the Soviet Union will allow the United States to spend less on the military.
Democrats have harped on those issues on the campaign trail and in Washington, and the President feels the need to regain the offensive, his staff members say.
With that in mind, say Administration officials and their allies in Congress, the President will propose these new measures in his budget:
*A total increase of about $2,000 in the personal exemptions that a family of four could claim on their income tax return. That would mean a tax cut of $300 for families in the 15 percent tax bracket with a total income below about $50,000, a $560 reduction for those in the 28 percent bracket with an adjusted gross income between about $50,000 and about $100,000 and a $620 tax cut for families in the 31 percent bracket with incomes between about $100,000 and $158,000. Only families with incomes below about $15,000 and above about $280,000 would get no help at all.
*Refundable tax credits for poor people and deductions for the middle class to help offset the cost of medical insurance.
*A tax break of several thousand dollars for first-time homebuyers who buy any but the most expensive houses.
*An additional tax incentive for savings by middle-income taxpayers that would actually raise revenue for the Government in the first year but would cost money in the years ahead when today's budget rules would not apply.
*A change in depreciation rules to encourage businesses to invest in plants and equipment.
*Rules that would allow people actually in the real estate business to deduct their real estate losses from income earned from other businesses or investments.
*Cuts in military spending of about $30 billion beyond what was previously planned for the next five years.
The Democrats want much bigger reductions in military spending. But otherwise, except for their differences over tax policy, the Democrats differ with the President only in the details.
For example, Senator Mitchell, in his speech at the National Press Club today, advocated a tax credit for business investments, savings incentives and help for first-time home buyers.
 
Mitchell Targets Military
 But he called for a $100 billion cut in the military budget over the next five years, and he excoriated what he called the President's "trickle-down" tax policy.
Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, said today that the President's budget proposals "have essentially been decided upon and completed."
But other officials said three issues still were not settled: how exactly to calculate the increased personal exemption, how much detail to include about medical insurance and how extensively to specify the nature of military spending reductions beyond the next fiscal year that begins Oct. 1.
The officials said the personal exemption, now $2,300 per person, could be raised by about $500 a person, or it could be limited to children and raised by about $1,000 each. As a tax matter, personal exemptions are counted the same way as deductions. That means the higher one's tax bracket, the more the exemption is worth.
So an additional $2,000 worth of exemptions for a family of four would be worth less for a family in the 15 percent bracket (taxable incomes below $35,801, which means a total income before deductions of about $50,000) than it would for those in a 28 percent or 31 percent bracket.
Democrats tend to favor tax credits in the range of $300 to $450 for a family. A credit is subtracted directly from the taxes owed and is worth the same to all taxpayers.

HEADLINE: Manila Journal;
Wow, It's 'Eee-mel-da!' Now Shopping for Votes

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANILA, Jan. 14

 BODY:
To some people, her name may be synonymous with greed and plunder and excess, but Imelda Marcos -- the new candidate for President of the Philippines, who calls herself "mother of the nation" -- is being greeted on stretches of the Philippine campaign trail as a resurrected hero.
It seems as if no one remembers, or cares, about all those shoes. 
 At a campaign rally last weekend along the narrow streets of Onse, a working-class Manila neighborhood, Mrs. Marcos was nearly crushed as she tried to make her way past hundreds of jubilant supporters screaming "Eee-mel-da!"
An old woman in ragged clothes was in tears as she tried to touch the former Philippine First Lady, the widow of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos, and to grab a few threads of the white lace handkerchief in Mrs. Marcos's right hand. "We love you, Imelda!" she cried out. "You must be our President."
 
'Sick and Misguided' Policies
 To a degree astonishing to Filipinos who remember the Marcos Government and its rampant corruption and record on human rights, Mrs. Marcos is being taken seriously as a candidate in the May presidential election, the first since the Marcoses were forced into exile in 1986.
Mrs. Marcos, who is 62 years old, waited in a Manila hotel room one day last week and powdered her unlined face, preparing for a live satellite interview for the ABC program "Good Morning America." (Her campaign has received more attention from foreign news organizations than from some of Manila's pro-Government newspapers and television stations.)
As technicians adjusted the camera angle and lights, Mrs. Marcos explained that she had joined the presidential race in part because of what she sees as the public's fury over the "sick and misguided" policies of her nemesis, President Corazon C. Aquino.
"I am so sorry for her and ultimately for the country," Mrs. Marcos said. "Everybody wanted to give her a chance, and she blew it."
With a political shrewdness that surprises many who know her reputation only as that of a world-class shopper, Mrs. Marcos says her attacks on the Government have struck a chord with disenchanted Philippine voters. And she may be right.
 
Fares Poorly in Polls
 "The Philippine people are looking for some kind of relief from this misery and suffering," Mrs. Marcos said, although many Filipinos say there was no shortage of misery and suffering during her husband's 20-year reign. "I had no political agenda when I came home. But when the people speak, Imelda follows."
None of which means that Mrs. Marcos will be the next President of the Philippines; she fared poorly in public opinion polls that were taken just before her entry into the race.
But even if her presidential attempt fizzles out, Mrs. Marcos may still emerge as the election's kingmaker, throwing money and her family's political machine behind one of half a dozen other politicians hoping to succeed Mrs. Aquino, who has said she will not seek a second term.
Although Mrs. Marcos now pleads poverty, she recently acknowledged that $350 million frozen in Swiss bank accounts was her family's. Prosecutors say Mrs. Marcos controls dozens of other, still-secret bank accounts around the world.
Campaign aides of Mrs. Marcos have yet to identify exactly who is paying for her $2,000-a-night hotel suite overlooking Manila Bay, or for the silver, six-door Mercedes-Benz limousine with the license plate IRM -- her maiden name is Romauldez -- that is used to ferry her around the capital.
 
Solicitor General 'Appalled'
 The Philippine Solicitor General, Francisco Chavez, said he was "appalled and disgusted" by the enthusiastic reception that Mrs. Marcos had received since she returned last November from exile.
"It's evidence of the short memory of Filipinos," he said, nodding toward a color-coded chart on his office wall that diagrams the movement of hundreds of millions of dollars in the Swiss bank accounts. "She is a thief."
Mrs. Marcos was allowed to return from exile not out of any sense of charity by the Aquino Government, but to face scores of tax fraud and corruption charges brought by Mr. Chavez and his team of prosecutors.
Mrs. Marcos is now being received with open arms by many of the same Filipinos who poured into the streets of Manila six years ago and forced the Marcoses to flee the country.
A senior Western diplomat shook his head as he explained that Filipinos "had simply forgotten about the diamonds and the shoes" -- hundreds of pairs of imported, designer-label pumps found in Malacanang Palace after Mr. Marcos's ouster.
 
An Echo of Reagan
 Mrs. Marcos seems to be enticing voters with a campaign slogan that owes much to Ronald Reagan's famous 1980 dig at President Jimmy Carter. "Are you better off than you were six years ago?" Mrs. Marcos asks at her election rallies.
Six years after Mrs. Aquino took power, the Philippines remains one of the poorest nations in Southeast Asia -- per capital annual income is about $700, the economy posted zero growth last year, inflation is running at 18 percent a year.
"We had poverty and corruption under President Marcos," said Tessie Maglinao, a shopkeeper who attended the Onse rally. "Now what do we have? We have poverty and corruption."
Mrs. Marcos acknowledges that she is seeking the presidency "in small part" to put an end to the criminal charges against her family. She describes the prosecution as a waste of taxpayer money.
"The ultimate victims of this vendetta are the Filipino people, who are crying for help in their struggle for survival," said Mrs. Marcos, who was acquitted on more limited charges in a United States Federal court in New York in 1990, and who seems confident of vindication in the Philippines.

HEADLINE: Seeking Voter Reward, Bush Still Predicts Fall of Hussein

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16

 BODY:
Facing criticism of a Persian Gulf policy that President Bush hopes will help catapult him to re-election, the White House today offered new predictions of President Saddam Hussein's downfall and proclaimed the war a "tremendous victory."
"We can all take pride in the results of that effort," Mr. Bush said in a written statement marking the passage of one year since he ordered the bombing against Iraqi forces in Kuwait. 
 In the statement, which his spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, also read before television cameras, Mr. Bush vowed "to keep the pressure on Saddam Hussein" and called again on the Iraqi people to overthrow their leader. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney predicted that Mr. Hussein would be removed "in the not-too-distant future."
Administration officials have long said Mr. Hussein was crippled by the war and in danger of being overthrown, but there is no indication that the Administration is taking concrete steps to topple him, other than continuing economic sanctions.
 
On Defensive Despite Victory
 The Administration's attempts to cast the war in the most favorable light underscored a political problem Mr. Bush faces as the 1992 campaign unfolds. Instead of celebrating the anniversary as an example of strong leadership, Mr. Bush has found himself increasingly on the defensive not only about Iraq, but also about a broad range of his foreign policies, including the Middle East peace talks, which Mr. Bush declared a central achievement of the military victory over Iraq. And despite an intensive effort to portray his trip to Japan as a success, Mr. Bush has not been able to shake the impression that he went seeking trade concessions and returned with political and personal embarrassment.
Aware of polls showing that Americans are increasingly dubious about the extent of the American victory over Iraq and increasingly critical of Mr. Bush's handling of foreign as well as domestic policy, the White House hopes to keep such criticism from damaging the President's re-election campaign.
Today Mr. Bush focused on an effort to underscore the accomplishments of the American-led coalition that drove Baghdad's army out of Kuwait.
"Kuwait is liberated and the legitimate Government restored, the fires set by Saddam's retreating army are extinguished, the flow of oil from the gulf is secure from political and economic blackmail," the President said.
 
'Dividends' of the War
 Listing what he said were the "dividends" of the partnership he forged to fight Iraq, Mr. Bush said: "A critical region of the world vital to its economic well-being is secure. Thanks in large part to our efforts, direct peace talks between Arabs and Israelis are under way for the first time, multilateral negotiations on regional arms control have begun, and America's hostages in Lebanon are home."
The President added, "Much of Iraq's arsenal is destroyed and what remains is now under international supervision."
But his remarks contrasted with testimony a day earlier by Robert M. Gates, the Director of Central Intelligence, who warned Congress that Mr. Hussein could rebuild Iraq's nuclear, poison-gas, germ warfare and ballistic missile programs within a few years.
In the months between the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, 1990, and the onset of combat, critics of Mr. Bush, and some Administration officials, said the President erred by turning the showdown into a personal confrontation between himself and Mr. Hussein and by elevating the Iraqi leader into a larger-than-life figure whom Mr. Bush compared to Hitler.
 
Bush Still Focuses on Hussein
 But since the war, Mr. Bush has kept up his personal focus on Mr. Hussein, as he did today.
"The American people and I remain determined to keep the pressure on Saddam until a new leadership comes to power in Iraq," he said."

HEADLINE: A New Battle Is Ahead for Powell: The Budget

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13

 BODY:
As Gen. Colin L. Powell revises American military policy to fit a world without the Soviet Union, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff is running into strong Congressional pressure to cut deeper and faster into the Pentagon budget than he would like.
Democratic leaders in Congress have already made clear that reducing money for a few weapons systems while leaving the basic Pentagon budget intact in the 1993 fiscal year will not be acceptable. But so far that appears to be the kind of effort General Powell has in mind for the budget that Congress will start considering next month and that will become effective on Oct. 1. 
 In speeches and Congressional hearings over the last several months, General Powell has discussed his strategic vision for the military after the cold war. It includes a smaller force, tailored for rapid response to regional conflicts, like the war in the Persian Gulf, instead of global combat with the Soviet Union. It is a force with fewer troops serving abroad and fewer nuclear weapons, although still enough to maintain superpower status.
 
Big Troop Reduction
 General Powell's vision is reflected in a five-year plan for military spending that calls for a steady but slow decline of about 25 percent from the current budget of $291 billion by 1995 and a cut in the armed services from their current level of about 2 million troops to 1.6 million by 1995. General Powell contends that the plan remains reasonable, even though it was largely drafted in 1990, before the disintegration of the Soviet Union.
As a concession to Congress, he has found some immediate savings that could wring $6 billion to $8 billion from the $292 billion budget that the Administration will request later this month for the fiscal year 1993. That seems unlikely to satisfy Congress, where members have been talking of cuts in the range of $15 billion to $20 billion.
The savings General Powell has identified would primarily come from the cancellation or contraction of plans to buy several major new weapons systems.
In meetings shrouded with unusual secrecy, Pentagon officials say, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney recently told the military's uniformed chiefs and civilian bosses that the Navy's new Seawolf attack submarine would be canceled, saving several billion dollars. The Pentagon would also aim to build 20 to 25 B-2 Stealth bombers, not 75 as initially planned, with the plane's cost nearly doubling, to $2 billion. Congress has agreed to pay for only 15 planes.
The cuts recommended by General Powell and Mr. Cheney are expected to be announced in President Bush's State of the Union Message on Jan. 28. But General Powell's staff has been quietly preparing the new reductions since at least November as the opening gambit of a strategy to counter members of Congress who are seeking deeper, faster cuts.
 
Powell Ready for Battle
 "We'll be fighting a legislative war this year instead of one with people getting killed and injured," General Powell said last week, seeming to relish the prospect of a spirited debate with lawmakers over potential threats to the United States and military needs. "But we're not going to be ripping apart the military," he continued in a conversation at a reception given by the French Embassy for American officers who served in the gulf war.
For General Powell, the name of the game is keeping control over how fast the armed forces shrink and avoiding the mistakes he says were made in previous military reductions. Those errors, he says, left American forces woefully unprepared for early battles in World War II and the Korean War.
Until now, General Powell and Mr. Cheney have publicly refused to consider deeper reductions in what they call their "base force" for 1995. This is defined by General Powell as the "minimum force needed for our enduring needs." Under that plan, the Army would shrink to 12 active divisions from 18. The Navy would have 12 aircraft carriers instead of 14, and the Air Force would have 26 wings, down from 36, with 72 planes in a wing.
This smaller force would be concentrated in the United States, with fewer overseas bases. American forces would be designed to respond quickly to regional crises, often using equipment stored on ships or in depots around the world. This differs from the current strategy that relies heavily on deploying troops to hot spots from Europe or Asia.
Some Democrats have called for deeper cuts in troops, but so far no lawmaker has offered any detailed alternative to the Pentagon's plan. Some outside experts have suggested cutting the armed forces to about 50 percent of their current levels. These views are expected to help shape the debate on the size and strategic aims of the military.
 
Lag Seen in Powell Plan
 The General's critics argue that his plan took into account the collapse of the Warsaw Pact, but lags behind the momentous changes caused by the breakup of the archrival superpower.
"No program that was initiated with the specific purpose of deterring the former Soviet Union and Warsaw Pact has a sanctuary today," said Senator John W. Warner of Virginia, the ranking Republican on the Armed Services Committee.
Representative Les Aspin, the Wisconsin Democrat who heads the House Armed Services Committee, criticized General Powell last week for shaping his future force around the capabilities of potential foes instead of specific threats. Mr. Aspin said the notions were unjustifiably vague and out of touch with budget realities.
General Powell retorts that he recognizes the budget crunch, but argues that Mr. Aspin's approach of guessing at threats does not work in an emerging world of unpredictable regional conflicts.
Where past chairmen of the joint chiefs might have dug in their heels to protect military constituencies, General Powell is guided not only by the military's needs but by his own political antennae.
 
Politics in the Budget
 As the President's chief military adviser, General Powell tells Mr. Bush what he needs militarily. As a former national security adviser to President Ronald Reagan, General Powell also knows when Mr. Bush needs some political breathing room on the budget, particularly in a Presidential election year.
Cutting expensive weaponry like the Stealth bomber saves little money immediately because the plane takes several years to build. But it scores quick political points. Senior Pentagon officials say that General Powell has also identified deeper cuts in Army divisions, Navy carriers and Air Force wings in case Congress demands more, but the Administration is trying to delay those reductions until after the fall election or later.
This approach avoids breaking faith with an all-volunteer force in a recession and buys time for Pentagon planners to scale back recruiting, encourage early retirements and take other steps to avoid forcing people out of the military.
"Colin Powell doesn't want to cut forces so dramatically that you put them out of work right after they won a war," said Representative John P. Murtha, a Pennsylvania Democrat who is chairman of the House Appropriations subcommittee on military spending.
General Powell has repeatedly criticized Congress for shielding National Guard forces and armories in their districts from cuts by the Pentagon.
"Sure, it's frustrating" to be choosing cuts in this political environment, General Powell said last week, refusing to confirm the B-2 and Seawolf reports and scoffing at suggestions that any reductions were politically driven. "But Washington is a political town and especially so in a Presidential election year."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
Harkin Emphasizes Steadiness but Looks for Lift

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16

 BODY:
In a calm aside from his regular verbal assaults on his Democratic rivals and President Bush, Senator Tom Harkin offers his own assessment of his quest for the Presidency: "Unlike the other campaigns, I haven't had any big highs, I haven't had any lows. Just steady as she goes."
This is Mr. Harkins's effort to get his audience to ignore early polls and some pundits' predictions by making a virtue of his own perserverance as Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas and Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska have enjoyed more of the highs so far. 
 Although the first voting in the Presidential campaign is more than four weeks away, there are signs that Mr. Harkin could use a lift: His fund-raising has been sluggish; he has not kept pace in early polls, and he has been struggling to hang on to support from influential labor groups.
Even Mr. Harkin was at a loss for concrete examples that his campaign was winning over voters in the first primary state. "Patience," the Iowa Democrat said in an interview. "Patience. I'll catch up. My strategy is to peak on Election Day."
Tim Raftis, Mr. Harkin's campaign manager, acknowledged that the Senator had failed to make a convincing case thus far of why people should vote for him. He said the campaign's first two television advertisements, which were unveiled today for use in New Hampshire, were intended to help change that.
The two 30-second television commercials introduced Mr. Harkin as the candidate who would rebuild the nation with new investments. The advertising, created by Ken Swope, a Boston-based consultant, came later than that for Mr. Clinton or Mr. Kerrey. But Mr. Harkin's aides said they would make up for the later start by buying more time for their commercials.
One advertisement is of a shirt-sleeved Mr. Harkin at his announcement speech at an Iowa steak fry last September, promising to build new roads, bridges and schools and health care for everyone. "No more trickle down," he says, with American flags as his backdrop. "Let's have resource-based economics. Put it in at the bottom and let it percolate up for a while."
In the other commercial, Mr. Harkin sits calmly in a chair, a darkened room behind him, telling an unseen interviewer that the nation is wasting too much money on tax breaks for the rich and spending overseas. "I want to be known as the President that rebuilt America," he says.
Joseph Grandmaison, a former Democratic chairman in New Hampshire, said that while some polls had shown Mr. Harkin lagging in the state, he still had enough time to turn his fortunes around. "Voter support can turn on a dime in this state," he said. "My sense of Harkin is that he's very comfortable with what he has to say and delivers his message exceptionally well. There's an interest in seeing what the substance of his programs are as opposed to exclusively Bush bashing."
 
A Catchy New Slogan
 Yet in dozens of appearances over the past several days in Iowa, South Dakota, New Hampshire and Ohio, Mr. Harkin sought to distinguish himself from the other Democrats by presenting himself as the only candidate who could beat President Bush because he was a fiery campaigner whose devotion to traditional Democratic values made him the clearest alternative to the President.
In a catchy new slogan written by an aide that has brought Mr. Harkin laughs at every stop, he asserts: "I'm not a microwave Democrat."
He then compares his opponents to leftovers he heated up in the microwave: "Took it out. It was steamy and hot. I cut into it. It was hot on the outside and cold on the inside. I thought that's like a lot of those Democrats out there running. Boy, they sound like great Democrats. But you pull away the layers and it's still cold, hard-hearted Republicanism."
Mr. Harkin seems to be banking on the hope that his opponents will falter. Asked in an interview what he needed to gain momentum, he talked not about himself but about two opponents: Mr. Kerrey and Mr. Clinton.
While the two rivals rarely mention Mr. Harkin as they campaign through New Hampshire, the Senator readily attacks them. In appearances in South Dakota last week, where he and Mr. Kerrey are both presenting themselves as practically native sons, Mr. Harkin derided the centerpiece of Mr. Kerrey's campaign, a national health care plan, saying "we don't need more taxes on small business."
In a subsequent interview, he criticized Mr. Kerrey as lacking experience. "I don't think that he's been seasoned enough in one term as Governor of Nebraska and three years as a Senator. It's almost becoming clear to many people that he is trying to position himself for 1996."
As for Mr. Clinton, Mr. Harkin asserted that the Governor's support would erode once people learned more about him. He contended that Mr. Clinton's strategy was "to be all things to all people -- conservative to conservatives and liberal to liberals," and that Mr. Clinton had benefited from favorable press coverage because "someone told me that for years he's been schmoozing with the press."
Pressed on why Democrats want another liberal after the defeats of Mr. Dukakis and Mr. Mondale, Mr. Harkin said they "weren't aggressive enough."
Explaining this philosophy to a small but enthusiastic group of union workers in Rapid City, S.D., the other day, Mr. Harkin said: "There are people saying, 'Harkin can't win,' I submit to you, there's a little bit of difference between me and Mike Dukakis. When they swing at me, they'd better duck."
But even many who came out to see Mr. Harkin, and would like to see him in the White House, question the depth of yearning for an old-fashioned Democrat.
"The guys are looking at Clinton and Kerrey," said Ritchie Nordstrom, a Harkin backer, said of his fellow A.F.S.C.M.E. union members in Rapid City. Despite Mr. Harkin's reputation as the closest to labor among the contenders, he said, "I guess they feel that Clinton is more electable nationally."
At another forum in Rapid City, Millie Payne, president of the Western South Dakota Alzheimers Association, came away wondering how Mr. Harkin would finance his sweeping health care program, a question the Senator said he has not resolved himself.
"I felt that he had some good ideas," Ms. Payne said, "But there is going to have to be some way to pay for everyone in the country having medical care. We'd all love it, but the money has to come from somewhere."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Media;
Democrats Press TV Campaigns to Reach New Hampshire Voters

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16

 BODY:
The Democratic candidates are stepping up their campaigns to woo the voters of New Hampshire, battling it out on the airwaves with advertisements that hammer at the Republicans' management of the economy.
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas continued his theme of help for the "forgotten middle class" with a second commercial that began appearing on television in New Hampshire today. 
 In the 30-second advertisement, newspapers bearing headlines about the pay increase for Senators and tax breaks for the wealthy are superimposed on a photograph of the White House at night. The image is a reminder of the vote by Congress for a $23,200-a-year pay raise for senators in the dead of night last July, and it sends a subtle message that the White House supported it.
 
Hitting Hard on Taxes
 Then comes Governor Clinton talking directly into the camera: "For 12 years the politicians in Washington have raised their pay, cut taxes on the rich and raised taxes on the middle class. That's wrong."
And he is not the only Democratic candidate with whom television viewers in New Hampshire are becoming acquainted.
Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa also began appearing in New Hamsphire today in one of two commercials his campaign has produced. The second is to be broadcast on Friday.
Mr. Harkin's commercials, produced by Ken Swope, a media consultant who worked on some of the advertisements for Michael S. Dukakis in the 1988 primary campaign, blend patriotic images and a sharp partisan edge.
One features Mr. Harkin in shirt sleeves at a rally, American flags flapping behind him. "Let's put this country to work," he tells the audience. And in contrast to the Republican message of trickle-down economics, Mr. Harkin suggests: "Let's put it in at the bottom, let it percolate up for a while."
Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska joined the advertising fray last Friday. He shifts from talking about his record in the Vietnam War to a discussion of health care and he assails President Bush for his recent trip to Japan to "beg for a few concessions."
Paul E. Tsongas, the former Senator from Massachusetts, has appeared in two commercials. The first shows him swimming laps, with an announcer saying that Mr. Tsongas has confounded the naysayers throughout his political career.
In the second, Mr. Tsongas talks of his accomplishments as a Senator, including his role in winning Congressional approval for a bailout of the Chrysler Corporation.
No political commercials have appeared for Edmund G. Brown Jr., the former Governor of California. He is relying on radio and on an "800" telephone number to carry his message and to raise money.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
Quintessential Insiders Put on Airs of Outsiders

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16

 BODY:
Caveat New Hampshire.
There are two Republicans wandering around your state claiming that they disdain everything Washington stands for, that they are fed up with everyone who runs the city and that they would like to boot out all those colluding, golf-playing, inside-the-Beltway bums. 
 Do not believe George Bush and Patrick J. Buchanan when they claim to be outsiders. As the President himself might say, they are really wolf kind of guys out there in sheep's clothing.
The Republican rivals sparring over who is the true outsider are both quintessential Washington insiders, having spent, between them, more than 65 years in this town.
 
Live-in Bureaucrat
 Mr. Buchanan is a home-grown pundit and former aide to three Presidents who lives so close to the Central Intelligence Agency in suburban Virginia that his cat keeps setting off the security sensors buried in the woods around the agency headquarters. This would-be populist says he has never even ridden the Washington subway.
Mr. Bush has been a Government official, chauffeured around in Government cars, for so long that his main experience behind the wheel in the last couple of decades has been in a golf cart. He drives so seldom -- there was a picture-taking session once with a car fueled by ethanol -- that Barbara Bush said she was nervous about riding with him.
When Mr. Bush tried to get a tax break on the house he bought in Kennebunkport, Me., in 1981, the Internal Revenue Service refused and told him that his principal residence was the Vice President's mansion on a naval installation in Northwest Washington. It was reminiscent of the Postal Service's declaring Macy's Kris Kringle the real Santa Claus in the classic Christmas movie, "Miracle on 34th Street." When the revenue service declares you a live-in bureaucrat, the label sticks.
Consider this, New Hampshire: Mr. Buchanan, as a speechwriter for President Richard M. Nixon, and Mr. Bush, as chairman of the Republican National Committee, were among the last officials in Washington to offer a defense of Mr. Nixon during Watergate, and that is about as far inside the Beltway as you can go.
 
Yearning for an Outsider
 Whether it was Dwight D. Eisenhower coming home from war, Jimmy Carter marching up from Georgia or Ronald Reagan galloping in from the West, Americans have long had a romantic yearning for a bold outsider who could tame the Jabba-the-Hut bureaucracy. Even though voters realize that politicians shamelessly exploit their desire for a political Robin Hood, this longing has intensified this year, with surveys showing that Americans are more disgusted than ever with the Federal Government.
Of course, except for Walter F. Mondale in 1984, the Democrats have usually presented themselves as outsiders in recent campaigns. They do not have much choice, having been shut out of the White House for a dozen years now.
But the Republican race has put an absurd twist on the insider-outsider debate, with an incumbent President with one of the longest Government resumes in history and a Washington native and member of the city's journalistic elite competing for outsider status.
When Mr. Buchanan appeared on Wednesday night as a guest on his former Cable News Network program, "Crossfire," his one-time partner, Michael Kinsley, asked him how he could portray himself as the anti-Washington candidate.
"You lived here all your life," Mr. Kinsley said. "You've either been in the media or the Government. You never had an honest job in your life and you've never run anything in your life. What makes you qualified to be President and run the whole country and makes you qualified to portray yourself as some sort of outsider populist?"
 
Shameless Flattery
 With the sort of shameless geographic flattery that passes for logic in a campaign, Mr. Buchanan replied, "Well, what qualifies me, if I am qualified, will be the people of New Hampshire."
Asked on a plane ride home from New Hampshire last week how he could present himself as an outsider, Mr. Buchanan replied: "I am in Washington, not of it. No insider challenges an incumbent President. That makes me, de facto, an outsider."
Politics, as the much-wooed voters of the first primary state know better than anyone, is a matter of perception. And these two old Washington hands believe that they can give the impression of being fiery populists through their rhetoric.
Mr. Buchanan argues that Mr. Bush has lost the right to be President because he has cozied up too much to the Democrats, cutting tax and budget deals with them and then "going off to play golf with Dan Rostenkowski."
Indeed, Mr. Bush, who is not only a bureaucrat but a bipartisan at heart, does like to play golf with the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.
But at the Rotary Dinner in Portsmouth, N.H., on Wednesday night, Mr. Bush blasted "these tired subcommittee chairmen in Washington, D.C., that haven't had a new thought in the 50 years they've been sitting there" and accused the Democrats of offering "cheap promises coming out of deep left field, past the running track, up against the fence, in the left field" on the economy.
Even though Mr. Bush has made more official visits to Japan since he was elected President than to New Hampshire, he said that he felt so close to the state that he had "New Hampshire values," rather than bad old Washington values. Mr. Bush explained New Hampshire values this way: "Remember Lincoln, going to his knees in times of trial and the Civil War and all that stuff."
 
Good Ol' Boy Drawl
 Mr. Bush also says he believes it makes him more down-to-earth when he puts on a bit of a good ol' boy drawl, dropping the final consonant of words like fixin' and drillin'. At the Cabletron Systems computer parts plant in Rochester, he began a sentence concerning the Persian Gulf war with his usual manner of speaking, starting to say "about to begin," and then thought better of it and switched to a Southern synonym mid-phrase, "It was one year ago, one year ago that Desert Storm was about -- fixin' to begin, as they say in another of my home states, Texas."
Mr. Buchanan's vivid oratorical style, his manner of insulting highly placed Washington officials with Don Rickles-relish, is his main weapon in helping the Washington native project an outsider persona.
He mocked the budget director, Richard G. Darman, as the "Doctor Kevorkian of the American economy," referring to the doctor who invented a suicide machine, and suggested that Environmental Protection Agency officials were tree-huggers who were "walking around in sandals."
Mr. Buchanan said two Bush campaign strategists, Charles R. Black Jr. and James H. Lake, who have stirred controversy for having Japanese business clients, "should be wearing kimonos." And he said the Republican Party should change its moniker from "the big tent" to "the big pagoda."
But, whatever they say, New Hampshire, remember that these two men are not only insiders, but insiders who want to make you believe that they are outsiders so that they remain in Washington as insiders even longer.
Now you know.

HEADLINE: University of Bridgeport Plans Takeover by Sacred Heart

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 16

 BODY:
The University of Bridgeport said today that it has decided on a plan to have all its programs, including its law school, taken over by Sacred Heart University in Fairfield.
But the announcement set up a confrontation between the financially troubled University of Bridgeport and its law school that could undermine not only the agreement with Sacred Heart, but also the law school's own accreditation. 
 The law school's faculty has voted unanimously to affiliate with another private institution, Quinnipiac College in New Haven. Today's announcement, in effect, was notice that the university's trustees will fight that move.
Sacred Heart has said the 750-student law school must be part of any plan for it to take over Bridgeport's programs.
 
Issue of Viability
 The declaration of war between the university and its law school was evident this afternoon in the auditorium, where the decision to affiliate with Sacred Heart was announced. Hundreds of law students loudly heckled every speaker, from Edwin G. Eigel Jr., the university's interim president, to Senator Christopher Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut.
"The issue that is at stake here is the viability of an entire university, not just one school," said Senator Dodd, plainly angry at the shouts and taunts. "There are thousands of other students, and they deserve an education, too."
Officials from Bridgeport and Sacred Heart said the collaboration would preserve a college campus in Bridgeport's South End, where the University of Bridgeport owns 85 acres. Keeping the university's jobs and students in the city has been a prime goal of Senator Dodd and other local, state and Federal officials who have worked to keep the university from shutting down entirely.
 
Matter of Accreditation
 But the law school has vigorously pursued a move to another institution since October, when the University of Bridgeport's trustees appeared ready to consider an offer to affiliate with the Professors World Peace Academy, an institute financed by the Unification Church.
The issue, the law faculty and students say, is not the economic health of the city of Bridgeport, but the fact that the law school is in danger of losing its accreditation from the American Bar Association because of the university's troubles.
Sacred Heart, they say, is not strong enough financially and academically to satisfy the A.B.A.'s requirements; Quinnipiac is.
"They have apparently turned this into a political circus, saying affiliation with Sacred Heart will serve the local community, without acknowledging they'll just lose accreditation," said Terence H. Benbow, whom Mr. Eigel dismissed as law dean in November.
Mr. Benbow, a faculty member, is still considered dean by the law faculty and students. Mr. Eigel cut short today's news conference when Mr. Benbow, supported by chanting students, demanded to speak.
Mr. Dodd and other speakers suggested today that the law students were selfishly thinking only of themselves, rather than of the entire university. But as registration for the spring semester continues this week, it remains unclear just how many students are left at Bridgeport, which had an enrollment of 9,100 in 1969.
The university began this academic year with 3,900 students, about half of them part-time. After a fall semester filled with turmoil, sharp cutbacks in academic programs and the threat of closing, the university expected enrollment to drop by as much as a third, to 2,600.
Today Mr. Eigel said more than 2,600 students had registered, but there were no figures on how many full-time students were among them, beyond the law students and seniors hoping to graduate this spring.
Neither Mr. Eigel nor the president of Sacred Heart, Anthony J. Cernera, who issued a statement, offered details of their collaboration except to pledge that they would keep part of the University of Bridgeport's campus open.
The president of Quinnipiac, John L. Leahy, and Mr. Benbow will make a presentation on Feb. 1 to the American Bar Association's council on legal education, seeking provisional accreditation for the school at Quinnipiac. Bridgeport and Sacred Heart also plan to make a proposal to the council.
One danger now, Mr. Leahy said, is that each side in the dispute could thwart the other, leaving the law school without any accreditation.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
30-Year Bond Off More Than Point

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Long-term interest rates rose for the sixth straight session yesterday, as credit market participants sold Treasury bonds and long-term notes despite additional evidence that inflationary pressures are very tame.
Prices were off sharply, with the benchmark 30-year bond down more than a point. That pushed its yield up to 7.66 percent, compared with 7.57 percent late on Wednesday. 
 Traders chose to focus on the prospect of an early end to the economy's current problems rather than look at the moderate inflation report from the Government.
Consumer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in December and at a 3.1 percent rate for all of 1991, down from 6.1 percent in 1990.
 
Betting on Recovery
 Bond investors usually warm to indications that inflation pressures are easing, because lower inflation rates tend to increase the value of fixed-income securities. But the recent news, coupled with forecasts from most economists that inflation is not likely to become a threat through all or much of 1992, has been of scant solace lately.
"People are betting on an imminent recovery," one government securities trader said. "They have been doing that in this market, in the stock market and in the foreign exchange market.
The trader added: "It's a bit like what happened last April, after we got that surge in confidence at the end of the gulf war. Market participants have a tendency to re-create old trades, and they are putting on the post-gulf trade now."
The sense that the economy's fortunes may be about to improve began on Dec. 20, when the Federal Reserve Board sent a clear, bold signal to financial markets by cutting its discount rate a full point, to 3 1/2 percent, and lowering its target on the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market to 4 percent.
To many credit market participants, the nature of the Fed's move implied that the central bank would follow up its actions with further reductions in short-term rates.
Economic reports since then have continued to show an economy in distress, but the Fed has been silent.
Fed officials have suggested publicly in recent days that the actions already taken will be sufficient to initiate a recovery. But the rise in interest rates over the last week has made that forecast a bit shakier, analysts said.
 
'A Return to Gradualism'
 "The spirit of Dec. 20 has evaporated," said Neal M. Soss, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation. "In December, the Fed moved boldly. Since then their language and actions suggest a return to gradualism. Those factors, in turn, have withdrawn the rally that had been in place."
Over the last week, long-term bond yields have risen by more than 25 basis points, or more than one-quarter of a percentage point.
That increase is forcing up home mortgage interest rates, a move that could jeopardize further improvement in housing activity.
The shift in sentiment that Mr. Soss identified as a big cause for the rise in rates has been augmented by a huge volume of new corporate bonds. To hedge positions against unsold corporate inventories, fixed-income traders have been selling Treasury securities over the last week.
"There is always some technical flow-of-funds aspect that intersects with demand for securities," Mr. Soss said. "But if spirits were bullish, the corporates would be sold, and the spirit would be there."
 
$1 Billion Offering
 Traders said a $1 billion offering of 30-year bonds from Hydro-Quebec, the Montreal-based electric utility, played a role in the sharp selloff in the Treasury bond market yesterday.
In late trading, the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at 10327/32 , down nearly 1 1/4 points, or almost $12.50 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, to yield 7.66 percent.
On Jan. 8, the last day of the market's rally, long-term bond yields stood at 7.38 percent.
"There is no reason why long rates should be stuck above 7.50 percent, let alone move back toward 7.75 percent or 8 percent," said Victor Chang, president of VC Management Inc., a New York-based money management firm.
"It may be the economy is no longer going down," Mr. Chang added, "but we are still in what is likely to be a prolonged period of slow growth with inflation falling to under a 3 percent rate."
Prices of long-term Treasury notes continued to be hammered, but for the first time since the current selloff began, prices of short-term issues were little changed.
Among note issues, the 7.50 percent 10-year notes were offered in late trading at 10214/32 , down 3/4 point, to yield 7.14 percent. But the 5 percent two-year notes dipped by just 2/32 , to a price of 9929/32 , to yield 5.05 percent.
During the last week, yields on two-year securities have risen by more than 40 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.
Short-term Treasury bill rates fell slightly.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.78 percent, down 2 basis points. And six-month bill rates fell by a similar amount to a late offered rate of 3.87 percent.
The Hydro-Quebec offering dominated activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market.
The $1 billion worth of 8.40 percent 30-year bonds were priced at $99.268 to yield 8.467 percent, 85 basis points more than the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 at the time of pricing.
First Boston acted as lead manager for the underwriting. The securities, which are noncallable for life, are rated Aa-3 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and AA- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In addition to the Hydro-Quebec securities, investors had the opportunity yesterday to purchase the first publicly sold debt issued by Woolworth since May 31, 1974.
The retailing concern priced $200 million worth of 30-year securities through an underwriting group led by Merrill Lynch & Company.
The 8.50 percent bonds were priced at $99.425 to yield 8.553 percent, 90 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated A-1 by Moody's and A by S.& P.
The slide in Treasury prices continued to have an adverse effect on outstanding issues in the secondary markets for investment-grade corporate bonds and in the tax-exempt municipal securities market.
Traders in the corporate market said that prices of most issues fell by 1/8 point to 1/4 point.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, prices of the most widely quoted bonds were down by a full 1/2 point, participants said.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported that all three measures of the nation's money supply fell sharply in the week ended Jan. 6.
Because of technical factors, most analysts had been anticipating large declines in the monetary aggregates. But the numbers reported yesterday far exceeded expectations, especially the $25.2 billion drop in M-3, the broadest money measure.
The surprising weakness in the numbers reported by the Fed had no impact on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: Consumer Price Index Up 3.1% in '91, 5-Year Low

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16

 BODY:
Consumer prices advanced a moderate three-tenths of a percent in December, the Labor Department said today, helping to hold inflation to a five-year low of 3.1 percent for the year. The rate was nearly half the 1990 rate of 6.1 percent.
Two-thirds of the moderation in inflation last year came from a big swing in oil prices, which soared after Iraq invaded Kuwait in August 1990 and then fell after it became clear the Persian Gulf war would not permanently crimp the world's oil supply. 
 Energy inflation hit a 10-year high of 18.1 percent in 1990. In 1991, energy prices fell 7.4 percent.
Even after factoring out the volatile food and energy sectors, inflation was still down. The core rate was 4.4 percent last year, down from 5.2 percent in 1990 and from the same level as in 1989.
In December, the core inflation rate was three-tenths of a percent, the same as November.
Analysts attributed the long period of moderation in the price index to the economic decline and stagnation that began in July 1990. Consumers' reluctance to borrow and spend has forced retailers to hold prices steady or watch lackluster sales erode.
 
Lowest Since '86
 The inflation rate for last year was the lowest since 1986, when prices rose 1.1 percent. It was the second-lowest rate since 1967, when prices were up 3 percent.
The December rate compared with a November price gain of four-tenths of a percent.
"We have some problem areas, like health care and college tuition, but if you take that out, you're really talking about a minuscule amount of inflation," said Lawrence Chimerine, a senior adviser at DRI-McGraw Hill, a consulting firm in Lexington, Mass.
With most analysts expecting only a weak economic recovery this year, the prospect is good for only moderate inflation, between 3 percent and 3.5 percent.
At the White House, Marlin Fitzwater, the President's spokesman, said the Administration was "especially encouraged by the sharp deceleration in price increases." But, he said, "Obviously, the unfortunate side of it is a good deal of that is because of the economic slowdown."
 
Jobless Claims Down
 Separately, the Labor Department said today that first-time claims for unemployment insurance fell to 403,000 for the week that ended on Jan. 4, down from 452,000 the previous week.
The decline, after an increase the week before, could be good news, but analysts cautioned against reading too much into weekly fluctuations in the volatile number. They also noted that the occurrence of New Year's Day in the middle of the week left laid-off workers with one less day than usual to file claims.
In a third report, the Labor Department said Americans' average weekly earnings, after adjusting for inflation, increased by seven-tenths of 1 percent in December, after a rise of one-tenth of a percent in November. But, over the year, real weekly earnings were up just three-tenths of 1 percent.
Last year, inflation was marked by a 2.5 percent rise in food and beverage prices, the smallest gain since 1976, when they were up just five-tenths of a percent. The most significant factor was a 2.1 percent decline in 1991 meat prices, which had been up by 11.3 percent the year before.
 
Food Up 0.4%
 In December, food prices rose four-tenths of a percent, the same as in November. But vegetable prices moderated, rising only by eight-tenths of a percent after being driven 4.4 percent higher in November by the infestation of the whitefly in California. Lettuce prices, for instance, fell 15.7 percent in December, after soaring 44.5 percent in November.
Although energy was responsible for much of the inflation moderation in 1991, other sectors showed smaller cost increases.
Housing costs were up by 3.4 percent, compared with 4.5 percent a year earlier; clothing and upkeep costs, by 3.4 percent versus 5.1 percent in 1990, and medical care, by 7.9 percent, after a 9.6 percent gain.
The various changes in December put the index for all consumer items at 137.9. That means a hypothetical selection of goods that cost $100 in the 1982-84 base period cost $137.90 in December 1991 and $133.80 a year earlier.

HEADLINE: A New Loss At Security Pacific Seen

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 16

 BODY:
The Security Pacific Corporation said today that it expected to lose about $400 million in the fourth quarter, its second consecutive hefty loss. Officials at the BankAmerica Corporation said the new loss would not deter it from going ahead with its acquisition of Security Pacific.
"That was all in line with our expectations," Frank N. Newman, BankAmerica's vice chairman and chief financial officer, said at a news briefing here today. BankAmerica reported its own earnings for the fourth quarter of $285 million, roughly equal to the $287 million reported a year earlier. 
 The expected loss at Security, which will report its full results on Tuesday, reflects the addition of $730 million to reserves for loan losses. The Los Angeles-based bank has been buffeted by loan problems stemming largely from the slump in the California economy, particularly in real estate. These problems helped make Security receptive to BankAmerica's takeover offer.
In the third quarter, Security had a net loss of $509 million after setting aside $1.2 billion for loan loss reserves. For the year, Security said today that it expects to lose about $765 million.
The possibility that BankAmerica, which suffered its own horrendous loan problems just a few years ago, might drag itself down by taking on Security Pacific's troubled portfolio has always been the big uncertainty surrounding the deal.
The transaction, a stock swap valued at more than $4 billion when it was announced in August, would create the largest bank in the West and second largest in the nation behind Citicorp. The acquisition has been accepted by shareholders of both companies but still needs regulatory approval.
Mr. Newman of BankAmerica declined to say whether he expected further problems in Security Pacific's performance. But he said that even with the new losses, the combined bank would have adequate capital and would "start out with a fully adequate reserve" for loan losses.
 
BankAmerica Satisified
 Thomas Brown, banking analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said actions taken by Security Pacific now to clean house would just mean less for BankAmerica to do after it completed the merger. Given the huge expected savings in expenses from the merger, "The problems have to become a lot worse before this doesn't make sense for BankAmerica," he said.
Mr. Newman termed BankAmerica's own earnings as pleasing in light of the weak economy. While net income was equal to that of a year ago, earnings per share of $1.20 were a bit less than the $1.29 a year ago because of an increase in shares outstanding.
For the year, BankAmerica reported record net income of $1.124 billion, compared with $1.115 billion in 1990, making it the third year in a row that the bank has exceeded $1 billion in earnings. On a per share basis, earnings were $4.81 in 1991, compared with $4.95 in 1990.
BankAmerica did not completely escape the loan problems that have afflicted its California rivals. Its net credit losses in the fourth quarter were $279 million, more than double the $132 million a year ago. The provision for credit losses in the quarter was $275 million, up from $210 million in the third quarter and $250 million a year ago.
Nonaccrual assets other than those related to countries that are restructuring their debt were up $202 million from one quarter ago and $873 million from a year ago.
But the San Francisco bank offset loan problems by increasing revenue, both from interest and fees, and controlling expenses. There were also gains from sale of investment securities and from the disposition of formerly leased aircraft.
On the New York Stock Exchange, BankAmerica's shares slipped 12.5 cents, to $41.375, while Security Pacific was unchanged at $34.75.
While the weakening of the California economy has caused problems for banks in that state, many banks elsewhere are reporting that the worst of their loan problems are past.
The Continental Bank Corporation, Chicago, for example, yesterday reported a $159 million decline in its troubled loans since Sept. 30 to $814 million. The drop in bad loans, plus reduced losses on its worst loans, helped the company earn $50 million in the fourth quarter, or 77 cents a share, up 42.9 percent from $35 million, or 46 cents a share, a year ago. Because of heavy loan losses earlier in 1991, Continental lost $76 million, compared with a 1990 profit of $75 million, or 70 cents a share.
Continental's shares gained 50 cents, to $12.625.
