HEADLINE: Volunteers or Not, Tennessee Lawyers Help Poor

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 14

 BODY:
So many natives signed up for the War of 1812 and the Alamo that Tennessee became known as "The Volunteer State." But at the Knox County courthouse these days, the proud tradition of Tennessee voluntarism is being sorely tried. With the court docket clogged, the public defender's office swamped and the state's treasury depleted, every lawyer in the county has been ordered to represent the poor at no charge.
The notion of mandatory public service for lawyers has been bitterly debated by bar groups throughout the country and, some courts have ruled, is of dubious constitutionality. But in Tennessee, a state so strapped for cash that it has grounded fleets of school buses, the judges are assigning first and asking questions later. 
 A June 1991 study commissioned by the Tennessee District Public Defenders Conference found that each lawyer in a public defender's office in the state was handling an average of 430 cases -- more cases than their counterparts anywhere else.
 
A Role for Mayor
 So this month, the four judges of General Sessions Court, which handles misdemeanors, decreed that all of Knoxville's 1,200 licensed lawyers would be assigned to represent indigent clients. That includes Mayor Victor Ashe, who hasn't practiced law for years and has never handled a criminal case.
In a pincer movement on the local bar, the judges promptly began selecting lawyers from either end of the alphabet for appearances in sessions court. But with the public defender's office choking on felony cases, too, criminal-law novices like Mayor Ashe may soon be all that stands between poor defendants and years of incarceration. "This is a crisis situation," said Bob McGee, one of the four judges to sign the decree.
If Knoxville's remedy is unusual, its problems are typical of those facing beleaguered public defenders everywhere -- a result, defense lawyers say, of recession and particularly the war against drugs. In Seattle, according to the National Center for State Courts, criminal filings more than doubled between 1983 and 1989. Over roughly the same period, the number of defendants charged with drug-related felonies doubled in Chicago; between 1981 and 1988, they more than doubled in Los Angeles, too. Public defenders in Louisiana and Georgia have filed suits claiming they they cannot both handle their caseloads and meet their ethical obligations to individual clients.
 
One Place to Cut
 "At times like this, one of the first things governments do is look around and say, 'Why are we paying all this money to defend these criminals?' So they cut back on the already meager resources available to indigent defense programs," said Mary Broderick, director of the defender division of National Legal Aid and Defender Association.
On Feb. 4 Mayor Ashe will appear on behalf of a 19-year-old man charged with trespass. Dick Wirtz, acting dean of the University of Tennessee's law school and an authority on intellectual property and antitrust, is handling a shoplifting defense. The university's general counsel, Beauchamp Brogan, has also been assigned, as has Bruce Anderson, an insurance defense lawyer and president of the Knoxville Bar Association.
Both Secretary of Education Lamar Alexander and Howard Baker, the former White House chief of staff, are on the lawyers' list, but as nonresidents of Knox County they appear to be exempt from the requirement. Not so Jimmy Duncan, the local Congressman. Or James Clayton, whose mobile-homes company is listed on the New York Stock Exchange. Or hundreds of other lawyers who know chapter and verse about leases, alimony and medical malpractice but nothing about assault or battery.
 
A State With Problems
 Mark E. Stephens, the city's public defender, contends that legal services for the poor bore a disproportionate share of the cuts in the state judiciary's $37.7 million budget, and that the poor in Knoxville were suffering more than those in Memphis or Nashville, whose public defender programs are older and better financed. It is, local residents say, something of a state tradition.
Ever since the Civil War, when its poorer, non-slave-owning residents opposed secession, Tennessee east of the Cumberland plateau has considered itself the state's stepchild. This is particularly true of Knoxville, whose terrain, Republican politics and barbecue are more redolent of Asheville than of Nashville or Memphis.
In July, citing the state's budgetary problems, Chief Justice Lyle Reid of the Tennessee Supreme Court urged the state's trial court judges to appoint public defenders, rather than private counsel, wherever possible. Before Tennessee established a public defender system, courts appointed lawyers to represent the poor, and they continue to do so in many cases, particularly those involving more than one defendant, when conflicts of interest can arise. Most other states have one or the other system, or elements of both.
By November, the caseload of the Knoxville public defender's office had doubled, and Mr. Stephens persuaded the General Sessions Court to assign no more cases to his office until Jan. 25. He has now asked the courts for the same relief for felony cases, and said he may decline assignments regardless of what they decide.
"I'd be willing to go to jail, even though I'd be afraid of who they'd appoint to represent me," he said.
 
Not Many Excuses
 The judges' order, issued on Jan. 7, made clear that no malingering would be tolerated. "No lawyer will be excused for any of the following reasons: (a) does not accept appointed cases; (b) does not practice criminal law; (c) is too busy," the order stated. It went on to state the only three acceptable excuses: physical infirmity, retirement or death.
The program has created some schisms in the local bar. Large corporate law firms like Baker, Worthington, Crossley, Stansberry & Woolf -- the "Baker" is Howard -- plan to assign their collective criminal caseload to a dozen junior lawyers. They have been told that they can call criminal lawyers elsewhere in town, should they feel lost or incompetent. Other firms can bring in ringers. Mr. Ashe, for instance, has enlisted the help of a lawyer in the city's legal staff, though he maintains he will handle the case himself.
 
'Fish Out of Water'
 Sole practitioners do not enjoy such luxuries. "I'm very unhappy about it," said Douglas J. Toppenberg, a divorce lawyer. "The big firms aren't having to dirty their hands at all, and while I'm sure the Mayor will show up in court for all the publicity shots, he's delegating his case. It's leaving small practitioners like me to bear the brunt of it.
"Most defendants admit their guilt and want an attorney to negotiate a very minimal sentence," he continued. "But if someone says he's innocent and insists on a trial, I'm going to feel like a fish out of water."
Then there are those lawyers, like Patrick Leonard, who have long made their livings off court-appointed work. Even after Knoxville's public defender office opened last year, they continued receiving assignments, for which the state pays $20 to $30 an hour.
But when state funds began drying up, that range was reduced to $5 to $7.50 -- less, one lawyer for the indigent pointed out, than an employee at McDonald's gets. Now, the funds have run out altogether. On Tuesday, 40 of these lawyers met to discuss their options, including suing the state and withdrawing from the cases they are already handling.
 
Starting From Scratch
 The public service requirement has moved at least one lawyer, 69-year-old Charles Amburn, to retire. Dozens of other lawyers have been forced to recall ancient courses in criminal law or to seek the advice of experienced criminal defense lawyers.
Defense counsel report receiving a flurry of such phone calls in the last two weeks, asking them such questions as "What is a warrant?" "Where is the General Sessions Court" and "What is a 'quail'? " (a quail, they are told, is a $20 heat-sealed bag of cocaine).
Judge McGee, too, has received numerous calls from "panic-stricken" lawyers, including one from the University of Tennessee who needed directions to the local jail. "They don't understand why they have to be dragged into an arena they didn't ask for, aren't qualified for and aren't getting paid for," he said. "And they won't suffer the insecurity and fear of a criminal defendant who doesn't know what kind of lawyer he's going to get."
The Mayor's client, Scott Hurst, said that when he was first told that his lawyer's name was Victor Ashe, "I figured it was someone else, not him." Only when a court officer told him that Mr. Ashe's office was convenient -- five flights upstairs from the courtroom -- did he realize he had landed Knoxville's leading citizen.
Asked if he felt competent to handle Mr. Hurst's case, he replied, "At this stage." But Mr. Hurst seemed unconcerned that Mr. Ashe and the lawyer working with him lacked criminal law experience. "I think they'll help me," he said.
Mr. Leonard, who is representing a co-defendant in the case, was not so sure. "If this ended up a felony and it went to trial," he said, "and with the Mayor not having any practical criminal experience ever, I think I'd really be concerned.
"At the time, Scott kind of laughed along with everyone else. He may come to the realization that it's not a joke any more."

HEADLINE: Chief of Transit Officers Resigns After 21 Months

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
William J. Bratton, who as chief of the New York City Transit Police for the last 21 months had earned high marks as a manager and motivator, resigned yesterday to take the No. 2 position in the Boston Police Department.
New York police and transit officials said Chief Bratton had engineered a remarkable turnaround in the New York Transit Police during his brief tenure. They credited him with increasing the department's morale, reducing the level of serious crimes in the subway and providing officers with new equipment and new strategies for policing the city's vast transit system. 
 "The guy did a terrific job with a force that had always been a problem," said Thomas A. Repetto, president of the Citizens Crime Commission, a group that monitors law enforcement. "He is a very able fellow. He knows how to motivate the troops. He's a good manager. He can communicate with street cops and business people and the media."
Chief Bratton's departure comes at a difficult time for the transit police, several officials said, because the possibility of a merger with the New York Police Department, which has been discussed intermittently for at least a decade, has gained momentum in the last month after it was endorsed by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.
 
Flynn Faults Police
 The announcement of Chief Bratton's departure was made yesterday at a news conference in Boston by that city's Police Commissioner, Francis M. Roache, who has been under fire for serious management problems in the agency. In a report released on Tuesday, a special panel appointed by Mayor Raymond L. Flynn of Boston sharply criticized the handling of civilian complaints by the police and recommended that Mr. Flynn replace the Police Commissioner when his term expires in April.
Mr. Flynn, who is a close boyhood friend of the Police Commissioner, has declined to discuss the recommendation.
Mr. Roache said at the news conference that he had been talking with Chief Bratton for three months about returning to Boston, which is the Chief's hometown and where he began his police career. Chief Bratton will have the title of superintendent and chief of the Boston Police Department, a new position in which he will serve in essence as the chief executive officer, Mr. Roache said.
On the surface, Chief Bratton's move may appear curious, he acknowledged in a telephone interview last night. He is going from the top position in the transit police, a force of 4,100 officers, to second in command of a smaller force. The Boston department has 2,100 officers.
 
A Pay Cut?
 Chief Bratton, who is 44 years old, is also taking a pay cut, from $110,000 to $90,000. But he contended in both the news conference and the interview that the job presented both intriguing professional challenges and important personal considerations.
The Chief's wife, Cheryl Fiandaca, is a lawyer who remained in Boston after he came to New York in April 1990. Ms. Fiandaca had tried to find a job in New York, but the recession made that impossible, several transit officials said. As a result, the couple have had to keep two residences and have commuted between New York and Boston on weekends.
"While it is a drop in pay, it really is not," Chief Bratton said last night, referring to the housing and commuting costs he will no longer have to pay. He phrased it somewhat differently at the Boston news conference: "With the cost of living in New York City, I'm getting a pay raise."
He said he thought he had accomplished most of his major goals in New York, including restoring morale and reducing the serious crime rate in the subways. Serious crime in the subway declined 15.1 percent during the first 11 months of 1991, compared with the same period in 1990, transit police officials said last night.
"What I've enjoyed doing as a police manager is going where there are challenges, going in and mixing it up," Chief Bratton said. "I like that. I don't like maintenance positions."
He also made it clear that he was attracted by the chance to return to his hometown. He said that there was no understanding that he would eventually replace the Boston Police Commissioner, a friend of 20 years.
"New York will not be easy to leave," he said. New York transit and police officials said he would not be easy to replace, either.
Alan F. Kiepper, president of the Transit Authority, said he had not yet decided how he would search for a replacement. Mr. Kiepper said that Chief Bratton had put in place some strong deputies.
"I think it's really important that we consolidate the gains that Bill has made," Mr. Kiepper said. "But I don't think you replace Bill in kind. He's unique."
Mr. Repetto of the Citizens Crime Commission said that he had been receiving two or three phone calls a week from officials around the country who were interested in Chief Bratton. The Chief acknowledged last night that he had been talking with officials in Los Angeles and Chicago about the top police jobs in those cities.
"The word was spreading all around the country about him," Mr. Repetto said. "If it wasn't Boston it would have been somewhere else sometime soon."

HEADLINE: The Squabbling Resumes Over Roosevelt Raceway

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 16

 BODY:
Once the nation's premier harness racing track, Roosevelt Raceway stands vacant now, the paint on its bleachers cracking, its turf in disarray, a decaying symbol of a developer's ambition and what state investigators called government mismanagement.
But now that a state inquiry into the publicly financed sale of the raceway has ended, the same government officials and developers are at war over the future of the 172-acre site, the largest stretch of undeveloped land in Nassau County. 
 Where racing fans once wined and dined and placed their bets, just across the turf from the grassy field where Lindbergh took off for his trans-Atlantic flight in 1927, the developers hope to build more than two million square feet of office space, a conference center, a hotel, a 10-screen movie theater and 200 units of housing.
Republican officials in Hempstead would rather see more open space and housing for the elderly on the site. The town has adopted a plan that would reduce the amount of office space to 1.5 million square feet and increase the housing units to 350.
 
Stadium Proposed
 And the Nassau County Supervisor, Thomas S. Gulotta, has called for construction of an indoor-outdoor stadium on the property. In his State of the County address, Mr. Gulotta, a Republican, suggested that the site could continue to accommodate a harness racing track during the off season. He said this week that he would appoint a special sports authority within the next few weeks to pursue the project.
Given the current economic climate, however, it is far from certain that any of these competing proposals will be adopted. Mr. Gulotta, in the midst of a budget crisis that will force the layoffs of 3,000 Nassau County workers, has not offered a plan to pay for his proposed stadium.
And in part because the Town of Hempstead has blocked the owners from selling or developing the site, they are now faced with foreclosure for failing to make payments on $72 million in loans. Moreover, the developers are facing a depressed real-estate market, particularly for office space.
Still, there is enthusiasm about the potential of the site, which Roosevelt Raceway Associates purchased in 1984 for $52 million, and which the owners valued at $200 million in 1988.
"It has unlimited potential," said James L. Larocca, the president of the Long Island Association and a spokesman for the island's business community. "We would like to see a range of possibilities examined, including a sports facility that the New York Jets might consider coming home to. The fun of getting back to some real choices is welcome."
The land, now used for a flea market on weekends, is in the heart of Nassau County, just east of the Roosevelt Field Shopping Center and directly behind Fortunoff's, which plans to begin construction soon on a $194 million shopping mall that also awaits final zoning approval from the Town of Hempstead.
The raceway was purchased in 1984 by a group headed by Charles L. Evans, an investment banker and race-horse breeder, from Gulf and Western Industries with the help of $52 million in tax-free bonds provided by the Town of Hempstead Industrial Development Agency.
Mr. Evans and his partners, Barry B. Goldstein, a public accountant; David Stevenson, a former jockey, and William B. Hopkins, the former president of the raceway for Gulf and Western, decided in early 1987 to close the track and sell it or develop the property, despite charges that they were reneging on promises to keep the track in operation.
The state inquiry, conducted by the State Investigation Commission, cleared the developers of any wrongdoing, but it was critical of the way the Hempstead Industrial Development Agency administered the bonds issued to Mr. Evans and his partners. The owners redeemed the bonds in 1987 and pursued private financing. The results of the inquiry were announced on Monday.
In 1986, when Hempstead officials learned that the owners wanted to sell part of the raceway property, they imposed a moratorium on development of the site that remains in effect. But Justice Gabriel S. Kohn of State Supreme Court has recently ordered Hempstead to stop dragging its heels and to take action on zoning requests necessary for the development plans.
Jeffrey Forchelli, a specialist in zoning law who represents the raceway property owners, said he was "optimistic" that differences with the town would be resolved by Feb. 25, when the next town board hearing is scheduled on the matter.
"The hard times have helped in this situation," Mr. Forchelli said. "Government leaders are beginning to realize that helping to generate jobs to boost the economy helps all of us."
He said that Joseph N. Mondello, Supervisor of the Town of Hempstead, had "recognized the need for a balance between retail and office space" and had been assured that the owners "could provide more affordable senior housing."
At least one real-estate expert, however, has doubts about extensive office construction on the site.
Paul Amoruso, a managing partner of Oxford and Simpson in Jericho, pointed out that real-estate values have dropped sharply in the last 18 months, noting that the office vacancy rate in the area was between 20 percent and 30 percent.
 Mr. Amoruso supports Mr. Gullotta's proposal. "At this time, a sports complex would make a lot of sense," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nassau County officials and developers are at odds over the future of the 172-acre Roosevelt Raceway, the county's largest undeveloped tract. (Alan Zale for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Carolco Reaches an Accord On Its Plan for Revamping

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 16

 BODY:
Carolco Pictures Inc. said today that it had reached a tentative agreement with its biggest foreign shareholders and its banks on a plan that would give the struggling Hollywood production company some financial breathing room.
The plan would provide Carolco with $45 million in new money, delay the repayment of existing bank loans and other obligations, and possibly allow additional bank loans. Analysts said the package should permit Carolco to complete and release its next several movies, including "Basic Instinct," a thriller starring Michael Douglas. But they said that unless these movies performed well, Carolco would once again face a financial crisis. 
 Carolco has been struggling for months, despite having produced last year's biggest box-office hit, "Terminator 2: Judgment Day," because the rest of its movies have not earned enough to cover the company's heavy debt payments and the cost of making new films.
 
Historical Strength
 Carolco recently abandoned its efforts to diversify into lower-budget movies and other businesses to concentrate on its historical strength: making a handful of relatively expensive movies each year, usually action films that play as well abroad as in the United States.
The plan announced today calls for Carolco's three main foreign shareholders -- Pioneer Electronic of Japan; Canal Plus, the French pay-television company, and RCS Group, an Italian media company -- to lend the company a total of $32 million and buy $13 million in new preferred stock. In addition, those shareholders will allow Carolco to delay repayment of another $10 million owed to them.
Carolco's banks, led by Credit Lyonnais, Bankers Trust and Chemical Bank, also agreed to defer until Nov. 30 the repayment of a $14 million loan due this month and to loosen restrictions on the company's credit lines to allow Carolco to borrow additional money above the $171 million it already owes the banks.
Completion of the restructuring hinges on the resolution of other issues including the previously announced effort by Carolco to buy back $67.5 million of its bonds at 65 cents on the dollar.
 
Up to 'Basic Instinct'
 "The $45 million from the foreign partners should get them through the next few months, but then it's going to be up to 'Basic Instinct' to start generating some cash," said Lisbeth Barron, an analyst at S. G. Warburg & Company.
Ms. Barron said the $45 million should be enough to insure Carolco's release this year of "Basic Instinct" and "Universal Soldier," an action adventure film. But she said it was less clear whether Carolco was correct in assuming that the money would be sufficient to release the two other films on its slate for this year, "Charlie," about Charlie Chaplin, and "Cliffhanger," starring Sylvester Stallone.
Ms. Barron said the company was heading in the right direction with its recent decision to slash employment and focus on a few ambitious movies each year. But she said Carolco might have to sell such operations as its Orbis Communications television distribution subsidiary, a step the company recently said it was considering.
Carolco's stock jumped 50 cents today, a 25 percent gain, to close at $2.50 a share on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Silver and Copper in Surge As Metals Rally Continues

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Silver and copper prices rose sharply in heavy trading yesterday as investors anticipated renewed interest in industrial metals.
Silver for delivery in March soared 17.8 cents, to $4.338 an ounce, and copper for March added 1.20 cents, to 97.05 cents a pound. Traders were active in both pits, and an estimated total of 47,000 silver contracts changed hands. 
 "Industrial metals as a group have made great strides in the last few days," one analyst said. The rally in stocks has been seen as a precursor of an economic recovery that would be a boon for silver, copper and platinum.
United States inventories of copper are also relatively low, spurring the market, said John Gross, president of J. E. Gross & Associates.
Gold for February advanced on the Commodity Exchange in New York, closing at $357.40, up $2.30. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $353.00, up $2.30 over Wednesday's late bid.
At the New York Mercantile Exchange, April platinum gained $6.10, to $343 an ounce, encouraged by remarks in South Africa by a mining executive at Impala Platinum Holdings that labor disputes with miners threatened the company's expansion plans.
 
Oil Gains Slip
 Crude oil for February closed only 6 cents higher at $18.91 a barrel, though the market rocketed up to $19.30 early yesterday on news that Algeria and Nigeria were cutting output.
The gains failed to hold, however, in light of doubts about whether other OPEC members, particularly Saudi Arabia, would agree to large-scale production cuts to bolster sagging prices.
"If Saudi Arabia doesn't cut, we are oversupplied, and that's the biggest concern right now," said John Bradberry, an analyst with the Continental Ozark Trading Company.
Libya and Venezuela have announced small cuts in output, hoping that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will agree to larger reductions when it meets on Feb. 12 in Geneva.
"I'd be very surprised if we see anything out of the Saudis until they meet next month," said James Ritterbusch of the Carson Petroleum Company.
Heating oil for February rose 0.82 cent, to 54.87 cents a gallon, and February unleaded gasoline gained 1.08 cents, to 54.42 cents a gallon.
March cocoa finally reached the plateau of $1,200 a metric ton, up $24 at the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls in Volatile Day And Mark Is Hit by Selling

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed lower yesterday in a volatile session dominated by selling of the German mark.
Analysts said the dollar, which has rallied over the last week, fell victim to profit taking and fears that central banks might intervene to force the dollar lower. 
 But the currency found support during the session from some positive economic news. The Labor Department said first-time claims for state unemployment insurance fell to 403,000 for the week ended Jan. 4, down from 452,000 the previous week.
Traders theorized the drop might lessen pressure on the Federal Reserve to nudge interest rates down to stimulate the economy. The dollar, like all currencies, draws support from stable or higher yields.
 
Focused on Mark
 John McCarthy, chief foreign exchange dealer with ABN-AMRO Bank N.V. in New York, said that "there's some sense we've bottomed out" and that the economy might begin some modest growth that would keep rates stable.
He added, however, that the market yesterday was more focused on the German mark. Rising concerns about the German economy and fears that German rates will decline prompted many investors to sell the mark against most other foreign currencies.
Reports of unrest in Eastern Europe and the Georgian republic also raised speculation that refugees would flow into Germany and strain the country's economy.
The mark gained against the dollar, which fell to 1.6170 marks in New York, from 1.6250 late Wednesday. In earlier European trading, the dollar fell to 1.6170 marks from 1.6215.
The British pound also rose against the dollar, closing at $1.7627 in New York, up from $1.7520 on Wednesday. In London, sterling rose to $1.7615 from $1.7560.
The dollar also weakened against the Japanese yen, closing at 128.22 yen in New York, down from 128.66. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar rose 2.38 yen, to a closing 128.43 yen, and in London, it was quoted lower at 128.30 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.4355 Swiss francs, down from 1.4455; 5.5120 French francs, down from 5.5430; 1.218.00 Italian lire, down from 1,224.25, and 1.15425 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15355.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A Time of Peril For World Trade

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
PRESIDENT BUSH took a beating on his trade mission to Japan, and Japan got off lightly. Instead of conveying the picture of a determined leader fighting to safeguard an open world economy, Mr. Bush appeared to be pleading for Japanese mercy -- especially for the suffering American auto industry. Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa responded by saying Japan would show "compassion."
Japan agreed to double imports of American auto parts from $7 billion last year to $15 billion in 1994, and to import 20,000 American cars, although it appeared that most of these cars would come from Japanese manufacturers in the United States. 
 For his pains, Mr. Bush was roundly attacked by Detroit's Big Three for not getting more. Detroit apparently wants nothing less than all-out managed trade -- a divvying up of the auto market in the United States and Japan.
In his role as car salesman in Japan, Mr. Bush appeared to have bought the managed-trade line -- to the dismay of American trade officials who have been desperately trying to get an agreement in the Uruguay Round of trade talks, under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, to open world markets to agricultural products, services and intellectual property, where America is strongest.
But on returning home, Mr. Bush reaffirmed the free-trade line, sowing confusion on what he really stands for. This confusion comes at a terrible time, with the GATT talks in deep trouble. A failure of the talks could lead to a breakup of GATT and a splitting of the world into hostile trade blocs.
While much criticism has been heaped on the President for his managed-trade mission, Japan again escaped with its thinly disguised mercantilist and protectionist policies intact. Those policies, aimed at maximizing exports over imports, have given it the largest trade surplus in the world -- a surplus that roughly equals everyone else's deficits. According to the estimate of C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics, Japan's trade surplus soared to $100 billion last year and is likely to rise even higher this year.
The Japanese insist that the fault for imbalance in world trade is not theirs but lies elsewhere -- especially in the United States, with its huge budget deficits and poor-quality goods. They insist that Japan simply has a comparative advantage in manufactured goods but is short of resources and must export manufactured goods to pay for resource imports; this does not stop them from protecting agriculture. And they sometimes concede that Japan was closed in the past, but is liberalizing fast.
"These arguments either miss the point or run counter to the facts," says Prof. Rudiger Dornbusch of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "The mechanisms that close Japan to outsiders are not clear -- neither tariffs nor quotas play a role -- but by any definition Japan is closed." He contends that Japan's protectionism has "multiple layers, like an onion, and the innermost layers are cultural."
He focuses on manufactured goods, where foreign penetration of Japan was only 3.1 percent of its gross national product in 1989, compared with 7.1 percent in the United States, 15.6 percent in West Germany and 18.7 percent in South Korea. Whichever country offers the best basis for comparison with the Japanese, Japan's acceptance of foreign manufactured products is the lowest of any industrialized or newly industrializing country. Mr. Dornbusch sees no evidence of improvement: Japan's manufacturing imports have ranged between 1.5 and 3 percent of gross national product without much change for a quarter of a century. And Japan's total non-oil imports have declined from 9 percent 25 years ago to 6 percent now.
While agreeing with Mr. Dornbusch that Japan has pursued a protectionist trade policy, Robert Z. Lawrence of the Kennedy School of Harvard University asserts that restrictions by Japan on foreign investment in its own country have been even tighter than those on trade. Japan, according to his estimate, takes in only seven-tenths of 1 percent of total world foreign investment. Well-publicized exceptions, like I.B.M., Coca-Cola and Procter & Gamble and some smaller companies, he says, do not change that basic fact about a country that has become the world's biggest foreign investor. Mr. Lawrence says Japan's keiretsu, the alliances of companies in many fields, should get particular blame for the exclusion of foreign goods, services and investment.
Japan has been an enormous beneficiary of the open world trading system. In its own long-term interests, as well as everyone else's, a far-sighted Japan should be out in front fighting to preserve it. Recession, unemployment and industrial shrinkage are weakening support for free trade in the United States. Europe, preoccupied with unification, is turning inward. A breakdown in the world trading system that has nourished economic development since World War II would be an incalculable economic and political tragedy. It happened once before -- 60 years ago.

HEADLINE: War of Hams Where the Stage Is All

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH

 BODY:
HAM actors may be a horror, but fine actors playing ham actors are almost always a joy. Brian Bedford, cast as the 19th-century British tragedian William Charles Macready in Richard Nelson's new play, "Two Shakespearean Actors," is no exception. Very grand, often pickled and prone to forgetting the end of any sentence well before he has made it to the verb, Mr. Bedford's puffed-up Macready would be right at home in the hapless theatrical companies of "Nicholas Nickleby," "The Dresser" and "Noises Off." Even his version of the actor's nightmare is egomaniacal: when Macready dreams this dream, he does not forget his lines but instead plays all the parts at once.
Mr. Bedford, a British actor who has been a mainstay of Broadway and Stratford, Ontario, over a 30-odd-year stage career, pours a lifetime of both classical and boulevard-comedy experience into this role. In Mr. Nelson's play, Macready is a tired, fading figure who arrives to perform "Macbeth" in the New York City of 1849 only to find his supremacy challenged by a younger local upstart, the first great American Shakespearean, Edwin Forrest (Victor Garber), who is performing his own "Macbeth" elsewhere in town. It's an ugly situation. A symbolic target for enraged nationalistic forces beyond his comprehension, Macready suffers the indignity of less-than-full houses, a pelting with stones and, finally, a full-scale Anglophobic riot that leaves more than a score dead outside the Astor Place Opera House. 
 Yet in Mr. Nelson's fictionalized retelling of this actual history, and in Mr. Bedford's meticulous performance, Macready never ceases to be human and never becomes the butt of the piece. Though he is always patronizing to his New York hosts (his idea of a compliment is to call Americans "intelligent in an instinctive sort of way"), Mr. Bedford cloaks the snobbery in a rheumy laugh, merry eyes and a glinting smile. For all the outrageousness of Macready's Macbeth -- performed in a kilt with a Lady Macbeth firmly consigned to the upstage shadows -- this babbling ham actor is, finally and all too fleetingly, a tragic figure. When the mob boos and stones him, Mr. Bedford gives a stunned reading of the simple line "They have interrupted my performance!" that conveys the abject terror of another actor's nightmare, an audience's rejection. When the riots break out later, the spent, frightened Macready drifts into a passage from "King Lear" that Mr. Bedford plays for keeps, a fallen giant baring himself to an empty house as "a poor, infirm, weak and despised old man."
People who love the theater will dote on Mr. Bedford, and they will be nearly as fond of Mr. Garber, who is just as good in a much less juicy role. But even if one does cherish the backstage lore and actors' shoptalk that are the currency of "Two Shakespearean Actors," it's hard to shake the feeling that this evening, often diverting and sometimes more than that when Mr. Bedford is center stage, never lives up to its promise. And a lot is promised. The star turns, the fascinating premise, the huge cast that greets the audience in the play's opening moments and the elegant staging by Jack O'Brien all imply that this production, a Lincoln Center Theater presentation at the Cort Theater on Broadway, will have epic ambitions akin to "M. Butterfly" or "Amadeus," or, perhaps more aptly, to the revisionist cultural-historical fictions of E. L. Doctorow. But Mr. Nelson's writing, as epitomized by the prosaic title, rises only sporadically to the scale of everything else.
This disappointment is unexpected, because "Two Shakespearean Actors" is poised to pick up where the author's savage previous comedy, "Some Americans Abroad," left off. As in that play about American Anglophiles agog in present-day England, this one trades in Jamesian themes: the cultural clash between the Old World and the New, the declaration of an independent American artistic identity that is at once brave and vulgar, dynamic and insecure. Unfortunately, Mr. Nelson does not expand upon these points this time so much as reduce them to a simplistic, frequently reiterated duel of acting styles. Macready, representing England, stands for textual fidelity and outward sophistication while the rising American, anachronistically portrayed as an incipient Method Actor, stands for raw energy and the obsessive, inward study of subtext.
Even if this formulation were an accurate picture of the contrast between English and American actors of 1849 -- which it is not -- it still would not be a big enough conflict, or, if you will, metaphor, to explain the bloody Astor Place riots. But no other explanation, real or imagined, is forthcoming in "Two Shakespearean Actors," which consistently whets the audience's curiosity about its subject only to leave it unsatisfied. The political, economic and xenophobic forces that lead to the evening's anticolonial conflagration -- sentiments that have resurfaced, less violently, as recently as the Jonathan Pryce-"Miss Saigon" contretemps -- remain hinted at but unexamined. Eventually the riots are all but forgotten, except as explosive noises off, while Mr. Nelson brings Macready and Forrest together for a sentimental, historically dubious display of noble theatrical fraternity that seems to belong to another play.
Since the personal stories of the title characters, notably Forrest's sad offstage juggling of a wife (Frances Conroy) and mistress (Jennifer Van Dyck), are also sketchily told, "Two Shakespearean Actors" often lacks emotional as well as intellectual bite. Anecdotal in structure, it is almost always at its best when it is dealing simply, parochially and sometimes uproariously with the theater of missed cues, onstage mishaps and offstage egos. The one conspicuous exception is a wildly overlong Act I sequence in which the rehearsals of the Forrest and Macready productions of "Macbeth" are supposedly contrasted but, accents and costumes aside, prove to be more alike than not.
There and elsewhere, Mr. Garber offers evidence that he can act Shakespeare at the same high level at which he acts everything else. (Having done a mock Otello in "Lend Me a Tenor" and a mock Macbeth here, maybe it's time for him to try the real thing.) His Forrest, a creature of the stage tortured by private demons Mr. Nelson never illuminates, is a commanding matinee idol who can make even self-pity and arrogance charming. In a company full of outstanding actors in cameo roles that never quite pay off, the better assignments, all executed superbly, belong to Zeljko Ivanek as a perennial understudy torn between two companies and countries, Eric Stoltz in a lecherous and opportunistic portrait of the Irish playwright Dion Boucicault and Tom Lacy as a cynical supporting player nearing the farcical end of an unsung career.
Like Mr. Nelson's play, Mr. O'Brien's production evinces an overwhelming affection for the theater. As bathed in silken simulated gaslight by Jules Fisher, the simple, wood-beamed set by David Jenkins allows the action to swing gracefully from auditorium to backstage to dressing room to tavern; the sense of being taken into a hermetically sealed theatrical world of the Victorian age is completed by the Cort Theater itself, a gilded relic closer in origin and spirit to 1849 than 1992. Though Mr. Nelson is an American writer, "Two Shakespearean Actors" was first produced two years ago with a different cast and director by the Royal Shakespeare Company at Stratford-on-Avon. Rather than risk another riot, I will assume that the English production was far inferior to our own.
 
Two Shakespearean Actors
 By Richard Nelson; directed by Jack O'Brien; sets, David Jenkins; costumes, Jane Greenwood; lighting, Jules Fisher; sound, Jeff Ladman; poster art, James McMullan; original score, Bob James; fight director, Steve Rankin. HEADLINE: Prices Down, Optimism Up for Antiques Show

BYLINE: By RITA REIF

 BODY:
"Welcome to my fantasy garden," said Thomas K. Woodard, a folk-art dealer, standing by a weathered 10-foot-high doorway dominating his booth at the Winter Antiques Show in the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan. The archway, as intricately carved and pierced with scrolls and leaves as a giant paper doily, is a century-old frame for the front door of a New England house, he said.
On either side of this doorway, Mr. Woodard placed two English 19th-century garden urns of fired clay and filled them with freeze-dried strawberries, artichokes and gardenias. "I'm a hopeless romantic -- or a hopeful romantic when it comes to gardens," he said. 
 Such optimism reigned throughout the armory this week despite freezing temperatures on Wednesday, when two boilers broke down, and the recession as 66 dealers, many in down jackets and gloves, set up their elaborately appointed settings at the fair. The bazaar, now in its 38th year, opens today in preview and tomorrow to the public for a nine-day run.
Coinciding with the fair are two smaller Manhattan antiques shows, at the Convent of the Sacred Heart and at St. Vartan's Cathedral, and several exhibitions of decorative arts at the city's galleries and museums. In addition, there is "Celebrating Art and Antiques in New York: 11 Treasures Revealed," in which Manhattan dealers are exhibiting paintings or furnishings that are not known to have been shown in the city. A portion of the proceeds will benefit the Frick Collection.
At the Seventh Regiment Armory, Americana is as strong as ever at the Winter Antiques Show, with album quilts, paintings, weather vanes, Massachusetts highboys, Revolutionary War drums and mechanical banks.
 
Many Prices Are Lower
 Although some dealers are stocking costly objects, some at the million-dollar level, there is also evidence of an increased awareness of the economy. Compared with the 1980's shows, this one has fewer objects with six- or seven-figure price tags and many more of $5,000 or less.
At the Colwill-McGehee booth, for example, there are seven American 19th-century children's chairs: a Shaker, a Hitchcock, two painted Windsors, a Victorian pair and a painted Pennsylvania one. They range from $1,500 to $5,000. At the Woodard booth, English 19th-century colored-glass bulb vases, with blooming hyacinths, are $200 to $500.
Among several new types of offerings at the fair is an architectural house model at Marguerite Riordan's booth. The 1850 Italian-style Connecticut residence has polychromed walls, gold-foil dormers and a paper-tile roof and comes with a carrying case. The price is $16,500.
Photography, another first at this fair, is being shown by Gerald Korn blau, a former photographer. The 17 photographs are of Dakota farm scenes and the town of Groton in the Dakota Territory. They are dated 1885 and stamped with the photographer's name, Carli & Stienhauer of the Gallery Above the Drugstore, Groton. The price for the group is $8,500.
At this bazaar, which once forbade 20th-century items, 1930's objects are now commonplace. Mr. Kornblau is exhibiting a 19-inch-tall plaster head from Carl Milles's "Astronomer," a fragment from one of two full-length painted green figures completed in 1938. (The other "Astronomer" was part of the Trylon and Perisphere exhibit at the 1939 World's Fair.) The price is $30,000.
Sporting memorabilia, which are selling well despite the recession, are appearing at this fair for the first time. Alexander Acevedo brought a shelf full of loving cups and medals that range in price from a pair of gold and silver medals from 1898 for $6,000 to a 1920's James Fenimore Cooper silver trophy costing $100,000.
Antiques enthusiasts who like to buy other people's collections have several to inspect at this show. The most colorful and visible group of objects offered is Leigh Keno's 53 bandboxes, made of printed paper on pasteboard between 1820 and 1840. Assembled over 20 years "with the help of my parents," Mr. Keno said, the collection is being sold as a group for $125,000. "If the collection has not been sold by 7 on Friday night, we'll offer them singly," he said.
What may well be the rarest group of objects at the fair is a set of 12 English silver Apostle spoons from 1637 at S. J. Shrubsole. "To the best of our knowledge, this is the only such set of one date and maker for sale," said Eric Shrubsole, the owner. The price is $500,000.
Oriental wares, shown by 10 dealers, may soon outnumber Americana at this fair. Japanese screens are exhibited by at least three dealers. The rarest, a 12-panel pair of gold-leaf Momoyama screens from about 1600, depicting a snow-covered bridge and the low-lying hills near Mount Fuji, is at Leighton Longhi's booth. He is asking $850,000 for the pair. Among the other Oriental objects at the fair is a Japanese bronze unicorn from 1800 inlaid with silver and gold. It is $46,000 at Michael Goedhuis of London.
One of the show's largest and most expensive treasures is a 1745 marble-topped monumental sideboard, 10 feet long, at the booth of Carlton Hobbs. "We bought it last year in a barn in Shropshire," Mr. Hobbs said. "It had been dismantled and made into two tables. We've put it back together again, and this is the first showing." The price is $1.8 million.
 
The Vetting Dispute
 Once again, after a decadelong controversy over whether to authenticate, or vet, everything at the fair, the Winter Antiques Show is not doing it, although the procedure is used at most European fairs and at the International Antique Dealers Show, held in October in Manhattan. The dealers asked for the authentication, and a year ago the sponsor of the Winter Antiques Show, the East Side House Settlement, a 100-year-old charity operating in the South Bronx, promised to vet the 1992 show. The plan failed when the dealers and the sponsor agreed that the dealers should guarantee their objects without vetting.
Actually, the dealers' turnabout came just as Betty Sherrill, president of McMillen Inc., one of the oldest interior-decorating firms in the United States, replaced Mario Buatta as the show's chairman. Mr. Buatta opposed vetting but Mrs. Sherrill said this week she favors the practice.
"I originally wanted to have the show vetted," she said. "But it wasn't my decision. I can understand the problems and I know it's very difficult and expensive to vet a show. Nevertheless, I still think it would be wonderful if we had vetting at the show."
But the show's manager, N. Pendergast Jones, agrees with the sponsor and the dealers on the vetting issue. Mrs. Jones said the dealers will issue guarantee forms with each purchase, and a card in each booth will explain the guarantee.

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Alex Witchel

 BODY:

A Move for 'Grand Hotel'
For weeks now, theater people have been waiting for the final showdown between Rocco Landesman, the president of Jujamcyn Theaters, and the co-producers of "Grand Hotel: The Musical." The stakes are high. Jujamcyn owns the Martin Beck, where the long-running Tommy Tune show is playing. It wanted to book Jerry Zaks's much-anticipated revival of "Guys and Dolls" into the Beck for an April opening, but "Grand Hotel" just kept on running. It still will, moving to the Gershwin Theater on Feb. 3 after playing its final performance at the Beck on Jan. 27. Which means "Guys and Dolls," at long last, will have a home.
One reason "Grand Hotel" has lasted so long is that until recently "Grand Hotel" and Jujamcyn had never negotiated what is known as a stop clause, a standard practice on Broadway. It means that if a show makes less money than a mutually agreed-on figure for two weeks in a row, the theater owner has the right to evict the show. But in this economy, most theater owners are flexible.
Martin Richards, a co-producer of "Grand Hotel," says: "We never had a stop clause because Rocco Landesman offered us everything but the ownership of the theater to get our booking. He never wanted to discuss a stop clause until 'Guys and Dolls' wanted our house." Mr. Richards says the ensuing negotiations were heated, and he maintains that during the talks Jujamcyn stopped printing tickets for the show at the box office, violating an agreement that tickets remain on sale for 13 weeks in advance.
"Rocco said that 'Grand Hotel' might run another year but 'Guys and Dolls' could run three years," Mr. Richards recalls. "How does he know that? Does he have a crystal ball?"
Mr. Richards also says Mr. Landesman promised to contribute $100,000 toward the $300,000 cost of moving the show, "but now he seems to have amnesia." James Nederlander, the owner of the Gershwin, will pay $200,000 toward the move and Mr. Richards will pay the rest. Mr. Nederlander says he plans to mount a London production of "Grand Hotel" and tour it through Europe.
Mr. Landesman refused to address any of Mr. Richards's charges. "I've been at Jujamcyn for four and a half years, and my integrity will have to stand on its own," he says. "I wish them the best of luck at the Gershwin."
 
Economizing on Tony Tickets
When Tony Randall envisioned a National Actors Theater, it seems that nothing so crass and commercial as a Tony Award was part of the picture. His company is presenting its second show of the season, Georges Feydeau's "Little Hotel on the Side," at the Belasco Theater, a Broadway house, but, as with "The Crucible," the 700 Tony voters are not invited. That means that none of the company's productions can be nominated for best revival, although the actors and designers are still eligible, says Harvey Sabinson, the executive director of the League of American Theaters and Producers, which sets the Tony rules with the American Theater Wing. But what good are nominations in any category if no one has seen the performances to vote on them?
Any nonprofit company, especially a brand-new one, needs to raise money strenuously in these times. Even if it is not interested in the commercial benefits that a Tony Award brings to other Broadway shows, wouldn't a Tony go a long way toward impressing potential donors?
Manny Kladitis, the general manager of the National Actors Theater, says that because subscribers hold 51 percent of the tickets for each show's seven-week run, the company cannot afford to give each Tony voter the customary pair of free tickets. But Todd Haimes, the managing director of the Roundabout Theater, the other nonprofit company reviving classics in a Tony-eligible house, says his theater does invite voters. He has found room for them in his seven-week runs, which are 80 percent subscribed in a theater roughly half the size of the Belasco.
One producer who spoke on condition of anonymity says other Broadway managements resent Mr. Randall's brand of economizing. The perception is that he has used Broadway's cachet for all his publicity without extending to the Tony voters the basic courtesies that other shows do.
A spokesman for the National Actors Theater says Mr. Randall's comment was that the company cannot afford to make Tony seats available.
 
Just Two Sisters? No Performance
 The 1,100 people who showed up to see the star-studded cast of "The Three Sisters" at the McCarter Theater in Princeton, N.J., on Sunday had quite a surprise at 2 P.M., when the curtain was to go up. The show's director, Emily Mann, went onstage to announce that the performance was being canceled. Mary Stuart Masterson, the actress playing the third sister, Irina, had the flu. She does not have an understudy, and neither do her co-stars, Linda Hunt, Frances McDormand, Laura San Giacomo and Edward Herrmann. Since most of the other performances were already sold out, this audience was offered the chance to reschedule for 10:30 A.M. Thursday or the evening of Super Bowl Sunday. You can imagine the reaction.
"Most regional theaters don't have understudies," says David Mayhew, the director of marketing for the McCarter. "The expense involved for runs of only a few weeks is too high. Once a show opens here, we only have 15 performances left. Up until opening night, we only have time to rehearse the main cast, so even if we had had the understudies, they wouldn't have been rehearsed."
Mr. Mayhew says Ms. Masterson returned for the next scheduled show on Wednesday night.
 
Dedications to Papp
 With the opening last night of Richard Nelson's "Two Shakespearean Actors" at the Cort Theater, at least three dedications to the late producer Joseph Papp are now to be found in Playbills around town. " 'Two Shakespearean Actors' is dedicated to the memory of Joseph Papp, who, for 35 years, served Shakespeare, the theater and New York in full and generous measure," it reads.
At the New York Theater Workshop production of Caryl Churchill's "Mad Forest," the dedication is to "the memory of our friend Joseph Papp, who first introduced Caryl Churchill to New York audiences, and inspired and supported many of our lives." And at Second Stage, the season's dedication says: "Joseph Papp was a friend, mentor and constant inspiration to us. He taught us that with adversity comes opportunity and that with risk comes change. But most importantly, he taught us that no matter what, the show must go on."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Next, an Emmy?" Wendy Wasserstein, the Tony Award- and Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright, will become a regular contributor to "Channel 2 First News," which makes its debut on Jan. 27 at 4 P.M. "We want her observations on being a woman in New York," says Martin Blair, the program's spokesman. "Everyone used to pass her New York Woman columns around the newsroom. She's original." (Star Black)

HEADLINE: Luxe on the Menu: Softening Hard Times

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER

 BODY:
LIFTON FADIMAN, the writer and editor, once remarked that when you have little money it is best to spend that little "on the unnecessary, the emotional dividends being higher." Certainly not the kind of advice your accountant would offer, but it carries a grain of logic. More to the point, if you are scrimping in other parts of your life -- foregoing a vacation, a new car, home improvement -- a dining splurge can be a potent spiritual anodyne. 
In these relentlessly stringent times, when every day seems to bring new woes about a national economy that is harder to revive than a rusty old lawn mower, it's easy to get a bit down at the mouth. What's more, the tribulations of New York City seem more intractable than ever. Yet people still queue up on Broadway for theater tickets; movie houses and concert halls are busy; museums are crowded, and restaurants, while scrambling for customers as never before, are holding their own surprisingly well, and with openings still outpacing closings.
New York City has always managed to put on a determined face in times of misfortune, like Scarlett at a smoldering Tara. Even in the grimmest situations, it has shown a spirit of glamour and romance. And what could be more uplifting than sitting at a window seat at the River Cafe in Brooklyn, sipping a glass of good chardonnay and watching tugs ply the East River to the towering backdrop of lower Manhattan.
Or how about the Rainbow Room, that glittering dance floor in the clouds? Occasionally, one might cavil about the uneven food, but not about the stunning views or the Fred-and-Ginger setting. While we are 65 floors up, we should mention Cellar in the Sky on the 107th floor of the World Trade Center, the classier cousin of Windows on the World. Cellar has the intimacy, the mood (including live classical guitar), the food and the wines to make for an enchanting evening. The seven-course menu at Cellar in the Sky changes regularly.
Those who feel more comfortable closer to sea level can hop a boat at the East 34th Street Pier in Manhattan and chug over to Water's Edge in Long Island City, Queens. The rather formal room, with its black-tie captains and pianist, looks back at midtown Manhattan: the United Nations, the Chrysler Building, the Citicorp tower and more. The staff is accommodating and the eclectic American fare by David Silver, the chef, can make the trip worthwhile: a monkfish-and-potato salad with turnip chips, scallions and a light vinaigrette; sauteed sweetbreads with crayfish, and sweet Chinese sausage dumplings in a delicious Oriental bouillon; perfectly cooked salmon with sun-dried tomatoes and pesto, and grilled sea scallops with Swiss chard and fried polenta.
Another striking harborside location that receives a sizable Wall Street clientele is the Hudson River Club in the World Financial Center on the Hudson River. The panoramic view from the handsome, contemporary dining room is exhilarating, as is the food by Waldy Malouf, the chef. An acquaintance proposed to his girlfriend at a window seat, then called both families on his ever-present portable phone. The chef's contribution to this type of occasion might be a terrific pumpkin-and-apple soup, braised veal shank with citrus and sage, and venison stew with wild mushrooms, cranberries and chestnuts.
The Upper East Side of Manhattan is rich in elegant and romantic dining. Foremost is the renascent Maxim's on Madison Avenue, a faithful reproduction of the original in Paris, which, sadly, has declined to a tourist trap. That is by no means the case in New York, where David Ruggerio, the chef, has whipped the kitchen into shape, offering a splendid blend of classical and contemporary French cuisine. The rest of the operation has followed in step. The dining rooms are a rococo delight, glistening with polished rosewood walls, vines of hammered brass, elaborate wall moldings, stained glass and pastoral murals. A sizable dance floor gets plenty of use when a combo picks up the tempo later in the evening.
Another famously romantic spot that I recommend often, and with flawless results, is the Sign of the Dove on Third Avenue, a brick and marble grotto with brick arches, wrought-iron filigree, explosions of flowers, skylights and suitably private tables. As for the food, it, too, can make one swoon. Andrew D'Amico, the chef, has a refined touch with game and seafood.
One of the most comfortable spots on the Upper East Side is Mark's, the dining room in the Mark Hotel with a polished English theme. The menu could be called sophisticated Continental, and there are plenty of winners: napoleon of asparagus with a ragout of chanterelles, red snapper on eggplant caviar, and dry-aged sirloin with a green-peppercorn sauce and garlic potato cake.
One does not ordinarily equate Chinese restaurants with romance, yet there are two settings in Manhattan that qualify. On the Upper West Side there is Shun Lee, the haunting black-and-white cavern with snarling dragons overhead, low lighting and cozy banquettes. On the Upper East Side, there is Chin Chin, with two dramatically different moods. The front room has warm pale peach walls and handsome woodwork with charming sepia-toned portraits of the Chin brothers family. The back room is like another restaurant, a snowstorm of white broken by colorful Oriental pottery perched on wall ledges. The food at both is captivating and elegantly presented. And each has unusually extensive wine selections for Chinese restaurants. Among other things, both offer a superior Peking duck.
Two of my favorite restaurants on the Upper West Side are Cafe des Artistes, the stylish salon on West 67th Street that serves brassy bistro fare, and the Terrace, uptown at Columbia University, an unabashedly romantic rooftop restaurant that offers a sweeping view of the Hudson River and much of Manhattan. The Terrace was my choice to take my wife-to-be on our first date, along with a buddy of mine. I no longer remember why I took a male chaperone; I do remember that we had such a great time, including some superlative wine, that he stayed with us right through the after-dinner drink downtown and the goodnight kiss.
Midtown Manhattan has the biggest crop of luxury restaurants, including two smashing new ones: Les Celebrite's, in the lavishly refurbished Essex House, and Lespinasse, in the deluxe St. Regis Hotel. The theme of Le Celebrites is the artwork of television and movie stars that adorns the walls. The inventive and generally light French food by Christian Delouvrier can be exquisite, and service is top-notch. Lespinasse has an aristocratic air, with its high ceiling, baronial tables and pretty murals. Gray Kunz, the chef, has French training and experience in Asia, which shows in his startling creations.
Midtown also has a bumper crop of old-line French restaurants that still offer indulgent pampering. Among them La Cote Basque on West 55th Street, one of my first big-city French restaurant experiences; La Grenouille, on East 52d Street, the opulent family business abloom with fresh flowers and turning out the same fare it has offered for years; La Caravelle on West 55th Street, a Gallic dowager that has been revitalized with a new decor and a new chef, and Le Perigord on East 52d Street, an endearing spot with a caring staff and wonderful Provencal food by Antoine Bouterin. It was on a deep red banquette in the mural-wrapped dining room of La Caravelle that, over lunch, I proposed to the woman who is now my wife. She sipped her Corton-Charlemagne, looked in the air, and said, "No." Then, she said, "Yes."
An Italian spot in midtown that ranks high on the mood meter is Palio on West 51st Street in the Equitable Tower. You can start off with an aperitif in one of the city's most spectacular bars while taking in the tumultuous mural by Sandro Chia, then hop an elevator to the second-floor dining room. Palio is a splendid color-drenched space with murals representing teams from the ancient Palio horse race overhead. Andrea Hellrigl, the chef and owner, combines refined Northern Italian fare with lusty winter specialties. Try the risottos and the roast goat when available.
In the same corporate complex is the city's finest seafood restaurant, Le Bernardin, a soothing teak-lined room adorned with a dramatic oil painting of fishermen and their catch. The glistening, fresh seafood is as stunning as ever, and desserts have taken a noteworthy step upward with the arrival of a new pastry chef, Francois Payard. Those with adventuresome tastes and a sense of whimsy could easily find bliss at the Quilted Giraffe on East 55th Street. Barry Wine, the owner, chef and culinary Japanophile, always has intriguing specials. On the winter menu are dishes like noodle-wrapped shrimp with ginger and soy, and prime sirloin cooked 60 seconds on one side with black and white sesame noodles. The high-tech stainless-steel and black granite room is delightful when the lights go down and the candles come up.
Two ethnic restaurants in midtown qualify as romantic for their artful use of color and architecture: Dawat, the unconventional Indian restaurant on East 58th Street that serves the vibrant creations of the cook and actress Madhur Jaffrey; and Eldorado Petit, the deserving Catalan restaurant with the glazed terra-cotta walls that are highlighted with artful projections of shellfish.
Also in midtown is Restaurant Raphael, a small, subterranean spot with a lovely outdoor garden for warm weather dining and considerably improved food on West 54th Street. For the moment the chef is Jean-Michel Bergougnoux, formerly of the late Le Cygne, who has turned the menu in the direction of refined bistro food.
A trend in the making is dining and dancing, and three atmospheric new clubs have opened in Manhattan in the past year. The Supper Club is a new restaurant in a former theater in the Edison Hotel on West 47th Street. This cavernous cobalt blue space is the brainchild of two Manhattan restaurateurs: Jean de Noyer, the owner of Le Comptoir, and Wayne Nish, the chef and owner of March. The menu is straightforward, moderately priced and well executed. Soft trio music early in the evening turns into a big-band dance sound later on.
Over on East 50th Street is a handsome former cabaret now called Tatou. The 30-foot ceiling, ornate wood moldings and giant chandelier hark back to the heyday of cabarets. The regional American food by Scott Cohen, the chef, is probably much better than patrons of the old Cafe Versailles were served.
One of the more elegant dining and dancing clubs is Laura Belle, the stylish spot in a former movie palace on West 43d Street. It is owned by Michael O'Keeffe of the River Cafe in Brooklyn and the Water Club in Manhattan. The amphitheater space has tables on several tiers facing a sizable dance floor. Music is soft in the early evening, cranking up about 11 P.M. The chef, Mitsu Kikuchi, who came from the River Cafe, serves an appealing menu largely free of saturated fats, substituting vegetable sauces and Oriental touches.
 
Downtown
 Greenwich Village is filled with romantic little nooks in the way of restaurants and bars. If forced to narrow the field, one might have to turn to Le Metairie, the rustic French bistro on West 10th Street, and Il Cantinori, the enchanting Tuscan restaurant on East 10th Street.
It's no wonder that so many couples flock to the banquettes of Le Metairie and its a barnlike setting of white walls and dark wood trim with farm tools, firewood stacked on overhead ledges, and dried flowers. The moderately priced menu is reliably appealing, too.
Il Cantinori is a Tuscan rendition of the same theme, with stucco walls, wood-beam ceiling, glazed tile floor and handsome country furniture. The best dishes are the pastas and homey specials.
On a smaller scale, but beguiling in its own way, is Le Pescadou, the seafood bistro on King Street. The main dining room has a wide-plank floors, pale yellow walls, brass sconces and a fireplace. The seafood is unassailably fresh and prepared with respect for the fish's flavor. In the little tavern room up front, a short seafood menu is offered for those who do not want a full dinner.
Far downtown, Manhattan boasts two of the most pampering restaurants in the city: Bouley, on Duane Street, and Chanterelle, on Harrison Street. David Bouley's Gallic dream is may well be the most alluring setting in the city; the food is right up at the top, too. The country French ambiance includes a graceful vaulted ceiling, gentle lighting, lace curtains, bucolic Impressionist paintings and splays of flowers. Chanterelle is a sparer environment -- soft yellow walls and decorative wood trim -- yet the tranquillity it offers plus the impressive French food can be rhapsodic in this shrill city.
Over the river in Brooklyn there is the century-old seafood house Gage & Tollner, which stands with dignity amid the urban mishmash of the Fulton Mall. The long, dark, mahogany dining room resembles a wide train parlor of another era. Overhead are gas-fueled chandeliers that waiters solemnly ignite every evening. The menu by Edna Lewis, the Southern-born chef and cookbook author, carries many of her native specialties along with Gage & Tollner shellfish favorites like the clam belly broil, clams casino and sundry oyster preparations.
Even if the oyster's putative role in spurring romance has not been substantiated, it's fun to ignore science while slurping down some iced bluepoints. In addition, it's hard to dwell on life's woes while savoring what Pliny called "the pleasure of the table." And if you are in a magical setting, all the better.

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

Paintings by Australians
Behind-the-scenes maneuvering for major works of art has always been a way of life for auction houses and dealers. But in this bleak season, when so few good collections are up for grabs, the competition is especially heated.
This week, three plum collections -- one of a celebrated collector, featuring works by Australian artists, another of Old Master paintings and decorative objects, and a third comprised of contemporary art -- have caused quite a scramble. By far the juiciest is the group of paintings and sculptures belonging to Alan Bond, the bankrupt Australian industrialist who became a famous figure in the art world five years ago when he borrowed $27 million from Sotheby's to buy van Gogh's "Irises" for $53.9 million, at that point the largest amount ever paid for a painting. (The painting has since been bought by the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif.) 
 The decision about who will sell the rest of Mr. Bond's art collection, estimated to be worth up to $20 million, isto be made by Duesburys, an accounting firm in Perth, Australia, handling the assets of Dallhold Investments, Mr. Bond's private company. Right now, it seems, there is a fierce race between Sotheby's, Christie's, the London dealer Neville Keating and numerous Australian auction houses to obtain the 61 paintings by Australian artists and sculptors, 12 French sculptures and one Renoir painting.
"We'll evaluate the proposals from the various auction houses," said Tom Iceton, a manager at Duesburys. "We'll probably sell everything through one auction house. But we're not art experts and making the right choice is difficult: it's all a bit of a wing and a prayer."
Before a decision can be made, the Australian courts must settle a dispute over the ownership of several paintings. Both Mr. Bond's wife, Eileen, and his son, John, are claiming several of the artworks. "We're hoping this matter will be settled by the end of the month," Mr. Iceton said. "Then we'll arrange for the art to be sold as soon as possible."
The fact that Mr. Bond did a lot of business through Sotheby's will not have a bearing on the decision, Mr. Iceton said. "Mr. Bond's preferences have nothing to do with us," he said. "We're just trying to raise as much money as possible."
Both Christie's and Sotheby's admit they've thrown their hats in the ring. "We have been in discussion with the agents acting for Alan Bond's creditors," said a Christie's spokeswoman, who refused to go into any of the details. At Sotheby's, Diana D. Brooks, president and chief executive officer of the auction house in North and South America, said that it, too, had submitted a proposal to Mr. Bond's creditors. "It's a fantastic collection," Mrs. Brooks said, "the best group of Australian pictures in private hands."
 
Old Masters on the Block
 Sotheby's announced one major victory this week: the collection of Old Master paintings, European silver and French furniture belonging to Jaime Ortiz-Patino, grandson of Simon I. Patino, the 19th-century Bolivian mine magnate known as the "Tin King." That the collection went to Sotheby's was no surprise. Mr. Ortiz-Patino and several members of his family have sold collections through the auction house many times before.
Three years ago, Sotheby's sold Mr. Ortiz-Patino's eight Impressionist and Post-Impressionist works for $67 million. The sale included Gauguin's "Mata Mua" ("In Olden Times"), which set a record for the artist when it was bought for $24.2 million by Baron Hans Heinrich Thyssen-Bornemisza. In 1986, Sotheby's was the seller of an extensive collection of French furniture that belonged to Mr. Ortiz-Patino's uncle, Antenor Patino. Three years later, Sotheby's also sold a collection of jewelry belonging to Mr. Ortiz-Patino's aunt, Luz Mila Patino. The auction fetched $31.2 million, making it a record for any jewelry sale in the United States.
The latest Ortiz-Patino offerings will go on the block May 21 and 22. They include eight paintings by Francesco Guardi, a group of Old Master drawings, an extraordinary collection of French silver commissioned by Catherine the Great for her lover Count Gregory Orloff and 17th-century English chinoiserie silver, as well as a collection of French furniture and decorative objects.
Mrs. Brooks said Mr. Ortiz-Patino had decided to sell these works because he had recently been appointed an adviser in Europe for the Bolivian Government and was moving from a large house in Geneva to considerably smaller quarters in London.
 
A Chicagoan's Collection
 One collection the auction houses have missed out on, at least for now, is the contemporary art, tribal art, ancient art and American Indian baskets from the estate of Claire Zeisler, a Chicago collector and fiber artist who died in October. Ms. Zeisler was at one time married to Harold Florsheim, an heir to the shoe company. Her son, Tom Florsheim, decided to appoint Richard Gray, a Chicago art dealer, as agent in charge of selling the collection. "That doesn't mean we won't use the auction houses," Mr. Florsheim said in a recent telephone interview. "Right now no decisions have been made."
Meanwhile, both Sotheby's and Christie's have approached Mr. Florsheim and Mr. Gray in the hopes that at least a few works will find their way to the auction block. Some experts say they believe, however, that the works will be sold privately because Mr. Florsheim isn't willing to risk selling in a venue as public as an auction, fearing that in these precarious times, if a piece doesn't sell, it will be considered undesirable.
Highlights of the collection include a 1910 Cubist Picasso, "Woman Sewing," as well as two early Picasso paintings, a 1925 Paul Klee painting called "Village in the Autumn Sun," two paintings by Max Ernst, two works on paper by Joan Miro and a rare 1932 Henry Moore sculpture.
 
French Art Tax (Cont'd.)
 The French Government has changed its mind. Again. For the second time in less than six months. The story of a Value Added Tax, or V.A.T., imposed last July on works of art, furniture, tapestries and silver continues to run its explosive and complicated course. The latest news: the Government has reduced the tax from 18.6 percent to 5.5 percent on the purchase and importation of paintings, prints and sculpture. The 18.6 percent tax on antique furniture, tapestries and silver remains. And artists must still pay a 5.5 percent tax on their earnings, that is, at least for now.
This is not the first time over the last six months that the Government has changed its mind. On Oct. 2, the eve of the F.I.A.C. (Foire Internationale d'Art Contemporain) in Paris, it reduced the V.A.T. on works by living artists from 18.6 percent to 7.5 percent (it's now down to 5.5 percent for all works of art). The change was an effort to stimulate business, which had been substantially hurt by the imposition of the tax.
The latest reduction, which went into effect the first of the year, was the result of fierce lobbying by art dealers and auctioneers who contended that the hefty tax coupled with the worldwide economic recession had been a disaster for business and a great blow to Paris as a major international art market. "We worked very hard to get the change implemented," said Guy Loudmer, the French auctioneer. "Doing business these past few months has been impossible. Sales dropped 50 percent."
"It's a very complicated issue," said Benoit d'Aboville, the Consul General of France. "And for a while there will be differences of interpretation." Under the French tax code, Mr. d'Aboville said, buyers who purchase goods through galleries will have to pay the tax based on the full value of the work. Art dealers will be obligated to pay the tax based on their profit margin. For those who buy at auction, both dealers and private buyers will have to pay the tax based on the full purchase price.
While the French auctioneers are happy with the latest change, some gallery owners say the tax reduction will not affect business. "We just changed our prices to account for the sales tax," said Yo-Yo Maeght, director in charge of contemporary art for the Paris-based Galerie Maeght. "But in some cases it was impossible. For example, I lost more than 10,000 francs on a sale to a Swiss collector who had seen a Giacometti lithograph in the gallery in June and came back to buy it after the tax had changed. Obviously, I was not able to raise the price."
But even these new tax changes are only temporary. Because of the economic unification process under way in Europe, the V.A.T rates will change again by Jan. 1, 1993, making them the same for all European countries.
