LENGTH: 770 words

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
What About the Other $386 Million?

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY

 BODY:
Whenever people say, "Isn't it awful how much money the athletes make?" my standard answer is, "I'd rather see Don Mattingly have the money than George Steinbrenner." The ball players, after all, can throw and run and hit a curveball, and do many other socially redeeming acts. The owners, on the other hand, merely own.
Pardon my class identification -- my parents were union members when it was dangerous -- but I've always believed in sharing the wealth. Whenever I see an athlete signing for $3 million a year, I figure some of the owner's money is going to trickle down to the player's relatives and friends, balancing things out a little. 
 At this point during the recession, baseball teams are making $14 million per team per year on a contract with CBS and ESPN. I have been operating under the assumption that the owners were keeping some of that money for themselves. In fact, I have never seen a poor owner.
So I am not totally astounded to hear that our old friend, the Man from Tampa, has finagled the Yankees' $486 million cable-television contract in order to make some money for himself and his partners. Why else is he in the baseball business?
The way I understand it, George Steinbrenner borrowed $100 million against his cable contract, and distributed the money among the 17 partners. Since Steinbrenner owns 55 percent of the Yankees, he got to keep 55 percent of the payout. It may be shortsighted and it may be selfish, but it sounds legal to me, as long as the partners pay back the loan.
There are, of course, just a few teeny-weeny ethical questions about what Steinbrenner does with his money. Like most sports franchises, the Yankees have been known to mooch for tax breaks, because of this wonderful thing they are doing for the city, providing hope and joy and identification for the masses, and a few jobs for vendors and ushers and athletes.
Presumably, the next time the Man from Tampa puts the arm on New York for increased police surveillance or glitzy new arc lights on public streets, somebody from the city will bring up the $100 million payout. Nevertheless, I am not being facetious when I maintain that the owners had the right to make some dividends, or profits, or booty or swag, or whatever they want to call it.
The problem with the Yankees is not that Steinbrenner is a capitalist. The problem is that he is a bad capitalist. He had a good idea nearly 20 years ago, which was spending money on free agents, but then the rest of baseball caught up with him. While other organizations were building modern computerized chains of command, Steinbrenner was presiding over the downfall of his family business, American Ship Building, and shouting "Off with his head" into a long-distance phone.
Even with the $100 million going to the ownership, there should have been money available for stable management of the Yankees. But this unctuous scamp was paying more attention to buying dirt on Dave Winfield from a gambler named Howie Spira than he was to running his ball club. Basically, the man earned himself a lifetime absence from baseball for having a bad scale of values.
But Steinbrenner is not that much more of a wrongo than a lot of other allegedly smart owners. No sooner had Crazy Neal (His Prices Are In-Sane) Pilson produced that $1.46 billion television contract through 1993 than the owners began tossing huge new salaries to ballplayers both skilled and inept.
This revelation of the $100 million payout should only pacify people in smaller baseball cities who get nervous about the extra cable money available to owners like Steinbrenner. Who says money wins pennants? Maybe the Mets bought a pennant with their cable money, or maybe Eddie Murray and Bret Saberhagen will be old and injured, respectively. Steinbrenner is now blaming the Mets for his recent flurry of spending. The devil made him do it, he says.
This is why Fay Vincent should reinstate Steinbrenner as managing general partner. Pronto. A lifetime ban is too good for the guy. Steinbrenner should be forced to take responsibility for the spending, the personnel decisions, the drift. It's his team. He's making big bucks from it.
Of course, if the network money dries up after 1993, my theory is that some teams are going down in 1994. We've seen airlines and newspapers and banks and department stores disappear. You think the sports teams are immune? If the partners cannot meet the loan, Uriah Micawber Steinbrenner could operate the Yankees from yet another distant site: debtor's prison. The history of the Yankees may yet be written by a modern-day Dickens.

HEADLINE: When the President Talks

 BODY:
President Bush long ago made himself famous for his tin ear in speech. Once, he told reporters that "I hope I stand for anti-bigotry, anti-Semitism, anti-racism," prompting Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York to express relief that the President hadn't gone on to offend Italians, too, by saying he was antipasto. 
 In Idaho during the 1988 campaign, Mr. Bush enthusiastically described his relationship with President Reagan: "For seven and a half years I have worked alongside him, and I am proud to be his partner. We have had triumphs, we have made mistakes, we have had sex."
After a stunned moment, he hastily corrected himself. "We have had setbacks." In New Hampshire that year, rubbing shoulders with truck drivers in a diner, he made aides wince by asking for just "a splash" more coffee.
The public has grown familiar with, even indulgent of Mr. Bush's verbal bumbles, and people chuckled this week when they heard the latest ones, from his first 1992 foray into New Hampshire. For instance, speaking of the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band, he unaccountably referred to the "Nitty Ditty Nitty Gritty Great Bird."
At times, however, the verbal lurches cannot be laughed off so easily; when the President of the United States talks, people listen. They were listening when he also said in New Hampshire, "I've known this economy is in a free fall. Maybe I haven't conveyed it as well as I should have, but I do understand it."
Mr. Bush has found that bumbles on matters of war, peace and diplomacy are costly and has disciplined his tongue. Such reckless exaggeration about economic matters can be costly, too. To describe the current downturn as a free fall borders on the irresponsible. This recession is one of the smallest downturns in 40 years; unemployment, now 7 percent, was higher in six of the ten years between 1975 and 1984.
Mr. Bush's loose words risk adding needlessly to the economic fears of millions. Worse, they might heighten the feverish urge of a jittery, pre-election Congress to overreact, turning a careless fumble into a self-fulfilling prophecy.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: School Reform Should Begin With Society and the Family

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I very much enjoyed reading "Which Students Are Worst at Science?" (Science Times, Dec. 24) and felt many interesting and noteworthy issues were brought up. One issue in particular was that of American society's role in education. 
 I am a senior at Brookline High School, a public school near Boston. When I was 5 or 6 years old, I enrolled in a small private school in my neighborhood, the South End, a mixed urban neighborhood. Although it was a private school it made itself accessible to people of different economic situations and ethnic groups.
I grew up, therefore, around a diverse group of kids. This small school went up only to the sixth grade, and at that point the students had to choose whether they would go on to public schools in Boston, the suburbs or attend private schools. For many it wasn't a choice; there were very few who could afford to send their kids outside the Boston school system.
Eight years later we had a class reunion. All of my former classmates got together and discussed what was going on in their lives. The majority were in the stages of applying to colleges, others were contemplating studying or working abroad.
The point I am trying to make is that we all developed to be "ideal" American teen-agers. We were all completely different: some very poor living in Roxbury, a poor black neighborhood; others fairly wealthy, taking vacations abroad every year. This is not a success story for my old school. The common denominator was that we all came from families -- single- and two-parent homes, adoptive parents -- who cared about education. We, the students of this small school, would not have ended up there if it wasn't for our families. From going to that school we have all come out with a great love, or at least respect, for education.
I believe that although our nation's school systems need reform badly, our society's view and interest in education is what really needs reforming. There is no way the American system can "fix the kids, no matter what is wrong with the family and the community." We should not be aiming for the top test scores to outdo our international competition, but to raise the number of kids who have a great interest in education, who will come out of school with hope for the future, with inspiration to work toward bettering our country. I believe this change needs to come from both the family and society.
 
LILA PLACE
Boston, Jan. 3, 1992

HEADLINE: War of Hams Where the Stage Is All

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH

 BODY:
HAM actors may be a horror, but fine actors playing ham actors are almost always a joy. Brian Bedford, cast as the 19th-century British tragedian William Charles Macready in Richard Nelson's new play, "Two Shakespearean Actors," is no exception. Very grand, often pickled and prone to forgetting the end of any sentence well before he has made it to the verb, Mr. Bedford's puffed-up Macready would be right at home in the hapless theatrical companies of "Nicholas Nickleby," "The Dresser" and "Noises Off." Even his version of the actor's nightmare is egomaniacal: when Macready dreams this dream, he does not forget his lines but instead plays all the parts at once.
 Mr. Bedford, a British actor who has been a mainstay of Broadway and Stratford, Ontario, over a 30-odd-year stage career, pours a lifetime of both classical and boulevard-comedy experience into this role. In Mr. Nelson's play, Macready is a tired, fading figure who arrives to perform "Macbeth" in the New York City of 1849 only to find his supremacy challenged by a younger local upstart, the first great American Shakespearean, Edwin Forrest (Victor Garber),who is performing his own "Macbeth" elsewhere in town. It's an ugly situation. A symbolic target for enraged nationalistic forces beyond his comprehension, Macready suffers the indignity of less-than-full houses, a pelting with stones and, finally, a full-scale Anglophobic riot that leaves more than a score dead outside the Astor Place Opera House. 
Yet in Mr. Nelson's fictionalized retelling of this actual history, and in Mr. Bedford's meticulous performance, Macready never ceases to be human and never becomes the butt of the piece. Though he is always patronizing to his New York hosts (his idea of a compliment is to call Americans "intelligent in an instinctive sort of way"), Mr. Bedford cloaks the snobbery in a rheumy laugh, merry eyes and a glinting smile. For all the outrageousness of Macready's Macbeth -- performed in a kilt with a Lady Macbeth firmly consigned to the upstage shadows -- this babbling ham actor is, finally and all too fleetingly, a tragic figure. When the mob boos and stones him, Mr. Bedford gives a stunned reading of the simple line "They have interrupted my performance!" that conveys the abject terror of another actor's nightmare, an audience's rejection. When the riots break out later, the spent, frightened Macready drifts into a passage from "King Lear" that Mr. Bedford plays for keeps, a fallen giant baring himself to an empty house as "a poor, infirm, weak and despised old man."
 People who love the theater will dote on Mr. Bedford, and they will be nearly as fond of Mr. Garber, who is just as good in a much less juicy role. But even if one does cherish the backstage lore and actors' shoptalk that are the currency of "Two Shakespearean Actors," it's hard to shake the feeling that this evening, often diverting and sometimes more than that when Mr. Bedford is center stage, never lives up to its promise. And a lot is promised. The star turns, the fascinating premise, the huge cast that greets the audience in the play's opening moments and the elegant staging by Jack O'Brien all imply that this production, a Lincoln Center Theater presentation at the Cort Theater on Broadway, will have epic ambitions akin to "M. Butterfly" or "Amadeus," or, perhaps more aptly, to the revisionist cultural-historical fictions of E. L. Doctorow. But Mr. Nelson's writing, as epitomized by the prosaic title, rises only sporadically to the scale of everything else.
 This disappointment is unexpected, because "Two Shakespearean Actors" is poised to pick up where the author's savage previous comedy, "Some Americans Abroad," left off. As in that play about American Anglophiles agog in present-day England, this one trades in Jamesian themes: the cultural clash between the Old World and the New, the declaration of an independent American artistic identity that is at once brave and vulgar, dynamic and insecure. Unfortunately, Mr. Nelson does not expand upon these points this time so much as reduce them to a simplistic, frequently reiterated duel of acting styles. Macready, representing England, stands for textual fidelity and outward sophistication while the rising American, anachronistically portrayed as an incipient Method Actor, stands for raw energy and the obsessive, inward study of subtext.
 Even if this formulation were an accurate picture of the contrast between English and American actors of 1849 -- which it is not -- it still would not be a big enough conflict, or, if you will, metaphor, to explain the bloody Astor Place riots. But no other explanation, real or imagined, is forthcoming in "Two Shakespearean Actors," which consistently whets the audience's curiosity about its subject only to leave it unsatisfied. The political, economic and xenophobic forces that lead to the evening's anticolonial conflagration -- sentiments that have resurfaced, less violently, as recently as the Jonathan Pryce-"Miss Saigon" contretemps -- remain hinted at but unexamined. Eventually the riots are all but forgotten, except as explosive noises off, while Mr. Nelson brings Macready and Forrest together for a sentimental, historically dubious display of noble theatrical fraternity that seems to belong to another play.
Since the personal stories of the title characters, notably Forrest's sad offstage juggling of a wife (Frances Conroy) and mistress (Jennifer Van Dyck), are also sketchily told, "Two Shakespearean Actors" often lacks emotional as well as intellectual bite. Anecdotal in structure, it is almost always at its best when it is dealing simply, parochially and sometimes uproariously with the theater of missed cues, onstage mishaps and offstage egos. The one conspicuous exception is a wildly overlong Act I sequence in which the rehearsals of the Forrest and Macready productions of "Macbeth" are supposedly contrasted but, accents and costumes aside, prove to be more alike than not.
 There and elsewhere, Mr. Garber offers evidence that he can act Shakespeare at the same high level at which he acts everything else. (Having done a mock Otello in "Lend Me a Tenor" and a mock Macbeth here, maybe it's time for him to try the real thing.) His Forrest, a creature of the stage tortured by private demons Mr. Nelson never illuminates, is a commanding matinee idol who can make even self-pity and arrogance charming. In a company full of outstanding actors in cameo roles that never quite pay off, the better assignments, all executed superbly, belong to Zeljko Ivanek as a perennial understudy torn between two companies and countries, Eric Stoltz in a lecherous and opportunistic portrait of the Irish playwright Dion Boucicault and Tom Lacy as a cynical supporting player nearing the farcical end of an unsung career.
 Like Mr. Nelson's play, Mr. O'Brien's production evinces an overwhelming affection for the theater. As bathed in silken simulated gaslight by Jules Fisher, the simple, wood-beamed set by David Jenkins allows the action to swing gracefully from auditorium to backstage to dressing room to tavern; the sense of being taken into a hermetically sealed theatrical world of the Victorian age is completed by the Cort Theater itself, a gilded relic closer in origin and spirit to 1849 than 1992. Though Mr. Nelson is an American writer, "Two Shakespearean Actors" was first produced two years ago with a different cast and director by the Royal Shakespeare Company at Stratford-on-Avon. Rather than risk another riot, I will assume that the English production was far inferior to our own.
 
Two Shakespearean Actors
 By Richard Nelson; directed by Jack O'Brien; sets, David Jenkins; costumes, Jane Greenwood; lighting, Jules Fisher; sound, Jeff Ladman; poster art, James McMullan; original score, Bob James; fight director, Steve Rankin. Presented by Lincoln Center Theater, Gregory Mosher, director; Bernard Gersten, executive producer. At the Cort Theater, 138 West 48th Street.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
DEMOCRATS VYING IN '92 RACE OFFER PAINLESS RECOVERY

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Taking their cue from the successful scripts of Ronald Reagan and George Bush, the Democratic candidates for President this year offer voters mostly painless solutions to the nation's economic problems.
Day after day in their campaigns, the candidates say the economy is the pivotal issue, and they repeat a common theme about ending a recession caused by the Bush Administration and launching a period of sustained economic growth. 
 But except for former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, the Democrats make no suggestion, at least in their public pronouncements, that some bitter medicine might be necessary now to guarantee a healthy economy in the long run.
 
Economists Express Distress
 Their omissions distress many economists who are usually aligned with the Democratic Party, like Ted Van Dyk, who was an associate of Hubert H. Humphrey, and Charles L. Schultze, who was budget director in the Johnson Administration and chairman of President Jimmy Carter's Council of Economic Advisers.
The Presidential candidates rarely mention such unpleasant topics as the budget deficit, poor people, energy wastefulness or urban decay. Instead, they concentrate on tax cuts, universal medical insurance and new public works projects.
Economists generally agree that there is no way to finance such popular measures without increasing the deficit, raising taxes or cutting Social Security and Medicare, but a voter would never know that from listening to the Democratic candidates.
 
A Reagan 'Legacy'
 "This is significantly a legacy of Ronald Reagan," said Robert J. Shapiro, an economist here who is advising Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas. "Reagan taught politicians and their handlers to focus on short-term benefits and that there was never any downside to the promise of a benefit."
Of the five major Democratic candidates, Mr. Tsongas and Mr. Clinton have published detailed statements of economic principles and proposals. They differ on many specifics but basically agree on the philosophy of using tax policy and Government resources to make workers and business more productive.
Senators Tom Harkin of Iowa and Bob Kerrey of Nebraska talk much more in generalities. But they have staked out distinct positions along the ideological spectrum: Mr. Harkin as the apostle of the liberal and labor wing of the party who advocates spending Government money on projects, Mr. Kerrey as a moderate who wants to overhaul the medical care system.
Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California says he is still working on the details of his platform, and he has avoided many of the economic issues that the other candidates discuss.
The other candidates deplore the growing gap between the incomes of the rich and the poor and blame the policies of the Reagan and Bush administrations. All the Democrats say the Government should be more actively engaged than it has been under Mr. Bush in using tax and spending policy to meet social and economic goals. And to one degree or another, all the Democrats advocate some form of economic nationalism, from Mr. Harkin's fist-pounding vow to "get tough on our trade competitors," to Mr. Tsongas's gentle urging of consumers to buy American-made products.
In his literature, Mr. Clinton maintains he is a free trader, but in campaign speeches his views are hardly distinguishable from those who openly favor a more protectionist trade policy. In the candidates' debate on Dec. 15, Mr. Clinton said he would "insist on fair trade," the euphemism used by those who favor trade restrictions, and suggested he would "retaliate" if Japan did not change its trade policies.
Many economists with strong Democratic connections said they were upset by the emphasis on trade restrictions and on the candidates' reluctance to discuss what these economists see as the country's economic difficulty, the enormous budget deficit.
"I'm terribly dismayed," said Mr. Van Dyk, who is now an economic and political consultant. He holds that any responsible Democratic platform would include a reduction in the deficit through a higher gasoline tax and a limit on what rich people could receive under Medicare and other Government programs.
Mr. Schultze, now an economist at the Brookings Institution, scolded the Democratic candidates for not coming to grips with the budget deficit. "You're not going to get out with nice, sugar-coated medicine," he said.
But the politicians remember what happened when Walter F. Mondale proposed a tax increase in 1984 and Michael S. Dukakis talked grimly about the deficit in 1988, while Mr. Reagan and Mr. Bush talked only of keeping taxes low.
Mr. Clinton, Mr. Kerrey and Mr. Brown support a tax reduction for middle class taxpayers, although most economists say that such a cut would do little for the economy.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Kerrey say they would finance tax relief for the middle class primarily through higher taxes on those with incomes of more than about $200,000 a year. Mr. Brown has not said how he would pay for a tax cut.
From different perspectives, Mr. Harkin and Mr. Tsongas oppose an income-tax cut and say the money could be better used elsewhere.
Mr. Harkin calls the few hundred dollars a year that would be yielded by a tax cut "a joke, a symbol," and would prefer to spend the money, as he said in last month's debate, on "roads and bridges and highways, mass transit, communications, energy systems."
Mr. Tsongas has a more downbeat tone and stresses the importance of the deficit and the strain an income-tax cut would place on the budget. But he favors other tax cuts that he says would increase saving and investment, and some of his proposals differ little from Mr. Bush's. For example, Mr. Tsongas would cut the capital gains tax, expand individual retirement accounts with favorable tax treatment and allow a new tax credit for business investments in plants and equipment.
Mr. Tsongas is not the only Democrat who sometimes sounds like Mr. Bush on economic matters. He is joined by Mr. Clinton and Mr. Kerrey in calling for a cut in the capital gains tax, long favored by the Republicans. Unlike Mr. Bush, who would apply the cut to profits from almost all investments, the three Democrats would restrict it to specific investments.
Mr. Harkin, in contrast, says a capital gains tax cut would "just dig the hole deeper" by subsidizing the rich.
 
Using the Government
 But however much some of their policies may sound like the Republicans', the Democratic candidates are distinguishable from Mr. Bush by an important feature. The President basically wants the Government to keep hands off and let the marketplace run the economy. To one degree or another, the Democrats want to use the Government's influence to guide the economy.
Mr. Kerrey and Mr. Tsongas use the phrase "industrial policy" in their speeches. This is a term, anathema to most Republicans, for throwing Government resources behind specific industries and even particular companies to give them a leg up on their international competitors. Mr. Clinton avoids the term but in many ways embraces the doctrine.
Mr. Kerrey and Mr. Clinton espouse a new agency in the Government to channel money into civilian research, modeled after the existing Pentagon research agency that some conservatives have criticized for violating free-market principles.
Mr. Harkin also talks about investment, but it is primarily Government investment he wants. He proposes public works projects like the New Deal efforts of the 1930's that he says would put millions of Americans to work.
All the candidates would finance at least some of their proposals with military budget reductions. But none have toted up the cost of their programs or said exactly where the Pentagon would be cut.
Mr. Clinton has an additional idea. He would divide the budget into investment spending and consumption spending. Each year, the consumption budget could rise no faster than the rate of increase in personal incomes.

International 2-5
 
OFFICERS GATHER IN KREMLIN
Fuming over hostile civilians and loyalty oaths, about 5,000 officers of the former Soviet military met at the Kremlin to demand that the armed forces remain intact and that soldiers not be abandoned. But the officers were quick to reject any hint of nostalgia for the Communists. 1 

EXECUTIVE FREED IN RUSSIA
The F.B.I. and Russian security police teamed this week to crack a $1.6 million kidnapping-and-ransom scheme that threatened the lives of two foreigners in Moscow. An Australian computer executive and his wife were freed and 10 Russians were charged with extortion. 1
 
PRICE RIOT IN UZBEKISTAN
Angered by soaring prices, students in the Central Asian city of Tashkent smashed windows and battled police officers, officials in the former Soviet republic of Uzbekistan said. Two students were reported killed. 4
 
BOMB KILLS 7 IN ULSTER
A big bomb hidden in a roadside culvert blew apart a van carrying construction workers home in a rural area of Northern Ireland, killing seven men instantly and wounding seven others. The I.R.A. claimed responsibility. 3
 
COMEBACK FOR A GREEK LEADER
Minutes after his acquittal on corruption charges, it became clear that former Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou of Greece is hoping to return to government. The 72-year-old Socialist demanded that elections be held immediately. 3
 
FAREWELL TO 2 ARMY DIVISIONS
As flags came down and a band played, the Third Armored and Eighth Infantry divisions marked their last day in Germany, disbanding their watch on what used to be the fault line between the free West and the Communist East. 3
 
SHAMIR COURTS ISRAELI CENTRISTS
With Israel's governing coalition on the verge of falling apart, Prime Minister Shamir seems to be preparing for imminent parliamentary elections by casting himself as the nation's best peace candidate. 5
 
NEW ERA IN CENTRAL AMERICA
From the signing of a Salvadoran peace accord to a chat between the Cuban Foreign Minister and the American Secretary of State, the world is witnessing scenes that were barely imaginable when Central America was aflame with violence a decade ago. The Bush Administration takes some credit. 5
 
In Algerian mosques, fundamentalist leaders counsel patience. 5

Taking their cue from the successful scripts of Presidents Reagan and Bush, the Democratic candidates are offering mostly painless solutions to the nation's economic problems. Their almost total lack of any pronouncement that bitter medicine may be necessary has dismayed many economists aligned with the Democratic Party. 1

BUSH SALUTES DR. KING
The President visited Dr. King's Atlanta gravesite, locked arms with his widow and sang "We Shall Overcome." But on a trip clearly aimed at smoothing the edges of Mr. Bush's image over the race issue, he continued to be criticized over it.1
 
The difference between Presidential and campaign trips: who pays. 7
 
THE BREAST-IMPLANT DEBATE
It is now clear that in the long medical history of silicone, there were many warning signs of danger, some of which were acted on, some of which may have been wrongly overlooked. 1
 
WHO ARE THOSE GUYS?
In his State of the State Message last week, did the Governor of California fabricate his accounts of three brave people struggling against the recession? Even his press office does not seem to be sure. 6

HEADLINE: A Fugitive, the Police and the Media

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., Jan. 17

 BODY:
Real life seemed to have turned into a bad movie here today as this quiet community was ruffled by an intensive manhunt for a transvestite convicted killer and escaped convict who slipped away on Thursday from the F.B.I. as a fellow escapee was captured.
All Thursday night and today, hundreds of officers -- followed by teams of reporters -- crossed and recrossed this area of Rockland County, knocking on the doors of frightened residents and shopkeepers. They were looking for Frank Vandever, 37 years old, who terrified residents of Somers, Conn., by escaping from a maximum-security prison there on New Year's Eve. 
 "I'm scared, frightened," said Mary Jersey, as she showed a team of officers around the barns behind her house on Pascack Road. All night, she said, she saw the flashlights of search teams off in the woods behind the barns. "I've been here 18 years and we've never had action like this."
The search sometimes created a carnival atmosphere, with reporters dodging traffic on busy Route 59 to keep up with police teams checking on reported sightings.
Speculation here centered on whether Mr. Vandever, who had dressed in women's clothes in the past, might have eluded the block-by-block search by dressing as a woman. But Don Clark, an assistant F.B.I. special agent in charge of the multi-agency investigation here, said that Mr. Vandever was dressed in men's pants and a waist-length jacket. "I don't think he ran away in high-heeled shoes," he said.
About 3 P.M., Sheriff James Kralik of Rockland County said, a cabdriver picked up a man at the Spring Valley Transportation Center, a bus and taxi station, who officials said was probably Mr. Vandever. He bolted from the cab near a Buick dealership on Route 59, and the search then focused on that area.
Late today, the police in Orangetown notified the authorities heading up the investigation that a man wearing heavy makeup had used a fake bomb to steal $10,000 from a drive-up teller at a Marine Midland Bank in the neighboring village of Nyack. Orangetown officials raised the possibility that the thief might have been Mr. Vandever, but Officer Charles Kozler of Rockland County said that the authorities had yet to link him to the crime.
The manhunt, including roadblocks on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway and the Palisades Parkway that caused long delays, began about 3:15 Thursday afternoon when Mr. Vandever pulled up to the Econolodge on Route 59, where the authorities said he had been staying for about 10 days.
Mr. Vandever, a former stockbroker who was serving a 40-year sentence for killing a client he had robbed, was accompanied by Ronald Rutan, who was serving a 19-year sentence for burglary when the two escaped from the Connecticut prison. In Connecticut the two tied up a husband and wife cleaning team in an office and stole their truck.
On Thursday, the F.B.I. office in Hartford received a telephone tip from a Connecticut woman who said that the two men were staying at the Econolodge here. Officials said she had seen a televised story on the two on the syndicated television show "Hard Copy." F.B.I. agents went to the motel just off the Thruway and saw the two men as they pulled up in the stolen truck and headed toward their room.
Mr. Clark, the F.B.I. special agent, said the agents spotted the two "before we were able to set up the way we wanted to." The agents, he said, identified themselves and the two ran in different directions. Mr. Clark said he would not answer questions about why the agents did not wait for back-up agents before confronting the men. Mr. Rutan was arrested several hundred feet away. Mr. Vandever vaulted over a fence and ran off.
F.B.I. agents and officers of New York, Connecticut and local police forces combed the woods with dogs. They warned residents to stay inside and not to pick up hitchhikers. They said they presumed that Mr. Vandever was armed and dangerous.
They searched cars at the toll plazas on the Tappan Zee Bridge, causing delays as long as three hours and infuriating drivers.
Harold Rannestad, a systems analyst from Bridgewater, Conn., whose trip home Thursday night was delayed two and a half hours, criticized the authorities for shutting down all but three toll booths.
"A lot of the cars were running out of gas," he said. "It was a dangerous condition, and I think it was poor judgment on the part of the police."
About 7 P.M. today, the search appeared to be growing less intense as the police stopped searching cars and traffic returned to normal.
This was not Mr. Vandever's first trip to Rockland County. In 1988, while he was being sought for the murder of Ronald Hiri, his former client, he was arrested in the nearby town of Orangeburg.
At the Econolodge here today, the desk clerk said Mr. Vandever had registered as Bill Weston of Causian Street in Sensor, Me., and said he was working for A. B. Capital Inc.
Officials said Mr. Vandever is a white man, five feet nine inches tall with hazel eyes and light brown hair.
The clerk, who said she would only give her first name, Roseanne, because she was afraid of Mr. Vandever, said he had been a charming guest who paid in cash and talked about wanting to move to the area. "It's scary," she said, "because he was such a gentleman. You can be taken in by him."

HEADLINE: A Pre-Election Israel: Focus on Talks With Arabs

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Jan. 17

 BODY:
With his governing coalition about to implode, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir seems to be preparing for imminent parliamentary elections by casting himself as Israel's best peace candidate, one flexible enough to talk with the Arabs but sturdy enough to protect vital national interests.
Not that Mr. Shamir has suddenly become a born-again dove. His position, restated more times than an electronic calculator can register, is that if peace means giving back even one square inch of Israeli-held territories to the Palestinians and Arab countries, forget it. 
 But talking peace is fine, he says. So is discussing some form of self-rule for Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, as long as it stops there and does not lead to an independent Palestinian state.
"My will," he said today as he discussed the likelihood of early elections this spring, "is to continue the peace process."
 
A Message to U.S.
 That remark was intended to send a message in two directions -- first, to the broad Israeli political center that approves of negotiations with the Arabs; second, to President Bush, from whom he still wants to get $10 billion in loan guarantees to help cope with a tide of Jewish immigration from the former Soviet Union. The last thing that Mr. Shamir wants to do at this dollar-crucial point is to give the President the impression that he sees the election campaign as a convenient way to dodge the peace talks.
The assumption that the Prime Minister would not weep if the peace negotiations collapsed is nurtured by a widely held view here that Israel would not be sitting at the bargaining table were it not for regular shoves in that direction by the United States.
Certainly, that is the argument offered by the political opposition. "We don't believe this Government is serious in the peace process," said Chaim Ramon, a member of Parliament and a rising star of the Labor Party. "Mr. Shamir is trying to pretend that he is interested."
Not so, aides to the Prime Minister say, insisting that he means business.
If so, he in a sense may be in a stronger position than ever to achieve a breakthrough with the Arabs, now that two far-right parties are poised to walk out of his coalition on Sunday because Israel's delegation in Washington this week uttered what they consider dirty words: Palestinian autonomy.
 
Shamir May Stay On
 Their departure will leave the Prime Minister two votes short of a majority in Parliament, and that means his Government is mortally wounded. But depending on the political machinations that ensue, and they are complicated in Israel's fractured democracy, Mr. Shamir might be able to soldier on as a caretaker for several more months.
Should that happen, he would theoretically be liberated to strike a quick deal with the Palestinians, because he would no longer have to cater to the no-concessions, not-now, not-ever orthodoxy of the far right. Few here would bet the family fortune on a fast settlement -- for one thing, the Government might wind up with an uprising by militant Israeli settlers on its hands -- but technically it is possible.
Moreover, some Israeli politicians argue that the Palestinians may recognize that it is in their self-interest to keep on talking even with a lame-duck Israeli leader, for they have few alternatives. They entered the process weak, they are divided among themselves, and the passage of time without tangible progress is unlikely to improve their situation.
While it is not clear what the next few months will bring, Mr. Shamir said today that it is "almost certain" that elections will be held before the present November deadline. May and June are the most frequently mentioned months, meaning that the campaign would have to begin by March at the latest.
Public-opinion polls suggest that Mr. Shamir's Likud Party has gained strength thanks to a rightward drift among voters and that the Labor Party is in serious need of resuscitation.
 
Memories of Scud Missiles
 It was a year ago that Iraqi Scud missiles started to fall on Israel, and lingering images of Palestinians dancing on rooftops and cheering Saddam Hussein have not been a boon for Israeli liberals and left-wingers. The same holds true for the recent wave of sniper attacks in the territories that have killed four Israelis and wounded many others.
Apparently sensing a winning issue, Mr. Shamir set the possible tone for the campaign by virtually labeling those on the left as traitors, declaring at a Likud conference last month that they were starting to "resemble our enemies, the leaders and murderers of Arab terrorism." Each Arab bullet may serve to reinforce his political position.
It may take weeks for the political situation to sort itself out, and besides, the stumbling Israeli economy and other domestic issues may be what will really get voter juices flowing, as they do anywhere else.
In the meantime, large questions loom.
 
Issue of U.S. Guarantees
 Perhaps the biggest is which way will the Russians and other new immigrants turn. There are an estimated 300,000 eligible voters among them, all unfamiliar with democratic ways. Except for a generally shared opinion that they will not support the religious parties, it is anyone's guess what they will do.
The United States is another important question mark, especially on the matter of loan guarantees.
Israel calls it humanitarian assistance. But if Washington comes through for Mr. Shamir in the midst of a campaign, he could cite it as proof of his political mastery in managing to talk peace but yield no land, to continue building settlements that the Americans hate and to get their help anyway. Would the Bush Administration be ready to bolster him like that?
On the other hand, if it withholds the aid, it could be accused of entering the campaign on Labor's side, for no doubt the opposition would waste no time declaring that Likud cannot deliver the goods after all.
And that says nothing about the prospects for ultimate Middle East peace if Israel goes through months of internal churning only to wind up with a political lineup that is not much different than now. How, some Israelis ask, will there ever be an autonomy agreement if ultimately Mr. Shamir must try to form a coalition by turning to the same right-wing partners who are now leaving him?

HEADLINE: U.S. LATIN POLICY YIELDS SOME GAINS

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 17

 BODY:
As the Government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro was preparing for today's first visit to Nicaragua by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, the Sandinista leader and former President, was clamoring for a meeting with Mr. Baker in Mexico before his arrival here.
Mr. Ortega's request was denied, and he had to content himself with seeking out the Secretary of State at an official lunch in Mexico City on Thursday. However, Mr. Baker was drawn into conversation not with Mr. Ortega, the Secretary of State told reporters later, but with the Cuban Foreign Minister, Isidoro Malmierca, who was at his table. 
 On Thursday night, when Mr. Baker arrived in San Salvador after witnessing the signing in Mexico of a peace accord to end the 12-year civil war, Marxist guerrillas with rock bands and red flags were holding a joyful rally in a city center plaza while President Alfredo Cristiani and his right-wing backers were celebrating in another square nearby.
Both scenes, barely imaginable a decade ago when Central America was aflame with ideological passion and violence, are illustrative of what Bush Administration officials regard as one of their most successful foreign policy initiatives: to bring peace, disarmament and economic development to this tormented region.
 
Collaspse of Soviet Union
 The strategy was immeasurably assisted by the collapse of the Soviet Union. But Bush Administration policy, low-keyed and methodical, has played an important role. First there was the virtual abandonment of the Nicaraguan contras, so championed by Ronald Reagan, followed by a diplomatic push for internationally monitored elections. Then came strong Administration pressure on the Salvadoran Government to accelerate negotiations to end the war and open the political process. Guatemala is next on the screen.
"The time has come to negotiate an end to Guatemala's 30-year-old insurgency," Mr. Baker told the Salvadoran National Assembly today. "When it ends, and it will end, we will be able to look across Central America for the first time in its history and see the promise of Esquipulas fulfilled: every nation living peacefully under a government freely chosen by its people."
Esquipulas is the Guatemalan town where in August 1987 five Central American presidents signed an accord calling for the cessation of regional conflicts, the strengthening of democratic institutions and the return of refugees and others displaced by conflicts. In mentioning Esquipulas, Mr. Baker acknowledged the importance of allowing regional leaders and organizations to take the lead. Keeping the United States in a supporting role lessens the chance of provoking traditional animosities born of Latin fears of United States dominance and interference.
 
Pressing Need for U.S. Aid
 There is also an important practical side to this. Administration officials recognize that the Salvadorans need assistance in rebuilding their country. But with foreign aid a pariah topic in an election year and the former Soviet republics already making large demands for assistance, the United States does not want to be in the position of having to refuse to pay the entire $1.8 billion estimated cost of the reconstruction of El Salvador.
Nicaragua has received about $535 million in American aid and has had $284 million in debts to Washington written off in the 20 months since the Chamorro Government came to power. An Administration official said this makes Nicaragua one of the highest per capita recipients of United States assistance.
But there were no pledges of new help made by Mr. Baker to the Central Americans. Indeed, Administration officials described this trip as in part a mission to assess the needs of the Central American nations and to begin to look for partners to help pay for regional development programs.
Among the groups that Mr. Baker hopes will contribute are wealthier Latin American nations and Canada, but the European Community is also being approached. A diplomat with years of experience in Latin America suggested that the longstanding concept of "spheres of infuence" has been substantially tempered by the Bush Administration's desire to "multilateralize" policies.
 
Role of Free Trade
 Greater regional problem-sharing is also fostered by the realization in the United States and throughout the hemisphere, where most nations now have democratic governments, that European and Asian trading blocs can be best tackled by a large free-trade area in this part of the world.
In his speech today, Mr. Baker spoke of a community of nations "whose citizens freely trade across borders from Alaska to Argentina." But many Latin Americans are convinced that movement in this direction can only be set back in an American election where a troubled economy is the main issue and voters may perceive trade agreements as foreign giveaways.
In Central America, the Administration has also encouraged a greater role for the United Nations, which is sending more than 1,000 peacekeepers to El Salvador to monitor a cease-fire due to start on Feb. 1. Secretary General Boutros Ghali presided over the signing of the Salvadoran peace accord in Mexico City on Thursday.

HEADLINE: I.B.M. Loss In Quarter And Year

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
Closing the books on its most difficult year in decades, I.B.M. said yesterday that it lost $1.38 billion in the fourth quarter, resulting in its first yearly deficit ever. In addition, revenues were off 6.1 percent for the year, the first time in 45 years that growth has faltered at the world's largest computer maker.
Calling the year disappointing, the company blamed a declining world economy, increased competition and the difficulties associated with introducing new product lines. 
 But a number of industry executives say the decline represents a more fundamental shift away from the centralized style of computing that since the 1950's has been the basis of the International Business Machines Corporation's business.
 
$3.4 Billion Charge
 For the quarter ending Dec. 31, usually the company's strongest, I.B.M. said revenue declined 4.2 percent, to $22.08 billion from $23.06 billion a year earlier. The loss in the period included a $3.4 billion charge as part of a sweeping decentralization and planned job cutback. By contrast, for the 1990 period I.B.M. earned $2.46 billion, or $4.30 a share. It put the cost of the restructuring at about $4.68 a share.
For the year, I.B.M. lost $2.83 billion on sales of $64.79 billion, compared with a 1990 profit of $6.02 billion on a record $69.02 billion in revenues. The results for the year included a one-time charge of $2.26 billion to cover an accounting change for retirement benefits.
After seesawing all day, I.B.M. shares ended the day on the New York Stock Exchange with a gain of 87.5 cents at $96.375.
 
Slipping in Many Areas
 "I think it's a terrible spending environment," said Stephen Cohen, an analyst at the Soundview Financial Group. "Beyond that, I think that I.B.M. is losing share in a lot of product areas, some of which they acknowledge and some of which they are not acknowledging."
Based on a trend variously referred to as "downsizing" or "network computing," corporate computer buyers have begun in recent years to move away from the multimillion-dollar mainframe systems that account for the bulk of I.B.M.'s earnings. Instead, they are buying smaller microprocessor-based systems and linking them to personal computers and work stations.
According to Computer Intelligence/Infocorp estimates, the number of I.B.M. mainframe shipments in the United States declined to 4,468 in 1991, from 6,181 in 1990. Computer Intelligence also estimates that the number of installed mainframes in the United States also declined to 24,448 in July 1991, from 25,636 in January 1990.
Yet other analysts discounted the effect of the mainframe decline. Robert Djurdjevic, an industry consultant who is president of Annex Research in Phoenix, said I.B.M.'s mainframe decline during 1991 was largely a result of the transition from one generation of systems to another. He said 1992 should see much stronger mainframe sales if the economy picks up.
Nevertheless, all sides agree that the trend away from mainframes is now reshaping the industry. On Thursday, the world's second-largest computer maker, the Digital Equipment Corporation, reported a $138 million loss for the quarter and said the company saw no early recovery. In contrast, Apple Computer Inc. said its revenues grew 10.7 percent, to $1.86 billion, for the quarter. Sun Microsystems, which is the largest producer of work stations and which will report its earnings next week, is also expected to have a strong quarter.
A number of Wall Street analysts said that despite the gloomy end-of-the-year report, I.B.M.'s efforts to control costs and restart growth would show results in 1992.
 
'In the Right Direction'
 "The momentum is beginning to move in the right direction," said Steven Milunovich, an industry analyst with Salomon Brothers. "The problem is we don't know how much better it will be this year. They will clearly need some economic help."
Last month the company told Wall Street that its special charge would be about $3 billion, but yesterday the actual figure came out $400 million higher. Analysts said that figure was a small surprise and that it suggested the company was moving rapidly on its employment cutbacks. Last year about 29,000 I.B.M. employees left the company.
Although I.B.M.'s stock has moved up strongly in recent days on rumors that the company's year-end report would be more positive than expected, it swung wildly yesterday after the company reported its results. Immediately after the announcement early in the morning the stock fell almost as low as 92, but swung back as high as 98 around noon after the company held a conference call with Wall Street analysts.
 
An Inventory Write-Off
 In the call the company said it had an inventory write-off that accounted for about 25 cents a share in earnings, which would be equal to $200 million to $250 million. This caused some analysts to revise their estimates upward and contend that the company had performed closer to expectations. However, other analysts said the company's tax rate had been lower than expected, tending to negate the effect of the inventory write-off.
In December, I.B.M. executives announced the company was radically rethinking its business to try to meet sweeping changes in the computer business. The company decentralized its management, freeing its various businesses to compete more aggressively and put in place a structure that will make it possible to sell portions of its business in the future. The company, which is based in Armonk, N.Y., also said it planned to reduce its work force by as many as 20,000 workers next year to try to contain costs.
 
'More Competitive' Now
 "We are moving into 1992 a tougher, smarter and more competitive business," said John F. Akers, I.B.M.'s chairman. "Assuming some improvement in the current difficult and uncertain economic environment, we expect to increase revenue and improve cash flow and returns as the year goes on."
Despite a precipitous 15.6 percent decline in hardware revenue in 1991 to $37.1 billion, I.B.M. saw improvements of 5.8 percent in software, 3 percent in maintenance, 35.3 percent in services and 10.4 percent in its rental and financing business.
The company also reported that during 1990 revenue from its non-United States operations fell. Revenue from foreign operations in 1991 was $40.4 billion, a decline of 3.6 percent from $41.9 billion in 1990. Foreign earnings were $1.8 billion in 1991, compared with $4.6 billion in 1990.

HEADLINE: Massachusetts Governor Seeks Tax Cuts

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
At a time when other governors are being forced by soaring deficits to make unpopular tax increases, Governor William F. Weld introduced a package of tax cut proposals today that would reduce personal and business taxes as part of an effort to reinvigorate the Massachusetts economy.
Mr. Weld's proposals include lowering the personal income tax rate, cutting the capital gains levy and offering a series of investment credits to businesses that hire new employees, expand their plants or offer job training and child care. 
 "The time has come to help jolt our economy into recovery through further tax cuts," Governor Weld, a Republican, said in his State of the State speech Thursday evening, when he first outlined his plan. Massachusetts has lost more than 11 percent of its jobs since the recession began here three years ago, one of the worst declines for any state since the Depression in the 1930's.
Mr. Weld's program was immediately praised by some business leaders. But some economists criticized it, questioning how he could afford to make the tax cuts and whether they would help the state's deeply troubled economy. Several prominent Democrats also expressed skepticism about whether the state could afford to make the tax cuts without falling back into the pattern of budget deficits that paralyzed Massachusetts for several years before Mr. Weld became Governor last year.
The Democrats control both houses of the Massachusetts Legislature, but it is unclear whether they will vote against a tax-cut plan in an election year.
"This is a very thoughtful plan," said John Gould, president of the Associated Industries of Massachusetts, a trade group that represents businesses. "I believe sincerely that we could narrow the gap by which we trail the national economy if these measures are passed."
But Robert Reich, an economist and lecturer in public policy at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, said Mr. Weld's planned tax cuts "will be of little help" in revitalizing the state's economy. "We're talking about peanuts as far as the individual is concerned," Mr. Reich said.
Mr. Weld's plan calls for reducing the state income tax to 5.75 percent from 5.95 percent, and cutting the capital gains tax to zero for assets held six years. He estimated that his tax cuts would amount to $192 million in the fiscal year that begins on July 1.
 
Criticism on Service Cuts
 Noting that there had been a series of major cuts in state support for education and social services this year to balance the budget, Mr. Reich said, "This is not the time to cut taxes." For the Governor to cut taxes now, Mr. Reich said, Mr. Weld "would have to take a meat cleaver again to social services."
Governor Weld, an avowed libertarian, has frequently proclaimed his intention to shrink state government. In the 1980's, under Governor Michael S. Dukakis, a Democrat, Massachusetts developed one of the most liberal and far-reaching programs of social services, which added to the costs of state government and helped give the state the reputation of "Taxachusetts."
In his State of the State address on Thursday, Mr. Weld said that if his tax-reduction program is passed, "We will all be able to take pride in casting aside once and for all the last vestiges of the old insulting label 'Taxachusetts.' "
But at a news conference today, Mr. Weld declined to spell out what government programs would have to be cut to finance his proposed tax reductions while keeping the budget balanced. "Well, we'll see," he said at one point.
Pressed further, Mr. Weld would only say that he had ordered all his cabinet officers "to be creative about how they could deliver the same services that they have in the past at a 10 or 20 percent cut."
"I think in a way it's a phoney question to say who's going to be hurt," Mr. Weld said. "We can absorb, we can afford these tax cuts. Not only do I not think anybody's going to be hurt, I think a lot of people are going to be helped."
One of Mr. Weld's proposals would require that any future tax increase be passed by a two-thirds vote of both houses of the Legislature.
Richard Manley, the president of the Massachusetts Taxpayers Foundation, a business-sponsored tax watchdog group, said he could not say whether Mr. Weld's proposed measures were practical until the Governor releases his budget for the next fiscal year, beginning on July 1. He is scheduled to do so next week. Only then will it be clear what cuts Mr. Weld intends to propose in government services.
One important element, Mr. Manley said, is how big a deficit the state really faces in the new budget. Until recently, Mr. Weld's own advisers have placed the gap at $1.6 billion out of a budget of $13 billion. But Mr. Weld hinted today that the deficit may not be that large, and some economists say that Mr. Weld has been covering up the fact that tax revenues this year have been higher than expected.
Mr. Manley commended Mr. Weld for passing a balanced budget this year. But he said that many business leaders would be happier if Mr. Weld had just stuck with that accomplishment.
"The business community more than anything else wants predicatability and stability," Mr. Manley said. "This is more important than tax cuts," which could lead to lengthy fights with the Legislature and unsettle the state budget again.

HEADLINE: New Philip Morris Cigarette Emphasizes Less Nicotine

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
In the tobacco industry's latest marketing wrinkle, the Philip Morris Companies, the world's largest cigarette company, introduced a major cigarette brand yesterday with 90 percent less nicotine than standard brands.
Philip Morris's low-nicotine cigarette is an attempt to appeal to smokers who want a seemingly healthier cigarette, but with more taste than other brands making similar claims. The industry's first such innovation, low-tar cigarettes, has now won a majority of sales. 
 Less nicotine would mean less satisfaction of the nicotine craving. The company discounted the possibility that some smokers might simply buy more cigarettes.
The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company's Now brand and the American Tobacco Company's Carlton cigarettes have similarly low levels of nicotine, but emphasize low tar levels. They have rarely, if ever, made reduced nicotine a marketing theme.
Philip Morris plans to market its low-nicotine cigarette to Now and Carlton smokers.
Tar is made up of the particles in smoke that result from tobacco combustion. Nicotine is a nitrogen-based substance found in tobacco that some researchers say is strongly addictive. Unlike nicotine, which is largely flavorless, tar provides much of the distinctive taste of tobacco.
Philip Morris calls its new offering Merit Ultima, an offshoot of its troubled Merit brand. Like other full-price cigarettes, which in some regions of the country sell for $2.50 or more a pack, Merit has been selling poorly compared with discount brands, which sometimes cost as little as half the price.
Some of the most fervent of smokers are blue-collar workers, who have been hit hard by layoffs during the recession.
Merit had a 3.1 percent market share in the nine months ended last Sept. 30, a decline from 3.5 percent during the comparable period the year before, according to figures compiled by John C. Maxwell, Jr., an analyst at Wheat, First Securities Inc. Merit shipments for the period declined to 11.5 billion cigarettes, or more than half a billion packs, compared with 13.3 billion cigarettes, or close to three-quarters of a billion packs, during the 1990 months.
Merit Ultima "kings" contain one-tenth of a milligram of nicotine, compared with 1 milligram in Marlboros, which the industry dubs a "full flavor" brand. Ultima also contains a milligram of tar, compared with 16 milligrams in Marlboro, or 94 percent less. Merit Ultima 100's, a longer version, have twice the tar and nicotine levels of the "kings" brand.
Philip Morris's Marlboros are the world's best-selling cigarette.
 
Changing Focus
 David E. R. Dangoor, the senior vice president-marketing for Philip Morris U.S.A., said yesterday that the company had experimented with a cigarette having an even lower level of nicotine, four-one hundredths of a milligram, called Next De-Nic. The cigarette was designed to compete against discount brands, but Philip Morris decided instead to market with a full-price brand with low nicotine.
"We think we can get smokers who haven't switched to low-tar, low-nicotine cigarettes because they haven't found anything smokable," Mr. Dangoor said.
Carlton and Now use low-nicotine tobacco blends and heavy filtration systems to reduce tar and nicotine. Merit uses what Philip Morris calls a "dual concentric filter," designed to make it easier to inhale the smoke while reducing nicotine.
 
A National Introduction
 Philip Morris, based in New York, is showing extraordinary confidence in the new product by introducing it nationally, rather than regionally. The new cigarette will be available on Feb. 18, backed by advertising devised by Leo Burnett, the advertising agency responsible for Marlboros and previous Merit versions.
The advertising slogans will be: "Introducing flavor at the lowest levels of tar and nicotine" and "Discover a new way to smoke at the lowest levels of tar and nicotine."
Philip Morris appears to be aiming Merit Ultima at men, judging from its advertising emphasis on flavor. At the end of the cigarette, it is using the brownish tipping -- a "cork" in industry parlance -- that is preferred by full-flavor cigarette smokers, usually males.
 
'Will It Work?'
 Analysts were undecided about the low-nicotine innovation yesterday. "Does it make sense? Will it work?" asked Mr. Maxwell of Wheat, First. "I guess we'll find out. Nobody really follows nicotine levels."
Low-tar cigarettes have been a growing portion of cigarette sales since Carlton was introduced in 1964, and now make up the majority of cigarettes sold. About 61.2 percent of cigarettes shipped last year had reduced levels of tar.
Such cigarettes are popular with smokers trying to quit, and, as such, have been a lucrative addition to tobacco companies' product lines.

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Narrows To Smallest in 9 Years

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Plunging demand for imports and a slight increase in exports shrank the nation's trade deficit in November to $3.57 billion, the smallest level in almost nine years, the Commerce Department said today.
October's trade deficit was also revised downward, to $6.32 billion from an initial estimate of $6.73 billion, further impressing economists, who look at the average of a string of monthly trade deficits rather than a single month's total. The deficit in November 1990 was $9.54 billion. 
 The Bush Administration, which emphasized trade issues and particularly car imports during the President's visit last week to Japan, greeted the news as a sign of increased American competitiveness in world markets. But private economists said a 5.5 percent slump in seasonally adjusted imports from October, the biggest such drop in nearly a year, also showed how weak the economy had become as consumers refrained from buying.
 
Economic Slump Stands Out
 "The important thing that comes out of these statistics is the slump in economic activity," said Jeffrey J. Schott, an economist at the Institute for International Economics in Washington.
One of the biggest improvements in the trade deficit came from a decline in imports of cars and car parts, which fell to $7.65 billion, from $8.79 billion in October. The improvement should help President Bush resist Congressional proposals for restrictions on automobile imports, said Robert D. Hormats, a deputy United States trade representative in the Carter Administration who is now the vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International.
But Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., a Michigan Democrat who is sponsoring a bill that would force reductions in Japanese car shipments to the United States if the bilateral deficit did not improve, said the schedule in Congress would not allow it to consider such legislation for another one or two months. The trade deficit may widen again during this period, he said.
The President cannot, however, claim credit for the drop in auto imports, which was evenly divided between imports from Canada and Japan, because it came before he began seeking to narrow the nation's annual $41 billion trade deficit in cars and car parts, Mr. Hormats added. The drop in auto imports mirrored a virtually identical drop in car imports from October to November a year earlier as the recession began to deepen.
Over all, seasonally adjusted imports dropped in November to $41.03 billion from $43.43 billion.
 
Rise in Aircraft Exports
 Exports, meanwhile, rose nearly a percentage point from October to set a record of $37.46 billion in November. But Stephen L. Cooney Jr., the director of international investment and finance at the National Association of Manufacturers, said the gain was not significant because it came in aircraft exports, a notoriously volatile category, in which a single delivery can be worth hundreds of millions of dollars.
The nation's three most controversial trading relationships all improved in November from October. The deficit with Japan narrowed to $3.41 billion from $4.64 billion, mostly because of the fall in car shipments.
The deficit with China slipped to $1.34 billion from $1.65 billion. The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, today signed an agreement reached Thursday evening that committed China to halt the illegal copying there of American pharmaceuticals, books, computer programs and music recordings.
 
Bush Fights for China
 President Bush has been struggling to win Congress's permission for an unconditional renewal of China's most-favored-nation trade status. Administration critics in Congress have focused on China's violations of human rights and ballooning trade surplus with the United States.
The American trade surplus with Mexico widened to $272.8 million in November from $62.3 million in October. The Administration is negotiating with Mexico a free trade agreement that many Democrats oppose because they fear it will result in a large loss of low-skill jobs and scant gains of high-skill jobs.
Continued gains for American manufactured goods in trade with these and other countries gave the United States a trade deficit of only $45.7 million in November, excluding oil. According to Commerce Department figures, it was the best performance for the non-petroleum trade balance since a $53.9 million surplus in June 1983.
 
Indicator of Competitiveness
 Rockwell Schnabel, who is the Acting Commerce Secretary pending Senate confirmation of Barbara H. Franklin, said non-petroleum trade was "a better indicator of our international competitiveness" than the overall trade deficit.
The overall November trade deficit was the smallest since a deficit of $2.84 billion in March 1983.
Several economists said today that recent growth in exports could be threatened if the weeklong rally in the dollar's value resumes and lasts into early spring, which would make American exports more expensive overseas, and if foreign economies continue to weaken, reducing their ability to afford American goods.
If both trends continue, Mr. Hormats said, "We're going to see a weaker share of a smaller market" for internationally traded goods.
 
Fed Intervenes in Markets
 Some Administration officials appear to share that concern, and some currency traders said the Federal Reserve intervened heavily in the market today to help the dollar reverse course.
The dollar had been rising in recent days despite official approval by President Bush and Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa in Tokyo last week for the downward drift in the dollar during late 1991. "The President and Prime Minister reviewed developments in financial markets and agreed that recent exchange rate movements were consistent with current economic developments," the two leaders said in a statement.
But the dollar has only gained back a third of the value it lost against the German mark in the second half of 1991 and an even smaller fraction of its losses against other foreign currencies, thereby retaining its competitive advantage for exporters.
"It would take a rally of historic proportions to have an effect on our exports now," said Mr. Cooney of the National Association of Manufacturers.

HEADLINE: For 2 U.S. Divisions in Germany, Taps

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Two United States Army divisions that landed at Normandy 48 years ago and later defended American interests in the cold war marked their last day in Europe today as they were officially disbanded.
As flags came down, the commander of the Third Armored Division, Maj. Gen. Jerry R. Rutherford, said: "The cold war is over. Our mission is accomplished. It's time to go home." 
 A band played under a chill, cloudy sky, and soldiers and their families stood in silence with American and German officers and diplomats, as cannon roared a 14-gun salute.
The Army Chief of Staff, Gen. Gordon R. Sullivan, deftly wrapped the colors of the Third Armored around a flagstaff lowered by a division standard-bearer. General Rutherford, then tugged a khaki casing over the colors, bringing to an end his troops' watch on what used to be the fault line between the free West and the Communist East.
Robert M. Kimmitt, the American Ambassador to Germany, told the remnant of the division that remained to form the honor guard, "You leave Europe and the people of Europe more peaceful, more prosperous and more stable than they have been in their modern history."
 
Most Go to Other Units
 When the day was over, the Third Armored and Eighth Infantry divisions, once powerful forces in NATO's forward defense, were no more. The Third Armored has been deactivated and most of its soldiers have been ordered to other units, while some have left the Army. The division headquarters, where today's ceremony was held, will probably soon be transformed into an industrial park by the Germans.
At a second ceremony, the Eighth Infantry was also deactivated and its remnants merged with the First Armored Division, which has headquarters in Bad Kreuznach, 40 miles southwest of here.
The troop withdrawals from Germany, where the mainstay of the United States forces in Europe have been stationed since the close of World War II, is part of President Bush's plan to reduce American military strength in Europe to about 150,000 soldiers, sailors and airmen by 1995. More than 300,000 were here at the close of 1989, when the Berlin wall came down.
Military spokesmen said the Army now has about 150,000 soldiers in Europe, down from a peak of 230,000. By 1993, when the reduction is to be completed, 93,000 will remain.
 
Relics of Last War
 At Drake barracks, a former German army encampment that was the Third Armored headquarters, relics of the last war bear testimony to the division's role in Europe. There are carefully kept Sherman tanks and other World War II-vintage armored vehicles of the kind that the unit used when it joined other American, British and Canadian troops at the Normandy landing in 1944.
The division's nickname, Spearhead, derives from its role in leading allied forces across northern France and into Germany, all the way to Dessau on the Elbe River.
Today, a small band of Dutch citizens from the Limburg region traveled by car to the ceremony. Each year, representatives of the Third Armored make a pilgrimage to the Netherlands to lay wreaths at war graves, including that of Maj. Gen. Maurice Rose, the division commander, who was killed in the 1944 fighting.
Deactivated after the war, the division was renewed in 1949 and deployed in Germany in 1956 at the height of the cold war, stringing its forces out along the Fulda Gap, across gentle valleys from the armies of the Warsaw Pact.
 
Thanks From Hesse's Premier
 Opinion polls have always showed a broad majority of Germans thankful for the American presence, and today, the Social Democratic Premier of Hesse state, Hans Eichel, whose party often appeared uncomfortable with American military might, thanked the soldiers profusely for the "decisive role" their presence played in bringing about Germany's reunification.
Among the soldiers who began gathering several hours before the ceremony began was Maj. Randall Scheffler, who fought with the Third Armored in the Persian Gulf last year after serving for five years at the Fulda Gap.
"It's not just changing politics, it's the changing of an era," he said. "Then, it was a question of alertness, of readiness, because you read the intelligence reports, you knew the enemy was right over here, moving up, then back, meaning that at any moment this might be it. Now, you're training for rapid reaction anywhere."
Many of the soldiers face uncertain futures as entire divisions yield to leaner and more mobile NATO forces supported by smaller nuclear arsenals.
 
6,000 Returned to U.S.
 Since the Third Armored returned from the Persian Gulf last summer, 6,000 soldiers and their families have been sent back to the United States, many of them to seek jobs outside the Army in a recession economy.
For German regions losing the troops, the blows will be equally harsh. The Army employs more than 50,000 German civilians, and by the middle of the decade that number will drop to about 33,000. Thousands more thrive indirectly on the army's presence.
"Just go up around Heidelberg or Kaiserslautern, and you'll see how hard it will be," said Hermann Schultz, 72 years old, who has run a handful of fried chicken shops near American bases since the 1960's.
 
A 'Normal' U.S. Presence
 For younger Germans, like Niels Bojunga, a 23-year-old student who commutes to Frankfurt University from a neighborhood laced with American military, the departure is met with indifference.
"For my generation, they became part of the landscape," he said of the Americans, adding, "Until German unification, I believe it was completely normal for them to be here."
Mr. Bojunga said he believed the alliance with America to be "still important, though a military presence is not necessary."
His is not a view shared by Government officials who complained this week to visiting Defense Secretary Dick Cheney that America's withdrawal is moving ahead too quickly, at a time when Bonn is only beginning to reflect on its changing role in a Europe marked by economic crisis to the east, turmoil in Russia, and 180,000 soldiers of the old Soviet Union still stationed in ther former East Germany.
But for some Germans, the American withdrawal is the natural consequence in a Europe from which the onetime adversary, the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact, has disappeared. "The real watershed was the end of the East-West conflict," said Volker Muller-Siebert, a Frankfurt lawyer in his 30's. "This withdrawal is merely a consequence. There is no need for them anymore."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Soldiers of the Third Armored Division carrying the encased division flag yesterday in Frankfurt in a ceremony marking the official withdrawal from Europe of the last two United States Army divisions remaining of those that landed at Normandy 48 years ago. (Reuters)
