HEADLINE: Dinkins's Role In Sanitation Is Faulted

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER

 BODY:
The departing Sanitation Commissioner of New York City is faulting the Dinkins administration for failing to acknowledge the fact that it is running out of ways to get rid of its garbage.
The Commissioner, Steven M. Polan, said that while Mayor David N. Dinkins has offered "tepid" support for new incinerators, he has failed to move forward in building them. The Mayor has also failed to fully support recycling, Mr. Polan said. 
 And Mr. Dinkins is not alone, the Commissioner said.
"Every elected official in this city and state that I have spoken to in the last two years has told me privately that we need to build incinerators here," he said. "But none will say so publicly. If the problem doesn't need to be solved today, in their terms of office, why should they bother? We haven't built a new solid-waste facility in this city in 30 years. The obvious question here is, are these people leaders or followers?"
 
'Ridiculously Naive'
 With its recycling programs floundering, its vast fleet of garbage trucks serviced by a dwindling crew of mechanics and its plans for up to three new incinerators opposed with a steeply rising intensity, Mr. Polan said the city faces problems it may soon be unable to solve.
His comments came during an unusually stark assessment of his tenure at the department and reflected his frustration with the city's failure to address a growing problem.
"The original premise of the recycling program was ridiculously naive," said Mr. Polan, who in April 1990 became head of the department and next month will turn it over to Emily Lloyd, who was appointed on Wednesday. "The underlying premise was that the city would embrace it. That didn't happen. We have not met our goals. Markets have not developed. And right now we are spending money we don't have."
Despite evidence that incineration and recycling have been compatible in many countries, the two approaches to waste disposal have created defiantly separate camps in New York City. Mr. Polan, however, has long argued that the city must broaden both its recycling program and its capacity to burn garbage. In doing so, he has often alienated both sides. But he has been regarded as a highly effective manager, softening the brunt of the large budget cuts his department has endured.
Environmentalists, however, who have often regarded him as well meaning and well spoken, say he has been unable to accomplish the city's goals: a sharp reduction in waste and a huge increase in recycling.
"He tried," said Eric A. Goldstein, a lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council. "But either he or the city weren't able to move as far forward as we need to go." Political gridlock has prevented building new incinerators. Anemic compliance and steady budget cuts have disemboweled the recycling program.
Since he announced his resignation more than a month ago, Mr. Polan has made it clear that he decided to leave out of deep frustration at his inability to convince the Dinkins administration of the need to address either issue more forcefully.
Mr. Polan stopped short of blaming Mayor Dinkins for the seemingly endless impasse on building new incinerators, although he questioned whether the Mayor or any other city official would pay serious attention to a major new solid-waste plan the department will release next month.
 
Volume for the Bookshelf?
 The 20-year plan, which will address the need for as many as three new incinerators -- at a projected cost of at least $1 billion -- and a much more vigorous recycling program, has been under development for more than a year.
"After all this time and effort I think there is a real question whether it will mean a thing," he said. "It may become just another volume for the bookshelf, and the city cannot afford that."
Mr. Polan noted that unlike most elected officials, the Mayor has said publicly that the city would eventually need new incinerators. But the Commissioner said that there would be no solution without more visible leadership, because few neighborhoods ever welcome such unpleasant necessities.
The Mayor's press secretary, Leland T. Jones, said that Mr. Dinkins was studying proposals for an incinerator at the Brooklyn Navy Yard and other locations, but had not made a final decision. Mr. Jones added that Mayor Dinkins was well aware of -- and shared -- Mr. Polan's frustrations about such issues as recycling, street cleaning and the loss of nearly 200 mechanics last year, which jeopardizes proper maintenance of the department's fleet of 4,000 vehicles.
 
Little Choice
 "Recycling has been difficult," Mr. Jones said. "And right now there is genuine concern about how much you can collect and how much you can recycle."
In New York, neither figure has been high -- and it has proven difficult to sell much of what has been recycled at a reasonable profit. Mr. Polan estimated that it now costs $300 to collect and process every ton of recycled waste in the city. By comparison, the expenses of collecting it and dumping it at the Fresh Kills Landfill on Staten Island is less than $200 a ton.
But Fresh Kills, the world's largest dump, will close within the next decade. At the same time, Congress has begun to edge toward permitting states to ban the importation of garbage. When those alternatives disappear, it will leave the city with little choice but to recycle or burn its refuse.
In the 12-month period that will end in April, the city had planned to recycle 2,100 tons of its 17,000 tons of residential trash each day. Sanitation officials concede that the department will be lucky to recycle 1,000 tons, barely 6 percent of the daily total. Commercial recycling, mandated by law as of November, has also struggled to prove economically viable.
Major recycling efforts in the city began only after the City Council required it in 1989. The law established gradually expanding goals -- 25 percent recycling by 1994 -- that now seem impossible.
"The situation here is very bleak," Mr. Goldstein of the Natural Resources Defense Council said. "But it is going to get much worse. Nobody is willing to break the logjam. There has been a revolution in handling trash in this society and in New York nobody wants to acknowledge it or invest in the future."
Mr. Polan agrees, up to a point.
"The program will have to be expanded to succeed," he said of recycling. "But it may be possible even with the best of efforts that the type of recycling this city envisioned won't work here. We have to begin to look at what makes sense and not just what we would like to see."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Republicans;
PRESIDENT JOINS KING OBSERVANCE

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 17

 BODY:
President Bush came to the resting place of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. today, locked arms with his widow and sang "We Shall Overcome" in a trip clearly aimed at smoothing the edges of the Presidential image on race.
But before Mr. Bush left the stage of the Martin Luther King Jr. Center for Nonviolent Social Change, he heard an angry benediction from one of Dr. King's daughters, the Rev. Bernice King. In her prayer, she said the problems of racism, poverty and violence that her father had fought against remained a blight on the land, although she did not link their persistence directly to Mr. Bush. 
 "How dare we celebrate when more than 40 million Americans are without health care?" she demanded in the closing prayer. "How dare we celebrate in the midst of a recession, when nobody is sure whether their jobs are secure?"
It was a tough note of implicit criticism in an otherwise gently planned day in which Mr. Bush surrounded himself with the symbols of racial tolerance and biracial democracy. He laid a wreath at Dr. King's tomb, signed a proclamation declaring Monday a national holiday to honor Dr. King and kept Coretta Scott King close to his side.
The President was accompanied by his only black Cabinet member, Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, Secretary of Health and Human Services, who seldom travels with him. Before joining the Cabinet, Dr. Sullivan was president of the Morehouse School of Medicine in Atlanta.
In Mr. Bush's speech at the King Center today, he appealed for "compassion" and "service" and the values that Dr. King "beseeched us to embrace -- of tolerance and decency and mutual respect." Mr. Bush talked of his committment to "root out bigotry wherever we find it." He listened to the glee club from Dr. King's alma mater, Morehouse College, sing spirituals like "I've Gotta Mind to Do Right Everyday."
 
'Cannot Walk the Walk'
 But there was blunt criticism of the President's trip from Democrats. John Lewis, the Democratic Congressman from Georgia who served with Dr. King in some of his bloodiest campaigns, said in an interview of Mr. Bush, "He's good at talking the talk, but he cannot walk the walk." Mr. Lewis added, "Dr. King didn't go in much for symbols."
And Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, declared in a statement: "Today, at the gravesite of Martin Luther King Jr., President Bush's hypocritical rheotric was at its worst. How can a President who allowed racially divisive ads to become the cornerstone of his Presidential campaign, who signed the Civil Rights Act only after insurmountable pressure from civil rights organizations, be taken at his word when he claims he's committed to ridding our country of bigotry and racism?"
Mr. Brown was referring to the Bush campaign's use in 1988 of the case of Willie Horton, a black convicted murderer who escaped from the Massachusetts prison system while on a weekend furlough and later raped a Maryland woman and stabbed her fiance. The campaign used the case to attack Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic nominee, as soft on crime.
 
Where Sensitivity Counts
 As he enters an election year, Mr. Bush has two political reasons to send signals of racial sensitivity. Republicans have long hoped to nibble away at the Democrats' support among blacks, which is overwhelming in Presidential elections and many statewide races. At the same time, Mr. Bush has to pay attention to his party's image on racial issues among centrist white voters.
Some analysts argue that these voters can be turned off by the rougher racial politics of recent years, including Mr. Bush's repeated attacks on Congress for advocating what he asserted was a "quota bill" but what its advocates, Republican and Democratic, asserted was simply legislation to combat job discrimination. Moreover, such voters are likely to be alarmed by the rise of David Duke, the former Klansman who ran for Governor of Louisiana last year and is now seeking the Republican Presidential nomination.
Mr. Bush told his audience at the King center today that he was proud that two major civil rights bills had been passed during his Administration: the Americans With Disabilities Act and the Civil Rights Bill of '91. The latter measure generated a two-year struggle between the White House and Congress that ultimately ended in compromise.
 
'Kindler, Gentler' Oratory
 Mr. Bush's day was infused with the kind of "kinder, gentler" oratory that he occasionally used in the otherwise hard-edged 1988 campaign. He talked of the importance of family -- "Barb and I feel it in our own lives" -- and the importance of community service. He noted that he had met this week with Magic Johnson and said he wanted to help the basketball star in fighting the spread of AIDS.
"I want to use the bully pulpit of the White House -- continue to use it for that same purpose, to speak out for strong research so to help people better understand the disease and to speak out for a change of behavior," said Mr. Bush, who has often been criticized by advocates for people with AIDS for not doing enough.
Mr. Bush also took the opportunity today to announce a reorganization of Federal job training programs that he said would make certain that such programs suited "the needs of the workplace and the marketplace." Administration officials said the move was intended to streamline and consolidate such programs, currently spread over several Federal agencies, and create "one stop shopping centers" for such services.
An Administration official said it would not involve any additional money.
Mr. Bush was greeted here today by a poll in The Atlanta-Journal Constitution that showed that even in the South, which is considered his stronghold, the President is suffering political harm. In the poll, conducted by telephone in 12 Southern states, Mr. Bush's approval rating had dropped to 55 percent, from 73 percent in September.
The survey, conducted by telephone Jan. 9-13, was based on interviews with 802 people considerered likely to vote and had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3.5 percentage points.

HEADLINE: Makers of Small Planes Wait for Brighter Skies

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Domestic makers of small airplanes sold fewer last year than at any time since World War II. One major manufacturer, Piper, is in bankruptcy; another, Cessna, is up for sale.
But like flying the rickety little machines that gave rise to the modern aviation industry, making small planes today has some long-term promise to compensate for the immediate perils. The industry is developing many new products, with exports and sales of business jets growing. 
 Still, the industry sold only 1,021 planes last year, a decline of 11 percent, the General Aviation Manufacturers Association of Washington reported this week. The association represents makers of planes including corporate jets, small personal aircraft and commuter planes with 19 or fewer seats, but not larger commercial airliners.
The latest news was a gloomy echo of what has been heard year after year, and it was attributed to familiar causes. Aside from the recession, the industry's perennial ills include high costs for product liability, uncomfortably congested airports and two tax changes: the elimination of the investment tax credit in 1986, and the imposition in 1990 of a 10 percent sales tax on luxury goods, including many small planes.
"That is how you go from building over 17,000 airplanes in a single year to only 1,021," said Brian E. Barents, president of the Learjet Corporation and chairman of the trade group, alluding to the decline in the industry's shipments since 1978, the peak year. "That is how you reduce employment in the general-aviation manufacturing sector by half."
Last year's results prompted John Modzelewski, an analyst at Paine Webber, to note that the industry's annual reports of recent years have always had the same message: "This is the bottom; no, this is the bottom; no, this is the bottom," he said.
 Among the causes for optimism, most companies in the business are efficient producers, he said. If sales of small planes rebound after sinking below $2 billion last year, manufacturers could find themselves suddenly making a lot of money.
"You don't need all that big a rebound," he said.
The industry wants the Government to stimulate that rebound with specific tax changes rather than with broadly stimulative fiscal and monetary policies.
"The secret, not only for our industry, but for many others, is to reintroduce the investment tax credit," said Mr. Barents, who does not expect an economic turnaround until the second half of the year. "We can't think of any other initiative that would have more impact."
Investment tax credits would refund to corporations part of taxes they owe, based on how much they invest in capital goods and equipment.
 
Seeking Repeal of Luxury Tax
 The association called not only for the tax credit, but also for repeal of the 10 percent luxury tax on planes used less than 80 percent for business purposes. The tax, the manufacturers said, has sharply reduced airplane sales and raised almost no revenues.
The Bush Administration is drafting tax proposals to help pull the economy out of recession. Although an investment tax credit is not often mentioned as part of the package, the plan is said to include accelerated depreciation for business investments, which would have the same stimulative effect as a tax credit on business spending for all types of equipment, including airplanes.
Whatever emerges in tax policy, changes in the industry appear inevitable, especially in the market for small, piston-driven propeller planes. Although the Raytheon Company's Beech unit and a few other companies are still making piston planes, only 613 were delivered last year.
 
Piper in Bankruptcy

The Piper Aircraft Corporation, which filed for bankruptcy protection in July, has agreed to sell most of its assets to Cyrus Eaton Group International Ltd., which plans to move production to Canada; some planes may also be built in Eastern Europe or the Soviet Union.
The company found that the cost was too high to insure itself against liability for accidents involving thousands of existing Pipers. A move to Canada would erect a barrier between the new owner and potential litigants.
The Cessna Aircraft Company, also citing liability concerns, stopped making small, piston-driven planes in 1986, and now its parent company, the General Dynamics Corporation, has put Cessna up for sale. Final bids are expected soon and a decision about whether to sell the company or spin it off into a separate entity could come within weeks.
Mr. Modzelewski said the fate of Cessna represented a test of the industry's health and the best single indication of Wall Street's outlook for the industry. "I have been saying they will get $700 million for it, which I think is a good price," he said. Today, Raytheon and Dassault Aviation S.A., of France, confirmed that they were separately bidding for Cessna, but declined to say how much.
 
Business Jets Do Better

Cessna delivered 176 planes last year -- many of them Citations, the most popular line of business jets in recent years. The business jet market did nicely in 1991, as the industry shipped 186 planes, 11 percent more than the year before. Billings were $1.3 billion.
Manufacturers have continued to invest heavily in new designs. Several new business jets have been announced, and others, including the Learjet 60 and the new Citationjet, are about to be certified by the Federal Aviation Administration.
But the suppliers, like their customers, said that the business jet market was being held down by both the recession and tax policy. "When the country regains its economic strength, we anticipate that the demand for business travel, and therefore business aircraft, will increase," said Cassandra Bosco of the National Business Aviation Association, a Washington trade group representing companies that own and operate planes for business purposes. The group strongly endorses renewal of the investment tax credit.
Export markets also held up well in 1991, largely because of favorable exchange rates. More than a third of the planes sold last year were exported.
But the market for turboprop planes -- whose propellers are driven by turbine engines -- including the smaller planes used by commuter airlines, was weak last year. Shipments dropped 21 percent, to 222 aircraft valued at $527 million.

HEADLINE: California Governor Tells of Suffering, But Question Now Is Whose Was It

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17

 BODY:
In his State of the State Message last week, did Gov. Pete Wilson invent a cast of brave California characters struggling with the recession? Even his press office did not seem to be sure today.
In a portion of the speech that he wrote, Mr. Wilson gave a detailed account of a farm worker, a businessman and a carpenter who had impressed him with their suffering and determination. But when reporters tried to track them down, his press office said they did not exist but were composites. 
 "I don't have the name," a deputy press secretary, Franz Wisner, is quoted as saying in today's San Jose Mercury News, which said it spent four days trying to find the carpenter. "There is no name. There is no carpenter. That first part of the speech is a composite of the thousands of Californians the Governor has come in contact with."
But today Mr. Wisner said: "There is a carpenter. His name is Shad Murphy. He is unemployed and he makes toys." He also identified a farm worker and a businessman who fit the Governor's descriptions.
 
Common Among Politicians
 "Isn't that funny?" said Susan Estrich, the former Presidential campaign manager for Michael S. Dukakis who now teaches law at the University of Southern California. "They finally found them. It seems to have taken a massive state effort by his aides to refresh everyone's recollections."
She said it was common for politicians to furnish vivid personal examples in their speeches but that it was obligatory for their staffs to be prepared to present living proof.
"Politics are theater, but they are not Hollywood," said Ms. Estrich. "There are rules of the game and one of the basic rules is truth."
Even as Mr. Wisner spoke today, another deputy press secretary, accompanying Mr. Wilson on a visit to the University of California at Davis, repeated his office's earlier explanation, saying: "Let's face it, every writer in the world has used allegory. Instead of focusing on one individual, the Governor used the image of Californians who are struggling for their livings."
And a press release issued today by the Governor's office called his heroes "symbolic representations" and said, "The statements are a composite of the many conversations he has had with people throughout California."
Mr. Wilson spoke of seeing "worry in the face of a farm worker idled by a killer arctic freeze" and of watching "the eyes of a gruff, gray-haired businessman grow wet as he spoke of having to lay off people who'd kept his small shop running for years."
Most colorfully, he described "the kindly face of a carpenter who could find no work framing houses and now makes children's toys for free."
Reached at the Mendocino Center for the California Conservation Corps in Ukiah, where he does general construction work, Mr. Murphy said he been among a group of workers who had met with the Governor on Dec. 20 in conjunction with a Rotary Club donation of handmade toys.
Asked if Mr. Wilson's description of him was accurate, he said, "Kindly face? Yes. A carpenter? I just wouldn't use that word for myself. Or making children's toys for free."
He said he had not told the Governor that he had been unemployed. But he added, "If he was using me as that, I feel that's fine."
 
'My Eyes Do Get a Little Wet'
 The businessman, Wesley C. Seastrom, chairman of Seastrom Manufacturing Company in Glendale, also said he was comfortable with Mr. Wilson's references to him. "He was at my plant and we discussed it, and my eyes do get a little wet when I talk about laying people off," he said.
The farm worker was identified by Mr. Wisner as Concepcion Meza of Visalia, but there was no Concepcion at the one Meza household listed in the Visalia directory.
Mr. Wilson's references to individual examples recalled the style of another Republican Governor of Californaia, former President Ronald Reagan. And today's controversy also called to mind the criticisms of Mr. Reagan for fabricating some of his examples.
"Reagan was famous for doing things like that," said Paul Slansky, who wrote "The Clothes Have No Emperor" (Simon & Schuster, 1989), a book about the Reagan years. "Supposedly there was some woman in Chicago, a welfare cheat, who Reagan talked about who drove a Cadillac to pick up her check, but when he was asked, he could never say who she was or when this happened."
 
A 'Good Story'
 After one of Mr. Reagan's misstatements in 1982, regarding strict firearms laws in Great Britain, his spokesman, Larry Speakes, said:, "Well, it's a good story, though. It made the point, didn't it?"
In the State Senate, where Mr. Wilson delivered his speech and where a battle is now under way over the budget he presented the next day, one staff member said good stories like these overstep the accepted norms of colorful rhetoric.
"This doesn't do much for his credibility," said Bob Forsythe, an aide to Senate President pro Tempore David Roberti, a Los Angeles Democrat.
"California is a place of professional politicians who have made countless speeches in their careers," Mr. Forsythe said. "They understand rhetorical devices -- pathos, ethos and logos, if you're following Aristotle -- but I don't know in my experience that anyone has made this big a stretch."
At The Mercury News, the managing editor, Jerry M. Ceppos, said, "Journalism has had its own problems with composite characters, and I had assumed that by this time, both journalists and politicians knew that you can't use composite characters unless you identify them as such."

HEADLINE: Consumer Report Shows Spirits Have Yet to Revive

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
The nation's spirits have yet to revive from last fall's recessionary levels, according to the closely watched University of Michigan Survey of Consumer Sentiment.
"Sentiment has remained largely unchanged" from December, its report to subcribers said. The sentiment index edged down from 68.2 in December to 67.1 in January, but a decline of a point or so is not statistically significant. 
 The report was disappointing, not only to investors but to Federal Reserve officials who were looking for some sign, however slight, that the Fed's latest easing move was having an impact on Main Street. On Tuesday, a rumor that the survey would show a sharp rise in confidence helped the stock market to a hefty rally.
"There's no great watershed reaction to the Fed's discount rate reduction," said Robert Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities, "Stock market euphoria hasn't swept consumers."
This initial look at the way consumers feel about the economy and their own finances in January is based on a telephone survey of about 300 families around the country in the first half of the month -- slightly more than half the total sample.
The closely watched monthly survey, which economists say tracks current consumer spending reasonably well, is included in the Department of Commerce's monthly index of leading indicators.
There are several crosscurrents in the January results. Though consumers have become slightly more upbeat about the present, they have also turned gloomier about the future. While the index of current conditions rose to 80.7 percent vs. 78.7 in December, the index of expectations declined to 58.4 percent from 61.5 percent.
The problem, not surprisingly, is jobs or, rather, the lack of them. Fifty-seven percent of households expect the jobless rate to climb in the year ahead compared with 47 percent just two months ago.
Interestingly, 64 percent of the consumers surveyed mentioned hearing news reports of rising joblessness. That is the highest portion ever recorded in the history of the survey, which began in 1954.
"Any pickup in consumption this quarter is likely to be modest," said Michael Niemira, an economist at Mitsubishi Bank Ltd.
Still, the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, will find one cheery footnote in the Michigan report. The fraction of households who say that now is a good time to buy a house spurted to two-thirds.

HEADLINE: New York Takes Hertz To Court Over Surcharge

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
New York City and New York State sued Hertz yesterday over its two-week-old surcharge for renters from four New York City boroughs, calling it illegal discrimination.
At a City Hall news conference announcing the suit, Robert Abrams, the Attorney General, said the Hertz Corporation "can charge whatever rate it wants." But he added, "What it cannot do is charge different people different rates based on where they live." 
 The company said it was doing nothing wrong and would see the city and state in court.
 
$56-a-Day Surcharge
 On Jan. 2, Hertz imposed a $56-a-day surcharge on Bronx residents and smaller fees for residents of Queens, Brooklyn and Manhattan. The company, based in Park Ridge, N.J., said it was paying $15 million a year to settle suits brought by pedestrians, passengers and others injured in accidents with Hertz cars and a disproportionate number of those suits involved cars rented by people from those boroughs.
In a statement yesterday, Hertz called the news conference "little more than political posturing for publicity purposes." The company said that what it had done was "reflective of real costs we've incurred."
"It is our fundamental belief that every company has a right to price its product in accordance with the costs associated with the delivery of that product," the company said. Joseph Russo, a Hertz spokesman, said that the company had not lost much business because of the change.
But Mayor David N. Dinkins said at the news conference that the company, which is the nation's leading car rental concern, was approaching the problem the wrong way.
"If you want to discriminate on the basis of a person being a lousy driver, fine," he said. "But it is unfair to target people for reasons unrelated to driving records."
 
Move to Terminate Leases
 Borough President Claire Shulman of Queens, saying she was galled by Hertz charging extra to Queens residents when most of its New York City business is at the airports, added that she had asked the Port Authority to terminate Hertz's leases at LaGuardia, Kennedy and Newark airports. She had previously called on the city to stop buying Fords because Ford owns 49 percent of Hertz, and Mr. Dinkins said yesterday that the city would consider it.
While many officials have expressed outrage at the charges, Mr. Russo said yesterday that the company had not seen "a significant negative impact."
Some renters from the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens have decided to rent elsewhere, he said, but that was what the company wanted. In Manhattan, where the surcharge is $3 a day, he said, some customers "make known that they are upset with the new rate structure, but we're trying to explain the reasons why." Nearly all go ahead and rent, he said.
At Hertz's chief competitor, Avis, business was good, but Russell James, a spokesman, said that he could not attribute this to Hertz's surcharges.
The suit filed by the city and state argues that the effect of the company's surcharges "will fall disproportionately upon African-American, Latino and Asian-American residents." There is a rough correlation between the charges and the minority population of each borough. Hertz said that it found those accusations inflammatory, and that they were "offensive and totally without merit."
The suit also said that the policy "inflicts significant economic, social and moral injury upon the state and city."

HEADLINE: U.S. Output Down 0.2% Last Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Industrial output sagged two-tenths of 1 percent in December, the third modest decline in a row, the Federal Reserve reported today.
This pushed production at the nation's factories, mines and utilities to the lowest point since June, when it appeared that the industrial sector -- about 30 percent of the overall economy -- had begun to lead the economy out of recession. 
 "It has gone from being a source of strength to being a small drag," said Stuart G. Hoffman, chief economist at the PNC Financial Corporation in Pittsburgh.
Today's report also showed that industry operated at 79 percent of capacity last month, down from 79.3 percent in November, also the third straight month of decline.
 
 
Decline for Year
 For all of 1991, industrial production averaged 1.9 percent less than in 1990 for its first annual decline since 1982, the final year of the preceding recession. From December 1990 to December 1991 production rose by six-tenths of 1 percent.
Signs of economic weakness were also evident in a Commerce Department report today on the November trade deficit. Although the trade gap shrank to $3.57 billion, its lowest level in almost nine years, a plunge in imports spotlighted consumers' reluctance to buy and a gain in exports was largely attributed to aircraft sales, a volatile category. [Page 50.]
Despite the obvious stagnation in the industrial sector in December, many analysts found at least some grounds for encouragement in the Fed report, noting, among other things, that output would have shown no change were it not for exceptionally warm weather that sharply cut demand for electric power and natural gas.
"I'm rather encouraged," Robert G. Dederick, chief economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago, said of today's figures. Output may not be rising, he added, "but it really isn't slipping" either. He said things were better than many people seemed to think.
 
'Special' Factors Cited
 This view seemed to be shared by Gordon Richards, economist for the National Association of Manufacturers, who pointed to two "special" factors as accounting for the December decline. In addition to the unseasonable weather, which chopped utility production 3 percent, Mr. Richards said the automobile industry was still suffering from excess inventories as it adjusted to the problem of chronic oversupply dating from the late 1980's.
Rejecting the notion that the economy was dipping back into recession, Mr. Richards contended that the latest figures "are consistent with a pattern of extremely slow growth," which he put at a rate of 1 percent or less for the fourth quarter.
Many others project a decline in fourth-quarter gross domestic product, which is to be reported by the Commerce Department on Jan. 29.
Output at factories edged up one-tenth of 1 percent last month after declining three-tenths of 1 percent in November. A two-tenths of 1 percent decline in durable goods was more than offset by a four-tenths of 1 percent advance for nondurables.
Durables, such as transportation equipment, furniture and other goods designed to last at least three years, account for about 48 percent of industrial production. Nondurables, such as foods and chemicals, account for 37 percent. The remaining output is accounted for by utilities and mines, each with about 7.5 percent.
Motor vehicles were assembled at an annual rate of 9.3 million last month, down from 9.5 million in November and 10 million in October. Autos, at 5.6 million, and trucks, at 3.7 million, were each about 100,000 below the November pace. Appliances and other goods for the home were also lower last month -- consumer goods over all fell four-tenths of 1 percent -- but many nondurables, including clothes, paper and chemicals, posted modest increases.
Output of business equipment, not counting cars and trucks, was virtually unchanged during the month while construction supplies climbed four-tenths of 1 percent after a five-tenths gain in November.
At 107.8 percent of its 1987 average, the Index of Industrial Production was at its lowest point since a reading of 107.3 in June. After posting four straight increases, the index peaked at 108.1 in July and has gone nowhere since. November's decline, initially reported at four-tenths of 1 percent, was cut in half today, but at the same time a downward revision showed October now one-tenth of 1 percent negative instead of unchanged.
 
Quarter Average Unchanged
 Industrial production is one of four components of the Commerce Department index designed to gauge the economy's current state. At 108, the average for the fourth quarter was essentially unchanged from the third quarter's 108.1.
Early indications are that January will see little improvement in output, said Brian J. Fabbri, chief economist for Midland Montague Securities in New York. He said today's trade report from the Commerce Department showing a big drop in imports during November showed that "Americans are not buying anything, no matter where it is made."
He added that "there's really no need for industry to gear up" yet for the stepped-up demand that sooner or later will come as the economy shakes off recession.

HEADLINE: W. John Kenney Is Dead at 87; Was Marshall Plan Administrator

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
W. John Kenney, a top official in the United States Navy during World War II and in the Marshall Plan program for postwar recovery overseas, died Thursday at his home in Washington.
He was 87 years old and died of pneumonia, his family said. 
 Serving under Presidents Franklin D. Roosevelt and Harry S. Truman, Mr. Kenney rose to the post of Under Secretary of the Navy and later became the administrator of the Marshall Plan.
His Government career began in 1936 when he was appointed chief of the oil and gas unit of the Securities and Exchange Commission. After practicing law for three years in Los Angeles, he returned to Washington in 1941 as a special assistant to the Under Secretary of the Navy, a post he later assumed.
Under the Marshall Plan, President Truman named him director of the Economic Cooperation Mission to Britain. From 1950 to 1952 he became the operating chief of the entire Marshall Plan under its director, W. Averell Harriman.
Returning to corporate law, he was a partner with Sullivan, Shea & Kenney in Washington until 1970 and then with Cox, Langford & Brown firm. In 1973 it merged with Squire, Sanders & Dempsey, where he remained a partner until his retirement in 1989.
A Democrat, he was the party chairman for the District of Columbia and in 1956 worked on Mr. Harriman's Presidential candidacy.
He helped found the School of Advanced International Studies at Johns Hopkins University and was a trustee of the George C. Marshall Foundation and a director of Riggs National Bank. He was chairman of the District of Columbia chapter of the American Red Cross and the Community Chest fund drive in Washington. He also headed the Alibi Club, a men's club whose members included President Bush and and the former Chief Justice of the United States, Warren E. Burger.
Born in Oklahoma, Mr. Kenney grew up there and in Washington, Los Angeles and Carmel, Calif. He graduated from Stanford University in 1926 and Harvard Law School in 1929 and practiced law in San Francisco until 1936.
Surviving are two daughters, Elinor K. Farquhar of Washington and Priscilla K. Streator of London; two sons, David Kenney of Washington and John Kenney of Nancy, France; 15 grandchildren, and three great grandchildren. His wife, Elinor, died last year.

HEADLINE: Another Dow High: 3,264.98, Up 15.43

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks rose modestly yesterday, again in busy trading, aided by the expiration of stock and index options and major market index futures. While smaller stocks showed weakness, the Dow Jones industrial average clicked off yet another record, ending at 3,264.98, up 15.43 points for the day and 65.52 for the week.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was heavy, at 287.4 million shares traded, but down from 336.2 million on Thursday. Gaining issues were ahead of losers by a margin of 922 to 831. 
 The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 0.65 point, to 418.86, while the American Stock Exchange index gained 1.55 points to end at an all-time high of 415.32. Trading in the secondary market pulled the Nasdaq composite down slightly, to 626.85, off 0.49 point, but the Russell 2,000 inched to a high of 205.06, up 0.67 point.
 
'Double Witching Hour'
 John H. Blair 3d, senior vice president and head of trading for County NatWest Securities USA, described the market as orderly, as it went through its "double witching hour."
"A large number of expiring indexes were on the buy side yesterday, causing blue chips to rise in late afternoon trading," Mr. Blair said. "But a selloff in the last few minutes moved the market lower at the close."
He liked the market's tone and volume, even though it was not as high as in the last couple of sessions, and noted that there was good rotation in stocks and some cycles, like I.B.M., which opened lower on a large fourth-quarter loss but recouped to close with a gain of 7/8 at 96 3/8.
I.B.M.'s performance was an indication that people are looking through earnings and taking comfort that things will get better, some traders said.
For a good part of the day the Dow struggled to hold on to mild gains as the broader market fell under pressure. A mixed batch of economic data and corporate earnings released early in the morning made investors unsure about the direction of the economy and of interest rates. Uncertainty generally puts a collar on buying and pressure on stocks.
Recent winners in the market, like airline and bank stocks, slipped in trading. Analysts said Apple Computer's higher-than-expected first-quarter earnings helped offset some of the anxiety generated by I.B.M.'s announcement of a $1.38 billion loss in the fourth quarter.
The mixed bag of data included a much-smaller-than-expected November trade deficit, which was a plus for stocks. But a decline in December industrial production and capacity utilization and the University of Michigan's consumer confidence index, which showed that consumer confidence faltered early this month, put downward pressure on the market.
Traders said bargain hunting in the "old" leadership stocks was apparent at one point in the session, as selling in some of the cyclical stocks eagerly sought during the week dampened buying enthusiasm somewhat.
Apple Computer was among yesterday's gainers, rising 2, to 64 3/4.
United Technologies gained 1 5/8, to 56 5/8; Du Pont was up 1 1/2, to 50 1/2; General Dynamics rose 1 3/8, to 61; Reebok added 1 1/2, to 31 1/2, and Commodore International picked up 1 1/8, to 17.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Sharply Lower On Troublesome Trade Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply against other currencies yesterday, depressed by Federal Reserve intervention in the market and by disappointment in United States trade figures.
The dollar dropped in early trading after the market found evidence of a weak United States economy in the trade deficit report for November. 
 The shortfall shrank to $3.57 billion, but that was largely because imports fell as Americans curtailed their purchases. Although the report also showed a gain in export sales, that increase was mainly attributed to strong aircraft sales, a one-time phenomenon, and did not reflect a surge in the manufacturing sector of the overall economy, analysts said.
Traders sold the dollar on the belief that if the economy is weak, the Fed will be under more pressure to drop interest rates again. Since stable or higher rates make United States investments and the dollar more attractive, negative economic news is often a signal to sell on the currency markets.
Ronald H. Holzer, chief foreign exchange dealer with Harris Trust & Company in Chicago, said a decline in interest rates in the bond market also undermined the dollar.
The dollar weakened further in afternoon trading in New York after it was reported that the Fed had sold dollars for Japanese yen. The move supports the view, Mr. Holzer said, that it is in everybody's interest "to keep the yen strong at this point."
A stronger yen would help lower the United States trade deficit by making American goods cheaper in Japan and Japanese goods more expensive in America.
The dollar skidded more than 3 yen in New York, to 124.55 yen from 128.22.
Earlier, the Bank of Japan governor, Yasushi Mieno, called for a stable yen. His remarks, which occurred during the trading day in Japan, served to weaken the dollar in Tokyo. The dollar fell to 127.95 yen in Tokyo overnight from 128.43 yen, and in London it fell to 127.40 yen.
The British pound jumped more than 3 cents against the dollar, climbing to $1.7955, from $1.7627 late Thursday in New York. Earlier in London, the British pound rose to $1.7780 from $1.7615.
Against the German mark, the dollar fell to 1.5920 marks from 1.6170 in New York trading.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's prices, included: 1.4085 Swiss francs, down from 1.4355; 5.4275 French francs, down from 5.5120; 1,199.25 Italian lire, down from 1,218.00, and 1.15025 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15425.
Gold fell $2.40 on the Commodity Exchange in New York, closing at $354.00 an ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $354.00, off $2.30.

HEADLINE: Theodore Small, 52, an Innovator In Finding Jobs for Disadvantaged

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Theodore D. Small, a pioneer in training and placement programs that found jobs for tens of thousands of disabled people, died on Monday at his home in Brooklyn.
He was 52 years old. The cause of death apparently was heart failure, his family said. 
 Mr. Small's programs aided a wide variety of people, including the physically impaired, the homeless, unemployed war veterans and ex-convicts. "Everybody is employable at something," he once said. "The key is to find the match."
The projects he set up often entailed the cooperation of businesses, nonprofit agencies and government. One of them, Utility Plastics, hires poor youths in East New York to recycle plastic waste into traffic cones. Another, Esteem, finds jobs for women who are beaten by their husbands so that the women do not feel economically trapped in abusive relationships.
Binding Together is a copy shop and bindery at which recovering drug addicts are trained. Multitasking Systems hires people with AIDS to provide office services to other companies. Other programs enable handicapped people to work at home.
Mr. Small began working with such programs when he directed Skill Upgrading, a training program in Cleveland, from 1968 to 1972. For six years after that, he was president of the Metropolitan Cleveland Jobs Council, a business and government partnership for disadvantaged people. From 1978 to 1984 he was president of the New York City Private Industry Council, which placed 18,500 people with 3,200 companies during his tenure.
Since 1984 he had served as president of Small and Associates, the consulting firm he founded to help companies hire the disadvantaged. Among its clients were I.B.M., Marriott, Holiday Inns, U.S. Sprint and Morgan Guaranty Trust. He was chairman of the National Association of Private Industry Councils and the State Labor Department's Job Service Employers Committee for Manhattan.
Mr. Small was born in Brooklyn. After graduating from Columbia College and Yale Law School, he served three years in the Peace Corps in Liberia.
He is survived by his wife, Barbara, and two sons, Ronald and Alan, all of Brooklyn; his mother, Frances, of Columbus, N.J., and a sister, Cheryl, of Manhattan.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 40; Column 4; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 576 words

HEADLINE: Deeper Consumer Gloom Lifts Bond Prices

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The credit markets stabilized somewhat yesterday, as buying of Treasury securities was enough to push prices of notes and bonds higher for the first time in a week.
The better tone was established in overnight trading in Asia, after results of the University of Michigan's midmonth snapshot of consumer attitudes became known. 
 At the height of the market's selloff on Thursday, there were strong rumors that the survey would show that confidence improved greatly in early January, in large part because of the Fed's decisive cuts in interest rates right before Christmas.
 
New Hopes for Rate Cuts
 The rumors were false. Indeed, based on the 15-day reading, consumer expectations were even gloomier than in December.
The report, coupled with the weak money-supply figures released on Thursday, renewed hopes that the Federal Reserve Board might cut interest rates again.
"The combination of the money numbers and the confidence survey don't give the Fed much room to stand pat," one Government bond trader said.
Steven Slifer, an executive vice president and financial market economist at Lehman Brothers, was one of many who had expected the Fed's move to generate a positive response among consumers.
"It is astounding to me that the Fed takes its best shot, one that puts it on the front page of every newspaper in the country, and you still can't get a pickup in confidence," he said. "It makes you wonder what you have to do to get the country back in a spending mode and feeling better."
 
 
Comments by Fed Governor
 Comments by Wayne D. Angell, a Fed governor, also tended to dampen growing fear in the credit markets that the economy was about to turn around quickly.
Mr. Angell told an audience at the Executives Club of Chicago that he expected nominal gross domestic product to expand 3 to 5 percent this year, well below the normal pace of postwar recoveries.
"A robust, roaring recovery isn't there," Mr. Angell told his audience.
In their daily market commentary, analysts at MMS International, an economic information and service company, said, "Mr. Angell's comments and the University of Michigan survey has given the market some much-needed perspective" about the nature of the recovery.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered in late trading at a price of 10418/32, up 5/8 point, to yield 7.60 percent, compared with 7.66 percent late Thursday and 7.45 percent on Jan. 10.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7.50 percent 10-year notes rose by 13/32, to an offered price of 10229/32, to yield 7.08 percent. The 6 3/8 percent seven-year notes were offered at 9725/32, up 17/32, to yield 6.77 percent. And the 5 percent two-year notes were offered at 1001/32, up 1/8 point, to yield 4.98 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were unchanged to slightly lower.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.76 percent late yesterday, down 2 basis points, or two one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates were unchanged at a late offered rate of 3.87 percent.
The pace of new-issue activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market slowed noticeably from the frantic pace of the last two weeks. During that time, an average of about $2 billion worth of securities were brought to market.
Activity yesterday was highlighted by a two-part, $260 million offering of securities from the Texas-New Mexico Power Company.
